title: Right Suspension Lifted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (Reuters) The Marine Corps said today that it had resumed flights of its Britishbuilt Harrier jets, suspended after a crash on Oct. 9 that killed a pilot.

title: Chris Evert Beats Miss Wade in Final
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S. C., Oct. 31 (AP)Chris Evert broke service in the second and sixth games of the opening set today and went on to beat Virginia Wade of England, 61, 63, in the final of the women's singles in the $135,000 World invitation tennis tournament.

title: Who's That With Her?
description: Great, thick columns of words have been written recently about the record crop of women candidates across the country this election year. But haven't read much about the battalions of sturdy little men, the candidates husbands, chasing behind these running women.

title: Hussein's Crossroads
description: The Rabat summit meeting of Arab leaders has abruptly redrawn the political map of the Arab world; King Hussein of Jordan seems almost to have acquiesced in the dismemberment of his kingdom. That Is the apparent meaning of the conference declaration that any territory liberated from Israeli occupation is to fall under the independent authority of the Palestine Liberation Organization, rather thanin the case of the West Bankunder the sovereignty of Jordan from which it was seized in 1967.

title: Reserve Again Turns Down Bid Of Chase Manhattan for Dial
description: The Federal Rdserve Board rejected yesterday for a second time the application of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the parent company of the Chase Manhattan Bank, to acquire the Dial Financial Corporation, a consumer finance company with headquarters in Des Moines, Iowa. The board gave as its reasons for rejection the possibility of future competition being eliminated by the proposed merger and that it posed a danger of undue concentration of creditgranting resources.

title: US. HEARINGS SET ON SUGAR PROFITS AND PRICE, RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 High officials of the Ford Administration announced two new actions today, both aimed (that dealing with the possibility that business misconduct is playing a major role in rising prices.

title: U.S. Keeps Golf Lead; Koch Stars
description: LA ROMANA, Dominican Republic, Oct. 31 (AP)Three United States golfers, led by Gary Koch, totaled 221 in the second round today to stay in first place in the Eisenhower Cup world amateur championship.

title: Mr. Rockefeller's Ordeal
description: Nelson A. Rockefeller is now facing an uphill fight for confirmation as Vice President of the United States. The curious thing is that the entanglements of wealth that may defeat him were scarcely even mentioned when he sought the Presidential nomination in 1964 and 1968, or in his four campaigns for Governor of New York.

title: Gas Shipments Resuming
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday its subsidiary, Esso Libya, was resuming shipments of liquefied natural gas to Spain on a limited basis after a threeweek shutdown. The shutdown resulted from a decision of the Libyan Goevrnment to increase the exported price of LNG and the refusal of the Spanish customer, the Gas Natural Company, to accept the higher prices. Exxon said the Spanish concern now had agreed to bear the full impact of the higher cost.

title: FRANK G. WHERRY
description: Frank G. Wherry, director of the division of economics and business administration at Community College of Philadelphia, died Sunday in Philadelphia. His age was 52.

title: Bonn Ends Soviet Talks Satisfied on Trade Deal
description: BONN, Oct. 31Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany returned from the Soviet Union today after saying, he was satisfied that his talks had produced fundamental agreement that a huge nuclear power plant the Russians want the Gernians to build near Kaliningrad could produce electricity for West Berlin.

title: GOLDIN SEES PERIL IN CITY BOROWING
description: Expressing serious concern over the widening gap between the city's spending and revenues, Controller Harrison J. Goldin warned yesterday in his annual report on the city's fiscal situation that New York could not continue to close the gaps with ever larger and more expensive borrowings.

title: Schmidt Ends Soviet Visit
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31 (Reuters) Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany left Kiev today for Hamburg to end a fourday visit to the Soviet Union during which he had talks with national leaders.

title: State's Mental Chief Meets Task Force
description: ALBANY, Oct. 31Dr. Alan D. Miller, head of the State Department of Mental Hygiene, in his first appearance before a mentalhealth task force that he set up more than a year ago, today defended his agency and then heard his department attacked as inefficient, racist and wasteful.

title: About New York Smoking Ban a Burning Issue.
description: Now it begins, one of those small things that go largely unremarked on in New York, but can touch off trouble, nonetheless. As of today, it is against the law to smoke in elevators, in supermarkets and in certain other public places, and while everyone agrees that the city law will not stop smoking, it is certain to do something else. It will pit citizen against citizen, and, already that war has begun.

title: Owen's Song at the D.C. Black Repertory Company
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31More than four years ago Robert Hooks, one of the country's leading black actors and a cofounder of the Negro Ensemble Company in New Yorks turned his back on Hollywood and Broadway and came to Washington. He came to build. What he has built is the D.C. Black Repertory Company.

title: 2 More Dissident Writers Released From Jail in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 31Two more South Korean writers, held since January on carges of antigovernment and espionage activities, were freed from a Seoul prison tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The inquisition to which Nelson Rockefeller is being submitted should clearly indicate to the American people why it is that so few members of our society who have demonstrated their capacity for success are willing to seek public office.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: FARM PRICES END DROP, RISING 47
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) Prices of raw farm products jumped 4 per cent from Sept 15 to Oct. 15, more than offsetting a decline one month earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: ES, HEARINGS SET ON SUGAR PROFITS AND PRICE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 High officials of the Ford Administration announced two new actions today, both aimed at dealing with the possibility that business misconduct is playing a major role in rising prices.

title: Events Today
description: Films

title: Lobstermen File Suit
description: PORTSMOUH, N. H., Oct. 31(AP)  Stephen Katz, a lawyer for the New Hampshire Fishermen's Association, has filed brief with the Supreme Court objecting to attempts by New Hampshire to block the lobstermen's entry into a marine boundary settlement with Maine.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Indiana Pacers, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I. 8:05 P.M. (Radio  WMCA, 8:05 P.M.)

title: Gunmen Rob Family Of Cash and Jewelry
description: Four gunmen masquerading as Halloween trickortreaters, robbed a Rosedale, Queens, family last night of $5,410 in cash and an estimated $600 worth of jewelry, the police reported.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Pege

title: MOSCOW MODIFIES TROOPCUT PLAN
description: VIENNA, Oct. 31The Soviet Union today modified its proposal for the reduction of military forces in central Europe, suggesting at EastWest negotiations here that Soviet and American troops be cut first.

title: News Summary and Index
description: About 75 civilians and policemen were believed to have been injured when, for the first time since the opposition to President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam took to the street two months ago, confrontations between riot policemen and antiGovernment demonstrators turned violent. The police abandoned their policy of leniency and attacked the demonstrators in an outlying neighborhood of Saigon, inhabited by Roman Catholics who fled North Vietnam. [Page 1, Columns 14.]

title: CHARLES W. HUSE
description: Charles W, Huse, who retired as a vice president of the United States Steel Corporation in 1970, died Sunday in San Francisco, where he lived. His age was 68.

title: Ford Gets Report on Coal Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31President Ford summoned the top negotiators for the coal industry to the White House today to receive an updated report on efforts to avert a miners strike, which could begin in nine days. The news he got was guarded but good.

title: Television
description: 5:57 (5)Friends

title: YUGOSLAVIA SAYS AUSTRIA AIDS FOES
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 31 Yugoslavia has formally accused Austria, her neighbor to the north, of harboring Nazis and tolerating activity hostile to Yugoslav interests.

title: Witness Describes Kent State Shooting By National Guard
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 (UPI)A Pulitizer prizewinning photographer testified today that he saw a group of Ohio Nationat Guardsmen walk away from demonstrating students at Kent State University, turn around, walk back and shoot into the crowd. Four students were killed and nine wounded.

title: Uncertainty Over the Watergate Trial Increased by Change in Nixon's Health
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The latest turn in the health of former President Richard M. Nixon has added new elements, of uncertainty to the Watergate coverup trial.

title: Farm Prices Climb
description: Prices of raw farm products climbed 4 per cent from Sept. 15 to Oct. 15, more than offsetting a decline in the preceding month, the Agriculture Department reported yesterday. Page 55.

title: Paul Stark, Nurseryman, Dies; Found Golden Delicious Apple
description: LOUISIANA, Mo., Oct. 31(UPI)Paul C. Stark, a nurseryman, credited with finding and developing the Golden Delicious apple, died, apparently of a heart attack, in St. Louis on Monday.

title: Union Will Protest Rise in Imports of Clothing,
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Leaders of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America annouced today plans for nationwide union demonstrations on Nov. 11 to protest the increasing volume of clothing being imported from lowwage, countries.

title: WNCN DELAYS. SHIFT TO FORMAT OF ROCK
description: WNCNFM said yesterday that it would end its operations as a classical music station at 12:01 A.M. today, but then yielded to a plea and agreed to continue on the air for at least the next few days.

title: Suspect Surrenders Here In Attack at Arabs Office
description: A 24yearold reputed member of the Jewish Defense League was arraigned in Criminal Court in Manhattan yesterday in connection with an attack on the Palestine Liberation Organization office at 11Park Avenue last Tuesday.

title: Frazier Hurt, Monroe Stars in Knick Victory
description: Earl Monroe went back to being Earl Monroe last night.

title: JERSEY TURNPIKE ASKS TO INCREASE ITS TOLLS BY 37%
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 31The New Jersey Turnpike Authority today approved and sent to Governor Byrne a proposal to increase tolls by 37per cent for trucks and passenger cars on the 142mile highway.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Oct. 31 Fresh from its fifth victory the season, Montclair State will face archrival Trenton State Saturday night, while Kean College will take Glassboro. State in another New Jersey Conference game.

title: GAMBLING CALLED POOR REVENUE AID
description: A study cosponsored by two foundations contends that the effects of legalized gambling on state government revenues and organized crime have been oversold, but suggests that some cities might benefit from experimenting with a highpayout numbers, or policy, game.

title: 2D AVE. SUBWAY DELAYED TILL 86AS COSTS SPIRAL
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that completion of the Second Avenue subway would be delayed at least five or six years, until about 1986, because costs have spiraled greatly.

title: New Miracle in Rice Seen by Some in Asia
description: HYDERABAD, IndiaWhile the onethird of mankind that lives on rice struggles desperately to grow enough food, scientists in Asia remain confident that harvests can increase faster than the need of a ricedependent population that is expected to double by the year 2000.

title: DISCLOSURE RULES WIDENED BY &EC.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted new rules today requiring publicly held companies to provide stockholders with additional and more meaningful information that until now has been supplied only to the S.E.C.

title: MISS KRUPSAK LISTS $90,800 NET WORTH
description: State Senator Mary Anne Krupsak, the Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, announced yesterday that she and her husband, Edwin Margolis, had a net worth of $90,800.

title: N.F.L. Bars Acquisition Of Players FromW.F.L
description: The The National Football League announced yesterday that none of its 26 teams would be able to sign players from the rival World Football League for the remainder of the season.

title: Subdued, Overcast Day At Coast Medical Unit
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 31  Halloween trickortreaters haunted the corridors of Memorial Hospital Medical Center today as former President Richard M. Nixon lay critically ill in a seventhfloor intensivecare wing.

title: JAPANESE LEADER VISITING AUSTRALIA
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 31 (Reuters)Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan arrived here tonight to begin a sixday visit to Australia to cement relations and promote trade with Japan's major supplier of raw materials.

title: Schedule Released Of Trip This Month By Ford to Japan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)  A Schedule for President Ford's threeday visit to Japan wate in November was made public tonight in a joint announcement issued in Washington and Tokyo.

title: Architects of Luxury Towers Shape New Manhattan Skyline
description: Philip Birnbaum, Schuman Lichtenstein Claman, and Horace Ginsbern and Associates are not names well known to even the most architectureconscious segments of the general public. In fact, the three firms are hardly known to many architects. But these firms, and a handful of others, are playing at least as big a role in shaping the design of Manhattan as any architects of more note. They are the apartmenthouse specialiststhe firms which have created their architectural practices largely on the design of the luxury towers which continue to sprout up throughout midtown.

title: Runaway May Get Wish: Life on a Delaware Farm
description: DOVER, Del., Oct. 31New Jersey childwelfare officials conceded today that a Newark runaway who had been given a home and was being cared for by a Delaware farm family might be better off in Delaware. They indicated they might not press their demand for custody of the youth.

title: Shocked Priest Denies Aiding Escape of Major Drug Dealers
description: The Rev. John J. Tirella, the Franciscan priest arrested Wednesday on charges of aiding seven major narcotics dealers in their escape from the Federal House of Detention on Sept. 22, said yesterday that he was shocked by the indictment against him.

title: Dining OutSuperlatives, and Then Quiet Contentment
description: All entrees at DeCuir's, on Madison Avenue between 89th and 90th Streets, are served with the restaurant's special soup (excellent), crusty hash brown potatoes (excellent), salad (welldressed) and dessert (including strawberries when we were there), which means that you can get an excellent dinner for as little as $7.50 (walnut fried Boston sole). But if you can resist the a la carte appetizers you are a person of stronger will, or one less interested in creole cuisine, than I am.

title: Gradual Nixon Gains Seen Despite  Lurking Dangers
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 31Former President Richard M. Nixon's doctors said late today that they expected gradual improvement in his condition, but that they remained concerned over postoperative complications and dangers lurking in the background.

title: United Parcel Threatens To Close if Offer Fails
description: The United Parcel Service threatened last night to close its entire New York metropolitan operation permanently if Local 804 of the teamsters union did not accept what was termed a final offer to end the 65dayold strike by 4,500employes.

title: President, in Iowa, Assures Farmers on Import Curbs
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Oct. 31President Ford, beginning his last campaign tour to help stem Republican losses in Tuesday's election, assured farmers today that he was prepared to limit beef imports that threaten to keep down cattle prices.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: N. J. Weekly100483

title: Screen. Prisoner Rights
description: Two impressive documentaries at the Film Forum both excel at dispensing complex information about the legal experiences of black radicals. FrameUp! The Imprisonment of Martin Sostre, by the Pacific Street Film Collective, and Mangrove Nine, by Franco Rosso, are truly educational films, which raise grim questions about the system of justice in America and Great Britain. The program is running through Sunday and Nov: 710 at 256 West 88th Street.

title: General Who Led. Intelligence Agency Arrested in Italy
description: ROME; Oct. 31Gen. Vito Miceli, head of the Italian military intelligence agency until three months ago, was arrested on charges of political conspiracy tonight.

title: Voters Guide
description: In making their legislative choices for Tuesday's election, voters will find invaluable assistance in series of booklets prepared by the New York Public Interest Research Group. The booklets list voting records, stands on issues and community and legislative performance evaluations for each of the 191 state senators and assemblymen who are seeking reelection this year. Free copies can be obtained by writing to the Public Interest Research Group, Room 407, 5 Beekman Street, New York, N. Y. 10038, orsince time is shortby calling at the office. Copies also are available at the Queens College Student Union Building. Mail requests should specify the name of the legislators or the districts involved and should be accompanied by a selfaddressed, stamped envelope.

title: Experts at French Wine Trial Explode Some Vintage Myths
description: BORDEAUX, France, Oct. 31 The mystique surrounding French wines bas been partly stripped away by the testimony of experts in a sensational trial centering on four million bottles labeled red Bordeaux.

title: OffDuty Officer in Costume Shot By Men Trying to Steal His Car
description: An offduty police officer dressed in a Halloween costume was shpt and seriously wounded last night in Staten Island after he chased several men who were apparently trying to steal or loot his car.

title: OFFICER IS CHARGED IN REWARD SCHEME
description: TRENTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)A Jersey City police lieutenant was indicted today on charges of scheming to extort $8,000 in reward money from the Security Council of the New York, State Motor Truck Association.

title: Notes on People
description: In oiler return yesterday to her official duties as White House hostess, Betty Ford served punch and cookies to a witch, a ghost, Dracula and three other scarylooking characters raising money for the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: Massengales Lead by Shot
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Oct. 31Here in the land of Mickey Mouse, par is not good enough to make the scoreboard, and if Mickey had a brother, then the Brothers Mouse would have to shoot nine under par to be noticed.

title: SUIT SEEKS TO BAR PALESTINIANS HERE
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith moved in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to bar delegates of the Palestine Liberation Organization from entering the United States, saying leaders of the group were responsible for crimes of murkier, acts of barbarism and savIagery.

title: Storm Turns Back Steamer by 140
description: SHREVEPORT, La., Oct. 31Pete Beathard hit Rufus Ferguson with two touchdown passes in the first half and the Portland Storm went on to a 14.0 victory over the Shreveport Steamer in a nationally televised World Football. League game tonight.

title: 2 NEWCOMERS DANCE 'BEAU DANUBE LEADS
description: It is a fact of life in ballet, or rather a faet of ballet, that second or third casts rarely carry the connotation of the understudy. It is firm tradition to regard alt4nate leads in ballet as separate but equalat the least.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Clarinet Concerto in A, Mozart; Symphony No. 49 in F minor, Haydn.

title: Javits Sees Clark Aura of Sainthood At Odds With Image in Johnson Cabinet
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he didrarot find it congenial to be such an aggressive campaigner. Then, apparently subduing his qualms, he flailed Ramsey Clark for having, on occasion, been a repressive Attorney General.

title: Rts Remain a Strong Forde Amid League in ConstantFlux
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 31As the New York Nets fleW home today after a 9591 victory over the Utah Stars that completed a satisfactory fourgame road trip with a 31 wonlost record, they had plenty of opportunity to contemplate the new shape of the American Basketball Association.

title: FUENTES CASE OPENS DESPITE A PROTEST
description: A hearing on charges by Community School Board against Luis Fuentes began yesterday despite the refusal, on procedure grounds, of Mr. Fuentes's lawyer to participate.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Julius Boros Demonstrates He Is Human
description: MONTAUK, L.I.  Julius Boros, the husky, agedefying professional golfer who has a reputation for being utterly phlegmatic, showed, if only briefly, during a striped bass fishing trip off Montauk last week, that he is subject to sonie of the frailties that ordinary flesh is heir to.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Mini Mundus is a new little shop awash with nostalgia. In this case, it's tangible memories of childhoodif not your own, then possibly your grandmother's.

title: Franklin Bank Lists $66.1Million Debt
description: The parent company of the Franklin National Bank left behind debts of $66.1million and known assets of $2.7million, its lawyers ed yesterday.

title: Effort by Diplomats For Cyprus Solution Is Increased at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31Diplomats stepped up efforts today to hammer out a Cyprus resolution acceptable to both the Greek and Turkish communities of the island.

title: NEW KENYA CABINET NAMED BY KENYATTA
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 31(Agence FrancePresse)President Jomo Keriyatta announced his new Cabinet today, following general elections Oct. 14.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE RAMAPO MOUNTAIN PEOPLE. By David Steven Cohen. Photographs by Robert Goldstein. 285 pages. Rutgers University Press. $15.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission approved yesterday a 3 per cent freight rate increase on recyclable commodities, with some exceptions, after completing what it termed an exhaustiveenvironmental impact study.

title: Lebanon Gets a Cabinet After 5Week Endeavor
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 31(Reauters)Rashid al Solh, lawyer and former judge, tonight formed a new Government made up mostly of members of Parliament to replace the Cabinet of Takieddin alSolh, who resigned five weeks ago.

title: State Voters Strongly for Democrats, Poll Shows
description: New Yorkers by substantial margins rate the Democratic party as superior to the Republican party in dealing with the critical issues of inflation, prosperity, taxes, jobs and restoring integrity in government.

title: DYNAMITER SOUGHT IN KANAWHA COUNTY
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va. Oct. 31 (UPI)The police, fearing new violence, reinforced patrols and searched today for the source of the third dynamite attack since the Kanawha County school textbook protest began.

title: Accountant at School in Bronx Sought In Forging of Bills and Cashing Checks,
description: Detectives from the city's Department of Investigation are searching for a former supervising accountant of a Bronx school district who, the department says, submitted fraudulent bills totaling several thousand dollars to the district and then forged and cashed the checks that were issued to pay those bills.

title: Gradual Nixon Gains Seen Despite Lurking Dangers
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 31Former President Richard M. Nixon's doctors said late today that they expected gradual improvement in his condition, but that they remained concerned over postoperative complications and dangers lurking, in the background.

title: 2 SEIZED, 2 SOUGHT IN PRIEST'S KILLING
description: PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 31Acting on a tip given to a foot patrolman, detectives today arrested two men and charged them with beating to death 79  year  old Roman Catholic priest on Tuesday in the rectory of St. Boniface Church in the city's downtown section.

title: People in Sports
description: Dr. Bobby Brown believes the operation has been a success. Brown, the former New York Yankee infielder, became the interim president of the Texas Rangers last May 1 to facilitate the transfer of ownership from Bob Short to a group of new owners headed by Brad Corbett.

title: Ford May See Nixon If Doctor Approves
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31(Reuters) President Ford plans to call on Richard M. Nixon tomorrow if the former President's doctor approves, a spokesman for Mr. Ford said tonight.

title: U.S.CANADA TALKS ON PIPELINES SET
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31A United States delegation will visit Canada tomorrow to open pipeline security agreement.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Although taxi fares will go up in New York City today, there was hope that the halffare program on subway, bus and commuter rail lines would be extended to include not just Sunday, but Saturday nights as well.

title: New Miracle in Rice Seen by Some in Asia
description: HYDERABAD, IndiaWhile the onethird of mankind that lives on rice struggles desperately to grow enough food, scientists in Asia remain confident that harvests can increase faster than the needs of a ricedependent population that is expected to double by the year 2000.

title: Bridge. Veteran Triumphs on Deal Muffed by a Younger Star
description: Most bridgeplaying countries have produced plentiful crops of young experts in recent years, and many of them earn international honors. Nevertheless, the Old Guard can still teach them a thing or two.

title: Architects of Luxury Towers Shape New Manhattan Skyline
description: Philip Birnbaum, Schuman Lichtenstein Claman, and Horace Ginsbern and Associates are not names well known to even the most architectureconscious segments of the general public. In fact, the three firms knownare to many architects. But these firms, and a handful of others, are playing, at least as big a role in shaping the design of Manhattan as any architects of more note. They are the apartmenthouse specialiststhe firms which have created their architectural practices largely on the design of the luxury towers which continue to sprout up throughout midtown.

title: Beverly Sills Leaves Hospital to Recuperate
description: Beverly Sills was released from New York Hospital yesterday to complete her recuperation from an operation last week for malignancy in the pelvic area. Since the operation was successful and she will not have to undergo further treatment, the soprano will begin performing again within three weeks.

title: Deaths
description: Memorial Services

title: Big A to Start Blood Tests
description: Postrace blood testing of thoroughbreds, a procedure designed to tighten security against the use of drugs and illegal medications, will begin today at Aqueduct. The new policy, announced yesterday by the State Racing and Wagering Board, also will apply at Belmont Park and Saratoga.

title: Domestic Air Fare Rise Of 4% Granted by
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized the nation's airlines yesterday to raise domestic air fares by 4 per cent Nov. 15 and made permanent a 6 per cent surcharge imposed on travelers last spring as an emergency measure to offset higher fuel bills. The surcharge had been scheduled to expire last night.

title: A New Skating Pond Among the Changes Due in Central Park
description: Guided bya hundredyearold vision of Central Park, the city is planning to replace the Wollman Rink with a manmade iceskating pond after this season.

title: Death of Liu Shaochi, Once 2d to Mao, Disclosed
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 31The Chinese Communists disclosed today that Liu Shaochi, who was purged as China's chief of state during the Cultural Revolution, is dead. No details of the time or cause of death were given.

title: PARENT TESTIFIES ON WILLOWBROOK
description: The president of the parents association of the Willowbrook State School for the Mentally Retarded testified yesterday that a 25yearold male resident choked to death last Tuesday evening after finishing a substitute meal of bread and potatoes.

title: NORWAY REJECTS BID TO SHARE OIL
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 31Ndway, rich in North Sea oil wealth, has refused to join a proposed plan to share oil in time of crisis with 11 other nations, including the United States.

title: CLEMENCY PROVISION EXPLAINED BY SAXBE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today that no one would be required to perform alternate service in President Ford's clemency program for draft evaders if there was insufficient evidence for prosecution.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Sun Oil Earnings Climb By 84.5% in 3d Quarter
description: The Sun Oil Company joined the oil industry's highprofit bandwagon yesterday, reporting earnings gains of 84.5 per cent for the third quarter, and 109 per cent for the first nine months.

title: U.S. JUDGE SIGNS ORDER TO BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31Federal District Judge W. Arthur Gardty signed today a final order instructing the Boston School Committee to develop a citywide school integration plan by Dec. 16.

title: Experts at French Wine Trial Explode Some Vintage Myths
description: BORDEAUX, France, Oct. 31 The mystique surrounding French wines has been partly stripped away by the testimony of experts in a sensational trial centering on four million bottles labeled red Bordeaux.

title: Intercity Truck Tonnage Off 5.10/0 From a Year Ago
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage in this latest cent per 5.1 bown was week from the corresponding week last year. Bassed on a weekly survey of 35 metropolitan areas, decreased tonnage from a year ago was repdrted at 26localities.

title: Skelly Sets Special Payout
description: The Skelly Oil Company announced yesterday that it would pay a special dividend of 20cents per common share in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 30 cents per share.

title: Chad Bans U.S. Aid After a Report of Corruption
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The Government of Chad has banned further American food relief efforts in reaction to New York Times article indicating that there had been corruption and inefficiency in the distribution of the aid by persons close to the Chadian leadership. Chad's action was confirmed today by United States State Department officials.

title: People and Business
description: Geoffrey Moore, vice president of economic research at the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private research institution, is not yet ready to join those who are saying the United States economy is in a recession. Mr. Moore, who is being asked the question frequently these days, said yesterday, Until the contradictions in the data run their course, I don't think we're able to say we are in a recession.

title: MRS. ZISHA LANDAU
description: Razel Levitsky Landau, widow of Zisha Landau, Yiddish poet and writer, and herself a contributor of verse to Yiddish magazines and newspapers, died yesterday in the Long Island Jewish Hospital in Far Rockaway, Queens. She was 85 years old and lived in East Rockaway, L. I.

title: HOSPITAL DEFICITS CITED BY TERENZIO
description: Seventeen of the city's 55nonprofit voluntary hospitals are. technically insolvent and are running deficits totaling $65million this year for their outpatient and emergencyroom services, Joseph V. Terenzio, president of the United Hospital Fund, said yesterday.

title: The Value Of the C. I. A.
description: WASHINGTONThe surge of sentimental piety and outrage over the public disclosure that the Central Intelligence Agency had attempted to influence*the course of political events in Chile in the nineteenseventies has shed more heat than light.

title: AUTO OUTPUT UP, BUT DROP IS DUE
description: DETROIT, Oct. 31 United States auto production is scheduled to reach a yearly high of 201,518 cars this week, according to the trade paper Automotive News.

title: Joseph Durso
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Oct. 30In a country besieged by inflation, Japan finally got something for nothing today: a pitching lesson by George Thomas Seaver of Fresno, Calif. And while you still couldn't buy a dozen eggs with It, the seven young pitchers for the Tokyo Giants who attended Seaver's Sapporo Clinic, treated the free lesson like money in the Bank of Hokkaido.

title: 2 EQUITY FINANCINGS ARE OVERSUBSCRIBED
description: Two large utility equity financings were reported to have been oversubscribed yesterday by managing underwriters. Underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch offered 4 million shares of Duke Power Company common shares at $11.625 per share. Underwriters headed by Kidder Peabody & Co. offered 2.3 million shares of United Telecommunications, Inc., common at $12.625 per share.

title: High Tides Afound New York
description: High Tides Afound New York

title: Democrats See Gain in House Upstate
description: Hoping to capitalize on Watergate and inflation, and to ride Representative Hugh L. Carey's coattails, New York Democrats expect to win at least two House seats now held by Republicans and to threaten five other Republican incumbents in Tuesday's elections.

title: CORPORATE BONDS SHOW PRICE RISE
description: Corporate bond prices, driven by the prospect of falling shortterm rates, moved up sharply yesterday to continue their monthlong rally.

title: Advertising
description: We found incredibleawareness, but not topofthemind awareness. People just seem to think about the hamburger places that have been drummed into their heads.

title: 75 Hurt in Street Clashes of Thieu's Foes With Police
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Nov, 1About 75 civilians were believed injured yesterday after a night and morning of violent clashes between policemen and antiGovernment demonstrators.

title: Business Records
description: Chapter XI petition for an arrangement by: WILLMARK SERVICE SYSTEM INC., a shooPing service agency, at 443 Park Ave. South, N.Y. Signed by Robert M. Bernstein, President. Liabilities, $90,594; assets, 553,700.

title: Big A to Start Blood Tests
description: Postrace blood testing of thoroughbreds, a procedure designed to tighten security against the use of drugs and illegal medications, will begin today at Aqueduct. The new policy, announced yesterday by the State Racing, and Wagering Board, also will apply at Belmont Park and Saratoga.,

title: Drugs a Bad Memory for Oilers Kiner
description: For Steve Kiner, the hazy world of drugs is just a nagging memory and even his outward image will be different when he trots onto Shea Stadium's gridiron with the Houston Oilers for a game against the Jets on Sunday.

title: For Bloomgarden, It's a Good Season
description: Approaching 70, an age when most producers have retiredwith laurels and/or annuities  Kermit Bloomgarden has once again become one of the most active men in the New York theater.

title: Profit Taking Halts Market's Advance,
description: Some bearish economic news and profit taking ended the stock market's twoSession sharp advance yesterday as prices finished mixed in slower trading.

title: Foreman Says Count Was Short
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct, 31(Reuters)George Foreman claimed today for the first time that he beat the count when he lost his world heavyweight title on an eighthround knockout by Muhammad Ali two days ago.

title: Radio Station Aide Jailed
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (UPI) Will Lewis, general manager of radio station KPFK, was sent back to jail today for his continued refusal to turn over to the authorities the original of a message from a terrorist group. Judge A. Andrew Hauk of Federal district court found Mr. Lewis in contempt when he declined to give up the message in which a group calling itself the New World Liberation Front took responsibility for hotel bombings in San Francisco and Los Angeles several weeks ago.

title: Allied Raises Dividend
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation announced yesterday it would pay a quarterly dividend of 45 cents per share of common stock, up from 33 cents per share in the similar period lof last year and 37 cents last quarter. The dividend is payable Dec. 10 to shareholders of record Nov. 12.

title: FORD ASKED TO NAME C.I.A.AIDED PAPERS
description: The Inter American Press Association asked President Ford yesterday to make public the names of Chilean newspapers that allegedly received financial assistance from the Central Intelligence Agency during the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: TRADE RESTRAINT ON TIRES CHARGED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission accused today four of the nation's biggest oil companies of conspiring to restrain trade by offering consumers a common line of tires, batteries and other automobile accessories.

title: DEALS DENIED IN CARTER CASE
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 31The former prosecutor in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter case denied today that he made any deals for leniency with two major witnesses whose testimony helped bring in a verdict of guilty to three murders in 1967.

title: Hearsts Withdraw Offer For Return of Daughter
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31(UPI)Mr. and Mrs. Randolph A. Hearst withdrew today the $50,000 reward they had offered for the safe return of their daughter, Patricia.

title: October Sales Up at Big Chains
description: The country's major chain store organizations reported yesterday substantial sales gains for October over the same month a year ago. The companies also reported record sales for the first 10 months of the year.

title: Morton Set And Happy As a Giant
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 31  Craig Morton looked relaxed and happy, even with the thought of facing a Kansas City defensive front four that averages 6feet 7 inches and 275 pounds.

title: Right Track
description: One of the most important options on next week's, ballot will be Proposition One, known as the State Railroad Preservation Bond Act. Its approval will go far to rescue this state's railroad system, five major lines of which are now facing bankruptcy. It can prevent the abandonment of 1,875 miles of branchline track, greatly improve the condition of commuter lines, significantly increase highspeed passenger service in the New York CityAlbanyBuffalo corridor and save freight service that is vital to agriculture and small industry.

title: ARABS ASK DELAY IN DEBATE AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31The Arab countries asked the United Nations today to postpone for one week scheduled debate in the General Assembly on the issue of Palestine.

title: Domestic Air Fare Rise Of 4% Grantedby C.A.B.
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized the nation's airlines yesterday to raise domestic air fares by 4 per cent Nov. 15 and nade permanent a 6 pei cent surcharge imposed on travelers, last spring as an emergency measure to offset higher fuel bills. The surcharge had been scheduled to expire last night.

title: Kissinger Pledges U.S. Support to Bhutto
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 31Secretary of State Kissinger assured Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto today that the United States would continue to back the sovereignty land territorial integrity of strong, secure and prosperous Pakistan.

title: CancerInhibiting Drugs To Be Given Mrs. Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) Hospital tests have found no sign of lingering cancer in Betty Ford, but the White House physician said today that she would receive cancerinhibiting drugs as a precaution.

title: Bills Vs. Patriots Gets Exposure Here
description: Two of pro football's most pleasing and exciting teams can be seen on television Sunday when the Buffalo Bills play the New England Patriots at Foxboro, Mass., (Channel 4) at 1P.M. The other locally televised game will be the Giants at Kansas City, Channel 2, 4 P.M. The Chiefs are favored by a touchdown.

title: Higher Gasoline Taxes Called a Way to Save Oil
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 31New gasoline taxes of as much as 45 cents a gallonmore than the total price of gasoline a few years agoare outlined as a possible oil conservation measure in an analysis that is expected to go to the Ford Administration soon.

title: Carey and Wilson Touch Issues Briefly in Debate at Fordham
description: Governor Wilson and Representative Hugh L. Carey last night debated for the third time in a tightly structured session that ranged over virtually every campaign issue.

title: Hasty Retreat
description: The ouster of John C. Sawhill as Federal Energy Administrator and the formation of a new team under the amiable but uninspiring leadership of Secretary the Interior Morton indicate abject retreat by President Ford from that spirit of urgency on the oil crisis on which he declaimed just five weeks ago.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: ;Defense Is Unable to Shake Magruder's Account of the CoverUp
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Defense lawyers questioned Jeb (Stuart Magruder vigorously today in an apparent effort to shake the account he gave yesterday about the Watergate coverup.

title: Sugar Industry's Profits, Like Its Prices, Have Risen Dramatically in Recent Months
description: At a time of dramatic creases in the price of sugar300 per cent within the last year and 25 per cent within the last month aloneprofits of the nation's sugar industry have soared to record levels.

title: FREDERICK GROEL, PRUDENTIAL AIDE
description: Frederick H. Groel, a retired executive vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived at 60 Troy Drive, Springfield, N.J.

title: More Auto Rules Opposed
description: Lee A. Iacocca, president of the Ford Motor Company, surged the Federal Government last night to suspend imposing any additional vehicle standards until inflation was controlled. He spoke at a meeting of Lehigh University alumni according to Reuters.

title: Britain and Europe
description: To judge from Queen Elizabeth's speech opening the new British Parliament, Prime Minister Wilson's Government intends to push hard for enactment of Labor's entire election platform, including outright nationalization of several industries and an extension of public ownership in others. But with a majority of three in a House of Commons of 635, and facing Britain's worst economic crisis since the war, Mr. Wilson wisely projected no timetable for Labor's more ambitious projects.

title: AFRICANS RESPOND TO VETOES AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31African delegates said today they might ask the General Assembly to adopt a resolution deploring yesterday's vetoes of a Security Council motion calling for the expulsion of South Africa from the United Nations.

title: BUDDY MYER, 70, DIES, 1935 BATTING TITLIST
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 31(AP)Charles S. (Buddy) Myer Jr., the 1935 American League batting champion, died today at a hospital here. He was 70years old.

title: The Pop Life
description: Black singers are moving with everincreasing numbers and everincreasing authority into the middleoftheroad repertory that used to be dominated by white singers. Sometimes they do it so successfully that they become firmly identified with such material to the exclusion of almost everything elseRoberta Flack, for instance. Sometimes they make the move tentatively, clinging to the biacker style that won them their first reputations, but still reaching out for something they really don't sound comfortable with Aretha Franklin, with her recent That's Entertainment showbiz revue.

title: Musica Aeterna Concert Is Sparked by Entremont
description: Although Frederic Waldman and his Musica Aeterna Orchestra are usually in residence at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, they do venture as far south as Lincoln Center a few times each year to play at Alice Tully Hall.

title: ISRAEL SEES PERIL IN ARAB DECISIONS
description: Israeli and United States military analysts say they believe Israel's military position has worsened appreciably as a result of the decision by King Hussein of Jordan and other Arab leaders to recognize the Palestine Liberation Organization as the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people.

title: Robert Well Jr., ExDean At Manhattan College, 66
description: Robert T. Weil Jr., dean of Manhattan College's School of Engineering from 1961 to 1971, died Wednesday of injuries from an automobile accident earlier in the day near Youngsville, N. C. He was 66 years old and had been living in retirement in Southern Pines, C.

title: Texts of Statements by Nixon Doctors
description: LONG BEACH., Calif., Oct. 31Following is a bulletin on the condition of farther President Richard M. Nixon issued at 10 A.M. today at the Meinorial Hospital Medical Center here by Dr. John C. Lungren, cardiologist who is Mr. Nixon's personal physician, and Dr. Eldon Hickman cardiovascular surgeon who headed Mr, Nixon's surgical team, and a statement by Dr. Lungren at a news conference this afternoon:.

title: Democrat Confident
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 31Representative Hugh L. Carey, his fellow Democrats flocking to his lengthening coattails, today brought his campaign upstate for a day. He was treated as a winner, and he acted as one.

title: Shorts: Na One Has. Declared a Right Length
description: PARIS  Pants must fit snugly, like wallpaper, from the waistline through the knees, then flare gradually until the hem, which practically brushes the floor. Right?

title: Treasury to Study Foreign Ownership in Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) Apparently prompted by reported heavy investments in the United States by Arab Countries, the Treasury Debartment announced today Cegulations designed to uncover the extent of such foreign Upending.

title: CANADIAN LEADERS MEET ON INFLATION
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 31Federal and provincial leaders, often at odds on fiscal issues, have agreed to direct future government expenditures toward projects that will discourage inflation without curbing this country's economic growth.

title: The Stage; 'Tubstrip' Reopens at the Mayfair Theater
description: "Tubstrip" by A. J. Kronengold opened on May 1, 1973, at the Mercer Arts Center. Sometime later the theater fell down. Unfortunately "Tubstrip" is still standing.

The satellite has equipment made in Bulil garia, Hungary, East Germany, Rornania and Czechoslovakia as well as in the Soviet Union, the Tass press agency said.

title: Newark Honors CivilRights Veteran
description: NEWARK, Oct. 31For William M. Ashby, the first step toward a lifetime commitment to the civilrights movement came one morning at the turn of the century when he gazed into the face of an acquaintance who was found hanging from a tree after a lynching in his hometown of Newport News, Va.

The company's revival of the 1944play, originally adapted by John Van Druten from Kathryn Forbes's novel and starring Mady Christians, opens Thursday night in the church annex, with Eugenia Rawls as the San Francisco matriarch.

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Mr. Ray has contended that he was treated unfairly by the state and by his defense attorneys before he pleaded guilty to murder in March, 1969.

description: Our big concern is the fact that they have improved a great deal each week and are now starting to play good football. They stands for Dartmouth, and the worrier is Carmen Cozza, Yale's football coach. Dartmouth's defending champions face the unbeaten Elis (50 over all and 30 in the league) tomorrow in the Bowl, and it appears Cozza has begun his psychological warfare.

title: SUGAR FUTURES CLIMB IN PRICE

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)The United States moved to a commanding lead in the 16th Washington International Horse Show at the D.C. Armory today, winning two international jumpero classes. Willie Wonderful, a 7yearold gelding ridden by James Hulick of Sterling, Mass., captured the doubles and trebles, competition to win the Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower Trophy tonight. Earlier, Idle Dice, ridden by Rodney Jenkins of Orange, Va., won the fault and out, timelimit event.

description: THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 31Dutch officials were jubilant today over the dawn rescue of 15 hostages held by four convicts in a chapel at Scheveningen Prison near here.

description: The Continental Can Company said yesterday that its flexible packaging division was increasing by an average of 3per cent the price on all product lines, including polyethylene laminations and specialty bag products, effective with deliveries on Jan. 1

title: About Real Estate Prewar Apartments on the West Side Illustrate Problems of City Landlords
description: The majesty of Riverside Drive is a curious thing. From the George Washington Bridge it is unmistakable a handsome line of apartment buildings flanking park, astride a river. But the lobby of one such residence, near 100th Street, turns out to be dim and shabby.

title: Lisbon Minister, Visiting Soviet, Reportedly Asking for Food Aid
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31A Portuguese delegation led by Alvaro Cunhal, secretary general of Portugal's Communist party, was reported today to be seeking Soviet shipments of grain and meat to offset troublesome food shortages in Portugal.

title: Ford Campaign: An Illusion of Normality
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 President Ford's appeals to voters to stem inflation by preserving Republican budgetary savers in Congress and to prevent the Democrats from establishing a legislative dictatorship have the ring of the legendary King nute ordering the tide not to come in. Professionalso of both major parties fully expect the tide next Tuesday to swell the Democratic majorities and erode the Republican minorities in the Senate and House of Representatives.

description: Priced of raw fain products climbed 4 per cent from Sept. 15 to Oct. 15, more than offsetting a decline in the preceding month, the Agriculture Department reported yesterday. Page 55.

title: Flyers Manhandle Rangers, Win, 51
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31The New York Rangers may not believe in ghosts, but one came back to haunt them on Halloween tonight. Servinab up tricks instead of treats, the Philadelphia Flyers extended their homeice witchery over New York with a 51 trouncing. It was the worst beating the Rangers have suffered at the hands of the Stanley Cup champions.

title: Haldeman? Ehrlichman? Well, It's One of Them
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Throughout the Watergate coverup trial, lawyers for H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman have repeatedly expressed concern about the tendency of witnesses and others to link or confuse the two defendants names. The two have faced the same problem as they walk through the hallways and encounter spectators.

description: Portland 14, Shreveport 0.

title: For Singles, Scene Has Sordid Side
description: Brigitte Albrecht, a former airline stewardess from Germany who was working as, a model here, was described by those who knew her as a wellbred kind of girl, somewhat aloof in her demeanor. Slim, with gray eyes and long auburn hair, she was just 25 years old when she died last month.

title: MEDICAL STUDENT TELLS OF THREAT
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31A medical student who was present at an abortion in which the fetus reportedly lived after the at ortion but was allowed to die toad an inquest today that an attempt had been made to intimidate hint into not testifying.

description: The newly elected head of the Aluminum Association called on the industry to lift its annual metal supply through recycling by one billion pounds a year instead of the present rate of 660 million pounds. Addressing the final luncheon of the trade association's annual meeting at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, David P. Reynolds, executive vice president and general manager of the Reynolds Metals Company, described the results of such program as staggering. He added:

title: Butz's Criticism of I.C.C. Is Assailed at Food Parley
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz opened today a hastily called twoday conference on high food prices by asking participants not to flay the middleman or try to place the blame for inflated food prices.

title: 2 Men Seized, 2 Sought In Jersey Priest's Slaying
description: PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 31Acting on a tip given to a foot patrolman, detectives today arrested two men and charged them with beating to death a 79  year  old Roman Catholic priest on Tuesday in the rectory of St. Boniface Church in the city's downtown section.

title: Pop Music
description: Tony Bennett found himself in an all but impossible situation Wednesday evening at the Minskoff Theater. He had to follow Lena Home in a program called Tony Bennett and Lena Horne Sing, which will continue through next Wednesday. After Miss Home had put in an electrifying hour on the stage, no onewell, hardly anyonecould have followed her successfully.

title: Pabst's 'Paracelsus' a Handsome Film:The Cast
description: "Paracelsus," which was shown at the First Avenue Screening Room last Sunday and will be repeated there at noon and midnight today and tomorrow, is a very special footnote to film and political history. Never before released in New York, it is the second film made by the great, supposedly left-wing German director, G. W. Pabst, after he returned to Nazi Germany just in time for World War II.Pabst, who died at the age of 82 in 1967, is a fascinating character, known as "the red Pabst" (Papst means pope in German) until he went back to Hitler's new German empire. His best films, including the silent "Joyless Street" with Greta Garbo and "The Threepenny Opera" (1931), are rather uproarious amalgams of stark realism, wild melodrama and pure poetry. Lots of elements in his films look dated today but also there is usually, something that looks totally new and surprising."Paracelsus," considering when it was made (1943) and under what conditions, is a remarkably interesting film, though full of not especially well disguised propaganda. It's the story of Paracelsus, the 16th-century Swiss healer whose reputation took on a new vogue in the Germany of the early nineteen-forties. Nazi writers and intellectuals began to attribute all sorts of Nazi ideals to the mystic healer who had been ridiculed and oppressed for choosing to write in German instead of Latin and who had challenged the authority of vested (feudal) interests.With the exception of Werner Krauss, who plays Paracelsus as a sort of medieval Dr. Gillespie, crusty but kind, the acting is operatic. The screenplay is full of noble opinions about the German character and its ability to triumph over the ignorance of its enemies.The physical production, however, is astonishingly handsome. In addition, the movie contains one of Pabst's most magical scenes, in which Death, in the person of a juggler, enters a town in the siege of plague and invites the citizens to join him in a celebratory dance. Realism moves into fantasy (and back again) with less awkwardness than most other directors display when making a simple cut between two scenes in the same style.A further footnote to this footnote to history: after the war, Pabst went on to make other films, including "The Trial" (1949), about anti-Semitism in Hungary in 1882, but Werner Krauss was blacklisted, largely for his participation in the notorious "Jud Siss."

title: Music: For Elliott Carter
description: Not all good music is difficult to listen to, nor is it all staggeringly difficult to perform. But there is no doubt That many composers in our day tend to equate newness with difficulty and going beyond that, to equate hard with good. Both listeners and performers have come to know they must struggle. On the performers side, at least, that struggle has rarely been More clearly illustrated than it was Wednesday night at the Whitney Museum, where the Composers Showcase sponsored An Evening With Elliott Carter.

title: Amex Closes Lower as Volume Dips; Market Summary AMERICAN EXCHANGE Thursday, October 31, 1974(Volume 2,118,125 shares)
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower yesterday as volume fell slightly from the previous session. However, prices finished higher in the overthecounter market as volume dropped slightly.

title: EMIL BERGEN
description: Emil Bergen, who retired in 1973 as director of the welfare fund department of the American Jewish Committee, died Thursday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was in his mid60's.

title: New Team In Soccer Is Chicago
description: The North American Soccer League awarded a franchise to Chicago yesterday and is on the verge of becoming the third largest pro sports league in North America.

description: HYDERABAD, IndiaWhile the onethird of mankind that lives on rice struggles desperately to grow enough food, scientists in Asia remain confident that harvests can increase faster than the needs of a ricedependent population that is expected to double by the year 2000.

title: News Summary and Index
description: About 75 civilians and policemen were believed to have been injured when, for the first time since the opposition to President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam took to the street two months ago, confrontations between riot policemen and antiGovernment demonstrators turned violent. The police abandoned their policy of leniency and attacked the demonstrators in an outlying neighborhood of Saigon, inhabited by Roman Catholics who fled North Vietnam. [Page 1, Columns 14.]

title: 13 MORE ARRESTED IN CHICAGO THEFT
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation rounded up today the last of the suspects in the reclord $4.3million Chicago vault burglary, bringing two deported men back to the United States from the British West Indies and arresting another man here.

description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Oct. 31Governor Wilson toured his home county of Westchester today and found it friendly territory, but most of the crowds that greeted him were small.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Important advances are being made against cancer, the director of the national cancer program said in his 1974 report to the President, but he cautioned that there is little prospect of any sudden conquest of all forms of the disease.

description: Accumulating evidence indicates that three of the huge outer planets in the solar systemJupiter, Saturn and Neptuneradiate more heat into space than they receive from the sun.

description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that completion of the Second Avenue subway would be delayed at least five or six years, until about 1986, because costs have spiraled greatly.

title: Fiddling With the 25th
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31In his news conference here the other day, President Ford suggested that the Congress might be wise to consider revising the 25th Amendment to the Constitution under which he became the 38th President of the United States.

title: PERISTS PARENT SEES BANKRUPTCY
description: Mr. Johnson noted that the The Penn Central Company, the corporate shell that holds all the stocks of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad, may have to file for bankruptcy itself, according to its chairman, Archibald DeB. Johnson.

description: Lesley Roberta Mandel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Mandel of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married here yesterday evening to Stepheh Frederick Anfang, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Anfang of New York. The ceremony was performed at the Regency Hotel by Rabbi Allan Block.

title: NEWS INDEX
General Dynamics Now NO. 1 Defense Contractor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31(UPI)  The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, the nation's No. 1 defense contractor for five straight years despite cost overruns and near bankruptcy, has been replaced by the General Dynamics, as the top contractor, the Pentagon announced today.

description: Representative Hugh L. Carey, who is widely considered to have a liberal voting record in Congress, has nevertheless opposed taxreform efforts that many liberal organizations support.

title: France Again Refuses To Back Nuclear Pact
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31France reaffirmed her refusal today to adhere to the sixyearold treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear Weapons to new nations. Addressing the Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, PierreChristian Taittinger, vice president of the French Senate, said that the treaty was discriminatory, fallacious, illusory and ultimately inefficacious.
