title: GOLDIN SEES PERIL IN CITY BORROWING
description: Expressing serious concern over the widening gap between the city's spending and revenues, Controller Harrison J. Goldin warned yesterday in his annual report on the city's fiscal situation that New York could not continue to close the gaps with ever larger and more expensive borrowings.

title: State Iskies: Pensions And Strikes Spur Clash
description: Should public employes have the right to strike? Should they be permitted to negotiate further improvements in their pensions, which some critics contend are already too generous?

title: 75 Hurt in Street Clashes of Thieu's Foes With Police
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Nov. 1About 75 civilians were believed injured yesterday after a night and morning of violent clashes between policemen and antiGovernment demonstrators.

title: Pro Transactions
description: CLEVELAND (AllSigned Mike O'Keefe, right handed pitcher, and assigned him; to Sarasota of the Gulf Coast League.

title: Labor Left Wing Rebuked By British Prime Minister
description: LONDON, Oct. 31  Prime Minister Harold Wilson told his ministers today that they must either promise to refrain from public criticism of Government actions or resign.

title: Court Rebuffs Meredith On Bid for Spot on Ballot
description: JACKSON. Miss., Oct. 31(UPI)James H. Meredith has lost another round in his legal fight to run for Congress as an independent candidate but has indicated he will carry his appeal to the Supreme Court.

title: Connally Author Doubts Rockefeller Sales Link
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The author of a critical biography of John M. Connally, former Secretary of the Treasury, said today that he had no evidence of any orchestration of the book's sales by the Rockefeller family.

title: Ford to Meet Liberian
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) President Ford and President R. Tolbert Jr. of Liberia will hold private talks Nov. 5 at the White House, the Administration said today. Mr. Tolbert is in the United States on a private visit.

title: President Is Nominated By Temple EmanuEl
description: Maxwell M. Rabb, a Manhattan lawyer and former secretary to the Cabinet during the Dwight D. Eisenhower Administration, has been nominated to be president of Temple EmanuEl, the 3,000, family Reform Jewish congregation at Fifth Avenue and 65th Street.

title: CASO GIVEN REPORT ON RAID AT L.I. HOME
description: MINEOLA, LI., Oct. 31Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso received an interim report from the Police Commissioner today on charges of an allegedly illegal search by the police of a Roosevelt pharmacist's home. He turned the report over to the District Attorney's office for possible grand jury action.

title: Special Interests Donate $8.5Million So Far in 74
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Organized special interest groups primarily labor unions, business societies and professional associations  contributed 38.5million by midOctober to candidates in Congressional races this year, according to an analysis released today by Common Cause.

title: Ravenel's Backers Are Pivotal in South Carolina Race
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 31Charles D. Ravenel's name will not appear on the South Carolina ballot Tuesday because the courts say he has not lived in the state long enough to run for Governor.

title: More Companies Announce Layoffs Tied to Sales Lags
description: More companies announced layoffs yesterday as slumps in major industries are beginning to affect employment in smaller, dependent secondary industries.

title: For Singles, Scene Has Sordid Side
description: Brigitte Albrecht, a former airline stewardess from Germany who was working as, a model here, was described by those who knew her as a wellbred kind of girl, somewhat aloof in her demeanor. Slim, with gray eyes and long auburn hair, she was just 25 years old when she died last month.

title: 21 Crime Figures Are Indicted Here On Bribes to Police
description: Twentyone reputed members of organizedcrime families were indicted yesterday on charges of making systematic payoffs of more than $47,000to undercover police officers to protect their multimilliondollar gambling operations in Brooklyn.

title: Easy Money
description: New Jersey voters who may be tempted Tuesday to support a constitutional amendment legalizing casino gambling in their state should first consider a report just issued by a task force on gambling sponsored by the Fund for the City of New York and the Twentieth Century Fund.

title: ROCKEFELLER GIVES TAX AUDIT FACTS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller described as inaccurate today published reports that the justcompleted Congressional audit of his taxes contains adverse infofmation and that he refuses to allow the audit to be made public.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 18.1billion tonmiles, 1.6 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 556,224 cars 0.08 per cent below last year.

title: Champion's Greeting for Ali in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP)Muhammad Ali, the heavyweight boxing champion again, landed in style here today with the comment: Yes, I've given thought to retirement. I'm getting old.

title: Magruder Says Trial Defendants Invented Story About His Taking Money to Make Him a Scapegoat
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Jeb Stuart Magruder testified today that the defendants in the Watergate coverup trial had concocted a story about his taking money from the 19722 Nixon reelection campaign in an effort to make him a scapegoat for the Watergate affair.

title: Train Toll Now 52 in India
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 1 (Reuters)The death toll in yesterday's train disaster in northern Indiain which an explosion caused a fire in an express trainrose to 52 today with the recovery of seven more charred bodies and two deaths in a hospital, a railway statement said. The explosion was believed to have been caused by a cigarette that ignited a bag of fireworks carried by a passenger.

title: REVERSIBLE LANES ON AGAIN UPTOWN
description: The onagain, offagain traffic pattern to ease vehicular problems on the Upper West Side is on again.

title: Contract Awards
description: United Aircraft Corporation has received a $286.8million contract from the Air Force for production of 180 engines for F15 fighter planes.

title: REFUNDS ORDERED ON RISES IN RENT
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that tenants of 80,000 rentcontrolled apartments here were entitled to refunds of rent increases they paid earlier this year, but the decision will be appealed by landlords.

title: Manhattan Riders Will Get Cut Fares On Buses at Night
description: Manhattan bus riders will be able to buy 75cent tickets that will be good for an unlimited number of bus trips between P.M. and 2 A.M. on any one day except Sunday, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday.

title: WILSON'S AIDES SCORE CAREYLOAN
description: Officials connected with Governor Wilson's election campaign charged yesterday that new documents filed with the state gave them substantial reason to believe that Representative Hugh L. Carey's campaign had violated the law by accepting a $750,000 bank loan guaranteed by Mr. Carey's brother.

title: W.F.L. Recognizes Player Association
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (UPI)The World Football League Players Association has been recognized as the exclusive bargaining agent with the league, Alan Miller, general counsel of the association, said tonight.

title: Titanic Goes Down, Again
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 1 (AP)The Buffalo Sabres of the National Hockey League assigned today Morris Titanic and Byran McSheffrey, wings, to the Hershey Bears, the Sabres affiliate in the American League. Coach Floyd Smith said Titanic and McSheffrey needed more ice experience.

title: Civic Groups Here Step Up Campaign On Rail Bond Issue
description: Representatives of environmental, transit and civic associations stepped up their campaigning in the metropolitan area yesterday for the $250million rail preservation bond issue on Tuesday's ballot.

title: Army Lightweights Trounce Colunibia
description: Capitalizing on four Columbia fumbles and a blocked kick for its first five touchdowns, the Army lightweight football team routed the Lions, 610, yesterday at Baker Field.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OPERA CAROUSELS Asti's 49th birthday party this week  a joyful chaos with a packed Rouse, champagne abd a typical flow of song from the owner and staffWas a reassuring reminder that two venerable restaurants with operatic hearts were still flourishing. The same spirit of hospitality, the range of music (operarooted, spilling into operetta, folk and musical comedy), the efficient service and approximately the same price range prevail at Asti's (AL 5.9773), at 13 East 12th Street, and Bianchi and Margherita across Green wich Village on West Fourth Street. Either place offers a comfortable, relaxing evening With a typical fullcourse meal in the $12 bracket.

title: Events Today
description: GENERATION OF GREEN FIELDS, from a Play in'Yiddish, by Peretz Hiershbein, adapted by David Licht, who also directed. Performed by the Folksbeine Players, at the Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th Street, 8.

title: William A. Healy, 84, Dies; Active in Albany Politics
description: William A. Healy, former assistant commissioner of labor for New York State and former chief clerk of, the State Senate, died Thursday at his home, 132 Monroe Street. He was 84

title: Haughton Entry Is Messenger Pace Pick
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 1There was a hit of that early morning carnival atmosphere at Roosevelt Raceway today as trainers, grooms and ownerseven those not involved in the racestopped to chat in the paddock and around the barns about the 19th Messenger Pace scheduled for tomorrow night.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 1 (AP)A State Supreme court jury took only 2 hours today to rule in favor of Rico Petrocelli in a $750,000 damage suit lodged against the baseball player, by a former airline stewardess. The verdict by a jury of four men and two women was unanimous.

title: Sports Today
description: The Arizona 150 Indianapolis car race, at Indianapolis Speedway, Phoenix, Ariz. A review of AliForeman fight will also be shown. (TelevisionChannel 7, 5 P.M.)

title: Shipping/Mails
description: South America, West Indies, Etc.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Jones Inlet (Pt. Lookout), deduct 19 min. from Sandy Hook time. For high tide at Atlantic City (Steel Pier), deduct 26 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: Daniels Campaigns in a 3Way Race
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 30Only one of the three candidates running for Congress in the 14th District will have campaigned throughout the entire area by Election Day, and he is Dominick V. Daniels, the Democratic incumbent.

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: LOCAL

title: MOTOROLA PLANNING 3,000MAN LAY OFF
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Nov. 1 Reuters)Motorola, Inc., said today its semiconductor products division would lay off about 3,000 workers worldwide within the next 10 days.

title: Race Is a Muted Issue In State, Survey Finds
description: Something of a quiet standoff is discernible in New York's race relations in this inflationridden election year.

title: WINE TALK
description: Slowly but surely, the American wine industry is moving toward better and better wines for the mass market. Several years ago, when Dr. Konstantin Frank said this country could have a hundred Chateau Lafites it sounded like a bit of hyperchauvinism, nothing more.

title: Loves for Sale in Detroit
description: DETROIT, Nov. 1 (UPI)The owners of the Detroit Loves have received offers by groups in three cities to buy the World Team Tennis franchise, Marshall Greenspan, the team's executive vice president, said today.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Meets Major Rival But Fails to Curb His Demands
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 1Prime Minister Indira Gandhi held an unusual 90minute meeting today with her most powerful opponent, Jayaprakash Narayan.

title: Glass Microspheres Used In Testing Laser Fusion
description: A critical element in the ambitious effort to derive energy from laser fusion has been disclosed following a decision by the Atomic Energy Commission to remove its secrecy classification.

title: WORLD SUGAR UP DAILY LIMIT AGAIN
description: For the fifth time this week, the world sugar price in terms of the key March futures contract moved up the daily pennyapound limit yesterday. Each day it has set a high.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1974 The Major Events of the Day
description: International In the wake of violent clashes between antiGovernment demonstrators and the police in Saigon, several Opposition leaders denounced President Nguyen Van Thieu and Mr. Thieu assailed his domestic opponents as lackeys of the Communists. Duong Van Minh, a retired general about whom sections of the Opposition are rallying, said in a statement that Mr. Thieu's Government was a regime that has completely lost the confidence of the people, [Page 1, Cols. 12.]

title: PEKING WILL OPEN VANCOUVER MISSION
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 1 Peking will establish the first Chinese mission on the Canadian West Coast with the opening of a consulate in Vancouver, British Columbia, this month.

title: Souvanna Phouma Returns and Finds Regime Intact
description: VIENTIANE, Laos Nov. 1Ending 10 weeks of recuperidon from a heart attack, Premier Souvanna Phouma returned today from Paris to find his coalition Government still intact and apparently durable.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: CORNELL DENIES HE HAS CONFLIC
description: Head of Delaware Port Uni Concedes Contracts Went to 2 Family Concerns

title: Haig Takes Over New Post
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Nov, 1After six years at the center of power in the White House, and a year as President Nixon's chief of staff, Gen. AlM. Haig. Jr. assumed command of United States forces in Europe today in a ceremony that his predecessor. Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster, did not attend.

title: Eye Better, Frazier Out Two Games
description: Walt Frazier removed the white patch from his swollen left eye yesterday in the bedroom of his new $100,000 nine  room condominium apartment and applied an ice pack.

title: $6Billion Plan for Harlem Is Delayed
description: The announcement of a $6.6billion redevelopment proposal for Harlem, planned for release over the last two months, has been shelved until after the election.

title: 2 GET JAIL TERMS IN MILK PAYOFFS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Two former leaders of the nation's largest dairy farmer cooperative were sentenced today to four months in prison in cases growing from massive illegal campaign payments made to gain influence with the White House and the Congress on milk price decisions.

title: People and Business
description: Ted B. Westfall, a director and executive vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, resigned yesterday. Neither he nor a spokesman for I.T.T. would say why he had taken the action, which is to take effect Dec. 31.

title: PRICES OF SUGAR ARE RAISED AGAIN
description: Sugar began a new round of wholesale price increases yesterday. In another pricing action, the Mobil Oil Corporation raised gasoline prices by 2 cents a gallon. The Amstar Corporation, the nation's largest sugar refiner, said it was increasing the wholesale price of its grocery product sugars, effective with the close of business yesterday. The new increases will raise the price of a bundle of 12 fivepound packages to $34.20 from $30.24, or 57 cents a pound, while the price of a bundle of six 10pound packages will go to $34.14 from $30.18.

title: UNEMPLOYED RATE AT 6% IN OCTOBER, HIGHEST IN 3 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Unemployment increased to 6 per cent of the work force in October, its highest level in nearly: three years, according to Labor Department figures made public today.

title: Moscow SemiSummit
description: The BrezhnevKissinger semisummit evidently was a sweetsour affair, with as many negative as positive aspects; but the overriding factor appears to have been a Kremlin conclusion that Moscow can do business with Gerald Ford.

title: AGENCIES WARNED BY MAYOR TO CURB CAPITAL SPENDING
description: Mayor Beame told city agencies yesterday that they would have less money to spend on new construction in the fiscal year that will begin next July 1 than in any of the last seven years.

title: Morton Holds Up Plan for Equalization Of Oil Prices Over Import Subsidy Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton, the new energy chief, has held up an announcement of a politically controversial oil price equalization program drafted by the Federal Energy Administration.

title: 2 STEEL EXECUTIVES SENTENCED TO PRISON
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov, 1 (UPI) A Federal judge has handed down 30day prison terms and fines totaling $7,500 to two steel company executives bn charges of violating antitrust laws in connection with the sale of reinforcing bars.

title: Women Police Officers and Their Husbands: Both Wed to the Force
description: Policemen's wives have picketed City Hall. The PaItrolmen's Benevolent Association makes no bones about its objection to cop couples on patrol when one member As male and the other female. Nobody says that jealousy has anything to do with it, hot even when one partner is a pretty blonde with a model's figure who may spend eight hours in a radio car with her male partner.

title: Soviet Said to Give U.S. Woman Exit Visa After a 30Year Wait
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 1A Brooklynborn woman in Lithuania who has been seeking to return to the United States for 30 years has informed the Amerjean Embassy here that the soviet authorities have at last granted her an exit visa.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: Thomas Milbank, 60, Dies; Bank and Rail Director
description: Thomas Fowler Milbank, industrialist and philanthropist, died Thursday at his home, apparently of a coronary attack. He was 60 years old and lived at 781 Fifth Avenue.

title: Stratospheric Spiral
description: The Government's latest set of economic indicators provides disturbing new evidence of the vicious circle created when higher living costsand the failure of either the White House or Congress to do anything effective to restrain themimpel unions to push for wage increases far in excess of productivity gains.

title: Ethnic Turks. Resettling. In Greek Area of Cyprus
description: KYRENIA, Cyprus, Nov. 1Turkish Cypriotes are resettling in large sections of Cyprus that were occupied last summer by troops from Turkey.

title: More Critics Attack Thieu
description: Continued From Page 1, Col. 2 from what lie described as the political opportunists and underground henchmen of the Communists.

title: Antiques: Witty Pennsylvania Folk Art
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa.  The repertory of symbols was not that large. And the tools and paints at their disposal were limited too. Yet, thanks to their verve and wit, amateur and itinerant artisans of 18thand 19thcentury Pennsylvania invariably managed in frakturs and furniture to produce some arresting variations on traditional themes.

title: OIL TRUST CASE AT A STANDSTILL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) Staff lawyers have told the Federal Trade Commission its major antitrust case against the nation's eight biggest oil companies is at a standstill because of complex rules resulting in a long delay.

title: Islander Success No Myth
description: It may turn out to be the best success story since the Mets in 1969.

title: ALASKAN PIPELINE NEARS $6BILLION
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 1 (AP)Inflation, escalating salaries and the soaring cost of steel have put a new price tag of $5.98billion on the transAlaska pipeline, up from the previous estimate of $4.5billion a company official said today.

title: Dance: Triumphant Duo
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The new ballet partnership with which American Ballet Theater is currently standing Washington on end would have been unthinkable 12 months ago. It brings together Gelsey Kirkland, formerly of the New York City Ballet, and Mikhail Baryshnikov, formerly of Leningrad's Kirov Ballet. Unthinkable. But Mr. Baryshnikov has defected from the Soviet Union and Miss Kirkland has defected from George Balanchine, and here they are dancing together in Washington.

title: Celtics Top 76ers, 11498, As Havlicek Scores 29
description: BOSTON, Nov. 1 (AP)The Boston Celtics moved in front of the Philadelphia 76ers in the third period on the shooting of John Havlicek and went on to a 11498 victory tonight on a National Basketball Association game.

title: Business Records
description: Chapter XI Petition for an arrangement by; TEXLON SALES CORPORATION, 1.130 Broadway, N.Y. Bertram Blechman is president.

title: Student Wounded at Kent State Says One Man Started Shooting
description: CLEVELAND Nov. 1 (UPI)A former Kent State University student who was wounded by Ohio National Guardsmen testified today that a single guardsman fired into a group of students on May 4, 1970, and within a tenth of a second a number of other guardsmen turned and fired into the crowd.

title: FirstRate Housing Opens in Harlem
description: The housing complex of four Ushaped, dark brick steppeddown buildings on the East River between 107th and 111th Streetsknown as 1199 Plaza was formally dedicated yesterday morning by Mayor Beame. The dedication ceremovies marked the completion of one of New York's most architecturally significant housing projects and also one of its most troubled. The $80million lowincome and moderateincome cooperative, which has been under construction for four years, was planned over 11 years ago, when the Ruberoid Companywhich makes building materialssponsored a design competition for lowincome housing for this Harlem site.

title: RUDOLF SIVIUTNY, BROKER, 76, DIES
description: Rudolf Smutny, a major figure in investment banking cirIdles for many yearS, died Thursday of a heart attack in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L. I. He was 76 years old and lived at 85 11th Street, Garden City, L. I.

title: Canada Bank Cuts U.S.Rate
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 1 (Reuters)  The Royal Bank of Canada said today it would reduce its United States base lending rate to 11 per cent from 12 per cent, effective Monday.

title: Florida Tests Auburn Today; Penn State Meets Maryland
description: College football's regular season enters its final month today but it may be three or four weeks before most of the leading powers will be truly tested. These will be the Ohio StateMichigan game on Nov. 23, the AlabamaAuburn game Nov. 29, the Notre DameSouthern California game Nov. 30 and the Texas A. and M.Texas game Nov. 29 among others.

title: INDIANAPOLIS RABBI, JOINING RIGHTS PANEL
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 1 (UPI) President Ford has named Rabbi Murray Saltzman of the Indianapolis Hebrew Congregation to the United States Civil Rights Commission, Representative William Hudnut, Republican of Indiana, announced today.

title: Ford Visit Fails to Cheer A Candidate for Governor
description: FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 1 When it became apparent in Los Angeles last night that President Ford would pay a hospital visit to his ailing predecessor, a campaign aide to Houston I. Flournoy, the Republican candidate for Governor, groaned and said, We can't get rid of this burden.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Jurists Gather to Honor Judge Kaufman
description: An extraordinary assemblage of eminent jurists convened in the United States Court of Appeals here yesterday to honor Chief Judge Irving R. Kaufman for a quartercentury of service on the Federal bench.

title: Amateur Athletics Fleeing Big Cities
description: In making its pitch for the 1975 national women's and girls outdoor track and field championships, the city of White Plains offered more than a $15,000 guarantee to the Amateur Athletic Union.

title: Amritraj Brothers Quit India's Tennis Cup Team
description: PARIS, Nov. 1 (Reuters)Anand and Vijay Amritraj said today they would not represent their country again, in Davis Cup competition following India's refusal to play South Africa in the 1974 final.

title: U.N., in Compromise, Asks Cyprus Troop Pullout
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1The General Assembly, in a rare show of unanimity, adopted a resolution tonight that called on the Greek and Turkish Cypriotes to negotiate a mutually acceptable political settlement.

title: S.E.C. Corrects Data Date
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today a corrected effective date for rules adopted yesterday requiring public companies to provide additional information in annual reports to stockholders. Instead of Dec. 20, 1973, as promulagated, the date is Dec, 20, 1974, for corporate issuers who have fiscal years ending on or after that date and who solicit proxies or furnish information statements on or after that date.

title: TV Ban Is tiftea On 6 N.F.L. Sellouts
description: Tickets for six National Football League games scheduled for tomorrow have been sold out and the contests will be offered for local telecasts, league spokesman said yesterday.

title: U.S. Aides in Saudi Arabia Study Sales of New Arms
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 1United States defense experts are engaged in a major review of Saudi Arabia's security needs with an eye to maintaining a dominant position in arms sales to the oil producing country.

title: Art: Monumental Lichtenstein Works
description: Some of the most sumptuous of all European paintings Were painted by Matisse befare 1914. They had as their subject matter the painter's own studio. What Matisse enjoyed was to take already existing pictures and incorporate them, entirely or in part, in a composition in which complexity was piled upon complexity.

title: SHERWIN LOSES BID FOR PRISON RELEASE
description: TRENTON, Nov. 1 (AP)Paul J. Sherwin, the former New Jersey Secretary of State, lost another round in court today when United States District Court Judge ClarksorrS. Fisher refused to free him pending decision on his appeal for a new trial in the state courts.

title: Ford Visit Fails to Cheer A Candidate for Governor
description: FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 1When it became apparent in Los Angeles last night that President Ford would pay a hospital visit to his ailing predecessor, a campaign aide to Houston I. Flournoy, the Republican candidate for Governor, groaned and said, We can't get rid of this burden.

title: Boy Killed by Cyanide Put in Halloween Candy
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 1 (UPI)The. Harirs County medical Axaminer said today that an 8yearold boy had died of cyanide poisoning from eating Halloween candy.

title: New Orders Drop 3.3%; Sharpest Fall in 2 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) New orders for manufactured products in September, led by a plunge in durable goods, suffered the sharpest drop in more than two years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Ethnic Turks Resettling In Greek Area of Cyprus
description: KYRENIA, Cyprus, Nov. 1Turkish Cypriotes are resettling in large sections of Cyprus that were occupied last summer by troops from Turkey.

title: Miss Grumbach Is Jersey Bride
description: Elizabeth Ann Grumbach, who is with the commercial lending department of the Bank of New York and Lewis Turner Jr., a member of the corporate lending department of the Bankers Trust Company, were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George J. Grumbach in West Orange, N.J. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Turner of New York and Red Bank, N.J. Judge Leo Yanoff of the Essex County Court performed the ceremony.

title: Bridge: Bidder Opening at 3Level Can Overcome the Problem
description: The advocates of weak twobids point proudly to the bidding problems created for the opponents who often have to start their bidding maneuvers at the level of threetoo high, perhaps, to make accurate judgments.

title: Art: Jose de Creeft Sculpture
description: There is something almost archetypal about the career Josee de Creeft, the American sculptor who will be observing his 90th birthday Nov. 27, but the archetype is not that of a representative modernist. He must, I suppose, be classified among the artistic conservatives, but his is an honorable and eloquent conservatismthe conservatism of a sculptor determined, above all else, to uphold the purity and integrity of the carver's art. His work thus embodies an ideal that is rapidly being lost to us under the impact of new sculptural technologies and ideologies.

title: Factions to Be Included
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 1Representative Hugh L. Carey strongly indicated today that there would be cabinetlevel posts for women and Hispanic persons if he was elected Governor next Tuesday.

title: Confident Rodino Campaigns for Others
description: NEWARK, Nov. 1The election campaign of Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., this year goes something like this:

title: Inflation Beats Cards That Greet
description: Greetings. This is to advise you that greeting cards are also not immune to inflation.

title: ACTION ON THRUWAY COULD AID THE G.O.P.
description: ALBANY, Nov. 1 (UPI)The State Thruway Authority has adopted a resolution that could minimize Republican losses in terms of political patronage in the event the Democrats take over the state government in next Tuesday's election.

title: Concert
description: The Toho School of Music in Tokyo is one of the world's foremost institutions of its special kind, and the Toho String Orchestra dramatized that fact breathtakingly at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, The 54member orchestra, an earlier model of which appeared here in 1964, is made up of advanced students, but nothing one heard at this exhilarating concert suggested anything in the least studentlike.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: One man was killed and two othrs were seriously injured when they were attacked by three gunmen in a bar in Gloucester City. The three victims were members of the Pagans, a local motorcycle gang. The police said they believed the attackers were members of a rival gang, which they would not identify.

title: Stocks Move Narrowly Ref lecting Mixed News
description: The stock market wavered indecisively yesterday throughout most of the session because of mixed news of economic developments and ended the day practically unchanged in easier trading.

title: Peyser Record Is Big Issue In Westchester Campaign
description: YONKERSTwo years ago, Representative Peter A. Peyser, a Republican, won reelection in the 23d Congressional District by a narrow margin1,400 votes out or nearly 200,000 cast. President Nixon took the same district that year by more than 40,000 votes.

title: C.A.P. Proposes Charter Plan For OneStop Package Tours
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed major changes in Federal regulations yesterday that would abolish a 20yearold concept by which most cutrate charter flights have been limited to members of clubs, unions, professional and ethnic groups and other socalled affinity groups.

description: An extraordinary assemblage of eminent jurists convened in the United States Court of Appeals here yesterday to honor Chief Judge Irving R. Kaufman for a quartercentury of service on the Federal bench.

title: U.N. PLEA PLANNED BY PALESTINIANS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 1he Palestine Liberation Organnization piens to appeal to the United Nations to help it find common grounds for a settlement with Israel, a highrankh ing source in the grouping of guerrilla movements said today. The informant, whcich is expected to be a member of the Organization's delegation when appears at the General Assembly Nov. 13, said such international help was now essential to get the Palestinians Ind Israelisoff their present collision course.

title: Tech, Van Buren Win P.S.A.L. Titles
description: Brooklyn Tech and Van Buren won Public Schools Athletic League crosscountry championships at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

title: Chess: Korchnoi Plays Quiet French When Volune Is Imperative
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 1Viktor Korchnoi fooled many onlookers here in Tchaikowsky Hall tonight by not shifting to a dynamic counterattacking Sicilian Defense, but instead relying on the French Defense for a sober draw in 42 Moves in the 18th game of his final Candidates Match for the world championship with Anatoly Karpov.

title: NIXON IMPROVING, BUT PERIL IS CITED
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 1 Former President Richard M. Nixon's doctor said today that he is slowly and steadily improving and had less pain, although he still needed critical care for complications resulting from an operation last Tuesday.

title: Amritraj Brothers Quit India's Tennis Cup Team
description: PARIS, Nov. 1 (Reuters)Anand and Vijay Amritraj said today they would not represent their country again, Davisiri Cup competition following India's refusal to play South Africa in the 1974 final.

title: Policing The New

title: Tenor Stops the Opera To Register Complaint
description: Michele Molese, a tenor with the City Opera, interrupted an ovation at the New York State Theater last night during a performance of Verdi's Un Ballo in Maschera to take a verbal swipe at a critic who had commented unfavorably on his singing.

title: Manhattan Riders Will Get Cut Fares

description: GAINESVILLE, Ga., Nov. 1 (AP)Joe Hauser, a 55yearold retired Air Force colonel, beat Rob Hoskins today and won a 45mile race for Gproduction cars. The race, opened the threeday Sports Car Club of America amateur championship runoffs.

title: It's AfricaPart Victorian and part Swedish Modern
description: BANJUL, Gambia, Oct. 30 The great drought has also touched Africa's smallest country, but like every other important current that reaches Gambia, it has done so late and marginally. With about 9,000 tons of relief grain a year for the last three years, the world has been able to tide this country of 400,000 over the worst, preventing famine and suffering.

This fall, the site of that historic event was the battleground for another sports landmark, the third anniversary of the first intercollegiate game of Ultimate Frisbee.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your Oct. 25 editorial endorsement of Senator Javits, while not unexpected, was nevertheless disappointing. After carefully reading the editorial several times, my disappointment was all the greater.

title: DAVID BOWIE SHOW GETS A RESHAPING
description: It must be said for David Bowie, who opened a fiveday run at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night, that he keeps on plugging, restlessly unwilling to rest on whatever laurels he has accrued. Last July he bought his most lavish stage production to date to Madison Square Garden for two shows. Touring almost continually ever since, he has now dropped most of the overt theatrics, written a clutch of new songs and retooled his whole show.

description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 1 Israeli army raiders blew up two homes in Blida, a village a mile inside Lebanon last night.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1974
description: In the wake of violent clashes between antiGovernment demonstrators and the police in Saigon, several Opposition leaders denounced President Nguyen Van Thieu and Mr. Thieu assailed his domestic opponents as lackeys of the Communists. Duong Van Minh, a retired general about whom sections of the Opposition are rallying, said in statement that Mr. Thieu's Government was a regime that has completely lost the confidence of the people. [Page 1, Cols. 12.1 Turkish Cypriotes are resettling in a large section of Cyprus occupied last summer by the Turkish army. One of the key questions about the future of Cyprus is whether the Greek Cypriote refugees who fled the Turkish invasion will be allowed to return to their homes. Thousands of Greekowned houses, farms and businesses have already been taken over by Turkish Cypriotes who have moved into the occupied areas. [1:12.]Metropolitan

title: UNEMPLOYED RATE AT 6% IN OCTOBER, HIGHEST IN 3 YEARS

description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov.1 (UPI) A Federal judge has handed down 30day prison terms and fines totaling $7,500 to two steel company executives on charges of violating antitrust laws in connection with the sale of reinforcing bars.

description: The Travelers Corporation, the nation's second largest stock insurance organization, reported yesterday a 39.3 per cent drop in thirdquarter income, mainly reflecting the impact of inflation on casualtyproperty claims. The net income for the quarter as a result of securities losses plunged to $16.7million from $53million a year ago.

description: WOODBRIDGE TOWNSHIP, N.J., Nov. 1The Amerada Hess Corporation began closing down today its 65,000barreladay Port Reading refinery here. As a result, nearly 90 per cent of the refinery's 262 employes will be laid off within the next 30 days, a corporate spokesman said.

title: Former Head of Police Unit Is Convicted of Tax Evasion

title: Screen: 'Open Season':A Film of Dull Sadism at Neighborhoods
description: Perhaps there are only two kinds of sadism: lively or dull. Peter Collinson's "Open Season's," which arrived yesterday at neighborhood theaters, features the phlegmatic sort and includes some of the most sluggish shootouts we've seen in ages. Three youngish war veterans indulge in a yearly ritual of kidnapping, abusing, then releasing and hunting down a random couple; one of them explains, "After you've hunted men, animals just don't rate." However, animals also get their due in this movie, when a child's wavery voice sings "All things bright and beautiful, all creatures great and small" while the veterans gun down the furred and feathered beings of the woods.The movie may be meant to strike a blow for humanity, but the message is drowned out by the laughter of the lawless trioin fact, the picture is an anthology of yuks. Cackling, giggling, whooping, gurgling, checking and howling, the old buddies appear to have harvested a sense of the ridiculous from the battlefield. Peter Fonda's talents are wasted throughout. He manages to look formidable at moments, but he mainly behaves like the jovial entertainment director at a resort camp, and he soon runs out of variations on the hahas and the o-ho-hos and the heh-heh-hehs.William Holden appears briefly in an early scene; you then spend the rest of the movie waiting for him to come back. Perhaps he was just visiting the set or taking a shortcut on his way to an appointment on the lot. A hundred minutes pass until you see his face again, although there are a few shots of his boots.Cornelia Sharpe is as bad at screaming as she is at running, and only Albert Mendozaas the male victimacts with any conviction; his bitter reserve does seem just right for the part. Without betraying the plot, it seems safe to voice the suspicion that a couple of the actors had clauses written into their contracts that permitted them to die quite slowly in close-up. Still, although "Open Season" is innocent of all suspense, it's not the very worst movie I've seen this year.

title: Film: Brian De Palma's 'Phantom of the Paradise':Rock Music Impresario Sells Soul for Youth
description: Brian De Palma's "Phantom of the Paradise" is a very busy movie.Among other things it attempts to be a put-on of "Faust," "The Phantom of the Opera," "The Picture of Dorian Gray," rock music, the rock music industry, rock music movies and horror movies.The problem is that since all of these things, with the possible exception of "Faust" (and I'm not really sure about "Faust"), already contain elements of self-parody, there isn't much that the outside parodist can do to make the parody seem funnier or more, absurd than the originals already are."Phantom of the Paradise," which opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East, is about an evil, pint-size rock music impresario named Swan (Paul Williams), who has sold his soul for eternal youth and an exclusive franchise on the soul-buying business in the music industry. It's also about an innocent young composer named Winslow Leach (William Finley), whose music is stolen by Swan and who becomes the murderous phantom of Swan's new rock palace, the Paradise, after his head gets badly mashed in a record-pressing machine.At one point or another just about everybody in the film sells his soul to Swan (with much signing of heavy, thick legal documents in blood), including a pretty rock singer (Jessica Harper), the girl the Phantom loves and cherishes from afar.Mr. De Palma is a very funny man, as he has shown in marvelously eccentric comedies such as "Greetings" and "Hi, Mom," and even in his more conventional films, "Get to Know Your Local Rabbit" and "Sisters." Compared with even the least of these, "Phantom of the Paradise" is an elaborate disaster, full of the kind of facetious humor you might find on bumper stickers and cocktail coasters.The movie spends much too much time just laying out the plot, which is fatal to parody of any sort. It also becomes quite enchanted with its own special photograpic effects, as well as with its bizarre sets, which, because there's very little of interest going on within them, become the mildly amusing surrogate subjects of the film.Almost redeeming the movie is the rock score, by Mr. Williams, and the comic orchestrations that trace the evolution of rock from the duck-tailed, surfing nineteen-fifties and sixties to the seventies and the triumphant emergence of androgyny. The concert scenes  filled with pandemonium, blinking lights and extraordinary soundsare well staged but hardly seem worth the terrific time and effort that must have been required. Almost any A.I.P. "Beach" picture or Vincent Price horror film, being the real thing, is funnier.

title: Notes on People
description: The spokesman for the State Department, John F. King, said yesterday that the letter of resignation submitted by Spiro T. Agnew, the former Vice President, was missing and that it might have been stolen. An official investigation is under way into the disappearance of the possibly purloined letter, said Mr. King, who acknowledged that it could have great value on the open market. Several Government agencies are in on the search for the letter, which was hand delivered to Secretary of State Kissinger on Oct. 10, 1973. According to Mr. King, its disappearance was noted shortly after the former President, Richard M. Nixon, submitted his own resignation letter to Mr. Kissinger last August. Embarrassed officials of the National Archives had to report then that they could not find the original of the Agnew letter, although there were plenty of copies available. It had been assumed that the original of the letter was sent from Mr. Kissinger's office to the Archives, to be a part of the historical record.

title: Parton Keese
description: I'm not a freak. I'm just another 19yearold rookie coming out of junior hockey and trying to make it in the big leagues. I need what any player needs in the N.H.L.  good coaching and playing time. What I don't need is someone pointing at me and saying; Hey, look! There's a black hockey player!  To Mike Marson of the Washington Capitals, the color of a man's skin is not a statistic. The number of goals scored, assists tallied and bodychecks dished out are. Nevertheless, when the new expansion team played its first game in the National Hockey League last Oct. 9 and the helmeted Mike Marson skated out on the Madison Square Garden ice, the fact remained: Here was only the second black to play in the 58year history of the league.

title: Citibank to Reduce Base Rate to 10%
description: The First National City Bank, New York's largest bank, announced yesterday that it would lower its prime rate on corporate loans to 10 per cent on Monday. It was the fourth quarterpoint reduction in four weeks.

title: AMAX TALKS SET AT COPPER RANGE
description: Merger talks have been scheduled next week between Amax, Inc., on of the world's largest producers of molybdenum, and the Copper Range Company, a copper mining company, it was learned yesterday. Merger In making the anNews nouncement, Copper Range, which has its headquarters in White Pine, Mich., emphasized that no decisions had been reached about either the desirability or form of such a combination.

title: Pacers Defeat Nets at Buzzer
description: UNIONDALE, Li., Nov 1The Julius and George Show ended suddenly tonight when two spear carriers on the Indiana Pacers combined for a basket at the buzzer that snapped the Nets home winning streak at 17 games in a 99.97 defeat.

title: Moms Mabley in 'Amazing Grace':The Cast
description: Moms Mabley, one of the most durable resources of American humor, is treated like a holy relic in "Amazing Grace," a comedy about an old black woman of such grit and gumption she almost single-handedly masterminds the successful campaign of a black candidate for Mayor of Baltimore.Like Moms, whose age is somewhere in the 70's, the movie sort of shambles along from one scene to another, sometimes mugging outrageously, though it never displays (or allows Mom to display) a lack of respect for anything except safe targets (blacks who deny their blackness, crooked politicians).Moms has come to triumph over the years not through the force of her wit but through her candor. When someone says that something is too highly complicated, her most likely response is, "I'll highly complicate you on the seat of your pants."It wouldn't be funny if anyone else said it, but we laugh with Moms in appreciation of her implacable, firmly unbudgeable stand in favor of common sense. The people around her never come up to her instep."Amazing Grace," which opened at three theaters yesterday, keeps Moms on screen almost constantly, but it doesn't provide her with much material. Sometimes the camera just silently follows her as she moves around her house, or walks down a sidewalk, as if hoping she'll come up with a line or a bit of business that will save the day. She doesn't, and it seems rude of the film makers to have put her in such a spot.Two black performers associated with an earlier movie ageStepin Fetchit and Butterfly McQueenturn up in cameo roles that are unrewarding, both to us and to them.

title: The Unknown Judges
description: Most of the candidates running for the Supreme and Civil Courts in New York City are unknown to the voter. Although they wear party labelssome crossendorsed by merit, others by dealsthey are supposed to be independent in judgments. Their party politics should have no bearing on judicial decisionswhich is why we continue to stress that judges should be appointed after careful prior screening by the bar and community representatives, not elected.

The singly copy on newsstands remains at 15 cents. The Knoxville NewsSentinel will raise its homedelivery price to $1 a week, with the 15cent daily newsstand price remaining the same, The Sunday edition of The NewsSentinel will go from 30 cents to 35.

title: Books of The Times
description: The world is sagging, snagging, scaling, spalling, peeling, pinging, pitting, warping, checking, fading, chipping, cracking, yellowing, leaking, staling, shrinking, and in dynamic unbalance. You don't have to be a prophet of doom to believe this: According to Donald Barthelme, all you have to do is read the Consumer Bulletin Annual. The new, synthetic world our technology has invented to take the fatigue, dangers and inconveniences out of the old one has created a wholly original series of hazards, which the Consumer Bulletin, like a medieval tract on the sins of mankind, relentlessly chronicles.

description: A dispute between the two principal agencies in public television, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Public Broadcasting Service, could threaten the fiveyear funding legislation for public broadcasting that is now before the Congress.

description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 (AP)The Cleveland Plain Dealer was truck by the Newspaper Guild this morning and cancelled its Saturday editions when workmen refused to turn on electrical power in the pressroom.

title: Canada Geese Rescued
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (UPI) An oil slick endangering several hundred Canada geese spurred an allnight rescue effort led by Mayor Frank L. Rizzo that has saved all but about three birds, an Environmental Protection Agency official said today. The oil slick, which was discovered on the Schuylkill River Wednesday, had threatened between 300 aid 500 geese a and a half dozen swills.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 18.1billion tonmiles, 1.6 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 556,224 cars 0.08 per cent below last year.

title: Czechoslovakia Five Due
description: PRAGUE, Nov, 1 (AP)The Olympic basketball team of Czechoslovakia will leave Monday for a tour of the United States, including a Nov. 9 game in Milwaukee against Marquette University. Before returning home, the Czechoslovaks will take part in a college basketball tournament Dec. 2 through 5 at stony Brook, L.I.

title: Va. Tech Falls, 147, To Miami
description: MIAMI, Nov. 1 (AP)Miami fullback Larry Bates scored on an 18yard pass in the third quarter tonight to give the Hurricanes a 147 victory over stubborn Virginia Tech.

Today, Ernest, 65 years old, is chairman of the E. & J. Gallo Winery Company, by far the nation's largest vintker and mass producer of wine. Julio, 64, is president of the familyowned business.

title: All People Are Famous
description: This book forms a promenade of memory, a stroll backward to the cultural moment when the Method signified a revolution in theatrical craft, surrealism was thumbing its nose at traditional literature, and all the arts seemed aflame with modernist excitements. In his long and distinguished career as director and critic in the American theater, Harold Clurman seems to have brushed against every major cultural figure or movement of our century. His book of memoirs, rich, vibrant and roughtextured, reads like an affectionate postscript to the history of cultural modernism.

title: The New Look in cruises Prices, Ports and Packages
description: BUFFETED by economic tides, the passenger ship business has dramatically altered course over the past decadeand more changes are in the wind. For the traveler, they add up to a major increase in the options available and the conveniences offered (and, inevitably, the price tag). The boldest innovation of all has been the construction of a $35.9million passenger ship terminal in Manhattan, which is scheduled to open Nov. 23.

title: For the Future, OneStop Banking and Shopping?
description: TRENTON  Bankers are looking to the State Legislature for permission to install electronic devices in supermarkets, department stores and other highdensity shopping areas, thus offering customers the convenience of onestop banking and shopping.

title: A Storybook

Ungerer's tone throughout this compilation is cheerful; the most scarifying scenes are underlaid with an invisible smile.

title: Though Sometimes Violated, the Rules Make It Difficult qil
description: Justice Louis M. Greenblott, one of five candidates for two Court of Appeals seats, often tells the story of his greeting at Republican headquarters in New York City last summer shortly after he was nominated. The receptionist insisted that he spell his name. When he told her he was one of two Republican candidates for the court, she wished to know in which county he was running.

title: Dolores Root Affianced to Josiah J. L. Simpson Jr.
description: The engagement of Dolores Root to Josiah J. L. Simpson Jr, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Oren Root of New York and Bedford Hills, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fiancd is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Simpson of South Salem, N.Y.

title: In theory, at least, this House race should have been a Republican runaway
description: SKOKIE, III. There is no other way to say itTuesday is going to be a disaster for the Republican party. Two years after Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, having labored mightily, carried the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and lost the other 49 states for the Democrats, his party stands to score a historic sweep. The opposition has tried everything to reverse the tide, with all of the success of King Canute. The Democrats will gain Senate seats, perhaps as many as five or six, and they will pick up at least a halfdozen governorships. A West Coast Republican says that his party ought to be declared an endangered species.

title: The Good Word: Since I Went Away
description: Taking time out to write a novelpah, what a delusion! Counting the words written during my minisabbatical from this space, I find they come to the exact same number I would have written anyway. Novels move at their own stately limp, and all the mule trainers in Missouri cannot urge them any faster.

title: Anne Ragland Is Baltimore Bride

title: Future Social Events
description: Nov. 4Al Hirschfeld, who has been described as the bearded hard of the drawing hoard, has sketched, among other things, almost every theatrical celebrity who has appeared on the horizon during his career. So it's not surprising that Helen Hayes, Lillian Gish, Carol Channing, Zero Mostel and such will be hosts at the openingnight exhibition of a 46year retrospective of Mr. Hirschfeld's works at the Margo Feiden Galleries and a preceding dinner at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The tandem event will benefit the Circle in the Square Theater. Tickets from the galleries, at 51 East 10th Street, are $25. All the works are for sale, and if you purchase one of the droll delineations of show folk, it's your privilege to stipulate that 10 per cent may go to the beneficiary. The show will continue through Dec. 7.

description: Farmingdale's offense, relatively quiet this season, erupted for 46 points in the first half yesterday as Farmingdale overwhelmed East Meadow, 526, in a Nassau Conference I game.

title: Stolen Art Worth $1Million Recovered by Italian Police
description: MILAN, Italy Nov. 2 (AP)The police recovered a $1.6million Renaissance work of are stolen last year by anarchists who apparently planned to sell it abroad to finance their activities, officials said today.

title: Mind in The Waters
description: The cohesion of the group does not allow the dislocation of arguments or grudges. There seems to be little reason to fight. There are no objects to accrue or own. There is constant sexual play, enough to allow everyone the satisfying contact with friends and mates and lovers. There is enough food.

title: At Auschwitz, a Discordant Atmosphere of Tourism
description: OSWIECIM, PolandNearly 30 yetars after Auschwitz concentration camp was closed down, the underlying horror of the place seems diminished by the souvenir stands, PepsiCola signs and the touristattraction atmosphere.

title: Connecticut's Vote
description: Democrats in Connecticut appear headed for victories in Tuesday's elections for Governor and the General Assembly. They are also expected to gain at least one seat in the United States House of Representatives. Page 73.

title: Stampless Bill Payments Will Not Be Delivered
description: Stampless Bill Payments Will Not Be Delivered mediatety against the couple, authorities said.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Elections are probably the most dangerous part of democracy. I say probably, because a very strong case can also be made for the jury system, which puts a person's fate in the hands of 12 people anxious to be shed of a nuisance in time to get home before dinner. However, I suspect elections are even worse because the fates of whole cities, states and countries are apt to be settled even more cavalierly than a defendant's hash.

title: Very Soon Now, the Army Will Be R.A. All the Way
description: WASHINGTONSometime in the next few weeks the last 2,500 draftees in the Army will be discharged, and for the first time in 34 years the United States will have an allvolunteer military force will be a historic turning point in a socialmilitary experiment that is becoming an unexpected success.

title: Kathleen Guck To Be a Bride
description: Kathleen Anne Guck, director of special activities at Briarcliff College, will be married next June to Eben Putnam Smith, a financial analyst with the Charter New York Corporation. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Guck's parents, Dr. and Mrs. John Kelly Guck of Forest Hills, Queens, and Quogue, L. I. Mr. Smith's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Everett Smith Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The most challenging game in town these days is called value and it's getting more and more difficult to win. But not impossible.

title: L. I. School Stresses Free Choice
description: WESTBURYChildren do whatever they want to do at the Learning Tree free school here. Some days they do arithmetic and other days they work in the school vegetable garden.

title: Planners to Discuss Bypass
description: HAUPPAUGE  The proposed Sunrise Highway Extension is to face its first county test Wednesday when the Suffolk Planning Commission meets to discuss the controversial road.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: LAB PLANS STUDIES OF WILDLIFE DISEASE
description: MADISON, Wis., Nov. 2A health research laboratory designed to prevent and reduce comunicable disease among the nation's wildlife will be opened by the end of the year at the University of Wisconsin, the Fish and Wildlife Service has announced.

title: Amy Louise Altenhaus Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. Julian Altenhaus and Dr. Corrinne Altonhaus of Maplewood, N. J., Monmouth Beach, N.J., and North Miami Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Amy Louise Altenhaus, to Jonathan S. Kleinman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton L. Kleinman of New Brunswick, N. J., and Woodstock, N. Y.

title: Fulbright Calls Israeli Withdrawal Key to Peace
description: FULTON, Mo., Nov. 2Senator J. W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that solving the Middle East problem was the key to surmounting the world's economic and political crisis.

title: R. J. Fahey to Wed Susan Murphy
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lester V. Murphy Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Christiansted, St. Croix, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Catherine Murphy, to Richard James Fahey, son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Fahey of Andover and Scituate, Mass. The wedding is planned for August.

title: MINE TALKS REACH A CRUCIAL STAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2In,. tan atmosphere of gathering pessimism, negotiators for the coal'. industry and the miners union labored haltingly over the Weekend to avert a potentially disruptive strike.

title: G.O.P. Held Endangered
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) Mayor Jack Hunter of Youngstown. Ohio, has asked Represen tative Charles Carney to snonsor a bill in the House to add Republicans to the list of endangered species and to make it a crime to turn them out of office. Without agreeing to the Republican Mayor's plan Representative Carney a Democrat, said in a statement The Mayor's comments were made in jest but I can understand his feelings.

title: Women make good cops
description: It was a muggy summer night in the highcrime Washington, D. C., area known as the strip. On the corner of 14th and L Streets, a man built like a construction worker stood spreadeagled with his arms stretched out, touching the roof of his car. Oh, my God, he repeated over and over. Behind him stood a young blond woman half his size, pretty and freshfaced enough to pose for a shampoo ad. She held a .38 Smith and Wesson pointed at the man's back. With her free hand, she pulled a twoway radio from a pocket of her limegreen pants suit, gave her location and asked for transport.

title: UConn Upsets Rutgers, 9 to 7
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 2  Connecticut upset Rutgers, 9.7, on three field goals by Greg Sinay today before 12,500 spectators.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The Commerce Department's monthly compilation of leading economic indicators  a selected group of statistics that are supposed to foretell the futureis finally indicating that a recession is coming. The indicators declined in August, and last Tuesday the news was flashed across the nation that in September they took their sharpest drop in 25 years.

title: Amherst College to Admit Womenin'75
description: AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 2The Amherst college Board of Trustees voted today to make the college coeducational.

title: Lynn Marcucci Fiancee of M.D. Keeshan
description: Lynn Oberist Marcucci, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Marcucci of Amsterdam, N. Y., and Michael Derek Keeshan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Keeshan of Babylon, L. I., plan to be married on June 14. Their engagement has been an flounced by the parents of the prospective bride.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Peter Edelman's review of Serving Justice (Oct. 6) contains a serious error. An in forma pauperis petition to the Supreme Court is automatically denied unless at least one Justice asks that it be placed on the weekly conference list for discussion. But, contrary to Mr. Edelman's suggestion, precisely the same procedure is followed with respect to paid petitioners.

title: Concordia Defeats Manhattan, 29 to 12
description: Tom Shedrick rushed for 169 yards yesterday in leading Concordia College of Bronxville to a 2912 victory over Manhattan at Gaelic Park in the Bronx.

title: Menu suggestions
description: Menu suggestions

title: BROOKLYN UNION OPENS GAS PLANT
description: Customers of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company in Brooklyn and Queens and on Staten Island who use gas for cooking and in some cases for water heating, space heating or commercial use got reassurance last week that despite natural gas cutbacks the fuel will be available to them this winter, although at somewhat higher cost.

title: PALESTINIAN SAYS ARABS MUST GIRD FOR ANOTHER WAR
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 2The information chief of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today that the primary duty of the Arab countries was to ready themselves milltariily and economically to face new war that he said Israel was preparing.

title: Holy Family Wins 11th Straight, 2613
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Nov. 2Holy Family won its 11th straight game, the fifth this year, by defeating Berner today, 2613. Holy Family has won 24 of its last 25 games.

title: Milltown Borough Council Races: A Little Bit of Everything
description: MILLTOWN  This 1.6squaremile borough is offering its voters a little bit of everything on Tuesday: two teenage Republican candidates who are substitutes for their fathers, a 70yearold Independent who does not care if he wins, a second Independent who does and two Democrats who will have knocked on the door of every one of the borough's 2,000 homes.

title: Two Norwalk Stations Sold
description: NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 2The purchase of Norwalk's two radio stations, WNLK and WDRNFM, by Michael F. Ilanison of Greenwich was announced today by Fred Grossman, president of the Norwalk Broadcasting Corporation. The sale, said to be for an excess of $700,000, is contingent upon approval of the Federal Communications Commission, which is expected to take several months, The operation will conitnue under its present management for now.

title: Two Groups Clash On Queens Street; Man Fatally Hurt
description: A young man died yesterday of injuries suffered Friday night when he was thrown through the plate glass door of a diner in Hollis, Queens in the aftermath of a fight that pitted three young men against another three.

title: Concert: Maureen forrester at Hunter
description: Color, Tonal Richness Show in Her Songs

title: Amherst Triumphs Over Tufts, 3110
description: Amherst defeated Tufts, 3110, today on the strength of two touchdowns by a sophomore tailback, Jeff Hogan, who gained 115 yards and scored on runs of 5 and 1 yards.

title: World News Briefs
description: TOKYO, Nov. 3 (AP)George Bush, the new chief of the United States liaison office in China, met with Deputy Premier Teng Hsiaoping in Peking today, a Chinese broadcast said.

title: What Horse Racing needs is a Good World Championship Race
description: Too bad about masquerades. They work for a while, but eventually you leok underneath and a wolf is there in stead of Little Red Riding Hood's grandmother.

title: W. BRAUNSCHWEIGER
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (UPI) Walter Braunschweiger, who was one of the founders of the Bank of America, died yesterday in a nursing home at the age of 80.

title: Byrne Joins Dispute Over a TV Outlet
description: WASHINGTON  Governor Byrne has asked the Federal communications Commission to hold hearings and thus determine the possibility of New Jersey getting a commercial television outlet.

title: New York and New Jersey Have Bickered for 150 Years
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the powerful offspring of the two states, is embroiled in controversy with officials in New Jersey. That is not the cause of concern it might seem; the Authority was born out of interstate bickering and appears at times to thrive on it.

title: PIONEER TO REACH JUPITER IN MONTH
description: REDONDO BEACH. Calif Nov. 2 (AP)The Pioneer 11 spacecraft is headed toward a rendezvous Dec. 2 that will take it deep within the deadly radiation belts that surround Jupiter.

title: Three faces of Harlem
description: When fall comes I often walk through the streets of Harlem to see if, with the summer's green giving way to browns and yellows among Harlem's few trees, I can smell change in the air. I go to Harlem with hope muted in my chest and with unblinking eyes, and I find that although I pass from the noisome corners of 116th Street and 8th Avenue to the sanitary complex of the Esplanade Gardens at 145th Street and Lenox Avenue, nostalgia usually guides my feet so that I end up at the corner of 128th Street between Seventh and Lenox Avenues. For it was there that I first saw Harlem some 12 years ago, when fresh to New York, I had to celiver a package of herbs to the ailing cousin of a friend. It was on this block, then, that I first noticed the old men's faces wreathed in sullen despair and the young men's eyes angling like quicksilver through their hardened faces.

title: Georgetown Rolls Over Fordham
description: John Burke scored three touchdowns in the first half as Georgetown defeated Fordham, 357, to spoil the Rams Homecoming Day game yesterday at Jack Coffey Field.

title: DR. ERNEST MUIR
description: LONDON, Nov. 2 (Reuters)Dr, Ernest Muir, an authority on leprosy, has died at his London home at the age of 94, it was announced today.

title: Pilgrim's Progress
description: How many thanks do we give for books about Thanksgiving, especially when they are as curiously varied as these? If people thanked Louisa May Alcott one hundred years ago for her account of a New Hampshire farm dinner in AN OLD FASHIONED THANKSGIVING (Lippincott, $4.95) with its ingredients coming from the fields outside the kitchen, can we find a similar feeling for a dinner prepared by Charles Schulz's comic strip characters today?

title: Court Bars Picketing at School by Milwaukee Nazis
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 2  A sudden increase in activity by a Nazi party unit here has resulted in a police investigation and a courtimposed restriction on the party's recruitment at local high schools.

title: Ford's First 3 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  Looking hack over his first three months in the White House, President Ford must be aware that the vast majority of his fellow countrymen wish him well and yet are deeply worried about the economic condition of the nation and vaguely disappointed in his approach to their problems.

title: Soviet is Building 30 Containerships, U.S. Group Reports
description: The Soviet Union is about to enter international container shipping on a large scale.

title: Galleries at College Campuses Throughout State Offering a Potpourri of Exhibits
description: Art on the campuses of New Jersey's colleges and universities is thriving this season, with a variety of exhibitions on view. Some are in galleries especially set up by the colleges, but many are in libraries and student centers, which are open to the public all day long and late into the evenings.

title: Joel Spielfogel Weds Roni Ann Wasserman
description: The marriage of Roni Ann Wasserman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Wasserman of Island Park, L. I., to Joel Spielfogel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Spielfogel of West Hempstead, L. I., took place yesterday afternoon at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L. I. Rabbi Abraham Moseson performed the ceremony.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The New York Knickerbockers and the New York Nets begin long road trips this week. The Nets play the San Antonio Spurs at 2:15 P.M. today at the Nassau Coliseum, then embark on twoweek tour against seven American Basketball Association rivals. The Knicks play three National Basketball Association foes on the road this week, with all games to be televised here.

title: Prosecutors Voicing Optimism
description: NEWARK  The prosecutors of the state's three most heavily populated counties reported last week that, despite massive anticrime campaigns in recent years, narcotics use and the influence of organized crime are still their biggest problems.

title: 5 British Isles' National Teams Impressive in Soccer Shutouts
description: It all happened last Wednesday. England defeated Czechoslovakia, Wales beat Hungary, Scotland downed East Germany, Northern Ireland blanked Sweden and the Republic of Ireland beat the Soviet Union. It was a total triumph for all national teams on the British Isles as the victories came by impressive shutouts.

title: Blubber
description: Judy Blume's considerable gifts of humor, readability and child appeal mask her other vocation as a teller of moral tales. In Iggy's House, Then Again Maybe I Won't and now in Blubber she has dealt with questions of prejudice, conformity and cruelty. Although her heroes and heroines are never surrounded by a heavenly light, her bad guys and bad girls tend to be Oldfashioned villains in that they are evil to the core.

title: ART VIEW
description: Once upon a time the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh was the American museum that European artists most longed to know about, to talk about, and eventually to hear from. It owed this preeminence to the Carnegie International, which was founded in 1896 and was for many years an invaluable conduit for whatever was being done in the way of new art all over the world. Americans could go to Pittsburgh once a year and find out just what was cooking. Sometimes they bought, sometimes they didn't; but at least they knew that, as Shakespeare's Antony said in quite other circumstances, there is a world elsewhere.

title: Economist, Poll Thy People
description: By the criterion most beloved by the economics profession, economists have not failed. On the contrary, we are a glorious success. The criterion I am referring to, of course is, success in the marketplace.

title: Riverdale Tops Hackley, 2720, as Greene Stars
description: Bob Greene, one of the bright spots of the season for Riverdale, posted another as the Bronx eleven downed Hackley, 2720, on the winsolid performance yesterday ner's field.

title: Air Force, Naval Academies Are Urged to Admit Women
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI)  The United States Court of Appeals has been asked to order the Air Force and Naval Academies to admit women.

title: New Jersey
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, South Munn and Central Avenues, East OrangeHamlet. Thursday, Friday and Saturday at 8:30 P.M. and again Nov. 1416. $3.50 to $3.90 (Thursday and Friday); $4.50 to $4.90 (Saturdays). Reduced rates for students and the elderly. (201) 6751881.

title: CONFEREES WRGH MUSEUMS CRISIS
description: HARRIMAN, N. Y., Nov. 2Resisting the outdoor seductions of warm fall weather, some 60 conferees have holed up here in a spectacular ivory tower to consider the crisisridden state of art museums.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: Dome. House Hovers Above L.I. Treetops
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.When Robert Skinner decided to build his dream house he was less interested in setting trends than in finding a plan that would give him space on a tight budget. He accomplished both by erecting the first residential geodesic dome on Long Island's south fork.

title: What's Doing in SARASOTA
description: What's Doing in SARASOTA

title: Note: A Moveable Feast of Passports
description: FOR almost 40 years, hundreds of thousands of tourists have passed through that drafty, cavernous limbo of lost souls known as the New York passport office in Rockefeller Center, renowned not so much for the 325,000 passport applications it processes annually but for the interminable lines.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Photography's phenomenon of the Seventies, the photographic gallery has in just a few years, spread across the country and can now be found in all sizes, degrees of activity and levels of prestige in the cities of at least 35 states. Although the greatest concentration of show places is in New York State and California, established galleries are also located in such cities as Boston, Cambridge, Chicago, and Washington, D.C. As a result, the photography gallery, once regarded as animpossible dream (what collector would buy photographs when all the world's a photographer?), has become not only firmly established in the United States but has even migrated abroadto England, France, Japan, Italy.

title: Paper Strike in Cleveland Halts Publication a 2d Day
description: CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 2 (AP)A strike by the Cleveland Newspaper Guild halted publication of the Cleveland Plain Dealer for the second day, leaving half a million persons without their Sunclay news and sports sections.

title: Meredith Is Urging Writein Votes in Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 2James H. Meredith, accused earlier in the week by a Federal court of seeking to abuse the state election system, was urging voters today to write in his name for Congress in Tuesdays election.

title: Election in Suffolk Called Critical
description: BLUE POINTBoth Democratic and Republican political leaders in Suffolk profess optimism about the results of Tuesday's election, but they also say that even In this traditional G.O.P. stronghold it is a better year than usual to be a Democrat.

title: Shirley Steere Is Wed to John M. Hudson in Dallas
description: Shirley Duffield Steere and John Morgan Hudson were married yesterday afternoon in Perkins Chapel at Southern Methodist University in Dallas by the Rev. A. A. Taliaferro, an Episcopal priest.

title: Marketing Institute Slated on Thursday
description: JAMESBURG  The 1974 New Jersey Marketing Institute will be held Thursday at Forsgate Country Club.

title: City Orders Change in Menu
description: TULSA, Okla., Nov. 2 (UPI)An elderly couple will have to find a new source of meat for their dinner table. The City Commission ruled yesterday that Albert Sandridge, 74 years old, and his wife, Martha, 73, can no longer raise and butcher their own rabbits. A 60day period was allowed for the couple to raise and slaughter the 12 rabbits already in their hutch. A 11173 ordinance prohibits the raising of any domestic food animals in residentially zoned areas.

title: Elizabeth Woo And Aubrey Li Plan Nuptials
description: Elizabeth Elay Woo, an assistant designer with Hang Up Sportswear., Ltd., here, and Aubrey Kwoksing Li, an assistant manager with the international banking division of the chemical Bank, plan to be married in April.

title: Bulls, Paced By Walker, Top Knicks
description: Chet Walker, who deals in real estate, dabbles in politics and is always talking about retirement, and Bill Hewitt, an insurance salesman last season, led the Chicago Bulls to a 9590 victory over the Knicks at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Deaths
description: ADLERGertrude, beloved wife of Seymour. Devoted daughter of Fannic, Loving sister of Julius. Services Forest Park Chapels, Queens Blvd., and 76th Rd. Forest Hills, Sunday, November 3 at 2:30 P. M.

title: The bachelor candidate, flower in buttonhole, used to buss the girls and make them squeal
description: OTTAWAOn a bitingly cold February day in 1971 about 100 truck drivers, protesting their dismissal over a postoffice dispute, marched on Parliament Hill and accosted Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau in his black limousine. They jeered and shouted insults at him, and he retaliated by thumbing his nose, lowering the window and calling out: Mangez de la. The literal translation is somewhat stronger than the phrase's relatively benign meaning: Kiss my behind. Nonetheless, it was hardly the language or conduct the urbane head of a reasonably conventional country is supposed to engage in. But since no one at that time expected orthodox deportment from Trudeau, the incident passed with the barest of mention in the press.

title: PRESIDENT NAMES 10 TO ADVISORY PANELS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) President Ford has appointed 10 persons to advisory panels dealing with the education of disadvantaged children and with the teaching professions.

title: 20 Nations Begin Meeting Tuesday on World Food Problems
description: On Tuesday, an American delegation will sit down in Rome withepresentatives of more than 120 other countries to see whether global cooperation on food problems can be achieved, and what the other delegates will want to know as much as anything else is what the Americans have in mind.

title: YALE LAWSCHOOL MARKS 150 YEARS
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 2There are two types of closed institutions, Judge David L. Bazelon said at a seminar at Yale School yesterday. You must distinguish, he said, between institutions that are hard to get into and those that are hard to get out of.

title: Middletown Trounced By Brick Township
description: Brick Township clinched at least a tie for the Shore Conference A Division championship yesterday with a 357 victory over Middletown in Brick.

title: Crowded Union City Glum on Change
description: UNION CITYThe marginal highway that leads to the Lincoln Tunnel divides this city of 58,600 in a way that seems to establish a sharp difference between a heavily commercial cornThe Talk munity and one that is struggling of for an identity. Union City On both sides of the road, however, Union City is crowded, with little open space, practically no greenery and houses that touch each other. Parking is a major problem for the homeowner, the shopper and the visitor.

title: Data Bank Planned on Breast Cancer
description: TRENTON  Area physicians will soon have a computerized data bank from which to draw information on breast cancer and treatment. The bank will be situated at the Fox Chase Cancer Center in Philadelphia, which also includes the Institute for Cancer Research and the American Oncologic Hospital.
