title: The Objective Is Not to Let It Become a Communist State
description: WASHINGTON  From the beginning of American involvement in Vietnam, It has not been geographical abstraction and not a people and a culture to most American leaders. And, even as the awareness of the war fades, Vietnam remains a landscapeor rather, an objective, It must not be taken over by the Communists.

title: Homosexuality in Dance
description: Statistically speaking, I don't know whether there is more homosexuality in dance than in any other part of the theater, or, for that matter, the Navy or the Government, but I would be mildly surprised if there were any less. At one time, ballet was tagged as the pansies ball game, and there seemed to be a disproportionately large homosexual element in dance, especially moderndance, partly because of the emphasis on male physical beauty and partly because dancing had a reputation for being one of those professions where the homosexual could feel at home.

title: Carey's Shadow Clouds Future of the City Council's HighestRanking Republican
description: I've been in this business 20 years, and if there's one thing I've learned, it's to always run scared.

title: THREE HOSPITALS ARE FINED BY CITY
description: The City Health Department, has assessed three leading nom profit, voluntary hospitals a total of $135,000 for failing to comply with the standards of care set forth under the Ghetto Medicine Program, according to the Health Commissioner, Dr. Lowell E. Bellin.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: ATLANTAEvery week thousands of readers of blackowned newspapers are provided with a view of business and economics from a special perspective in a column by Berkeley Graham Burrell, owner of a small dry cleaning operation in Washingtonand president of the National Business League, the major trade association of black businesses in the United States.

title: Javits and Clark Offer Voters a Study in Contrasts: A Pragmatic Sancho vs. the Idealistic Don Quixote
description: For 28 straight years in elective office, the last 18 in the Senate, Jacob K. Javits, a liberal Republican walking on tiptoe between his party's dominant conservative wing and the state's Democratic majority, has mastered what he calls the politics of conciliation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 21yearold man was found guilty in Newark yesterday of stabbing five persons to death on July 5, 1973, in what officials there described as the most brutal killings in the history of that city. A Superior Court jury returned the verdict Friday night in the case of James L. Lipscombe Jr. of Newark after weighing evidence for nearly six hours at the end of a fiveday trial.

title: Black Officer of Auto Union Is Killed in a Detroit Shooting
description: DETROIT, Nov. 2 (UPI)The first black, vice president Iof the United Automobile workers union was fatally shot today when he tried to break up an argument at a West Side Detroit bar.

title: Make Room for The Loom Boom
description: Mahatma Gandhi tried to make India a nation of weavers by setting a personal example of conspicuously weaving in public on state occasions. Americans may be on their way to becoming nation of weavers too, even without any such exardple from Washington.

title: Oklahoma Takes 7th By 2810
description: AMES, Iowa, Nov. 2 (AP)Joe Washington scored one touchdown and set up another today, leading Oklahoma to a 2810 victory over Iowa State in a. Big Eight Conference game.

title: Record Collecting: A Fine Madness
description: A $750,000 stamp collection can fit into a desk drawer if the collector has taken pains to pick rarities. A comparably valued record hoard is more likely to consume considerably more space  in fact, it can easily pose a constant buckling threat to both floors of a large brownstone duplex.

title: Return of Ron Johnson Buoys Giants for Chiefs
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 2Assuming that they have nowhere to go but up, the New York Giants will begin what amounts to their third season tomorrow at 4 P.M. (E.S.T.) against the Kansas City Chiefs at Arrowhead Stadium (Channel 2; Radio, WNEW).

title: Aaron to Milwaukee
description: Henry Aaron, baseball's career home run champion, was traded yesterday by the Atlanta Braves to the Milwaukee Brewers, Details, Section 5.

title: Melissa Jane Naul Is Engaged To Prof. Garry Evans Clarke
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Marshall Naul of Granville, Ohio have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melissa Jane Naul, to Garry Evans Clarke of Chestertown, Md. He is a son of Mrs. Clarence Henderson Clarke of Milan, Ill., and the late Mr. Clarke. A late spring wedding in Chestertown is planned.

title: SOCIALISTS PLAN FOR MARKET TALKS
description: THE HAGUE, Nov. 2Socialist party leaders from eight European Common Market countries agreed, after a twoday meeting that ended here today, that the twin problems of unemployment and inflation should be the main topics at a planned conference in December of heads of government of the Community.

title: END OF BRITISH USE OF NAVAL BASE SEEN
description: LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP)The Labor Government of Prime Minister Harold Wilson, which is publicly opposed to the racial policies of South Africa, plans to scrap Britain's naval agreement with at country early next year, wellplaced Government sources reported today.

title: A Greenhorn's Tour of French Guiana's Green Hell
description: IT was a typical morning at Elhae. Peering out from, my plaid hammock under the magnificent thatched dome of the Oyana Indian guesthouse, I saw a barebreasted maiden in red loincloth with matching red elastic garters, her body tinted red with vegetable dye, stoking the breakfast campfire. Meanwhile, one of the boatmen shot a green parrot for his lunch. A 79yearold French captain of industry was jogging over the beaten earth of the island village's main street. Merenge was intoning his morning prayer to Massa Gadu in melodious, Englishflecked Takitaki. Stomach growling from the previous evening's peccary stew, I charged into the jungle, grabbing a banana leaf in lieu of toilet paper. I took one step into the forest, tripped on a liana, but I did not fall. The dense wall of undergrowth smacked me in the face and held me upright had I realized, just confronted the fabled Green Hell of French Guiana.

title: Kudu Gets Stiffest Test In Race Off Key West
description: The Key West offshore power boat race, a 190mile venture in Florida waters next Saturday, will serve as an interesting test for a remarkable new boat, a power catamaran called Kudu. Kudu is the product of a California industrialist named Paul Cook who has put about half a million dollars into this swift toy, which could make a significant mark on the future of recreational boating.

title: James Tuite So Much For Loyalty
description: Sports of The Times Alan N. Cohen is a quiet, unassuming man with a, shy smile who looks, more like the friendly corner grocer than legalistic genius who runs Madison Square Garden and its racetrack interests. He is the complete opposite of Mike Burke, sharp of visage and shaggy of hair, the resident manager of Mr.

title: Where the Sidewalk Ends
description: One of the things that annoys me is the way publishers have of labeling children's books with age categories: 4 to 6, 8 to 14, that sort of thing. Here's a volume of verse for children labeled all ages. It's either the ultimate in silliness or the ultimate in good sense. Quite possibly the latter.

title: Marilyn Cannon Nicholls a Bride
description: Marilyn Cannon Nicholls and Thoburn Milar Stamm Jr., both of New York, were married yesterday afternoon in the BethesdabytheSea Episcopal Church in Palm Beach, Fla., by the Rev. Dr. Hunsdon Cary Jr., the rector.

title: RecessioncumInflation
description: With each succeeding week, it has become increasingly clear that the American economy is in a recession, as Chairman Arthur Burns of the Federal Reserve and President Ford's top economic advisers now concede. The real output of the economy has fallen for three quarters in a row, and is 3 per cent below its rate the final quarter of 1973; the number of jobless workers has risen from 4.1 million a year ago to over 5.5 million now. Many private economists fear that this recession could become the longest and most severe of the postWorld War II period.

title: President Back in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) President Ford flew hack to Washington tonight and arrived at the White House about 1 A.M.

title: Child of Fire
description: This novel is strong, spicy picadillo for a 12yearold. It brims with violence as well as cruelty, usually involving animals. It also focuses so narrowly on a few minor and unfortunate aspects of Chicano culture that would be an exceptionally poor introduction for young readers to that large, vivid ethnic group.

title: Curser of Police Takes Fall
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (Reuters)Awakened by police sirens, John Smith, 30 year old, leaned out a sixthfloor window in a hotel here to curse at the police, felland lived. The police who picked him up after the 50feet drop Tuesday said Mr. Smith swore at them all the way to the hospital.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: Nat'l Football League

title: Costs Driving Luxury Buildings Into Default
description: Some of the city's largest and bestmaintained middleincome and upperincome apartment projects, caught between soaring energy costs on the one hand and tight rent restrictions on the other, are moving into default and foreclosure.

title: Molloy, Farrell Win Title Runs
description: Archbishop Molloy and Monsignor Farrell won championships yesterday in Catholic High Schools Athletic Association sectional crosscountry competion at Van Cohtlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Naomi in The Middle
description: Norma Klein's latest book is short, realistic and disappointing. A slight story about a family waiting for the birth of a third child, it has the requisite active little girls with their active mother (a soprano) and their active grandmother (a tennis player who wears shocking pink). The prepre pubescent girls talk about penises and vaginas and imaginary friends and boyswholike dollstoo. The dialogue is short and snappy. Mrs. Klein's ear for the conversations of today's child is accurate, and she has a penchant for the comic scene.

title: Choate Remains Unbeaten With 73 Victory
description: Choate Remains Unbeaten With 73 Victory

title: Mood of the Electorate: Anger Plus Frustration and Pessimism
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2It has been a curious campaign, The voters who will be going to the polls across the nation on Tuesday have been telling politicians and reporters and pulsetakers for weeks that they are angryabout high prices, about Watergate, about the Presidential pardon, about the loss of their jobs. Senator Walter F. Mondale, a Minnesota Democrat who has been traveling around the country on behalf of his party, says that he has never heard as much resentment and frustration.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Donald Georgen's succinct article concerning the switch from FIFO or average cost to LIFO for inventory valuation was most insightTar (Inflation, a Time to Think of Switching to LIFO Oct. 13).

title: By Rail in Mexico: Chihuahua to the Sea
description: A SLEEK silvertmed observation car, which opened up vistas for travelers on the Missouri Pacific Railroad between St. Louis and Denver a generation ago, is now doing the same for tourists in Mexico's Sierra Madre Mountains. The car is running on the tracks of the Ferrocarril Chihuahua al Pacifico, a railroad that is a marvel of engineering skill and passes through some of the most awesome scenery in the world.

title: Exacta Pays $4,158
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 2 (UPI)Churchill Downs paid a track record of $4,158.60 for $2 on an exacta today when Dramatic Lady won the fifth race and Chips and Petals finished second, The previous record exacta was $2,676.20. Dramatic Lady paid $53.40 to win and Chips and Petals was $41.40 to place.

title: Headliners
description: The Rev. John J. Tirella, who for ten years has been aiding Greenwich Village addicts and exaddicts, has been charged in a Federal indictment with helping seven prisoners, described as international narcotics figures, escape from the Federal House of Detention in Manhattan.

title: Television This Week
description: 11:00 A.M. (2) CAMERA THREE. A Video Event with Merce Cunningham and Dance Company. A look at the company in rehearsal.

title: Delay Urged on Coney Island Housing
description: Coney Island public officials and communitygroup leaders called on the city last week to postpone action on starting the proposed Polar Gate Gardens lowrise housing development next to the Seagate community.

title: Youth, 12, Serves Notice to Older Handlers As She Shows the Best Dog at Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto RicoYouth is the thing on Puerto Rico. Ponce de Leon, the first governor, would have smiled his approval had he been at Fort Buchanan last Sunday.

title: ZAPPA IN GOOD FORM AT THE FELT FORUM
description: Frank Zappa is celebrating his 10th aniversary in the rock business this year, and the quality of the second of two shows he offered Thursday night at the Felt Forum should keep him on the scene for another decade.

title: The. Region
description: What New York Thinks

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Kings Point Routs Hofstra by 350
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. L, Nov. 2  Kings Point routed, Hofstra, 35.0, today in the final home football game for the losers coach, Howdy Myers.

title: Rapid Transit Suicide
description: BERKELEY, Calif. Nov. 2 (UPI)A man jumped in front of a Bay Area Rapid Transit train yesterday and became the first suicide in the twoyear history of the rail system. The victim was identified as Stephen Zelonis, 24 years old, of Berkeley.

title: view.
description: A 3yearold girl left alone at home by her parents plunged to her death last night from 17thstory window of an apartmerit house in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, the police reported.

title: Brown Rally Edges Princeton, 1713
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 2 Whatever Coach John Anderson told the Brown football team in the locker room at halftime today, it worked wonders.

title: Nursing Program at Medgar Evers College Is Given Full Accreditation
description: The nursing program of the health sciences division of Medgar Evers College of Brooklyn has received full accreditation by the State Department of Education and the National League of Nursing.

title: Fish Combats Mosquitoes
description: A tiny, voracious fish that reproduces phenomenally is being used successfully on Long Island as a substitute for pesticides in the control of mosquitoes.

title: VOTERS ARE WARNED ON 11 THHOUR ISSUES
description: VOTERS ARE WARNED ON 11 THHOUR ISSUES

title: Pro Transactions
description: HOCKEY

title: TV VIEW JOHN J. O'CONNOR
description: I ike some festering sore, the issue of violence on television is given serious examination at monotonously regular intervals. The experts are summoned, the evidence is considered, the conflicting opinions are delivered, and all is forgotten until the next crisis of inflammation. This pattern has served the financial structure of television well. The programing status quo is threatened only briefly, continuing undisturbed after little more than minor adjustments and touchingly sincere promises.

title: Food
description: The London of the Edwardian era, a city of dramatically mysterious peasoupers and romantic guttering gaslight, was the stage for intrigues the like of which the world had never seen. Its fascination still exerts its pull  particularly on those television viewers on both sides of the Atlantic who follow the adventures of the aristocratic Bellamy family and the domestic staff that ran (and occasionally ruled) the quintessential Edwardian household depicted in Upstairs, Downstairs.

title: M.D. Mann Fiance Of Meryl J. Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Spring have made known the engagement of their (laughAar, Meryl Jane Spring, to Michael David Mann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Mann of Hewlett, L.I., and North Miami Beach, Fla. The wedding is planned for May.

title: A family haunted by death
description: This subtle and ingeniously conceived novel, Frederick Busch's second (the first is I Wanted a Year Without Fall), begins: After I died they moved from Massachusetts and they bought a house and acres of land in New Hampshire where they rose early and worked all day at projects with their hands. You forget with your hands, my tall blond father said. The voice is that of a dead child, a notyetborn child, lost in the ninth month of the mother's pregnancy. Two other voices join his, two ghostly beings not quite dead and yet not released from the death of the childthe mother and the father, Anne and Phil Sorenson. The novel is presented in stark, chilling detail by these three separate voices, and though it is for the most part a meditative, poetic achievement, there are moments when Busch accumulates such tension that the reading of it is almost painful. An extraordinarily powerful work, guided by the voice of the dead baby, who speaks of himself as the voice of romance.

title: GENTLE GIANT ROCKY TOWARD TOP BILLING,
description: Gentle Giant is a British progressive rock band that has been around a while, and even made two previous American tours, opening for other acts. It won something of a cult following before, and is still, opening for other bands on its current tourprecedinr, Focus Friday night at the Academy of Music. But with the rapturous responses Gentle Giant is getting thes days it will probably be headlining very soon.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Book on Johnson Published
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 2 (UPI) Lady Bird Johnson received! this week the first copy of a limited edition book, on sale for $100, on the life of her husband, the late President Lyndon B. Johnson. The book, 37 Years of Public Service, is encased in polished central Texas cedar, strapped with Texas mesquite and branded with the initials LBJ. The book, by Joe P. Frantz, a University of Texas history professor, was published by Shoal Creek Publishers, Inc.

title: Swiss Tycoons: The Secret Rich
description: Swiss Tycoons: The Secret Rich

title: Alfred Vanquishes Rochester Tech
description: ALFRED, N. Y., Nov. 2Alfred Newton, a sophomore from Utica, N. Y., intercepted five passes for a school record today as the Alfred Saxons defeated Rochester Tech, 350. Tim O'Neil, also a sophomore, ran 7 yards and 22 yards for two touchdowns.

title: New Orleans Chimney Sweep Dies, and So Does an Era
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 2The last of the chimney sweeps who used to walk neighborhood streets looking for work atop old New Orleans houses was buried today. Perry Tillman, 71 years old, had worked cleaning and repairing chimneys until January of this year, when heart ailment prevented him from climbing any more roofs.

title: MacDonald's 200 Yards Sparks So. Clarkstown
description: Rockland County's leading ground gainer, Billy McDonald, paced the No. 1 team in Rockland County, Clarkstown South, to a 340 rout over Nanuet yesterday.

title: Natural Dyes from Plants
description: After a century of neglect, the ancient craft of nature dyeing is enjoying brisk revival at the hands of a small but determined group of adherents.

title: STAGE VIEW WALTER KERR
description: E quus is all risk. Consider the simplest, but in a way boldest, risk that director John Dexter has taken in mounting Peter Shaffer's stunning play as though it were simultaneously a laboratory dissection in an operating theater and a savagely bloody contest in a bullring. At the Plymouthas at the British National Theater last yearthe intimate struggle between a boy and a doctor takes place in a railed enclosure near the footlights, while the upstage area beyond is filled with banks of seats for spectators like ourselves, facing us. (These seats are sold, as ours are, though in future they will be sold mainly to students.)

title: Bergen Poets List a Reading Session
description: PARAMUSThe public is invited to attend an evening of readings and discussion that the Bergen Poets, a countywide cultural group, and invited guests will present at Bergen Community College on Nov. 12.

title: JEWS WILL, OFFER BOOKS ON HISTORY
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith announced yesterday a program intended to eliminate distortions, misconceptions and negative stereotypes of Jews and Judaism and to develop a deeper understanding of the Nazi holocaust.

title: Doing Unto Others as
description: PARIS  For years theoreticians have been arguing about the prospects of Soviet Russia developing a freer society as it becomes, with the steady increase of outside contacts, more bourgeois in its outlook. What nobody seems to realize is that this has already happened.

title: Volcanos in the stomach
description: With 350 stunning photographs, most of them in color, Lennart Nilsson presents the human body as a series of interior landscapes in a way that has never been seen before. Because of the enlarged scale of the photographs, which are magnifications up to 45,000 times, what has previously been invisible now becomes monumental. Hairs of the head are seen as a grove of trees amid mossy stones; glands of the stomach as volcanic terrain; mucosal folds within the Fallopian tube as beautiful silken veils; calcium crystals of the inner ear (they help us keep our balance and are only one threehundredths of an inch long) are seen as monumental boulders, like some moonlit primitive Stonehenge.

title: Letters: Paestum's Pleasures
description: To the Editor. I read the article entitled A Visit to Ancient Greecein Italy by Esther Benson (Travel Section, Oct. 13) and was appalled to see that Miss Benson wrote about Paestum without having visited the excellent museum there, since the museum houses a most important archeological find, namely four wall paintings of the year 480 B.C. discovered recently in a tomb near the temples.

title: Irish Rally in Fourth Period To Beat Stubborn Navy, 146
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov, 2With offers of $600,000 to appear in the Orange Bowl and $500,000 in the Sugar Bowl hanging in the balance, Notre Dame scratched and scrambled back to score two touchdowns in the final period and beat a spectacular Navy team, 14.6, at Veterans Stadium today.

title: Picture Books
description: Some 9and 10yearolds I know have an assignment to write and illustrate picture books for the little kids at school. A few of these new authors, hunting ideas, asked me what picture books are usually about? Anything. From ABC's to death. If there is a secret ingredient it isn't subject matter but the tone. There are books created to idealize childhood. Great aunts buy those. Other works are intended by the author and artist for a jury of their peers. Art directors delight in these. But there are bookmakers who neither talk nor draw up or down. They speak, instead, directly and easily to their audience.

title: What Are Those Funny Little Things?
description: Many of the greatest oddities in the plant kingdom grow in semidesert areas of South Africa. Among the most fascinating are those highly succulent and diminutive stonemimicry plants that belong to the nmembryanthemum family. They are called flowering stone.

title: Sponsors Defend Showing of Nazi Art in Frankfurt
description: FRANKFURT, West GermanyAn exhibition of Art in the Third Reich is drawing crowds of highschool students here, and the Frankfurt Art Association is being subject to much criticism for staging it.

title: In Montclair, Butcher is a Craftsman
description: MONTCLAIRWhen they pound the veal at Jim Intili's meat market here, they use an antique Sicilian silver pestle, one that has felt the strong grips of five generations of Intilis.

title: Marine Is Decorated
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 2 (UPI)An officer at the Kaneohe Marine Corps air station has become the first marine to be decorated for action while a prisoner of war in Southeast Asia. Navy Secretary J. William Middendorft presented the award yesterday to the marine. Chief Warrant Officer William F. Thomas Jr. on behalf of President Ford.

title: Amarcord and Lacornbe, Lucien Illuminations of Things Past
description: The two best European films of the past year are both studies of provincial life just before and during World War II. Federico Fellini's Amarcord is set in the thirtiei, when Mussolini was at the height of his influence; Louis ??? Lacombe, Lucien covers a few months in 1944, shortly before the Allied liberation of France.

title: Dead Solid Perfect
description: There are approximately four deep belly laughs and some minor tickles in this book. But you've got refried beans here in comparison to the voluptuous sirloin of SemiTough, Dan Jenkins's funny and nasty smasher about pro football. Kenny Puckett is the narrator of this one, a pro golfer on his way to the spotlight at the U. S. Open in Heavenly Pines, N. C. Formerly Kenny has tied for 7th or 4th (you can still keep yourself in Lincoln Continentals and cashmere turtlenecks, as Puckett says), but now he leads the tournament by one stroke and might get his name on the plaque of golf history as well as carry off the trophy and the inflated winner's check.

title: Children's Books Fall 1974
description: This edition of Grimm's Fairy Tales was first published in 1944 and at that time reviewed for The New York Times Book Review by no less a personage than W. H. Auden. Everything he said then remains relevant and valid. He praised the work of James Stern in revising the 19thcentury text of Margaret Hunt, and the imaginative and skillful drawings of Joseph Scharl. He pointed out that nowhere in a modern democratic society, which consists almost entirely of conscious and responsible individuals, are the gemeinschaft conditions, which created folk tales and kept them alive, any longer to be found. Instead, the imaginations of nonintellectual, laboring people, who have lost their folk heritage, are deformed and mutilated by a popular art not of their own creatinga degenerate  horror, massproduced for profit.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: The late Alexander King used to recount the poignant story of a man he had metsomewhere in northern Europe, as I recall during his travels as a youth. This man invited King to his home to see with his own eyes the machine he had been working on for 20 years. The machine, which he felt to be on the verge of perfection, was to be a great boon to mankind. King observed the man as he placed a piece of paper into the prototype and pressed a number of buttons. But it was not until he had watched the device attack and mangle the paper for several minutes that he realized the was reinventing the typewriter.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Eddie Robinson, Grambling College coach who has sent two black quarterbacks into pro footballJim Harris of the Los Angeles Rams and Matthew Reed of the Birmingham Americanspredicts: The way things are going, within the next 10 years, over half of the quarterbacks in the pro leagues are going to be black.

title: MOSCOW SOFTENS STAND ON PEKING
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 2Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin took a moderate line toward China today in a speech emphasizing Moscow's objective to extend. the process of detente to all areas of the world.

title: Best Seller List
description: General

title: POLITICAL REFORM DOUBTED IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, Nov. 2Despite reassurances from Premier Carlos Arias that he intended to pursue a reformist policy, there is a growing belief here that a key project to allow the formation of political groups will be highly restricted.

title: Grambling Beats Texas Southern
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 2 (AP)Doug Williams, a freshman quarterback, threw touchdown passes of 16 and 35 yards today while guiding Grambling to a 3421 victory over Texas Southern.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater

title: Yancey Duo Leads in Team Golf
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Nov. 2Playing what they call a game of total partnership in the most enjoyable kind of golf, Bert Yancey and Ed Sneed took a oneshot lead today in the third round of the Professional Golfers Association team championship by shooting a nineunderpar 63.

title: Chicago Chemist Given Award for Research
description: FREDRICKSBURG, Va., Nov. 2Dr. Percy L. Julian, a Chicago chemist, was awarded the $1,000 Proctor Prize of Sigma XI, the national scientific research society, at the society's annual meeting here today.

title: ELIZABETH ROGERS
description: Elizabeth Frances Rogers, who was professor of history and bead of the history department at Wilson College, Chambershurg, Pa., from 1923 to 1957, died Friday in the Mount Carmel Home, 539 West 54th Street, where she had lived for the last eight years. Her age was 82.

title: Outspoken Woman Named to Key Post
description: NEW BRUNSWICKFrom the outset of his campaign for Governor, Brendan T. Byrne has been a strong advocate of women's rights, even appointing three women to cabinet positions. But, according to leaders of women's groups throughout the state, he has hedged and delayed on matters concerning the reactivation of the Division on Women in the Department of Community Affairs.

title: Utilities Are Confident on Fuel
description: TRENTON  The state's three electric companies report that they have sufficient amounts of coal and oil to fire their boilers this winter and that they are not being affected by the sharp cutbacks in deliveries of natural gas.

title: BRIDGE
description: Holding up a king is almost as we an episode at the bridge table as in real life. Most defenders lack the alertness required to make such a play without a revealing tremor. They feel, wrongly, that a trick in the hand is worth two in the postmortem. Take this situation:

title: ANIMAL SOCIETY FACES SHUTDOWN
description: The treasurer of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said last week that the organization had a deficit of $1million that would force the society to close its shelaters for the city's lost, strayed or homeless animals within five years.

title: Wallace Markfield impersonates Lenny Bruce
description: Wallace Markfield's new novel confirms a suspicion I have long entertained that most of the explicitly ethnic Jewish novelists are really, by the nature and the limitations of their gifts, writers of short stories and satiric sketches. One painfully vivid illustration of this ruleofthumb is the precipitous slide of Philip Roth's career from the modest peaks of short fiction in Goodbye, Columbus down through Portnoy's Complaint to the disasters of his most recent attempts at novelwriting.

title: 599 U.S. Counties Are Found to Lack Catholic Ministry
description: A fifth of the nation's 3,140 counties lack a resident. Roman Catholic priest, according in the Glenmary Home Missioners of Cincinnati.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The acronym WIN (Whip Inflation Now) did not originate with the war against inflation. Had the President done his homework, he would have found that a Federal WIN program the Work Incentive Program already exists.

title: Spring Bridal For Miss Crosby; Hendrick Smith
description: Mr. and Mrs. G. Kingman Crosby of St. Maarten, Netherlands Antilles, and Centerville, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katharine C. Crosby, to Hendrick S. Smith. He is the son of Mrs. Reuben Dahl of Sacramento, Calif., and Henry F, Smith of Edwardsburg, Mich.

title: MORE AIR TICKETS INVOLVED INFRAUD
description: In midAugust, James Fine, the owner of a midtown travel agency, placed an ad in. The New York Times offering to sell the agency. Two weeks later, a man who gave his name as John Gordon visited Mr, Fine and bought the agency for $35,Within five weeks, the travel agency was closed, Mr. Gordon had vanishedalong with 2,000 blank airline tickets potentially worth more than $500,000and the tickets were being peddled at cutrate prices in the underworld.

title: U.S. Aid Chief Warns Africa Famine Goes On
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Nov. 2 (Agence FrancePresse)The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development called here yesterday for continued food aid for the subSaharan famine despite improved rainfall and better harvests this year.

title: DANCE VIEW CLIVE BARNES
description: Iam a secret opera lover. In my few respites from the theater, when I should be watching sand, sea, air, grass and lizards, or at least playing golf, I go secretly to the opera by night andwhile I am confessingthe movies by day. In between, I watch television commercials while reading novels. But much as I love opera, I hate operaballet.

title: State Acts on Women Drinkers
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Health believes that there are 90,000 alcoholic housewives in New Jersey, and it has undertaken a special effort to advise them about abusecontrol projects.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, SU
description: Albertsona Print techniques by Selene Yarnell, through this month, Shelter Rock Public Library, 165 Searingtown Road. For hours, call (516) CH 87363.

title: Panel Will Screen Malpractice Suits in Nassau to Ease Court Load
description: MINEOLAAn attempt to speed up medical malpractice suits and keep them from clogging analready overburdened court calendar will start tomorrow in Nassau County.

title: Shady Character Scores at Big A
description: Sent into the lead at the start by Angel Cordero, Shady Character remained there all through the running of the 1%mile Knickerbocker Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The performance attracted a generous round of applause from many in the crowd of 34,919, despite the fact that Shady Character defeated two strong favorites in the turf race.

title: Louisiana a Disaster Area
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 2 (AP)President Ford has dedared Louisiana a major disaster area, clearing the way for the state to receive Federal aid to repair damage caused by severe storms earlier in the week, White House officials said. His action was announced while Mr. Ford was in Portland to campaign for Republican candidates.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following may be obtained front the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Checkout counter
description: Checkout counter

title: Arkansas Loses, 2010, To Aggies
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 2 (UPI)  A reserve fullback, Jerry Honore, scored two touchdowns one on a 60yard run  to propel Texas A. and M. to a 2010 victory over Arkansas today and keep the Aggies atop the Southwest Conference.

title: NEWARK SCHOOLS CALLED LACKING
description: NEWARK, Nov. 2A detailed examination of the city's publicschool system has found that, despite the implementation of many programs aimed at improving the basic skills of its students in recent years, achievemet rates have shown little or no improvement, and in many areas have actually declined.

title: California Plays U.S.C. To 1515 Tie
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (AP) California's Jim Breech missed a 34yard field goal attempt with 7 seconds to play and the Golden Bears settled for a 1515 tie with sixthranked Southern California today in a Pacific8 football game.

title: Little Owl, Keeper of the Trees
description: It all happens to Little Owl, but the real hero Is a toothless troll with floppy lips who sings, dances, adores chocolate cake and lurks under bridges.

title: Aide to Governor of Delaware Among 11 Subpoenaed in Inquiry
description: DOVER, Del. Nov. 2Wayne D. Ellingsworth, administrative aide to Democratic Gov. Sherman W. Tribbitt, is among 11 state employes subpoenaed to appear before a Kent County grand jury on Tuesday in connection with an inquiry into state hiring practices.

title: Soviet, in Accord with ABC, Plans Summit TV Coverage
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 2 (Reuters)The Soviet Union today announced an agreement with the American Broadcasting Company aiming at broader exchanges of television programs with the United States on news, sport and entertainment.

title: 78 KILLED IN FIRE IN HEART OF SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sunday, Nov. 3 (UPI) A fire swept through the crowded upper floors of a sevenstory officebuilding complex in downtown.; Seoul early today, killing scores,. of persons. Some leaped to their deaths in panic.

title: Planting Fields in Flower As Garden Clubs Compete
description: OYSTER BAY  Planting Fields Arboretum, once the private horticultural domain of a wealthy businessman, was host to more than 15,000 plant enthusiasts at its fall flower show held for four days last weektestimony both to the greening of America and the pull of a golden autumn day.

title: Teaneck Shoppers See a Classroom In Action
description: TEANECKAbout 100 pupils from the second, third and sixth grades here went to school in a local supermarket last week.

title: Lions Are Trounced by Cornell, 240
description: Normalcy returned to Baker Field yesterday. Columbia, which ended a string of 11 straight football defeats with a 3833 triumph over Bucknell last week, returned to Ivy League competition and absorbed a 24.0 trouncing from Cornell before a shirtsleeved crowd of 5,180.

title: A School With a Flexible Style
description: SAYREVILLE  For Peter Fland, the challenge was irresistible.

title: ATOM POWER PLAN IS GIVER PENTAGON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2The director of a nuclear laboratory has proposed that the Defense Department, to ease the energy crisis, build nuclear power plants for military bases, using fuel from fissionable material from obsolete atomic weapons.

title: It's A Going Concern, but Some Early Momentum Has Been Lost
description: PARISAround the year 200 B.C., a group of Greek coastal towns banded together to form the Achaean League, under the leadership of a general named Philopoemen. They wanted to protect themselves against pirates and more powerful citystates such as Sparta.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: President Ford's latest campaign cry for cooperative, bipartisan support of his foreign policies reflects a dangerous attitude that should not be accepted in a democratic government. This attitude holds foreign policy to be a sacrosanct, handsoff responsibility of the Presidency which should be insulated from the influence of the public and the other branches of government.

title: A WOMAN PRIEST QUITS. AS CURATE
description: The Rev. Nancy C. H. Wittig, one of the 11 women ordained to the Episcopal priesthood last. July, has resigned as curate of St. Peter's Church in Morristown, N.J., because, she said, she did not have the support of the vestry.

title: Mary E. Earls Coburn Everdell Married in Ohio
description: Mary Elizabeth Earls, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Earls of Cincinnati, was married there yesterday to Coburn Darling Everdell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Everdell 3d of New York and Queenstown, Md.

title: FinalSecond Victory
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 2 (AP)Mitch Sanders hit Carmine Bove with a 7yard touchdown pass at the end of the game and Homer Wanamaker added the extra point to give Bridgeport a 7.6 victory over Southern Connecticut tonight.

title: News of the Realty Trade Office Center Planned in Jersey
description: The Bellemead Development Corporation has acrullred a 98acre tract in the ParsippanyTroy Hills area of New Jersey for development as an office center.

title: Ford Reported to Lay Off 400 White Collar Workers
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Nov. (AP)About 400 white collar workers are the latest victims of costcutting efforts at Ford Motor Company, industry sources said today.

title: The French Alert Their Broadcasters: En Garde!
description: PARIS Senator Sam Ervin: Who was wa'?

title: VISIT BY KISSINGER BUOYS NEW DELHI
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 2Although tensions and tesentments still shade their relationship, American and Indian officials say they have been buoyed by the threeday visit here of Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: 30 years in the publishing profession
description: This is an informal memoir of 30 years in publishing. It is not a structured account of the author's career, nor does it try to reveal his inner life. For the most part Hiram Haydn, who died last December, has jotted down his recollections of books he published and persons he knew, under the honest title Words & Faces. There is not much criticism of the books, beyond the sort of comments one finds in readers reports, and Haydn's judgments of people are benevolent except in the few cases in which he tells a briefly cruel anecdote. Yet his personality does emerge, as reflected in action or opinion, and the book is fascinating to anyone connected however remotely with the publishing profession.

title: Miss Kirkland and Baryshnikov Give Memorable Performance of Coppelia
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2There are some performances in dance that simply take off at the beginning and never come down. Just such an occasion was American Ballet Theater's performance of Coppelia last night at the Kennedy Center.

title: Unbeaten Ohio State Wins, 497
description: COLUMOUS, Ohio, Nov. 2 (AP)Woody Hayes achieved his 200th college football coaching victory and Ohio State's junior sensation, Archie Griffin, set a national rushing record today in leading the top ranked Buckeyes to a 497 Big Ten victory over Illinois.

title: AMTRAK BETTERS ON TIME RECORD
description: Amtrak has reported a substantial improvement in overcoming one of the main difficulties on its nationwide rail passenger network  getting the train into the station on time.

title: Brazil Expects to Control Meningitis in Rio Soon
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 21 (UPI)  Brazilian authorities, said today that meningitis cases; had tripled there but that a largescale inoculation programm, should bring the outbreak under control within three months.

title: Penn State Conquers Maryland
description: UNIVERSITY, PARK, Pa., Nov. 2In a hardhitting, tense game featured by a wild secondperiod sequence in which three touchdowns were scored in a 25second span, Penn State today opened the door wider to a fourth straight major bowl bid.

title: Nixon Medical Bulletin
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 2Following is the text of a bulletin on the condition of former President Richard M. Nixon, issued at 9 A.M. today by Dr. John C. Lungren, Mr. Nixon's physician, at Memorial Hospital Medical Center:

title: ART VIEW
description: W ho would:have thought that Henry Mooresurely, with Alexander Calder, the most universally admired of living sculptors and, like Mr. Calder, long the darling of architects and building committees the world overcould still have become a figure of controversy as recently as the 1960's? Yet it happened, and not in some backwater crossroads where modern art might still be regarded as the work of the devil but in Toronto, which boasts agreat university, an enlightened municipal government, and a cultural atmosphere of some sophistication.

title: Garden AROUND THE
description: 1 Last call to plant hardy bulbs for spring bloom. They must be underground to make some root growth,

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONA new system that permits state residents to register to vote by postcard is expected to benefit Democratic candidates on Tuesday.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Despite some unfavorable economic developments, the stock market managed to make a strong advance last week in moderate trading.

title: UPGRADING EFFORT IS ON IN CARACAS
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Caracas is a city of handsome skyscrapers, elegant mansions and luxury boutiques and restaurants. It is also a city of brutal poverty, with grim, unsafe and unsanitary slums, illequipped and overcrowded schools and hospitals, and legions of unemployed.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE FEDERAL RESERVE BANK of New York reported a drop of $814million in business loans for the week ended Oct. 23 First National City Bank lowered Its prime rate to 10% per cent from 11 per cent, effective tomorrow.  Savings and loan associations reported savings balances rose by $1.4billion In September compared with rise of $1.8billion In September, 1973.

title: Recreating the Revolution
description: The Bicentennial is a splendid occasion for children to learn about the Revolution, and publishers are obviously willing to cooperate. But can an event so complicated be presented satisfactorily to children?

title: A Billionaire Makes His Dream Come True
description: IN his old age, the richest man in the world remembered a dream of his youth. J. Paul Getty had visited Italy in 1912, when he was a 19yearold art student and pil billionairetobe. He fell in love with a magnificent villa on the Bay of Naples, near the Atilet fishing village of Herculaneum. Called the Villa dei Papyri, for its extraordinary library, it was built in the last century before Christ as a seaside resort for a wealthy Roman.

title: DR. OSCAR H. BLOOM
description: Dr. Oscar H. Bloom, former chief of obstetrics and gynecology at Beth El Hospital, now part of the Brookdale Medical Center in Brooklyn, and former gynelogist of Parsons Hospitals, Flushing, Queens, died Friday in Miami, where he lived. His age was 76.

title: ART VIEW
description: N of all artists are in love with art. For some, their work is a continual struggle with intractable materials and elusive inspirations. Such artists would echo Marianne Moore's opinion, expressed with her fastidious poetic diction, of poetry: I, too, dislike it. Something like distaste often spurs this kind of artist to innovate, to modify the terms of his medium in a spirit almost of revenge. He may be a creator of great vigor and even humor, but his is an essentially cheerless passion.

title: CAREY IS FAVORED TO UNSEAT WILSON IN TUESDAY'S VOTE
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey is the heavy favorite, cording to politicians and polltakers alike, to defeat Governor Wilson Tuesday and end 16 years of Republiban rule in New York State.

title: Backers of Mills Worried Despite Big Lead in Polls
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 2 The Arkansas Democratic party and several of the state's best political operatives have gone to work to save Representative Wilbur D, Mills from an annoyed electorate.

title: Alison Livingston Early Is a Bride
description: Alison Livingston Early, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Early of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Samuel Peter Shuler 3d, son of Mrs. Robert Gregory of Monticello, Ind., and Mr. Shuler Jr. of Bowman, S.C. The Rev. S. Hughes Garvin performed the ceremony in St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J.

title: When the Whale Came To My Town
description: Walking to school along the beach at Provincetown one midwinter morning, the boy discovers a dead thing bigger than a bus, a whale stranded, awash in the surf. Huge and mysterious, beautiful too, the Whale awes and fascinates the boy. He wonders why it's there. It stirs his sense of wonder and his curiosity. I listened to his breathing sound. Was he lost? Did he chase something into shallow water? Was he old? Was he a she?

title: Shah and Kissinger Hint At Bid to Hold Oil Prices
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 2Shah Mohammed Riza Pahievi and Secretary of State Kissinger agreed today that the oilproducing countries and the industrialized consumer nations must cooperate to prevent world disorder stemming from inflation.

title: Miss Saranec Fiancee Of Samuel Livermore
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edmund C. Saranec of Hamden, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Ross Saranec, to Samuel Morgan Livermore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman B. Livermore Jr. of Sacramento, Calif.

title: Bergenfield Tops Ridgewood In Battle of Unbeatens, 186
description: Bergenfield defeated Ridgewood, 186, yesterday in the battle of unbeaten clubs that virtually settled the Northern New Jersey Interscholastic League race in Bergenfield.

title: Expansion at Airports California Complaint
description: SAN FRANCISCOIn the midst of all the gloomy talk by and about the airlines, the San Francisco International Airport, fifth largest in the nation, is contemplating a $398million expansion program to double passenger capacity to 31 million by 1985 and triple cargo capacity.

title: Endowment for Harvard
description: BOSTON, Nov. 2 (UPI)The Harvard School of Public Health has established a $400,000 endowment in the memory of Gregory Pincus, inventor (lithe birthcontrol spill. The endowment was paid for by G. D. Searles & Co., a Chicago pharmaceutical firm that manufactures an oral contrapceptive.

title: Lumberjack
description: Can a painter write a good book that has no plot, no characters, no dialogue? Yes, but like lumberjacking, it's hard work. Yet this is a real story by firmfisted woodsman. I know, because I was a jack myself. I've hauled many a cord of rough spruce through Adirondack snow, and my index and middle finger can still feel divided by the iron stem of a woodhook. So I know his work.

title: Miss Ratcliffe Has Nuptials
description: Susan Farny Ratcliffe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Ratcliffe of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to John Nicholas Cameron. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles V. Cameron of Houston.

title: H. R. Gray Jr. to Wed Mary Cunningham
description: Shirley Sears Cunningham of Hanover, N. H., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Elizabeth Cunningham, to Howard Russell Gray Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gray of Boston.

title: Who Is Paying for the Election? People Who Want Something
description: WASHINGTONWhen all the bills have been paid, this year's Congressional election will probably have cost the candidates somewhat More than $50million.

title: N. Hempstead Sets Hearinz on Cable TV Dispute
description: A public hearing in the Town of North Hempstead has been ordered for Thursday by the State Cable TV Commissionfollowing proiests that the town's renewal of its cable television franchise was illegally con cluded with Communications Development Corporation. ??? H. Sweeny, ??? counsel to the commission, said It's seldom we get this kind of, public interest in a cable TV franchise, especially concerning public access.

title: A Tale of 2 Cities
description: A letter to the editor of The New York Times asserted last week that there was a critical difference between resistance to school desegregation in Little Rock 17 years ago and in Boston today. The letter reflected the persistent myth that efforts to desegregate in the North are unwarranted or even racism in reverse.

title: Legislative Fight Looms Over Raises In Newark
description: NEWARKA measure designed to allow this city to continue to collect up to $18million a year in special local taxes has been freed from a bottleneck in the Assembly, but a fight still looms in the Legislature Over pay raises voted by the Newark City Council on Oct. 2.

title: PATH Line to Airport Urged
description: NEWARK  The Regional Plan Association has proposed a revised formula that would bring PATH's rapidtransit trains right to the front door of each of the three passenger terminals at Newark International Airport.

title: FIRE FIGHTERS GET RAISE AND DEDUCTION
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 2About 11,150 firemen employed by the counties on six islands agreed this week to new wage terms, but they will have to give up from $130,000 to $180,000 in retroactive pay because of massive sickins last July.

title: Council's Parks Unit to Meet
description: The City Council's Committee on Parks has scheduled a public meeting for next Thursday at 10 A.M. in City Hall to consider several bills, including one death ing with safety equipment in playgrounds.

title: Jets Play Oilers Today In a Battle of Losers
description: The Jets and the Houston Oilers gather at Shea Stadium today in what could have some resemblance to a football game. The Jets, with only one victory in seven games, are a loss away from equaling the worst start in their 15year history.

title: Nibbling at Hunger
description: In preparation for the World Food Conference that opens this week in Rome, the Ford Administration has at last got around to promoting establishment of an emergency world food reserve. Secretary of Agriculture Earl Butz has announced that the dollar amount of food aid to be made available this year will be increased to $1 billion as opposed to $900 million last year; but that rise barely matches the erosive effect of higher prices. The reason for the inadequate American initiative appears to be Dr. Butz's apparently unshakable belief that the free market system better serves America's farmers and consumers and his continued underestimation of the food problem faced by the world as a whole.

title: Interborough Road Will Be Remodelled
description: A $1.7million reconstruction of a 4,100foot section of the Interborough Parkway connecting Brooklyn and Queens will begin tomorrow.

title: A Failing Coop Revives as a Rental
description: By JUDITH C. LACK When it was last detailed in these pages nearly two years ago, Charel House, as it was then called, a new, 25story luxury residence at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and 80th Street, had stood empty for more than a year, its 39 cooperative apartments unsold, its streetlevel store unrented, its carrying charges running a stiff $50,000 a month and its ownerdevelopers, twins Ralph and Daniel Elyachar, desperately seeking alternative solutions. Eleven months and several leads later, they found one in the person of Sidney Weniger, a New York mort gage broker and financing specialist who learned at a Washington real estate investment convention that the building was available, decided to buy within four days and closed the deal 10 days after it was first discussed.

title: The Nation
description: With unemployment rising and worker produbtivity declining, President Ford has reshuffled the team of administrators who must deal with one of the major factors in the nation's economic picture, energy. John C. Sawhill, head of the Federal Energy Administration, was out of a job.

title: Perels of Wisdom Before an Opening
description: If you have the temerity to loiter in the lobby of the American Place Theater during the next few weeks, you may encounter a selfdescribed cunning homunculus, buttoncute, rapierkeen, cucumbercool and gallbitter. You will have come face to face with S. J. Perelman, 70yearold belletrist for The New Yorker magazine, onetime Hollywood scenarist and Broadway playwright. Perelman's 1962 play, The Beauty Part, has been revived by the American Place and has its official opening tomorrow nighta development that has almost imperceptibly softened its author's famous strabismic leer. When I approached him recently in hopes of more news about play and playwright, I tried to show no fear of the prognathous jaw and sudden riposte. Instead, I offered him a large pastry, and I was not bitten for almost two hours.

title: Coast Convict Exonerated
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov, 2 (AP)Sergeant Herbert Jackson, who had served eight months of a life sentence, has been exonerated after a teenager implicated himself in a robberymurder at a gasoline station. Judge William A. Low of Superior Court dismissed charges against Mr. Jackson, who is 21 years old, after an 18yearold youth walked into police headquarters and implicated himself and another youth in the robbery and murder.

title: Greenwich, McMahon Near Showdown
description: Greenwich and Brien McMahon of Norwalk yesterday continued their undefeated progress toward a Nov. 16 meeting in Norwalk as each took its eighth victory.

title: Skill and Energy Transform a Bad Buy
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y.  Lauren and Marco Martelli bought a three story French Normandy stucco house here three years ago, intending to do some remodeling  updating the kitchen, for example, and the bathrooms.

title: Election 74: Where Have All the Fat Cats Gone?
description: Often, when we have discussed political finance and regulations, our words have elicited smiles and winks and nice pats on the back, the memorandum says. We hope you will take this law and the forthcoming regulatons very, very seriously.

title: Bringing the war home
description: This second novel by the author of A Hall of Mirrors iS a dark descendant of Conrad's and Hemingway's adventure stories, a tale of Vietnam and California, a narrative meditation on the counterculture. Its subiect and complex, ironic tone prompt the thought that the 1960's could be described in a chain of aphorisms, oldies but goldies: History is a nightmare from which I am trying to awake: Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it. Turn on, tune in, drop out. Blow your mind. The tigers of wrath are wiser than the horses of instruction. Sooner murder an infant in its cradle than nurse unacted desires. Let it all hang out. Let it be. Let it bleed. Sorry about that. Stonewall it.

title: Nast's Elephant, at 100, Is Feted in Morristown
description: MORRISTOWNNo matter what the polls say, this is the Year of the Elephant. Even those Republicans who find nothing to celebrate on Tuesday can cheer up by toasting the 100th birthday of their party pachyderm two days later.

title: A country vet remembers
description: James Herriot is at it again with that easy, ingratiating way of telling a story. Readers of his bestselling All Creatures Great and Small are undoubtedly ready to devour its sequel in one gulp. Which may not be the best way to approach this supplementary collection of reminiscences of the Yorkshire country vet before World War II. It deserves more leisurely treatment, a few chapters at a time.

title: WaterHistory Show in Newark Extended
description: NEWARKWater in New Jersey History, a major exhibition at the New Jersey Historical Society, has been extended through the end of the year.

title: MARKETS PRICING IS AT ISSUE ON L.I.
description: MARKETS PRICING IS AT ISSUE ON L.I.

title: J. D. Salinger Speaks About His Silence
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2Goaded by publication of unauthorized editions of his early, previously uncollected works, the reclusive author J. D. Sallinger broke a public silence of more than 20 years last week, issuing a denunciation and revealing he is hard at work on writings that may never be published in his lifetime.

title: ARTISTS IN SOVIET CONDEMN THREAT
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 2A spokesman for unofficial Soviet artists who held a successful outdoor exhibition in September after an earlier attempt had been disrupted charged yesterday that a Moscow newspaper review unambiguously threatens all who participated in the show.

title: Whitman Halts North Babylon Streak
description: Suffolk's longest winning streak ended yesterday when Whitman halted North Babylon's 13game winning streak, 87, on Dave Loehle's 51yard touchdown run in the third quarter, handing the Bulldogs a damaging setback in AAI where the losers are defending.

title: Jerry Reed, at Bottom Line, Plays the Guitar Ebulliently
description: Jerry Reed is a singer, songwriter, producer and, above all, a guitarist, who has been a fixture in Nashville for nearly 20, years. A protg of Chet Atkins, Mr. Reed really began to emerge as a star in his own right only in the nineteenseventies. But by now he seems firmly fixed in the country pantheon.

title: U.S. Is Urging U.N. to Expand Program of Disaster Assistance
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2The United States, offering $750,000 for disaster relief next year, has urged the United Nations to expand its twoyearold program of providing assistance to victims of emergencies.

title: Q: How Do I Get an Arts Subsidy? A: Become a Symphony Orchestra
description: Even before the St. Louis Symphony made a formal application for funds to the Missouri Arts Council this year, it was a foregone conclusion that the symphony would get its $632,459 from the current state appropriation. On the other hand, the less politically powerful, but eminently worthy St. Louis Community Music School, which serves youngsters in the inner city, applied to the Council for modest state grants on three separate occasions and never even received an acknowledgement. The contrast in the treatment accorded to a big organization and to a small one exQ: How Do I Get an Arts Subsidy? A: Become a Symphony Orchestra emplifies the way things work sometimes in Missouri, where two orchestrasthe state's cultural bullyboyscustomarily receive 75 to 80 per cent of all state funds appropriated for the arts.

title: Tuesday: Accounts Due
description: Perhaps the central question that is entwined among hundreds of elections Tuesday is what sort of Republican party will survive the beating that almost all the experts predict.

title: Hearing on Chemical Waste
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency will hold a public hearing Nov. 14 on the burning of chemical wastes In the Gulf of Mexico.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: Letters to the F.T.C
description: I would normally not take time for this response, but the industry abuses make it criminal to remain silent.

title: Much Unclear Along the Potomac
description: WASHINGTONThe argument over whether the nation is or is not in the midst of a recession appears to have been settled with a truce. The President, the Secretary of the Treasury and others have agreed that the name applied to the current economic situation does not matter, and that what does matter is that the nation has economic problems.

title: Brazil originally comes from Africa
description: Down the middle of the Atlantic Ocean there is a ridge, and down the middle of the ridge there is a rift, a crack through which molten lava bubbles up. Once there were glaciers in the Sahara. A lot of mountains contain fossils of sea creatures; often the rocks, folded like tablecloths, are youngest on the bottom. The earth's magnetic field, the thing that causes compass needles to point north, occasionally reverses to make them point south. Once there were swamps in Antarctica; once there were seas in the American Middle West. The water under the Red Sea is hotter and saltier be. These are facts.

title: B.C.'s Runs Top W.Va., By 35 to 3
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Nov. 2 (UPI)Keith Barnette tied a school scoring record with four touchdown runs today as Boston College defeated West Virginia, 353.

title: J. S. Bach Takes a Baroque Bow
description: It took a harpsichordist to show Sergiu Luca how the latter felt Bach's music should sound on the violin. The Rumanianborn violinist had been playing the Bach solo violin works for a long time without being happy about the results. He likened what he heard to reading literature in translationthe sense was there but slightly altered. He asked among specialists in Baroque music what he should do. A friend told him to listen to recordings made by the harpsichordist Gustav Leonhardt of Bach's transcriptions of the violin works. Luca did so and was finally satisfied that this was the way they should sound.

title: Zaire Remembered
description: Once two Zairians paddled a dugout canoe past the N'Sele complex of modern stucco buildings, flowers and fountains where Muhammad Ali lived and where All and George Foreman both trained. But mostly the Congo River was empty except for the hyacinth pads that floated by in the swift current.

title: Princeton Stages RareBook Show
description: PRINCETONThe Princeton University Library has mounted a spectacular and extensive exhibition of rare books by a man whose name may be a mystery to many visitorsBartolome de Las Casas  and contemporary accounts.

title: PartTimers at Stony Brook
description: STONY BROOKOfficials at the State University here are considering providing evening and Saturday classes and childcarp services to encourage registration by parttime students.

title: Jeannette Rankin
description: History seldom repeats itself with the cruel symmetry it conferred on Jeannette Rankin. Elected to Congress in 1917, the Republican from Montana was the first woman to sit amid the spittoons and cigar smoke in that venerable, leatherbound allmale club. Woman suffrage had been won only in some of these United States; the Susan B. Anthony (19th) amendment had not yet passed, and the curious eyes of the nation were on the suffragists proudest symbol, the woman who was to prove for the franchised and soontobefranchised that females were capable of responsible participation in the serious affairs of the nation.

title: The Nonaligned Voter Is Gradually Becoming Democratic
description: WASHINGTONOne of the major reasons that Republicans wish that Tuesday would never come is the attitude of the independent (or ticketsplitting or unaffiliated) voter. The Republicans, who claim the full allegiance of only a third of the nation's voters, need the independents to win.

title: New Book Traces History of Whaling
description: TRENTONThe most recent in the New Jersey Agricultural Society's 25volume series of historical publications is Whaling in New Jersey. The 160page book was written by the late Dr. Harry B. Weiss, in collaboration with Howard R. Kemble and Millicen T. Can.

title: Food Stamps for 8 Teachers
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 2 (AP) Eight Mississippi teachers received food stamps this spring because their salaries were low enough to make them eligible, according to Max Cole, the State Welfare Commissioner. The minimum salary for teachers in Mississippi is $6,572. Eligibility for food stamps depends on a variety of factors, including size of the family.

title: Caso Denies He Urged Step if Wilson Loses
description: Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, who is running for Lieutenant Governor with Governor Wilson, denied yesterday that he had said that Mr. Wilson should step aside as state leader of theparty if he lost on Tuesday and allow Mr. Caso to emerge as a very important eprson in the Republican hierarchy.

title: She Come. Bringing Me That Little Baby Girl
description: By JULIUS LESTER

title: FUND ROLE SHIFTS TO SECRET SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2The Secret Service, under legislation that took effect last summer, has been given the responsibility for financing socalled security improvements or alterations that it requests for private Presidential dwellings outside of Washington.

title: New Restaurant in Huntington Specializes in Chef Du Jour
description: HUNTINGTONChefs come and go with regularity at the Linden Tree Cafe here, but not because of any dissatisfaction on the part of the restaurant, which specializes in diversity.

title: Airlines Slumping But Outlook for Aircraft Is Strong
description: Russians strode through the cavernous hangars of the Boeing Company's big assembly plant at Everett, Wash., last week. They have begun talks in earnest with company executives about ordering 10 Boeing 747 jetliners for about $300million.

title: O'Dwyer and Leone at Odds Over Proposed Funds For Comerery in Canarsie
description: City Council President Paul O'Dwyer ??? municipal ownership of Canarsie Cemetery, has piqued the civic pride of Brooklyn Borcugh President Sebastian Leone.

title: Rent Board Picked In Nassau County
description: State housing officials announced yesterday that they had completed formation of the nine  member Nassau County Rent Guidelines Board, which will determine maximum rent increases permitted in the 10,000 apartments thus far covered in the county by the state's new rentstabilization law.

title: 500,000 Years May Be Added to Man
description: The fossilrich volcanic deposits of the bleak Hadar River Valley in Northern Ethiopia have given up another piece of evidence in support of the current trend in scientific thinking on the origins of man.

title: Post Takes Collegiate Title Run
description: Post College, which needed special approval to compete because its entry was filed late, easily won the team title yesterday in the 22d annual Collegiate Track Conference crosscountry championships.

title: MOOD IN BULGARIA: A VIGIL FOR SPIES
description: MOOD IN BULGARIA: A VIGIL FOR SPIES

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PARIS, Nov. 2 (UPI)George Foreman said today he never thought he could lose to Muhammad Ali in their world heavyweight title fight last Wednesday and he gave only 50 per cent of his potential.

title: The House: Beyond N.Y.
description: In view of the seniority system's inhospitable atmosphere and the inadequate opportunities it offers to energetic, ambitious members in the House, it is striking that there are so many able men and women in the middle ranks who doggedly keep on working year after year and have substantial accomplishment to their credit. Among tomorrow's leaders of the House Democrats (outside the New York metropolitan area whom we have discussed in previous editorials) are several outstanding legislatorsSidney R. Yates of Illinois; Morris K. Udall of Arizona; John Moss, Phillip Burton, Don Edwards and Augustus Hawkins of California; John Brademas and Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana; John Dingell and James G. O'Hara of Michigan, and Donald Fraser of Minnesota  who have served for ten years or more and who are only now moving into subcommittee chairmanships.

title: Second Thoughts on Shale
description: DENERRemember the story about the hobo who knocks on the back door, holds up a rock and says he can turn it into a wonderful soup if he can just have access to your refrigerator?

title: UMass Falls, 4234, To Colgate
description: HAMILTON, N. Y., Nov.2 (UPI)Colgate stormed to a fourtouchdown lead and then hung on desperately to weather a late Massachusetts rally and defeat the Minutemen 4234 today.

title: Science Symposium Slated for Students
description: WEST LONG BRANCHStudents wishing to attend the Junior Science Symposium at Monmouth College and the Army Electronics Command at Fort Monmouth on March 6 and 7 must make application by tomorrow.

title: U.N. Parley on Women Draws Support
description: The scheduled United Nations conference on women Appeared to muster support as week representatives of member nations gathered to give their views of what the conference should be.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Princeton Examines Its Image
description: PRINCETONLast spring, Princeton University surprised the movie world when a film it commissioned, Princeton: A Search fdr Answers, won an Academy Award.

title: Changes in Social Security Law To Affect Tax and Income Limits
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) The Government has announced that it will take more Social Security taxes out of millions of upper income workers paychecks next year but allow retired persons to earn more money without losing Federal benefits.

title: SOVIET SPACECRAFT BEGINS MOON ORBIT
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 2 (UPI)The Soviet Union's automaed spacecraft Luna 23 went in orbit around the moon today, Tass, the press agency, said.

title: 2 Men Held in New Britain
description: NEW BRITAIN, Cont., Nov. 2 (UPI)Two New Britain men were questioned today concerning the robbery and six murders at the Donna Lee Bakery on Oct. 19 and then arrested on unrelated charges, New Britain police said. The police identified the men as Roland Piskorski and Gary Schrager, who were taken into custody last night on bench warrants at an undisclosed location. Mr. Schrager was charged with thirddegree assault and threat.

title: Better Quality of Goods Urged in Peking Press
description: PEKING, Nov. 2 (Agence FrancePresse)The Hsinhua press agency this week broached a subject rarely mentioned by the official Chinese press: the quality of consumer goods made in China.

title: Misplaced Circulars Get Special Delivery
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Nov. (AP)The United States Postal Service says that letter carriers had to make special deliveries at a cost of $4,000 in overtime to deliver 58,000 thirdclass advertising circulars it had misplaced.

title: Cosmos 692 Launched
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 2 (AP)The Soviet Union today launched Cosmos G92, the latest in its series of unmanned satellites, Tass press agency reported.

title: Daughter to Mrs. Dunn
description: A daughter was born Oct. 18 to Mr. and Mrs. M. Douglas Dunn of Chatham, N. J., at the New York LyingIn Hospital. The child has been named Gillian Elizabeth. Mr. Dunn is with the New York law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: In the Cambridge Camera ad of Sunday, Nov. 3, Drama Section, the last lens listed should be 75.26014.5T4 Zoom lens.

title: Plaints
description: It's a pleasure to have Wilfrid Sheed back in his monthly cage on Page 2, complete with tiger stripes, after almost a year of stalking the wild fiction in Sag Harbor. Our other monthly columnist, Victor Navasky, disappeared in June, shortly before the New York Democratic party's nominating convention, and is still at large. Instead of working on a novel, he has been managing a political campaign. What happens at the polls on Tuesday will determine whether he returns to serious business here or slouches south to cloud men's minds along the Potomac.

title: Art Pompier Revived at Hofstral
description: HEMPSTEADThe current exhibition of Art Pompier at Hofstra University's Emily Lowe Gallery is a chronometric miracle. Like Marcel Proust's madeline, it has the magical power to remove observers from the matteroffact everyday existence of the 20th century and transport them into a fantasy world of the 19th century.

title: 2 INMATES CASE CALLED MISTRIAL
description: 2 INMATES CASE CALLED MISTRIAL

title: The Sound of Laughter
description: When the time comes for me to pass on, check out, cross the bar, cash in my chips, expire, etc., I hope my soured old soul will carry with it a memory of the sound of children's laughter, which is somewhat akin to the pealing of heavenly bells. Children laugh at a wide variety of things, among which are funny faces, Punch and Judy, Jim Dale in Scapino, clowns, moron jokes, grapeetal, jokes, delicious terror, parents making fools of themselves, silliness, Danny Kaye, Abbott and Costello, slapstick and someone else's pratfall.

title: BUS ACCIDENTS GET FEW CHECKS BY U.S,
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2The Department of Transportation, apparently failing to fulfill, its responsibilities under its Congressional mandate, has not been investigating most accidents involving interstate buses, according to officials within the department.

title: Ashland Loses Its Appeal In a Water Pollution Case
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 2 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit has ruled that the Federal Government has jurisdiction in cases involving the pollution of nonnavigable waters.

title: Newark Gets Hispanic Judge
description: NEWARKJohn Dios, who was sworn in as a Municipal Court judge, last week, ascribes his appointment to the longterm political growth of Newark's Hispanic minority, not to the recent violent demonstrations by some of its members.

title: KARL MATHIASEN
description: Karl Mathiasen, who retired five years ago as president of the Federal Seaboard Terra Cotta Corporation of Perth Amboy, N.J., died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 300 West 108th Street.

title: Outstanding Books
description: CHILD OF FIRE. Scott O'Dell. (Houghton Mifflin. $5.95.) A powerful portrait of a young Chicano gang leader, who desperately looks for ways to prove his machismo and his fiery idealism.

title: Wood, Field&Stream Bidding a Fond Farewell to Fall
description: ARLINGTON, Vt.A few miles west of this hamlet the fabled Battenkill flowed across the Vermont  New York State border under a lowering late October sky.

title: Offices of U.S. Bank Are Attacked in Rome

title: A Home
description: One may be ravished unawares, without preparation or prior notice. Myself, I have spent no time to speak of in Sweden, and I never heard of Carl Larsson until today. (My loss. He was a painter, interior decorator and illustrator of substantial influence.) Also, I am no seeker after, nostalgia and am quite unable even to name many of the objects in Larsson's pictures. Yet am entirely content to find myself in the dazed condition of one who has had a revelation. The pictures in A Home speak with such eloquent and loving exactitude of a time and place (an artist's country home and family in Sundborn, Sweden, in the 1890's) as to give the pleasant illusion that one could write a novel about them with perfect accuracyfrom the sunlit absorption of CrayfishCatching Day on the river to the secrecy of the snowy farmyard with its sheaf of grain hung up for the birds from the owlheaded decanter to the curl on the end of Suzanne's braid as she bends over the churn.

title: Hearing Is Set for Boyle

The former president of the United Mine Workers of America was convicted in the 1969 slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski, an insurgent union leader, and his wife and daughter. Mr. Boyle, who is 72 years old and is serving a threeyear term at the Federal prison in Springfield, Mo., for illegally contributing union money to political campaigns, was convicted last April in the deaths of the. Yablonskis.

title: Discriminations
description: Once the brilliant young leftist Dwight Macdonald, now old Dwight, he has been around close to forever. He doesn't call himself a leftist anymore, but a conservative anarchist which, one hopes, is meant to suggest affinities with Henry Adams as well as with Paul Goodman and Norman Mailer. Mostly Macdonald just calls himself a critic, and while his new collection, Discriminations, goes back almost 40 years for some of its material, the most obvious revelation it offers is how little he has changed over the years. He uses midcult more and bourgeois less, he tends now to call U.S. Presidents consuls rather than capitalists, but the prose and the stance are still the same. His chosen task has been to be in the midst of things, detached, critical, looking straight at some target.

title: A Spate Of Sport
description: Sports books for children are the processed breakfast foods of publishing: Overpriced, gaudy packages of leftover facts and empty truths and guaranteed pre  digested sentences. Now that adult sports books frequently contain Marxist exegesis and /or Nixonian expletive, the childrens books are heading on beyond sepsis into a world so free from those minor upsets due to words that a current biography of Vince Lombardi can rehash his final illness, operations, death and funeral without using the word cancer.
