title: Screen: 'Little Prince':An Exasperating Film at the Music Hall
description: "The Little Prince," based on the late Antoine de Saint-Exupry's fable, is a very exasperating experience. It's the kind of movie that refers to adults as grown-ups to show us where it means its sympathies to be. Yet it's too abstract and sophisticated to be of interest to most children, and too simple-mindedly mystic and smug to charm even the most indulgent adult. You don't have to be W.C. Fields to want to swat it.More exasperating is that it's the first film musical in years to be directed by Stanley Donen, who has made some of the best ("Seven Brides for Seven Brothers," "Singin' in the Rain," "Fusny Face"), and its book and lyrics are by Alan Jay Lerner and its music is by Frederick Loewe. This score, the first Lerner-Loewe collaboration since "Gigi" and "Camelot," is full of lovely things that are a total waste in these barren circumstances.The film opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall.I doubt that anyone could make a really satisfactory movie out of the tiny Saint Exupry book, a fable about a pilot who crash-lands in the Sahara where, while he repairs his plane, he is befriended by a small extraterrestrial boy who happens to be on a sight-seeing tour of the universe.The pilot and the Little Prince talk at great length. The Little Prince reports on his own planet (which is the size of a house) and his earlier encounters on other planets with facetious caricatures, (all of which we see), but nothing much happens. So little happens, in fact, that the movie, which is stretched out with the Lerner-Loewe music, lasts only 88 minutes and seems at least five times that long.Even though "The Little Prince" is virtually a two-man musical supplemented by specialty numbers by a handful of other performers, it's been given the big movie-musical treatment (including a location trip to Tunisia), which simply emphasizes the coyness of its philosophy and the desperation of actors who never seem to know what kind of movie they're making.When Richard Kiley, who plays the pilot, races across the Sahara singing (in very good voice) a new Lerner-Loewe love song, Mr. Donen photographs him from what seems to have been a swooping helicopter. The song will sound great in the soundtrack album, but the actor, seen alternately in long shots and close-ups, appears to have lost his mind.Six-year-old Steven Warner, who plays the Little Prince, is a sweet-looking child who bears a strong resemblance to the original Saint-Exupry illustrations (the best things in the book), but since he is never more than a sweet-looking child, it's difficult to understand how he could prompt the stereophonic passions of the score. He has a delightful laugh, but the way things are done these days I wondered if it might be Mercedes McCambridge.Bob Fosse, an extraordinarily talented actor-director-dancer-choreographer, shows up ino in one sequence as the personification of the poisonous snake who finally provides the Little Prince with transportation home. What a child might make of this scene I can't imagine; Mr. Fosse, dressed like a 19th-century Chicago pimp, dances around the Sahara in those marvelously eccentric movements that look great when done by Gwen Verdon but embarrassing in this context.Less peculiar but not much more effective is Gene Wilder as a fox who hands on to the Little Prince one of the nuggets of wisdom that is supposed to make the movie meaningful. What is essential, says the fox, is invisible to the eye. Another variation is that "it's only with the heart that one can see clearly."This is the sort of gimcracky wisdom that only a self-absorbed adult could conceive of as being comprehensible to a child. When children imagine things, they see them. There is no nonsense about it. The imagined things are invisible only to jaded adults who patronize children and childhood, either because the real world is too much for them or because they don't know better.In addition to the score, particularly a song called "I've Never Loved a Rose," there are some other isolated good things in the movie, including the opening sequence in which a small boy tries to convince his elders that a picture he has drawn is not of a hat but the silhouette of a snake that has swallowed an elephant.There are lots of pleasures that children and adults can share: zoos, circuses, "Alice in Wonderland," Charlie Brown, roller coasters, hot dogs between meals. "The Little Prince" is not one of them.

title: Material Witness in Shooting of Judge In W anaque Is 2d Charged With Murder
description: PATERSON, Nov. 7Robert Carroll, who has been held for two days as a material witness in the murder of a Wanaque magistrate Monday night, was charged today with the murder.

title: FUCHSBERG WINS APPEALS CONTEST
description: Jacob D. Fuchsberg, the Manhattan trial lawyer whose election was opposed by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, has won a seat on the State Court of Appeals, based on a late counting of nearly complete returns.

title: City Finds Spoiled Food at 96 Stores; Starts New Drive and Asks New Law
description: In a survey of food stores here this week, city inspectors bought large quantities of food in leaking, rusted or bloated containers, some of it spoiledsuch as a twopound container of potato salad topped by greens mold.

title: City Rules Access To 2d Ave. Subway Is Special District
description: The city yesterday enacted zoning controls, the first of their kind, designed to assure that streetlevel entrances for the new Second Avenue subway will be spacious, protected from the weather and out of the way of sidewalk traffic.

title: Argentine Officer Is Killed as Rebels
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 7 (UPI) Gunmen shot and killed an Argentine army major and wounded his military bodyguard today in the first challenge to the Government's crackdown on guerrillas and its declaration of a nationwide state of siege.

title: 5 M.T.A. PROJECTS POSTPONED TO 87
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority disclosed yesterday that completion of five major projects including the rail link from Kennedy International. Airport to midtown Manhattan and the cup handle subway route on the Lower East Side, would be delayed at least Until 1987 under a major shift in construction plans.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS Nov. 7, 1974
description: Tickets matching only the last number become eligible for the millionaire semifinal drawing to be held later.

title: Protesters Picket WNCN Studios in Attempt to Force Return to Classical Format
description: About 100 protesters picketed the Starr Broadcasting Company's studios at 42 West 45th Street at noon yesterday as WNCNFM converted from classical programming to progressive rock, tinder the new call letters WQIVFM, after weeks of legal and regulatory delays.

title: Television
description: 5:57 (5)Friends

title: Cattlemen Ask Ford's Aid For Inquiry on Beef Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Nov., 7 (UPI) The American National Cattlemen's Association called on President Ford today to help find out why beef prices remain high in supermarkets despite ample supply in stockyards and on ranches.

title: RIOTING BREAKS OUT IN ANGOLAN CAPITAL
description: LUANDA, Angola, Nov. (Reuters)  Tension in this Portuguese territory erupted in rioting and shooting in a Luanda suburb last night, and radio and newspaper reports today said 50 people had been killed or injured.

title: 8% BROKER FEE RISE EXPECTED ON NOV. 19
description: The New York Stock Exchange disclosed here yesterday that an 8 per cent increase in commission fees on transactions between $5,000 and $300,000cleared on Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commissionis expected to go into effect on Nov. 19.

title: Neighborhood Restaurant of 1974's Vertical Society
description: The way I remember it, neighborhood restaurant in New York used to mean a cozy place with some straggly, sunstarved plants in the front window, oilcloth on the tables, about 20 chairs, no menu and either mama or madame combining cookery and table service with social pleasantries among the habitues.

title: Tarnished Justice
description: By turning a Civil Court judge who was about to be tried for conspiracy into an undercover agent, and then letting him off the hook by a form of judicial plea bargaining, Special State Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari has engaged in highly questionable practices. No matter what leads may be developed for future indictments, spies in the courthouse equipped with recording devices give the criminal justice system a criminal air.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Use of Repudiated Confession Barred The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that prosecutors might not disclose to a jury that a criminal defendant originally pleaded guilty but then withdrew and pleaded not guilty. In a 7to0 decision, the court established a precedent in the state that revelations of retracted guilty pleas are prejudicial to defendants.

title: Lame Ducks in State Jobs Paddling to New Waters
description: Having grown up in the labor movement, I don't get panicky at the prospect of losing a job, Louis L. Levine, the New York State Industrial Commissioner, was saying yesterday. I'm one of those familiar with standing on unemployment lines.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.04billion, up 5 per cent from the yearearlier $995million. Total retail store sales were about $10.41billion, up 6 per cent from last year's $9.83billion.

title: Arson Suspect's Bail Is Set
description: OCEAN CITY, Nov. 7 (AP)An Ocean City man is being held in $100,000 bail in this Cape May County community on three charges of arson and two of attempted arson. The man, Alfred Pular, 67 years old, was arrested Tuesday night outside a delicatessen at 340 Ocean Avenue. The police said the address, which includes several apartment residences, had been the scene of five fires since March 9. They said none of the fires caused serious damage.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: BYRNE STAYS RISE IN TURNPIKE TOLL
description: TRENTON, Nov. 7Governor Byrne effectively blocked today a move by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority to increase is tolls by 37 per cent.

title: ARMED BOY ON ROOF SHOT DEAD BY POLICE
description: A 17yearold boy was shot and killed by two policemen early yesterday morning as he crouched on a roof and pointed an underwater spear gun at an officer investigating a burglary at a store in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: Nessen Has a NIM Button
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) The White House press secretary, Ron Nessen wore his WIN (whip inflation now) button uphide down today his daily briefing. It reads NIM no immediate miracles, he joked.

title: Today's Entries at Monmouth
description: Today's Entries at Monmouth

title: White House Now Oppoies Minimums on Air Charters
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7In what appeared to be a major reversal of Administration poiicy, a Justice Department official said today that the Government now opposed establishing minimum price guidelines for transAtlantic charter air fares.

title: 96% Tally Shows He Beat Stevens by 81,133 Votes
description: Jacob D. Fuchsberg, the Man hattan trial lawyer whose election was opposed by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, has won a seat on the State Court of Appeals, based on a late counting of nearly complete returns.

title: Domed Arenas, Financed by Bonds, Planned for Four State Sites
description: Warning that time was running out, the New York Sports Authority disclosed plans yesterday to make the the Empire State No. 1 again in professional athletics.

title: FOODRICH LANDS WEIGH A PROGRAM TO FIGHT HUNGER
description: ROME, Nov. 7Major grainproducing nationsincluding the United States, the Soviet Union and Chinahave agreed to consider a program to limit their foreign sales in an effort to free grain supplies for emergency aid to hungry people.

title: Capital Spending by Industry Expected to Rise 12% to a Peak
description: Industry's capital spending plans for 1975 will rise by a projected 12 per cent to a record $125.38billion, but will give little additional strength to the economy, McGraw  Hill Publications said yesterday.

title: People in Sports
description: Because of missing treatments for his strained right knee and for walking out of the Miami Dolphins camp on Wednesday, Mercury Morris was suspended indefinitely yesterday by Coach Don Shula. A spokesman for the Dolphins said Shula would reconsider the suspension on Monday, after a game against the New Orleans Saints, but would answer no questions on the subject.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Nov. 7Seton Hall from South Orange and Upsala from East Orange will clash in the Oranges Bowl Saturday. It will be the third meeting between the schools. Upsala won the first two games.

title: New Lottery in Jersey Has a $250,000 Prize
description: The New Jersey Lottery Commission announced yesterday that because of declining tickets sales it would institute a simplified lottery, with sales starting on Nov. 20. The first drawing under the new lottery will be on Dec. 5.

title: Judge Rules on Ousted Widow's Estate
description: HACKENSACK, Nov. 7One of the preliminary questions involved in the determination of who will inherit the $500,000 in cash and real estate left by Mrs. Marian Greenberg Parker, the 72yearold widow who committed suicide last August after being evicted from her home by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, was settled here today by Superior Court Judge George F. Gelman.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Not long after Simon Gourdine joined the National Basketball Association staff four years ago, he and Commissioner Walter Kennedy were attempting to unwind in their offices high in 2 Penn Plaza from another fullcourt press by one of their contentious club owners.

title: Coroner's Jury Clears Doctor Of Negligence in Abortion Case
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7 (AP) A coroner's jury today exonerated a doctor of allegations that a baby was allowed to die on a hospital table after surviving an abortion.

title: Market, in Higher Range, Finishes With Small Gain
description: The stock market moved in a higher range throughout most of yesterday's session and finished with a moderate gain in active trading.

title: SchoolAudit Unit Is Called a Failure
description: A confidential report made yesterday by Deputy School Chancellor Bernard R. Gifford has declared that the investigative arm of the Board of Education's office of audit and investigation is now virtually nonexisent.

title: Braves Trade Frisella
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 7 (AP)The Atlanta Braves traded a righthanded reliever, Danny Frisella, to the San Diego Padres tonight for Clarence Gaston, outfielder.

title: Canucks Triumph Over Scouts, 64
description: KANSAS CITY, Nov. 7 (AP)  The regular goalie, Gary Smith, replaced Ken Lockett in the nets for the final 14 minutes tonight and the Vancouver Canucks scored two late goals for a 64 triumph over the Kansas City Scouts. Vancouver blew three leads before Smith took over with the score at 4all.

title: Peru's Junta, After 6 Years, Still Has Little Support
description: LIMA, Peru, Nov 1After six years in power the leftist military Government that has vowed to carry out a revolutionary, transformation of Peruvian society still appears to lack significant popular support.

title: Mass. Factory Burns
description: LOWELL, Mass., Nov. 7 (AP) A fouralarm fire destroyed tonight a fourfloor brick factory building that housed the Pellon Corporation. There were no reports of injuries.

title: FRANK L. M'NAMEE
description: Frank L. McNamee, former president of the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League, died Wednesday in a Cleveland hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Aetna Now Reported New Suitor for Avis
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company yesterday became the second publicly known suitor for Avis, Inc., the carrental company.

title: The Major Events of the Day FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1974 News Summary and Index
description: In what was regarded as a major accomplishment at the World Food Conference in Rome, the principaI grain producing nations including the United States, the Soviet Union and Chinahave agreed to consider a program to limit their foreign sales in an effort to free grain supplies for emergency aid to hungry people. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Bob Kennedy Dead at 41; Chicago TV Broadcaster
description: Bob Kennedy, a Chicago broadcaster who had been scheduled to become Midwest correspondent for the ABC HA:M. America show in January, died of cancer Tuesday in Northwestern Memorial Hospital, Chicago. He was 41 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Mideast Forebodings War Widely Expected Within a Year If Kissinger Can't Win Breakthrough
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 7 Secre tary of State Kissinger's arrival in Israel today comes at a crucial point in the United States mediation efforts, with Arab and Israeli leaders agreed that unless some political breakthrough is achieved, a new round of fighting is all but inevitable in the next 6 to 12 months. This mutual foreboding about the possibility of renewed fighting emerged from a twoweek journey through the area that included stops on both sides of the political fence.

title: Coed Dorms: Living Is Easy, Not Perfect
description: A book in the door, and three feet on the floor may have set limits to the way college students, males and females, could meet alone in the past, but to students today, used to sexual freedom, such rules sound more ancient than Plato.

title: SOCIAL ACTION HIT BY FINANCIALWOES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7The National Welfare Rights Organization, which rose to become one of the nation's most potent voices for poor people, has run out of money and is searching for a way to survive.

title: Lame Ducks in State Jobs Paddling to New Waters
description: Having grown up in the labor movement, I don't get paa nicky at the prospect of losing a job, Louis L. Levine, the New York State Industrial Commissioner, was saying yesterday. I'm one of those familiar with standing on unemployment lines.

title: Bench and Politics
description: An analysis of the vote in judicial contestsranging from the statewide race for Court of Appeals to local Civil Court judgeshipsreveals that, as usual, voters in most counties merely followed the party line. If a judicial candidate was on the CareyKrupsak ticket, his election was virtually assured. The prospect of an independent judiciary, free from political coattails, has hardly been enhanced by this election.

title: Newburgh Sets Up Curfew As Disturbance Persists
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Nov. 7A citywide curfew was imposed on Newburgh tonight after a second day of disturbances in tne East black community, where hundreds of young people took to the streets, throwing sticks and stones and molotov cocktails.

title: Democrats Invite Carey To Governors' Session
description: Democrats Invite Carey To Governors' Session

title: Rangers Click on Line Change
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 7 The notable success of four rearranged lines in last night's 73 victory over the California Golden Seals, and now two days to practice in this area before the next game in Los Angeles Saturday night, have brightened the New York Ranger mood.

title: PRICES ADVANCE ON AMEX O.T.C
description: Prices rose on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market yesterday as volume dropped slightly.

title: ERIC LINKLATER, WRITER, DIES AT 76
description: LONDON, Nov. 7Eric Linklater, novelist, playwright and biographer, died in Aberdeen, Scotland, today at the age of 75. He had been in a nursing home for several weeks.

title: Recently Published Books
description: Catnapped: The Further Adventures of Undercover Cat, by the Gordons (Doubleday, $5.95).

title: World Football League
description: World Football League

title: Another First for 74
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) Joseph Fisher is proof of the prediction that 1974 was to be a big year for women and Democrats. Democrat Fisher defeated Republican Joel T. Broyhill in Virginia's Tenth District, a seat he held for 22 years, and in doing so became the first male member of the League of Women Voters to go to Congress. A new bylaw to give men equal rights was adopted last May, and Mr. Fisher promptly joined up.

title: Johnson Worries Giants
description: A sore knee forced on Johnson to sit out practice yesterday, and threw an element of doubt into the New York. Giant running back's availability for Sunday's game against the Jets at Yale Bowl.

title: Returns Day in Delaware
description: GEORGETOWN, Del. Nov. 7 (AP)Carrying on a 19thcentury tradition, politicians and voters gathered for Returns Day on the town green here today to hear the town crier pronounce the election news that everybody already knew. So there were no surprises as the town crier, Ronald Dodd, a local undertaker, called out the final canvassed vote count from a balcony of the Sussex County Courthouse.

title: Madison Democratic Club Brings Influence to Brooklyn
description: Stanley Steingut was sitting in his Manhattan law office yesterday, remembering a remark his mother made to him at Mayor Beame's inauguration.

title: Giants Favored, but Not by Television
description: The Giants are favored by a touchdown over the Jets for their game Sunday at New Haven, where the Yale Bowl will not be filled. That is a break for television fans because the contest will therefore not be televised here. The Redskins against the Eagles, the more worthy replacement, will be seen on Channel 2, starting at 1 P.M. To complete the video doubleheader, Channel 4 will televise Pittsburgh at Cincinnati, 4 P.M. The Monday night game should be a good one matching probable playoff teams, Minnesota and St. Louis, Channel 7, 9 P.M. Here is a preview of all games with wonlosttied records in parentheses.

title: Post No.3 Is Given To Dahlia
description: LAUREL, Md., Nov. 7Dahlia, the Kentuckybred filly who has raced brilliantly through most of her career in Europe, and with complete success in her three appearances on this conAt the tinent, is getting better all the Race time. At least, Tracks that is the comment offered today by Maurice Zilber, who trains the 4yearold for Nelson Bunker Hunt. Zilber offered his analysis at the draw for post positions for the $150,000 Washington, D. C. International, which will have its 23d consecutive running at the Laurel Race Course on Saturday. Dahlia won the 1973 renewal and her trainer suggested that there was no reason why she should no repeat.

title: Nursing Student Slain On Campus at Wagner
description: A. 19yearold woman nursing student at Wagner College was stabbed to death on the Staten Island campus yesterday evening during an attack on a main walkway in view of passing students.

title: U.S. Ships to Indian Ocean
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (Reuters)A United States navar task force, including the arcraft carrier Constellation and three destroyers, left Singapore today on one of the fleets periodic visits to the Indian Ocean, the Defense Department said.

title: 26 FURTHER TAPES CLEARED BY SIRICA
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7Judge John J. Sirica ruled today that the prosecution had provided enough proof of the authenticity of 26 additional White House tape recordings to enable it to introduce them as evidence at the Watergate coverup trial.

title: Harvard, Yale in Countdown
description: Harvard and Yale, both with 4.0 wonlost records in Ivy League competition, seem on a collision course leading to the championship in Cambridge, Mass., Nov. 23. However, there Ivy are one or two slight confrontaLeague tions the Crimson Roundup no Elis must cope with before then, and in the, unpredictable world of the Ivies, anything can happen and often does.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Penn Central Company, the corporate shell that holds all the stock of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad, yesterday was enjoined by Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia from proceeding with an action against the Federal Government in the United States. Court of Claims.

title: InterAmerican Blueprint
description: A privatelyfunded commission headed by former Ambassador Sol M. Linowitz has produced a report that could vastly improve this country's relations with Latin America if carried out by the Administration and Congress. The great virtue of this effort is that it substitutes specific recommendations33 in allfor the highflown rhetoric that has characterized too many previous United States initiatives in the hemisphere.

title: Indian Boy Sues School Over Curb on Long Hair
description: SAN FRANCISCO, NOV, 7 (AP)A 5yearold Indian boy has filed suit in Federal court against San Joaquin Valley school officials who will not let him wear his hair long in traditional Indian fashion.

title: Analysts Surprised as Money Supply Shrinks Again
description: In a dramatic swing that surprised the money market, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday that New York bank business loans increased sharply and that the money supply shrank for the second straight week.

description: Summary

title: Business Records
description: TWIGGS SPORTSWEAR, INC. 498 Seventh Ave., N.Y. Petitioners are Martin Lacktit: and Elfriede Lackritz.

title: An ExPoliceman Indicted In 1970 Holdup Attempt
description: A former Queens policeman11970 was named yesterday as they mastermind behind a carefully planned $1million Wells Fargo armored truck robbery in 1970 that went awry minutes after the truck pulled away from a curb in midtown Manhattan.

title: General Dynamics Net Up By 23.4% in Third Quarter
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, now the nation's largest defense contractor, reported last night higher sales and profits for the third quarter and the first nine months this year.

title: Dr. Dan, Successor to Thieu?
description: DEKALB, IIIBroad opposition to President Ngu'en Van Thieu's leadership has been mounting steadily.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Byrne yesterday effectively blocked a move by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority to increase its tolls by 37 per cent. The Governor asked authority officials to reexamine the financial reasons for the increase, and to return with some major downward revisions, The authority, aware of the Governor's intentions, withdrew the request for his approval for the increase, which would have gone into effect on Jan. 1.

title: Women Charge The Times With Sex Discrimination
description: Six women employes charged The New York Times yesterday with sex discrimination in a class action suit filed in Federal District Court.

title: HISTORIAN REPORTED ILL IN SOVIET JAIL
description: Valentyn Moroz, a 38yearold Ukrainian nationalist and historian jailed by the Soviet since 1970, was reported yesterday to have been afflicted by liver and heart ailments since he began a hunger strike in Vladimir prison outside Moscow on July 1.

title: Radio
description: 67 WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Cello Conc'rto in C, Haydn; L'Arlesienne Suite No. 2, Bizet.

title: William Gardner. Smith, Author And Newspaperman, Dies at 47
description: PARIS, Nov. 7  William Gardner Smith, an American writer and newspaperman, died here Tuesday. He was 47 years old.

title: A.E.C. Gives Plan For Tight Security At Nuclear Plants
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today new security measures it plans to impose on nuclear power plants and fuel shippers to guard against sabotage and the theft of nuclear materials.

title: Hawks Lead Suns by 24, Scramble to Win, 109108
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 7 (AP) Mike Sojourner, a rookie, scored on a Iayup with eight seconds remaining, triggering the Atlanta Hawks to a 109108 National Basketball Association victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight.

title: McCall Backs Outdoor Lights
description: PORTLAND, Ore. Nov. 7. (UPI)  Gov. Tom McCall has given his official approval to outdoor Christmas tree lighting this year. Last year, because of of a shortage of electricity, he discouraged outdoor lighting during the holiday season.

title: G.A.O.Report Says $1Billion System
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) Congressional auditors said today that the Postal Service was investing nearly $1billion in a mechanized, centralized system that will often result in slower delivery of parcels. The Postal Service denied the criticism.

title: CITY REPORT FINDS BUILDING INDUSTRY INFESTED BY GRAFT
description: A report of widespread corcuption in the construction industry made public yesterday by Mayor Beame implicated 170 city employes and 63 executives representing every phase of the industry in bribery charges.

title: REVOLT PUT DOWN, BOLIVIA DECLARES
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 7(UPI) President Hugo Barrzer Suarez took command of loyalist troops today and crushed an army rebellion in the city of Santa Cruz de la Sierra, in the southeast, the state radio said. A state of siege was declared in this landlocked Andean country of more than five million people.

title: Do Right Victor in Puissance at Garden
description: Do Right, the sturdy 7yearold jumper who was sold last year because his owners felt the gelding was too nervous, last night rose to his greatest heights at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

title: G.O.P. Suffers Setbacks In the State Legislatures
description: The Democratic tide in the elections Tuesday wiped out Republican control of one or both houses of the legislatures in 13 states and severely eroded Republican minorities in many other state legislatures around the country.

title: Music: Hanani, Cellist
description: Yehuda Hanani's cello recital Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall left one in no doubt about his talent, and it succeeded in sketching out a clear picture of his musical personality. The young Israeli played with exceptional technical assurance and drew a large, rich tone from his instrument.

title: Weeden & Co. Profits Soar
description: Weeden & Co., stockbrokers, reported yesterday that profits during October, the first month of its 1975 fiscal year, soared to $1.5million, or 90 cents a share, from $180,000, or 10 cents a share, a year earlier. The concern, which deals in Big Board stocks although it is not a Big Board member, attributed the showing to high profits in bond trading.

title: Organist Free on Bail Raised by Pastor
description: TORRINGTON, Conn., Nov. 7 Gary Wayne Carr, the 27yearold Sharon, Conn., church organist and choir director whose arrest last week on charges of arson and burglary stunned residents of the affluent community, was released from jail today after members of the church congregation raised $7,500 to his bail.

title: Price of One Gasoline Is Up And Another Goes Down
description: Two oil companies announced price changes yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: Jacob D. Beam, a career diplomat for more than 40 years and Ambassador to the Soviet Union when he retired in 1972, has been elected chairman of Radio Free Europe, to succeed Gen. Lucius D. Clay.

title: India Shifting Policy To Get Major Help From U.S. on Food
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 7India plans to receive at least one million tons of food on easy terms from the United States over the next year, Indian official sources said today.

title: ' Whole Earth Catalog' Recycled as 'Epilog'
description: The Whole Earth Catalog, which folded its dome three years ago at the height of its success, is back, chock full of the latest ideas in organic gardening, windmills, ecology, solar energy, marijuana, ceramics and sexual techniques.

title: FAMILY DECLINES TO SEEK AID
description: ALAMAGORDO, N.M., Nov. 7 (UPI)They're proud people; it could have been a religous question with them, a hospital official said today of a wandering family of six. Penniless, hungry and out of food, they sat for days in a stalled an along a highway without seeking any help while the father and a daughter died.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: A Golden Day for Fishing
description: EAGLEVILLE, N.Y.  The river was mine, and I was the river's.

title: Rockefeller On the Sidelines
description: On the morning after the election, Nelson Rockefeller spent hours on the phone in his Manhattan office congratulating the winners and consoling the losers. Nothing seems to subdue or depress this man. 'll his party's troubles all his family anxieties, all the opposition to his confirmation as Vice President of the United States merely seem to have liberated his boundless supply of energy and optimism.

title: GENERAL TELEPHONE PLANS STOCK OFFER
description: Directors of General Telephone and Electronics Corporation authorized yesterday the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public sale of 6 million common shares.

title: U.S. Officials Divided
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 United States officials were divided today in reaction to the Chinese message calling for a nonaggression pact with the Soviet Union. Most saw it as nothing new; some said it could have important meaning.

title: New State Lottery To Let Winner Vie For $250,000 Prize
description: The State Lottery Commission announced yesterday that because of declining ticket sales it would institute simplified weekly lottery, with sales of tickets starting Nov. 20.

title: About Real Estate
description: First there was Joseph Kalikow. He built apartments in Brooklyn in the nineteentwenties and thirties, and in the late thirties he built them in Queens. Then there were his sons Harold, Nathaniel and Sidney. They built apartments too, but they parted ways in 1967. They are still at it, separately.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: Federal Reserve Statement

title: Manila Halts the Export Of Sugar After Storms
description: MANILA, Nov. 7 (UPI)The Philippine Government ordered the suspension of trading and export of sugar today in the wake of a chain of six storms that destroyed cane still in the fields.

title: Sirica Sometimes Runs Court With a Schoolmaster's Manner
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7There are moments in the Watergate cover  up trial when Judge John J. Sirica seems like a schoolrnaster and his courtroom like a schoolroom.

title: STATE IS SCORED ON MENTAL CARE
description: Leaders of the city's most important voluntary mentalhealth agencies conferred yesterday with a representative of Governorelect Hugh L. Carey on the majot shortcomings of the state's mentalhealth proding and methods of overhauling it.

title: Auto Output Slumps
description: Automobile production in the United States is expected to be off nearly 15 per cent this week from the level in the corresponding period a year earlier and the slump is being felt by some of the industry's big suppliers. Details on Page 57.

title: A Federal Judge Upholds Sex Criteria in the Army
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (AP)  A Federal judge has ruled that there is no discrimination in the Army's policy of requiring different ages and educational standards for male and female soldiers.

title: Battle for Soul of G.O.P. In State Is Seen by Javits
description: Weary after a hardfought election campaign, Senator cob K. Javits vowed yesterday to enlist on the progressive side of what he foresaw as upcoming battle for the soul and ideology of the Republican party in New York and the nation.

title: Aspects and Prospects
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7Random notes on the election results: Maybe 1976 will be the year when one of the major parties could profitably put a black or a woman on its national ticket. Both did well in Congressional, state and local campaigns this year and both have been doing well enough for some time now to provide a small stable of experienced officeholders and proven votegetters. Such an offbeat ticket would instantly lift the party sponsoring it out of the ruck of politicsasusual. Against FordRockefeller ticket, for example, the Democrats could do a lot worse than to run, say, Tom Bradley, the black Mayor of Los Angeles, or Ella Grasso the new Governor of Connecticut, for Vice President. The Democrats probably will do worse, too.

title: U.S. and Spain Recess Talks On Use of Military Bases
description: MADRID, Nov. 7 (UPI) The United States and Spain today ended the first round of formal talks aimed at renewing their agreement on American use of Spanish military bases.

title: Volkswagen Official Replaced: Split on U.S. Plant Is a Factor
description: BONN, Nov. 7Hans Birnbaum, 62 years old, the head of the Governmentowned Salzgitter steel workers was named yesterday by the supervisory board of Volkswagen in Wolfsburg to replace Dr. Josef Rust as its chairman.

title: Administration Indicates Doubt on Energy Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7The White House indicated today that President Ford might be having second thoughts about his announced intention to nominate Andrew E. Gibson as Federal Energy Administrator.

title: Contract Award
description: Contracts totaling $109.7million have been received by the Boeing Company from the Air Force. One, of $103.3million, involves the purchase of six 707type planes and spare engines that will be sold to a foreign country, according to the Pentagon, which refused to identify the country. Sources said the nation involved was Iran.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS Nov. 7, 1974
description: N. J. Weekly002821

title: Workers in Richest Philippine Sugar Region Are Still Untouched by Boom
description: BACOLOD, the PhilippinesIn the hope of undermining the powerful sugar oligarchy, Philippine social reformers have long dreamed of the day when the sugar industry would lose its guarantee of access to the lucrative American market and would face a government in Manila strong enough to take big tax bite out of its profits.

title: SEAMAN ASSAILS CAMPS IN SOVIET
description: Simas Kudirka, the Lithuanian seaman whose attempt four years ago to escape from a Soviet trawler led to his forcible capture and imprisonment in the Soviet Union, yesterday thanked those who had campaigned for his release and for his right to leave the Soviet Union as an American citizen.

title: Fla. State Wins After 20 Defeats
description: MIAMI, Nov. 8 (AP)Florida State snapped the nation's longest collegiate football losing streak at 20 games tonight as Leon Bright and Jeff Leggett ran for touchdowns and Joe Goldsmith scored on a 48yard pass play in a 2114 upset of the University of Miami.

title: Montreal Police Announce Arrests of 3 in Coin Theft
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 8 (UPI)The police here announced today that they were holding three Americans in connection with the multimilliondollar theft of ancient Greek and Roman coins from Harvard University's Fogg Museum last December.

title: Bridge: Italy and Sweden in a Battle For European Championship
description: TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 8The European open bridge championship here has developed into a battle between Italy and Sweden. Italy, lacking almost all its world champion players, held a slender lead with nine rounds completed, but has o somewhat harder program of opponents than Sweden in the remaining 10 rounds.

title: 100 Protest a P.U.C. Ryle
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 8 (UPI)  More than 100 people, most of them aged, walked out of a hearing on rate increases for the Atlantic City Electric Company to protest a Public Utilities Commission rule barring cameras or tape recorders. The hearing was on a 17 per cent rate increase sought by the utility. Paul Doyle, head of a citizens group, said they, were also protesting because none of the commission members attended the hearing. The commission chairman, Anthony J. Grossi, has said that the rule exists because the commission is considered a quasi legislative body and the devices are not permitted at legislative sessions.

title: SIRICA WILL SEND DOCTORS TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Federal Judge John J. Sirica said today that he would appoint a panel of three leading doctors to examine Richard M. Nixon to determine whether the former President would be Able to provide testimony for the Watergate coverup trial.

title: Wilson Gives Ghezzi Title As His Secretary of State
description: ALBANY, Nov. 8 (AP)Governor Wilson has named John Ghezzi, who has been serving as Acting Secretary of State for 10 months, to be Secretary of State.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: Mr. Ford's Chance for Greatness
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8If President Ford were a cruel man he could spoil the Democrats triumphal hour by announcing his resignation at once. There is every sensible reason for him to do so. It would be good for Gerald Ford and good for the Republican party. In fact, it might very well be the salvation of the Republican party.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: A free Sunday oasis of classical music played by young professional musicians in a midtown restaurant, including reasonably priced food and refreshments, will be inaugurated tomorrow at Mykonos (2651590), at 349 West 46th Street (between Eighth and Ninth Avenue). Under the label of The Musicians Salon, three successive Sunday sessions, organized by Barbara Markay, a 22yearold composer and pianist, will continue from 11 A.M. until 11 P.M., with piano, vocal and chamber selections by students and graduates of the Juilliard School and other major conservatories.

title: Money
description: Money

title: Connie Francis. Raped at Motel After Singing at Westbury Fair
description: MINEOLA, LI., Nov. 8Connie Francis, the singer, was raped at knifepoint early this morning in her room at the Howard Johnson Motor Lodge in Westbury after having sung at the Westbury Music Fair, the Nassau County police reported.

title: AntiAbortion Spot Seen as Editorial
description: AntiAbortion Spot Seen as Editorial

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: LOCAL

title: 44 Saigon Legislators Complain To U.S. Congress About Thieu
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 8A group of 44 opposition legislators called on the United States Congress today to use its influence to stop the repressive tactics of the South Vietnamese Government.

title: Manville Woman, 60, Killed By Train in New Brunswick
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 8 (UPI)A Manville woman was, killed at about 1 P.M. today, when she stumbled on a platform of Penn Station here and was struck by a passing freight, train, the police reported.

title: In Quito Now, Even Day of Dead Is Lively
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 8Everybody used to say that Quito was too high up for international conferences, recalled an ambassador who has been stationed here for several years. You won't hear that anymore. The city is 9,000 feet above sea level, tucked away in valleys and bluffs and surrounded by pinecovered Andean mountains and snowcapped volcanic peaks.

title: A Company Policy
description: SOUTH WINDSOR, Conn., Nov. 8 (AP)Charles MacArthur, a businessman who underwent a vasectomy 12 years ago, is now offering to underwrite sterilization for any of his male or female employes.

title: SADIE G. LOUIS
description: SADIE G. LOUIS Sadie Glick Louis, a leader in Jewish philanthropy, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 82 years old and lived at 12 (West 72d Street.

title: Hugh Carey's Choice Patrick Joseph Cunningham
description: Last spring, some students invited Patrick J. Cunningham of the Bronx to speak at Harvard, a place where the study of politics ranges from 18thcentury theories to computerized voter surveys, but not very often to the clubhouse world of New York.

title: General Revises Account of Spying on U.S. Civilians in Germany
description: BONN, Nov. 8The United States Army's highestranking intelligence officer here has made a new sworn court statement modifying his response of last June to a lawsuit charging illegal surveillance of American citizens.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: CAMPAIGN FUND LAW SETS 3YEAR LIMIT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI)  A loophole in the new campaign finance law permits those who made and received illegal campaign contributions during the 1972 Congressional races to avoid prosecution, a spokesman for the Watergate prosecutors said today.

title: Ouster of Indians From Amazon Lands Is Charged
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8A group of anthropologists and political activists accused multinational corporations and the Government of Brazil today of conspiring to drive Indian tribes from their native grounds along the Amazon River in an effort to encourage industrial development.

title: Books of The Times
description: There are only a few American autobiographies of surpassing greatnessBenjamin Franklin's, Frederick Douglass's, Henry Adams's, Booker T. Washington's and Theodore Dreiser'sand now there is another one, Nate Shaw's. It joins the small pantheon while simultaneously enhancing it with a work that is at once powerful, unfettered and genuine. But what really lifts it to the highest rank is that Nate Shaw, in telling about himself, enlightens us about his times and his culture. A whole way of life in America is expounded through the experience of one man, who stretch[ed] my eyes at conditions and abominat[ed] what I seed.

title: A Marriage Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)Americans are getting married less and divorced more than in the past, according to a Census Bureau report.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Hockey, Basketball Standings

title: Arafat Says U.S. Holds Key to Mideast
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 8Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, said today that peace in the Middle East would remain distant until the United States recognized the right of the Palestinian people to, statehood and ceased what he said was the arming of Israel for another war.

title: Judge Acquits Guardsmen In Slayings at Kent State
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 8The chief judge of the Federal District Court here acquitted eight former Ohio National Guardsmen today in the 1970 Kent State shootings. In a sudden and dramatic end to the trial that began Oct. 29, Judge Frank J. Battisti held that the Government prosecutors had not proved beyond a reasonable doubt that the guardsmen willfully intended to deprive the students of their civil rights.

title: Cairo Sees No Gain by Kissinger
description: CAIRO, Nov. 8Seen from Cairo, Secretary of State Kissinger's swing through the Middle East fulfilled a vital psychological purposestilling fears that the door to negotiation would be shut but it brought no substantive gains toward a political settlement between the Arabs and Israel. Reports from Jerusalem today made it clear, Egyptians said, that the Secretary has received no new ideas from the Israelis worth subto Egypt.

title: WNCN, WQIV, F.C.C.
description: Loyal listeners who tuned into classical music station WNCNFM hoping to hear Beethoven's Eroica symphony instead heard a progressiverock number called Roll Over Beethoven this week. Beethoven must indeed be whirlingcertainly serious music fans are steaming now that WQIVFM is operating on the WNCNFM frequency. Despite legal action taken to protest the change in format that gives metropolitan New York listeners still another rock radio station, the Federal Communications Commission is dragging its affidavits.

title: BLUMENTHAL JOB IS PUT IN DOUBT
description: A movement is under way in several parts of the new Democratic majority in the Assembly to deny the No. 2 post of majority leader to Albert H. Blumenthal, a liberal Democrat from Manhattan.

title: Flames Defeat Hawks by 20
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 8 (AP)Curt Bennett and Tom Lysiak each scored for Atlanta as the Flames stretched their unbeaten string to 11 games at home tonight whipping the Chicago Black Hawks, 2.0 in a National Hockey League game.

title: 2,500 TURKS PROTEST U.S. CYPRUS POLICY
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 8 (AP)Some 2,500 university students staged an antiAmerican protest in Istanbul today, burning an American flag and accusing the United States of carrying out a twofaced treacherous policy over Cyprus.

title: People in Sports Tom Van Arsdale Is Traded to Hawks
description: Clyde Lee's stay in Atlanta was a short one. The 6foot10inch forwardcenter, who on Oct. 4 was dealt to the Atlanta Hawks by the Golden State Warriors to complete a transaction involving Zelmo Beaty, was traded yesterday with a thirdround draft pick to the Philadelphia 76ers for Tom Van Arsdale, a forward.

title: Puerto Rican Rider Triumphs in Jump
description: A former race horse, Don Juan, and a winner at that, achieved a National Horse Show milestone last night when he carried Juan Rieckehoff to victory in the jump for the Volco Trophy. It was the first time a rider from Puerto had triumphed in the international competition.

title: $330Million Reduction in Pay and Services Ordered by Beame
description: Responding to what he called an emergency and a totally unheard of situation brought on by inflation and the recession, Mayor Beame is ordering a new round of budgetary belttightening that will cut city payrolls and services by $330million. He had earlier ordered reductions of $100million.

title: PAROLE OF CALLEY GRANTED BY ARMY EFFECTIVE NOV.19
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 Former Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who was convicted of murdering 22 South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai in 1968, will be paroled later this month, the Army announced tonight.

title: Knicks LineUp
DR. JAMES CUSICK
description: Dr. James T. Cusick, a physiological chemist and former member of the Cornell University faculty, died Nov. in Hammondsport, N. Y., where he had conducted research on wine fermentation. He was 91 years old.

title: Hialeah Sale Is Delayed Until 1975
description: MIAMI, Nov. 8Hialeah Race Course has been reprieved and will open on schedule next Jan. 17 for what undoubtedy will be its last hurrah. The agreement to sell the track's franchise and dates to Gulfstream Park was deferred today until next year.

title: RollsRoyce, After 71 Collapse,. Now Yielding Windfall Profits
description: LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP)RollsRoyce, Ltd., is producing a windfall profit for shareholders who picked up its stock at pennies a share when the company went into receivership in February, 1971.

title: Evening Law Programs Voted by Rutgers Board
description: NEW BRUNSWICK. Nov. 8The Rutgers University Board of Governors today approved resolution to institute parttime evening programs at the university's Newark and Camden law schools in September, 1975.

title: Ash Sees a Possible Plea For Social Security Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (Reuters)Roy Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today there was a possibility that the Administration would ask for cuts in socalled income transfer social programs such as Social Security in the budget for the fiscal year 1976.

title: British Football
description: Doncaster Rovers 1, Shrewsbury Town 3. Lincoln City 3, Torquay United 1. Swansea City 0, Rotherham United 2. Workington 2, Reading 1.

title: Ali Honored in the City That Remembers Him When
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 8 They named a street after Muhammad Ali in his hometown today, but Mabel Clark still called him Cassius.

title: BAUXITE GROUP ENDS MEETING ON PRICING
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 8 (Reuters)An International Bauxite Association ministerial council meeting ended sere early today with a broad measure of agreement on several issues but no firm decisions n the crucial areas of pricing and taxation.

title: Tax Discrepancy Found in Data On Rockefeller's Gifts to Ronan
description: A discrepancy in tax data on Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller's $510,000 in gifts to Dr. William J. Ronan has turned up in information submitted by Mr. Rockefeller to Congressional committees. But a spokesman for Mr. Rockefeller attributed the discrepancy to a computer error that he said would be straightened out easily by other documentation.

title: Dance: Japanese Artistry
description: The Kabuki and Noh companies that have come here in the past have taught us that Japanese classical theater contains a strong dance component. This is hardly surprising since the origins of this drama were in dance itself.

title: 30Day Freeze Imposed on All Capital Projects Not Yet Under Way
description: In the latest of several moves brought on by the city's fiscal plight, Budget Director Melvin N. Lechner yesterday placed 30day hold on $316rhillion worth of municipal construction projects on which work was ready to start.

title: William N. Wallace
description: In a season that has had its troubles, two positive features for pro football have been the unexpected advancement in the standings of the New England Patriots and St. Louis Cardinals, both exciting, offensiveminded teams addition each features a little man, Mack Herron and Terry Metcalf, playing a key positionhalfbackand playing it very well. The average size of a pro football player is feet 2 inches, 228 pounds. Not many of us measure up, so right away we identify with the little man among the giants. David will always do better in the polls than Goliath. Herron stands 5 feet 5 inches and weighs 170 pounds. Metcalf is a big little man. His program size is 510, 190, but not even his teammates believe those figures and the suspicion is that someone, hardly Metcalf as he doesn't care, has stretched the numbers.

title: Price Discrepancies Cited
description: PARIS, Nov. 8The National Assembly has released a controversial report accusing French oil companies of cheating on the price at which they buy their oil, of secret understandings between the companies as well as foreign concerns in order to keep prices high, and of paying no appreciable taxes.

title: Soviet Hides China's Call For Pact From the Public
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 8 (Reuters)Tass told the Soviet people tonight that China had sent a message of greetings on the occasion of the anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, but the press agency did not say that the message included a proposal for a nonaggression pact.

title: 3 Called 'Vigilantes 'Indicted in Slaying Of Addict Suspect
description: Two brothers and a man on the list for appointment to the police force were indicted yesterday bya Bronx grand jury for manslaughter in the fatal beating of a drug suspect.

title: Scoppetta Tells How His Agents Uncovered Construction Graft
description: The undercover policeman had been masquerading only a few days as a city building inspector when another inspector, walking ahead of him, stopped suddenly. A man walking behind him bumped into the undercover man.

title: Trujillo, Navy Victors In Heptagonal Games
description: In a tone of total exasperation Dennis Trujillo of Army turned to his teammate, Curtis Alitz, and asked, Where is the rest of the team?

title: Newburgh Orders Curfew Continued In Racial Outbreak
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Nov. 8This community, which has been beset by two nights of racial disorders, has decided to continue an 8 P.M.6 A.M. curfew at least until next Tuesday morning.

title: LAWYER ADMITS AIDING TAX FRAUD ONNIXON'S BEHALF
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  A foimer White House lawyer pleaded guilty today to participation in a criminal conspiracy to create a fraudulent $576,000 tax deduction for former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Knicks Defeat Lakers
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 8Highcaliber team basketball, worthy of their tradition, brought the New York Knicks a 117105 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight before about 11,000 people in the Forum, where at least a couple of thousand of the 13,304 ticket purchasers were noshows.

title: Rand Is to be Revalued
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 8 (Reuters)The South African Reserve Bank said today that the rand would be revalued against the dollar to a middle rate of 1.44 to the dollar, against 1.43 now. The change is effective Nov. 11.

title: Giants Defensive Backs Alert To Variety in Jets Air Game
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 8Pete Athas may lose a foot race or two at left cornerback for the New York Giants, but he is seldom at a loss for words. He has been known to strike up casual conversations with rival quarterbacks and wide receivers between plays.

title: Screen: 'Le Trio Infernal; a Comedy:Sisters and Lawyer Murder for Money The Cast Romy Schneider Stars in French Importt
description: Philomene (Romy Schneider) and Catherine (Mascha Gomska) are sisters, two beautiful German girls trying to make their way in southern France in what appears to be the early nineteen-thirties. George Sarret (Michel Piccoli) is a former World War I hero, now a lawyer with a way of seizing the unexpected opportunity at a moment's notice.When Philomene and Catherine enter his life, George begins to plan things with care. He premeditates. He is the architect of what becomes their (mostly) astonishing good fortune. Their game: insurance fraud and murder."Le Trio Infernal," which opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie Theater, is an elegantly acted, handsome-looking French film, a macabre comedy with serious intentions that ultimately prevent it from being as funny as one longs for it to be.Philomene and George are made for each other, both being ambitious, calculating, venal and, when the occasion requires, horrendously vicious. Compared with these two, Catherine, the younger sister, is an old-fashioned sentimentalist.She doesn't mind sharing George with Philomene, and she doesn't object to George's marrying each of them off in turn to an elderly husband who is then quickly insured and dispatched in one way or anotherHowever, Catherine does become all weepy on Christmas Eve, when George, strictly according to plan, shoots their two dinner guests, a pushy, opinionated, overfed pawnbroker (Andrea Ferreol) and the pawnbroker's timid lover (Hubert Deschamps).Catherine becomes so upset she can hardly help lug the bodies up to the bathroom, where they are to be dissolved in sulphuric acid. A couple of days later, when it's time to ladle the contents out of each bathtub, Catherine gets sick to her stomach. In the context of these goings-on, Catherine is a silly goose."Le Trio Infernal" is the first feature to be directed by a new French director named Francis Girod, who also collaborated with Jacques Rouffio on the screenplay, adapted from a novel by Solange Fasquelle. He clearly is a director of talent, though not just because the film looks so good.After "The Conformist," "Stavisky," "Love and Anarchy" and "Amarcord," all thirties movies are beginning to look alike, if only because of the marceled hair, the slashing red lipstick and the vintage motor cars.Mr. Girod scores his success with his actors. For the first time in years, I was convinced that Romy Schneider is an actress of wit, capable of expressing all kinds of feelings simultaneously. Mr. Piccoli may have played this sort of role before, but he has never done it with such cold, comic, vain precision. Miss Gomska, who looks enough like Miss Schneider really to be her sister, expresses a kind of vestigial decency that finally seems to be what the film is all about.That is, if the film is about anything at all, and I'm not sure it is.Because of the emphasis the director places on grotesque though not really shocking details, he seems to be inviting us to interpret the film as some kind of extravagant comment on France (or Europe) midway between two extraordinary cataclysms. These details aren't funny. Neither are they interesting enough clinically to justify their inclusion in the movie. The tone is confused rather than ambiguous in the way that would allow us to appreciate it on several levels at once.

title: Arafat Says U.S. Holds Key to Mideast
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 8Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, said today that peace in the Middle East would remain distant until the United States recognized the right of the Palestinian people to statehood and ceased what he said was the arming of Israel for another war.

title: U. S. MAY DOUBLE HUMANITARIANAID TO HUNGRY LANDS
description: ROME, Nov. 8The United States expects to double its food assistance to hungry nations for humanitarian purposes, increasing the total in that category from the present one million tons to two million tons a year, according to key members of the American delegation at the World Food Conference here.

title: Archives of Art Goes Public in Capital Show
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Twenty years ago, when the Archives of American Art was founded in Detroit, it was little more than a bright idea in the minds of two people  Edgar P. Richardson, a historian of American painting who was then director of the Detroit Institute of Art, and Lawrence A. Fleischman, a local businessman who collected American paintings.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your article on new Canadian immigration policies in your Oct. 23 issue was interesting in many ways. It brought to mind what many have understood for a long time, but what many still refuse to recognize. The problem Canada is trying to avoid is not primarily a racial problem but a problem that occurs because of conflicts in life styles.

title: Ending The Great Divorce?
description: PARISWhen dealing with intimations of policy as put forth by Moscow and Peking one must be especially prudent because of their habit of camouflaging real intentions. Nevertheless, when something so apparently momentous as the hint of a SingSoviet nonaggression pact bursts upon a surprised world, at least some cautious comment is required.

title: FRAUD IS ALLEGED IN TRAINING PLANS
description: tin. He said that the task force's report was in final preparation and would be made public soon.

title: Powder Plant Blast Kills 2
description: ROOSEVELT, Utah, Nov. 8 (UPI)An explosion leveled a black powder plant yesterday, killing two employes and scattering men and debris over a mile of sagebrush country. The victims were identified as Fred Anderson and Lester Holt, both of Roosevelt. The plant was owned by the Western Technology Corporation.

title: A RISE IN JOBLESS SHOCKS GERMANS
description: BONN, Nov. 8A sudden jump in unemployment in October to 672,0003 per cent of the work forcehas caused shock and surprise among Government and private economists in West Germany, where the rate has not been so high for six and a half years.

title: Funerals Are Held for Slain Detective and Magistrate
description: More than 2,500 police officers attended funeral services in Union City yesterday for a Havana  born detective who was killed in a shoot out as he was conducting a narcotics investigation.

title: 8 Rivals Slated for $150,000 Laurel Race
description: LAUREL, Md., Nov. 8The $150,000 Washington D.C. International will be run for the 23d successive year at the Laurel Race Course tomorrow. Gaining prestige steadily in its more recent renewals, the International has now attained rank with the most important races in the world and is particularly acclaimed in Europe.

title: JOSEPH BERNSTEIN
description: Joseph Bernstein, a retired broker of the John Hancock Insurance Company and executive vice president of Congregation Beth El of Boro Park, Brooklyn, died Wednesday in Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 4802 12th Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: An Unpolished 'Window Cleaner'
description: Since the British film industry has been gutted by the economy and so very few English movies are being made at all, it's painful to report that Val Guest's "Confessions of a Window Cleaner" should be avoided. Oozing with a horrible jauntiness, this feeble sex farce is also very old-fashioned. Set in a world of birds and dollies, it reeks of something that Time magazine once called Swinging London, and even the miniskirts are out of date. The movie opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.A winsome window washer (Robin Askwith), who has a lovable tendency to shatter glass, manages to hit the hay with most of his female clients while wrestling with the difficulties of seducing a voluptuous young policewoman. The script strains hard for wit, as when someone brings home a stuffed moose head and all his relatives say "Oh, God." Then they promptly name it Clarence. But of course it falls off the wall. Even so, the picture would be no more than momentarily depressing if the cast didn't include some veteran English character actors, such as John le Mesurier, Dandy Nichols and Richard Wattis. Their dignified presence yields a bleak reminder that movie work is scarce in England now.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: LOS ANGELES  Monroe Brooks, 139 pounds, Los Angeles, out pointed Octavio Amparon, 137, Mexico, 10 rounds.

title: HEMPSTEAD CASTLE
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 8Hempstead Castle, a former chairman of the botany departpent at Yale University, died Wednesday at the age of 81.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Show Drop at Auction
description: Nov. 8Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: RULING ON TOMBS BACKED BY COURT
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday upheld a Federal trial judge's decision that conditions at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men, the Tombs, deprived inmates of their fundamental constitutional rights.

title: DUN &BRADSTREET CLEARED IN FRAUD
description: Dun & Bradstreet, the country's largest private creditrating concern, and the manager of one of its offices were acquitted yesterday of charges of conspiracy and making false statements in connection with what was described as a multimilliondollar scheme to defraud the Federal Housing Administration.

title: Television
description: Television

title: The Old Permissiveness
description: Seven years ago a New York drama critic received a letter from a reader complaining about his review of Bruce Jay Friedman's play Scuba Duba. The correspondent was furious about the play's obscenity. The critis looked back at his original review and noticed, with some small sense of justification, that he had described the play as frequently; obscene. He sent a copy of the original review to the complainant.

title: Issue and Debate
description: National concern over inflation has brought suggestions in recent weeks that one cause of the ballooning cost of living is the large national outlay for environmental improvement. In this view, relaxation of environmental strictures would be an economic plasma transfusion.

title: WINE TALK In a Chaotic Vintage Market, Prices Aren't Aging as Gracefully as the Product
description: Wine prices are in a state of chaos. Never was there a time when the consumer should be more cautious. Importers with large backlogs have cut their prices, and some, but not all, retailers are passing these cuts on to their customers.

title: Mass Transit Lines And Road Routes Called Bias Targets
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) A Justice Department official said today that the Department of Transportation could be guilty of racial discrimination in approving routes for new highways or mass transit lines.

title: SIRICA WILL SEND DOCTORS TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 Federal Judge John J. Sirica said today that he would appoint a panel of three leading doctors to examine Richard M. Nixon to determine whether the former President would be Able to provide testimony for the Watergate coverup trial.

title: WORLD SUGAR UP BY HIT AGAIN
description: Trading in world sugar futures contracts yesterday ended the two most spectacular weeks in the history of sugar trading, with the ninth consecutive daily rise by the daily permissible limit. The limit, formerly 1 cent a pound, is now 2 cents a pound.

title: Appellate Court Praises Sirica As It Upholds Liddy Conviction
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) A unanimous Federal appeals court, praising Judge John J. Sirica, upheld today the burglary, wiretapping and conspiracy conviction of G. Gordon Liddy, one of the seven original Watergate defendants.

title: David D. Alston, 84, Dies A Longshoremen's Official
description: David D. Alston, second vice president of the International died Association, died yesterday in Norfolk, Va. He was 84 years old.

title: Yugoslav Party Paper Affirms Common Objectives With Soviet
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 8The main Communist newspaper of Yugoslavia affirmed today that the country is linked to the Soviet Union by common objectives, despite differences in some policies.

title: Aides Say Ford Will Not Seek Senate Confirmation of Gibson
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Some White House aides said privately today that the nomination of Andrew E. Gibson as Federal Energy Administrator would not be submitted to the Senate for confirmation because of the conflictofinterest controversy that has been raised since President Ford announced Mr. Gibson's selection on Oct. 29.

title: Auto Makers Plan Additional Layoffs
description: DETROIT, Nov. 8The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would layoff 1,625 more workers indefinitely and would keep its plant in Metuchen, N. J., closed again next week. The plant's 3,000 workers there will be off their jobs for a second week.

title: Business Briefs
description: In a filing with the Federal Communications Commission, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company indicated yesterday it might do away with the requirement that telephone users utilize a connecting device that A.T.&T. provides for answeronly data sets and permit direct connection of its lines to the answering device.

title: $330Million Reduction in Pay and Services Ordered by Beame
description: Responding to what he called an emergency and a totally unheard of situation brought on by inflation and the recession, Mayor Beame is ordering a new round of budgetary belttightening that will cut city payrolls and services by $330million. He had earlier ordered reductions of $100million.

title: REBELS SAID TO FLEE TO BOLIVIAN JUNGLE,
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov, 8 (AP)  Bolivian soldiers pursued rebellious troops in the jungles) north of Santa'Cruz today after crushing a oneday army revolt in the city, the military Government said.

title: Hugh Carey's Choice Patrick Joseph Cunningham
description: Last spring, some students invited Patrick J. Cunningham of the Bronx to speak at Harvard, a place where the study of politics ranges from 18thcentury theories to computerized voter surveys, but not very often to clubhouse world of New York.

title: In South Africa, Tides of Change
description: SCAPE TOWN, SOUTH AFRICA INCE April, when the last of the colonial empires  Portugal's  collapsed, events in southern Africa have heightened the sense of urgency in calling for change in the Republic of South Africa. Suddenly, instead of being cosily insulated, the Republic finds herself exposed to militant black governments along her eastern and northwestern borders.

title: Remote Radio Paging System Gets a Patent
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8In a remote radio paging system, the pocketsized receiver alerts the recipient with a beep and then prints out the message, to be studied at leisure. If complete silence is desirable, even the beep can be suppressed. The Eikonix Corporation, a research and development company at Burlington, Mass., received Patent 3,846,783 this week, assigned to it by three staff membersSheldon P. Apsell, Olof C. Johnson Jr. and Robert W. Whitney.

title: Arabs to Discuss Costs
description: BEIRUT, Nov. 8A new single price for crude oil will be discussed tomorrow in Abu Dhabi by a group of Middle East oil countries, led by Saudi Arabia, the largest exporter.

title: Gustines Rides OddsOn Pick at Aqueduct
description: Lazy F. Ranch's Forego, the 4yearold gelding who is the oddson favorite to be named for the Eclipse Award as horse of the year, returns to the races this afternoon in the rich Jockey Gold Cup at Aqueduct.

title: Bell Tolls in London For Old Covent Garden
description: LONDON, Nov. 8 (Reuters) Piles of crushed fruit and wilting flowers, crowded bars and small groups of nostalgic porters today signaled the end of 300 years of trading at Covent Garden, one of the world's bestknown markets.

title: Interceptions Place Namath Under Fire
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I, Nov. 8 With a healthy Joe Namath at quarterback, the saying went, the Jets could win any game. So much for the saying.

title: Rally by Celtics Fails As Pistons Win, 105104
description: BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP)The Detroit Pistons opened a big firsthalf lead on the shooting of Dave Bing and Bob Lanier, then called upon their bench to stave off Boston rallies tonight in a 105.104 National Basketball Association victory over the Celtics.

description: PHILADELPHIA (NBA)Traded Tom Van Arsdale, forward, to Atlanta for Clyde Lee, centerforward, and thirdround draft choke in 1975.

description: News Summary and Index

title: Art: Dynamic Soto Abstractions
description: Jesus Rafael Soto was born in Ciudad Bolivar, Venezuela, in 1923. There was nothing to see in the way of modern art in Ciudad Bolivar, and not much more to see in Caracas, where Mr. Soto arrived as an art student in the illomened year of 1942. In fact there was nothing much of anything, from Mr. Soto's point of view, except the bright strong light and the sense of a nation that had not yet found happiness and to date has still not found it.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: Vladivostok May Welcome U.S. Ship for Ford's Visit
description: TOKYO, Nov. 8 (AP)A ship from the United States Seventh Fleet will be allowed to enter the Soviet port of Vladivostok during President Ford's visit there, the Kyodo news service reported today from Moscow. Vladivostok, headquarters for the Soviet Union's Pacific Fleet, is normally dosed to nonCommunist ships. The ship is expected to serve as a communications base for Mr. Ford when he meets with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, Nov. 23 and 24.

title: Democrats Win Close Votes For Assembly and Senate
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 8An official Rockland County tally completed tonight has the Democrats one more seat in the State Senate and the one more in the Assembly.

title: GEORGE AUERBACHER
description: George Nelson Auerbacher, former president of the Champlain Company of Roseland, N. J., now Bobst Champlain, Inc. printing and paperconverting machinery, died yesterday in Sarasota, Fla., where he moved from Mantoloking, N. J., in 1967. He was 74 years old.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures

title: Blackjacking the Elderly
description: Some supposedly public actions take place in such secrecy and have such, wretched results as to be almost unbelievable. The passage in the closing days of the Legislature in June, 1973, of Assembly Bill 7242A was one such event. It transferred the authority to regulate and inspect private nursing homes and hospitals in the city from New York City to the State of New York.

title: Federal Judge Bars Interference On Local Minority Hiring Plans
description: Federal District Judge Morris E. Lasker, expanding his July ruling upholding New York City's right to establish its own minority hiring standards ruled yesterday that the Federal or state governments might not interfere with local plans anywhere in the country.
