title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: William R. Phillips yesterday admitted that he had frequently perjured himself in arrest cases, but he denied emphatically and categorically that he had shot to death a procurer and an 18yearold prostitute in an East Sideapartment in 1968.

title: Notes on People Betty Ford Is Getting Along Beautifully
description: Betty Ford, who began taking an anticancer drug Monday, said yesterday she was getting along beautifullyI've been active all week, very active. Mrs. Ford, who underwent radical breastcancer surgery Sept. 28, is taking Lphenylaline mustard, designed to treat any possible cancer cells that may have remained after surgery. Mrs. Ford disclosed that she had been planning the first state dinner at the White House since her hospitalization. The dinner next week will honor Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria, who was to leave Vienna today for New Yorkwhere he will address the United Nations on Monday  and Washington, which he visits Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: LYRICISM PREVAILS IN GOODE'S PIANISM
description: As pianist of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Richard Goode is heard a great deal, but seldom on his own. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night he had the first part of a concert to himself, playing Schubert's posthumous Sonata in A. He then slipped back into his more familiar role as collaborative artist, with Benita Valente, soprano, in songs by Schubert and Wolf.

title: I.C.C. Clears Union Pacific Bid to Merge With Chicago, Rock Island & Application Was Filed 10 Years AgoCertain Conditions Fixed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The Interstate Commerce Commission, by a 6to4 vote, approved today the Union Pacific Rairoad's application to merge with the Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific railroad. The application was filed 10 years ago and led to the most complicated railroad merger case in the country's history.

title: Highs and Lows Friday, Nov. 8, 1974
description: NEW LOWS26

title: 2 Big Board Seats Sold
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported two seat sales yesterday at $95,000, down $5,000 from the last sale on Oct. 23.

title: 15 New Rockefeller Witnesses Listed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Nelson A. Rockefeller will be the first witness when the Senate Rules Committee resumes hearings Wednesday on his nomination as Vice President. He will be followed by many other witnesses including one of his brothers, Laurance S. Rockefeller, and Dr. William J. Ronan.

title: Frank Yablans Resigns As Paramount President
description: The resignation of Frank; Yablans as president and chief operating officer of the Paramount Pictures Corporation and as president of the Paramount television division, effective Jan. 5, was announced by the company last night.

title: TWO MAJOR BANKS CUT PRIME RATES
description: Two of the country's largest banksthe First National City Bank here and the First National Bank of Chicago reduced yesterday the base interest rates they charge on loans to the most creditworthy corporations to 10 per cent, the lowest level since late April.

title: Soviet Moves to Improve University Degree Levels
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 8, (Reuters)  The Soviet Government today announced stricter controls over the awarding of university degrees in a move aimed at raising the standards of graduation dissertations, many of which, it said, have no scholarly value.

title: Film Stars Sued for $2,944
description: CHICO, Calif., Nov. 8 (UPI)The owners of a house that Elizabeth Taylor and Richard The Clansmen near here last winter have filed a $2,944 suit against the film stars accusing them of ruining bedspreads, mattresses and carpets. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Henning said they filed the suit after getting no response in several efforts to collect for the damage.

title: People in Sports
description: Clyde Lee's stay in Atlanta was a short one. The 6foot10inch forwardcenter, who on Oct. 4 was dealt to the Atlanta Hawks by the Golden State Warriors to complete a transaction involving Zelmo Beaty, was traded yesterday with a thirdround draft pick to the Philadelphia 76ers for Tom Van Arsdale, a forward.

title: CORN IS CURTAILED BY POOR WEATHER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) The estimate for the 1974 corn corp, a key to consumer food prices next year, has been reduced a further 96 million bushels by poor weather and now is expected to be 18 per cent below the record 1973 harvest, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: U. S. MAY DOUBLE HUMANITARIAN AID TO HUNGRY LANDS
description: ROME, Nov. 8The United States expects to double its food assistance to hungry nations for humanitarian purposes, increasing the total in that category from the present one million tons to two million tons a year, according to key members of the American delegation at the World Food Conference here.

title: Mrs. Abzug Asks Carey to Back Women Delegates
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug, Democrat of Manhattan, has called on Governorelect Hugh L. Carey to use his best offices to insure substantial representation of women on the New York State delegation to the Democratic miniconvention in Kansas City next month.

title: McCloskey in Portugal
description: LISBON, Nov. 8, (Reuters)Robert J. McCloskey, U.S. Ambassador at Large, met today with President Francisco da Costa Gomes to discuss retention of an American air base in the Azores. The base was crucial as a refueling stop for United States planes carrying arms to Israel during the ArabIsraeli war a year ago.

title: Chess:Korchnoi, Nearly Out of Time, Tries Rare and Risky Opening
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 8Viktor Korchnoi stuck his head into the lamb's mouth tonight in the 20th game of his final Candidates Match with Anatoly Karpov in the Writers Club here and when play broke off after 45 moves it looked as if he would be able to get it out again.

description: Events Today

title: OnetoOne, Unit for Retarded, Plans 8 More Community Homes
description: OnetoOne, the nonprofit organization that helps mental retardates, announced yesterday an expansion program that would add, in six months, eight community homes for the retarded to the eight it has already opened or is in the process of opening.

title: Aides Say Ford Will Not Seek Senate Confirmation of Gibson
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Some White House aides said privately today that the nomination of Andrew E. Gibson as Federal Energy Administrator would not be submitted to the Senate for confirmation because of the conflictofinterest controversy that has been, raised since President Ford announced Mr. Gibson's selection on Oct. 29.

title: Arrest Records
description: Although President Ford promised that his Administration would undertake hot pursuit of privacy legislation, the Department of Justice has been dragging its feet on a critical piece of legislation involving use of the nationwide pool of arrest record information which the Federal Bureau of Investigation has built up and administered for the last fifty years. This information is basically the list of a person's arrests and the offenses charged at the police station. It rarely lists dispositions.

title: New Head Named for School Audit Unit
description: School Chancellor Irving Anter named a new director yesterday for the school system's muchcriticized audit operation Ind also set up a special task orce to monitor efforts to clear mismanagement or corruption in local school districts. J. Paul Barrett, a 43yearold ertified public accountant and former audit director with the Hertz Corporation, was appointed to the $34,762ayear post of director of the Board of Education's office of audit and investigation. He will take over the position on Monday, replacing Harry B. Newman, the acting director, who will soon retire.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 (AP)A group of prospective local investors, who could raise the private capital needed to purchase the Baltimore Orioles, has been given until Monday to make arrangements for buying the team. The deadline was set by the Mayor's Commission to Save the Orioies, according to F. Barton Harvey Jr., commission cochairman.

title: More Coin Theft Arrests
description: BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP)Three more persons have been arrested and more coins recovered in the 11monthold theft of rare coins from Harvard University's Fogg Museum, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: People and Business Gleason Forms Own P.R.Firm
description: Harold V. Gleason, former chairman and chief executive officer of the defunct Franklin National Bank, yesterday announced the formation of a new publicrelations firm, Harold V. Gleason, Inc., adding that he was pleased particularly to announce the European American Bank and Trust Company as the firm's first major client.

title: American Electric Power's Revenue Increases but Earnings Drop
description: The American Electric Power company reported yesterday higher operating revenue for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30. Earnings, however, were were lower, reflecting growing cost pressures, including substantially larger interest costs.

title: Montreal Mayor Is Set to Win Again
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 5Mayor Jean Drapeau, the man most Canadians credit with having called the world's attention to Montreal, is about to be reelected again.

title: STAFFORD REPP
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov, 8 (AP) Stafford Repp, who played Chief O'Hara in the Batman television series; died Tuesday in suburban Inglewood at the age of 56.

title: New Jersey Sports Park for Champions
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 8A small park on the south bank of the Raritan River will be the focal point for more than 2,000 New Jersey high school crosscountry runners as the state boys championships begin tomorrow.

title: Commodity Price Index Shows Rise of 2.7 in Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 231.3 from 228.6 last week.

title: Nonpartisan FundRaiser
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 (UPI)A$25aplate dinner will be held here to raise money for litter containers that would not carry advertising.

title: CAREY TO REQUEST CRANE'S OUSTER
description: Governorelect Hugh L. Carey has decided to oust Joseph F. Crangle as Democratic state chairman and replace him with Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic chairman and an early Carey Supporter.

title: Antiques: A Show of Shadow Puppets
description: It's a puppet spectacularrich in ancient Asian dramas and so effectively staged that the dolls seem to dance, the shadows tremble with life.

title: Gary Player Is Victor
description: LA MANGA, Spain, Nov. 8 (UPI)  Gary Player of South Africa won the third annual La Manga international proamateur golf tournament today with a birdie on the first hole of a suddendeath playoff with Clive Clark of England. The two were tied with 42under par totals of 244 at the end of regulation play.

title: Judge Acquits Guardsmen In Slayings at Kent State
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 8The chief judge of the Federal District Court here acquitted eight former Ohio National Guardsmen today in the 1970 Kent State shootings. In sudden and dramatic end Col the trial that began Oct. 29, Judge Frank J. Battisti held that the Government prosecutors had not proved beyond a reasonable doubt that the guardsmen willfully intended to deprive the students of their civil rights.

title: Market Place
description: During the last year stock prices have been at uncommonly low levels and there have been frequent announcements by companies that they would buy their own shares.

title: Carolyn Brown's House Party Is Danced on Stage and on Film
description: Carolyn Brown's House Party intriguingly occupied the Lepercq Space on Thursday evehing. The program, by the Among Company, was the first of the new experimental series of dance works to be offered by the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: 5 NATIONS JOINING OILSHARING GROUP
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 8  Five more countries said today that they wanted to participate in an emergency oilsharing system for oilconsuming nations, bringing to 16 the number of countries that will create the system in Paris next week.

title: Gold Price Reaches a Record of $184.50
description: LONDON, Nov. 8The price of gold, benefiting from heavy speculative interest, climbed $6.25 an ounce today and closed at the record level of $184.50.

title: Nixon Progresses in Recovery, but His Pneumonia Persists
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 8 Former President Richard M. Nixon advanced a step in his recovery from postoperative complications, but a new Xray showed that the pneumonia in his right lung persists, Mr. Nixon's doctors srt;d here today.

title: E.P.A. Orders a National Study of Chemical Contaminants in Drinking Water
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The Environmental Protection Agency ordered today an immediate nationwide study of chemical contaminants in drinking water after an agency study showed that 66 chemicals were present in Mississippi River water used by New Orleans and nearby communities.

title: Bowl Talk Fails to Distract Coaches From Job at Hand
description: When it gets to be this bowlpicking time of year, college football coaches can be as testy as a politician on election eve. These coaches, who strengthen their careers by getting their teams into bowl games, sound as if they had never heard of postseason games  at least until everything is signed, sealed and delivered.

title: THEODORE A. KAPLAN
description: Theodore A. Kaplan, who retired in 1965 as president of Victor's Home Appliances, a retail operation in Verona, N.J., died yesterday at his home in Seal Beach, Calif. He was 84 years old and formerly lived in Newark.

title: Steam Generators
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 8 (UPI)Salt Lake County commissioners have agreed to sell steam to a construction concern during work on a senior citizens apartment project next to the county complex.

title: A Mental Patient's Rights To Adequate Care Upheld
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 8 Mental patients as a class have a Federal constitutional right to adequate treatment when they are committed against their will to state institutions, and Federal courts may determine those standards, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled today.

title: LAWYER ADMITS AIDING TAX FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  A former White House lawyer pleaded guilty today to participation in a criminal conspiracy to create a fraudulent $576,000 tax deduction for former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: The Wire Skeleton of Vladimir Prison
description: A FORMER Soviet political prisoner recently emigrated to Israel. He brought this message: Tell them only thisI am kept with the insane. They are creating a constant hell for me. They are trying to drive me to the insanity of those with whom they locked me up. I cannot breathe!

title: Music: String Ensemble
description: I Solisti di Zabreg the Yugoslav string ensemble with the Italian name, had Henryk Szeryng, the Polishborn violinist from Mexico, as its conductor and chief soloist for the concert it gave at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night.

description: Deaths

title: Tanaka, Home, Faces a Political Battle
description: TOKYO, Nov. 8Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan returned from a 12day trip to New Zealand, Australia and Burma tonight to fight to preserve his political position.

title: Coal Talks Pressed As Walkouts Start; 2Week Strike Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Nov. 9A nationwide strike by coal miners beganin effecttoday despite continued bargaining by the coal industry and the United Mine Workers. Talks were scheduled to resume today.

title: AUSTIN L. PATRICK, FOUGHT SOIL EROSION
description: Austin L. Patrick, who played a major role in the development of the Department of Agriculture's soil and water conservation program, died at a Virginia nursing home Oct. 30. He was 85 years old.

title: Disputed Books to Return To West Virginia Schools
description: An embattled school board decided today to return the controversial textbooks it had previously removed from local classrooms, but it also promised that those who object to their content would not be forced to read them. CHARLESTON, W. V., Nov. 8

title: AIRLIFES VIOLATED MEETINGS RULING Data on Minutes Have Not Been Filed With C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8An organization of scheduled and supplemental airlines failed to comply with a Government requirement that they file public minutes when they met to work out transAtlantic charter air fares, a Senate subcommittee heard today.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Golden State Warriors, at Oakland, Calif. (TelevisionChannel 9, 11 P.M.) Nets vs. Kentucky Colonels, at Lexington. Ky. (TelevisionChannel 9, 8:30 P.M.)

title: Held in Slaying of Man Trying to Stop Mugging
description: Two young Queens men, one of whom is absent without leave from the Army, were arrested yesterday in the murder of a man who responded to the calls of a neighbor been mugged in South Ozone Park, Queens, last month.

title: 2 REFINERS RAISE SUGAR PRICE AGAIN
description: Shoppers will find another price increase on sugar at the grocery next week.

title: Last Major Rehearsal Held For ApolloSoyuz Mission
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 8 (UPI)More than 1,000 officials and engineers participated yesterday in the final major dress rehearsal for the 1975 ApolloSoyuz mission that will mean the end of careers in the space program for many of them.

title: SHOP TALK Mythical and Other Beasts Abound in Jeweled Garden
description: There is a faint aura of the Middle Ages about the pieces by the jewelersculptor Roberto Estevez, which Cartier will have on display through Nov. 21. Mythical beasts, as well as fauna of the real world, they are done in intricately worked silver, semiprecious stones, tiny patterns of enamel on porcelain or silver, and polished seashellswhich form part of the body or head of most of the animals.

title: Carey to Ask Ouster of Crangle And Cunningham as Party Head
description: Governorelect Hugh L. Carey has decided to oust Joseph F. Crangle as Democratic state chairman and replace him with Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic chairman and an early Carey supporter.

title: DERKLEY AGREES TO SELL INSURERS Equitable Life. Is to Pay $34.8Million in Cash
description: The W. R. Berkley Corporation said yesterday that a definitive agreement had been signed for the sale of three insurance company subsidiaries to the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States Merger for $34.8million News in cash. The agreement, first announced last April, has been amended, the company said, to take care of certain potential liabilities and will result in the withholding of $9.75million by Equitable to be applied against the liabilities as they occur.

description: College, School Results

title: All Honored in the City That Remembers Him When
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 8 They named a street after Muhammad Ali in his hometown today, but Mabel Clark still called him Cassius.

title: Market Finishes Mixed Despite Prime Rate Cut
description: The stock market finished mixed yesterday in subdued trading as investors showed increased concern over the effects of the impending coal strike on an already weakening economy and over the decrease in the nation's money supply.

title: Man Acquitted in Slaying After 14 Months in Tombs
description: A 29yearold man, in prison for 14 months awaiting trial, was acquitted late last night of the murder of the woman who was described in court as his girlfriend.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND OTC DECLINE
description: The American Stock Exchange ended slightly lower yesterday while the overthecounter market closed mixed.

title: Nets Overcome Sounds, 104102
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 8Maybe the New York Nets were thinking about tomorrow's game with the Kentucky Colonels or, perhaps, they took the Memphis. Sounds too lightly. Whatever the reason, the Nets had to work to score a 104102 victory tonight over the Sounds. The Nets were led by Julius Erving, who scored 26 points and pulled down 17 rebounds, and a stellar performance by brain Taylor.

title: U.N. Delegates Berated For Lazy Work Habits
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. (Reuters) United Nations delegates got a tonguelashing today for wasting time.

title: Public Advocate to Study Auto Insurance Fee Rise
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8Stanley C. Van Ness, the New Jersey Public Advocate who watches over citizens interests in their dealings with the state, said today that he would investigate the automobile insurance rate increases announced yesterday by the State Commissioner of Insurance.

title: Heller, in Sweden, Says Why He Likes Living in New York
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 8 Joseph Heller, whose new novel, Something Happened has become a best seller in Sweden, visited here this week and said he had had a better time here in two days than he has had in two weeks in New York.

title: BLUMENTHAL JOB IS PUT IN DOUBT
description: A movement is undsr way it several parts of the new Democratic majority in the Assembly to deny the No. 2 post of majority leader to Albert H. Blumento Blumenthal, a liberal Democrat from Manhattan.

title: SANLUCAR ASTOUNDS WITH GUITAR AGILITY
description: In the program at his Alice Tully Hall recital Thursday, night, Manolo Sanlucar was described as an artist who does not make virtuosity an end in itself but sublimates it to convey deep emotional qualities. Perhaps so, yet it was still the astounding technical agility of this young flamenco guitarist that drew gasps from his listeners. His control of tone and timbre is remarkable, as is his clarity of articulation, which gives uncanny precision to all manner of flamboyant runs, and trills.

title: Market Averages
description: STANDARD & POOR INDEX

title: PickYourNumber System Set For Daily Lottery Next Spring
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8  Some time next March or April, purjchasers of New Jersey daily lottery tickets will be able to choose their own threedigit number, as do people who bet illegally.

title: GROSSI IS LINKED TO MOB INTERESTS
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8The president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, Anthony J. Grossi, has been charged in sealed court papers with being closely tied to what one of the papers described as the mobdominated garbagecollection industry in New Jersey.

title: Error Blamed for Discharge Of Gun on Kissinger. Plane
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) The Secret Service said today that human error was responsible for the discharge of a submachine gun aboard Secretary of State Kissinger's plane during his Middle East tour last month.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: O.A.S. Meeting Opens With Call For Lifting of Cuban Sanctions
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 8The President of Ecuador opened a fiveday ministerial meeting of the Organization of American States here tonight with a call for an end to economic and political sanctions against Cuba.

title: 8:BRAOSTREET CLEARED IN FRAUD
description: Dun & Bradstreet, the country's largest private creditrating concern, and the manager of one of its offices were acquitted yesterday of charges of conspiracy and making false statements in connection with what was described as a multimilliondollar scheme to defraud the Federal Housing Administration.

title: Palestinians Get U.N. Delegate Status
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.,1 Nov. 8A United Nations spokesman, said today that they Palestinian representatives attending the debate next week on Palestine would have the status of a delegation because they had been formally invited, by the General Assembly.

title: U.S. UPHELD IN ET ON TV NETWORKS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) The Justice Department said today that the Special Prosecutor's Office had found no evidence to support charges by the three national commercial television networks that an antitrust suit filed against them by the department in April, 1972 had been improperly motivated.

title: WYMAN HELD WINNER OF SENATE CONTEST
description: New Hampshire Secretary of State Robert Stark has declared Representative Louis Wyman, Republican of New Hampshire, the winner of the state's race for United States Senator by 355 votes. Mr. Wyman defeated a Democrat, John Durkin, who has requested a recount, United Press International reported yeterday. The process is expected to take twoandahalf weeks.

title: The Building Payoffs
description: Corruption in the building industry is flourishing New York; what else is new? The word in the industry always has been that this is payoff city; and it has been common wisdom for decades that this fact has a lot to do with the exceptionally high cost of building here. The payoff figure has apparently risen dramatically from the $25 million estimated as the annual bribe tally three years ago. Everyone plays and pays, from the city's leading architects and engineers and contractors to highranking officials in city departments.

title: Borg and Ashe Win in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 8 (AP) Bjorn Borg of Sweden led fi sweep of the top four seeded players into the semifinals of the $100,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament. Borg defeated Manuel Orantes of Spain, 61, 61. He will play thirdseeded Tom Okker, who defeated Marty Riessen, 76, 64.

title: No GarageBut That Little Fact Didn't Stop Her
description: You don't have to have garage to have a garage sale, these days. If you happen to own a fivestory, 16room East Side townhouse with a garden, and you're a decorator and designer who is also a world traveler, a compulsive collector and a clothes fanatic, and your parents died and left you a huge house full of stuff in Californiawell, there comes a time when you just have to get rid of some of your possessions.

title: Knicks LineUp
Jobless Rate, at 8.4% Attains a 16Year High
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8 (AP)Unemployment in New Jersey reached a 16yearhigh of 8.4 per cent in September, according to Joseph Hoffman, State Commissioner of Labor and Industry.

title: White Plains Revives Renewal
description: WHITE PLAINSGovernment and community leaders gathered at a barren downtown site recently for a ground  breaking ceremony that represented, as one put it, some good news to go along with the bad.

title: Rick Hobard on Probation For 2 Years in Tax Case
description: Federal Judge Whitman Knapp has sentenced Rick, Hohard, a general partner and producer of the TonyAwardwinning play Find Your Way Home, to a twoyear probation conditioned upon payment of taxes and penalties he owes the Federal Government.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Training School for Girls, a 103yearold detention institution here that has been nearly empty recent years as a result of court rulings, has been officially closed. Edward Ramsey, a spokesman for the State Department of Institutions and Agencies, said only a small contingent of maintenance men would be left on the grounds of the 125acre jail until the state decides what do with its 18 buildings. Mr, Ramsey said most of the remaining girls in the home had been transferred Oct. 2 the Jamesburg Training School for Boys, where they are housed in a separate cottage, Others were placed in foster homes and some were paroled, he said. Mr. Ramsey said that a major reason for the shutdown was a United States Supreme Court decision that jail terms could not be given to juveniles for crimes that, if committed by adults, would not be punishable by prison terms. Such crimes included truancy and loitering.

title: John W. Boyle Is Dead at 64; ExNews Executive at TimeLife
description: John W. Boyle, deputy chief of the TimeLife News Service until his retirement in 1967, died Wednesday of an internal hemorrhage in Easton, Md., where he lived. He was 64 years old.

title: Waterless Months End As Protester Pays $661
description: HACKETTSTOWN, Nov. 8 Mrs. Anne Souders today had her water turned back on after eight months of carrying buckets from next door and bathing a mile away.

title: Business Records
description: Business Records

title: Archives of Art Goes Public in Capital Show
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Twenty years ago, when the Archives of American Art was founded in Detroit, it was little more than a bright idea in the minds of two people  Edgar P. Richardson, a historian of American painting who was then director of the Detroit Institute of Art, and Lawrence A. Fleischman, a local businessman who collected American paintings.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Key members of the American delegation at the World Food Conference in Rome said that the United States expects to double its food assistance to hungry nations for humanitarian purposes, increasing the total in that category to two million tons a year. The delegation cabled President Ford for permission to declare the United States intention publicly. [ Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Coal Talks Pressed As Walkouts Start; 2Week Strike Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Hard bargaining between the coal industry and the United Mine Workers Union continued almost up to the miners strike deadline tonight, and was scheduled to resume tomorrow.

title: Jamaica Big Loser On 73 Title Fight
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 8,(Reuters)The Jamaican government has finally admitted it took a beating on the promotion of the Joe FrazierGeorge Foreman world heavyweight title fight here 18 months ago.

title: BristolMyers Expecting Profit of $3.70 a Share
description: Earnings estimates of the BristolMyers Company for 1974 of $3.70 a share are reasonable, Richard L. Gelb, president, told an investment group were yesterday. The diversified Tharmaceutical and consumer products company had a net income in 1973 of $101.8million, or $3.16 a share, on sales of $1.36billion.

title: TV Series Will Emphasize Principles of Good Health
description: One of the most difficult jobs in public health  getting people to change their lifestyles to improve their wellbeing  is the theme of a new television series, Feeling Good, an adult version of Sesame Street.

title: Kissinger Tells of Mideast Possibilities
description: TUNIS, Nov. 8Secretary of State Kissinger, after concluding three days of talks with Arab and Israeli leaders, said today in Israel that possibilities do exist for further Americansponsored diplomatic progress in the Middle East despite the hardline decisions of last week's Rabat summit conference of Arab states.

title: MISSING CHILDREN BACK FROM AFRICA
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 8 (UPI)Six of seven children who were allegedly spirited away to an African farm two years ago arrived in Virginia last night with two Richmond parents who won their custody in a Rhodesian court.

title: North Sea Oil to Transform the Shetlands
description: LERWICK, Shetland Islands, Nov. 1The gray sky hung low over the fishing boats bobbing in the harbor, and the only sounds were the screeching of the sea gulls and the pelting of the rain. The people were indoors, taking refuge from the first winter storm.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Eating Our Lives Up With Work
description: WASHINGTON MY MOUNTING aversion to more than eighty or ninety hours of labor a week is rooted, no doubt, in some personality defect, or, perhaps, an unconscious desire to take too seriously the greater social aim of our New Athens. That goal, laudable and oftprofessed, is freedom from sheer toil the advent of the Age of Leisure.

title: After Rabat: Egypt
description: As the strains of ceremonies and the shock of communiqus fade away, the real impact of the Rabat summit conference on the politics of the Arab world is slowly coming up for measure. The participants themselves must be casting curiousperhaps uneasyglances at each other now that they are settling back into their respective capitals.

title: Jersey Official Is Accused Of Ties to Mob Interests
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8The president of the State Board of Pub lic Utility Commissioners, Anthony J. Grossi, has been charged in sealed court papers with being closely tied to what one of the papers described as the mobdominated garbagecollection industry in New Jersey.

title: U.S: ASKS COMMENT ON OILSUBSIDY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The Federal Energy Administration asked today for public comment on a proposal to give subsidies to importers of heating and residual oil but only when foreign prices, exceed, domestic prices.

title: Levi6ttown Division Wraps It Up
description: ??? Wasserman played less than a half yesterday, but that was more than enough for Levittown Division, the beneficiary of four Wasserman touchdowns in a 418 victory over Hempstead that wrapped up the Nassau Corifetence VI championship.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 9 (UPI)Greg Williams, the University of Illinois rugged defensive end, was fatally shot today at the fraternity house where he lived and another student was shot and wounded. Williams, a 20yearold junior from Miami, died at Burnham City Hospital barely four hours before the Fighting Illini were scheduled to take to the field for their homecoming game against powerful Michigan. A starter until he suffered an ankle injury against Iowa three weeks ago, Williams had not been slated to play today and had not spent the night with the team. His ankle was in a cast.

title: Fashion
description: Jeans, the campus uniform of the rebellious sixties when the antifashion movement erupted, are still as basic term papers, but today's college woman is smartening up. While there are some holdout campuses that still swear by jeans, sweaters and shirts topped by rumpled raincoats, the trend at many colleges is toward tidy wool and corduroy pants with carefully coordinated tops. The most striking change is the return to skirtsnot just the kneelength classics, but the fashionable midcalf styles. And stockings. Yes, stockings and real shoes and boots.

title: 4.000 City Nurses Win $925 Per Year in Raises
description: Staff nurses in 19 municipal hospitals and other city agencies will receive an annual acrosstheboard salary increase of $925 retroactive to July 1, 1974, under terms of a new twoyear agreement with the city last week by Arvid Anderson, chairman of the Office of Collective Bargaining.

title: Persian Gulf States Adjust Oil Prices
description: ABU DHABI, Nov.9 (Reuters) The Persian Gulf oilproducing states agreed tonight on a plan to lower the posted price of crude oil and to balance this cut with higher taxes and royalties paid by foreign companies, Government sources reported.

title: Mary Monsaert to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Monsaert Jr. of Hawthorne, N. J., have anounced the engagement of their daughter, Mary E. Monsaert, to James E. Joyce, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Joyce of the Bronx.

title: DEMOCRATS FIND 'CUSHION'IS GONE FOR STATE BUDGET
description: After years of charging that there were cushions of revenutes hidden in the New York State budgets fashioned by Republicans, Democrats are talking of bare cupboards now as they prepare to assume power.

title: Annabelle Gamson Reconstructs Work Of Isadora Duncan
description: No woman dancer in history has aroused as much curiosity as Isadora Duncan. What was lit that she did that made her so special? One scrutinizes the Walkowitz drawings and reads the testimony of others, but until one sees the movement, her special talent remains shadowy. At the American Theater Laboratory Friday evening, Annabelle Gamson cleared some of the mists with her program of lovingly reconstructed Duncan dances, among her other solos.

title: Grambling Is 3916 Victor Here Over North Carolina A. and T.
description: Grambling bounced back from a shocking 106 halftime deficit to trounce North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State College, 3916; before a crowd of 31,000 at Shea Stadium yesterday.

title: ItalianAmerican Writers Offered $10,000 in Prizes
description: Eight literary and journalism awards amounting to $10,000 have been made available to young authors of ItalianAmerican descent who enter a contest sponsored by UNICO National, Mario Albi, president of the organization, announced yesterday. UNICO stands for unity, neighborliness, integrity, charity and opportunity.

title: The Nation
description: The White House has been severely embarrassed by the disclosure that the man President Ford recently nominated to become Federal Energy Administrator is receiving almost $900,000 in severance pay from a company doing business in the industries he is supposed to regulate.

title: Island Machine Beneath Pacific Floor Believed to Have Generated Chain at Least 1,000 Miles Long
description: From a study of rocks col??? on Pitcairn Island, ref??? of those who mutinied aboard the British warship Bounty in the 18th century, it has been proposed that this lonely speck of land is the test product of an islandmaking machine beneath the Pacific Ocean floor.

title: Social Announcements
description: Engagements Births Weddings

title: BOYCOTT OF CUBA DEBATED BY O.A.S,
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 9Lifting of the economic and political sanctions against Cuba by the Organization of American States at its current session here could ease the way to a reconciliation between Washington and Havana, diplomatic sources familiar with the position of the United States delegation said.

title: CONSUMERS SCORE BEEF GRADING PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) Consumer groups said yesterday that the Government's proposal to change beef gradings would result in higher prices for lowerquality meat.

title: A Mandate To Do What ?; In the Nation, A Clear Shift To the Left; In the Region, Wall to Wall Democrats
description: The voters imposed the predicted penalty on the Republican party last week, and in the process they moved the nation leftward on the political spectrum. But the results also seemed to constitute an invitation to Republican reformation: The loss of Congressional seats and governorships was severe but not bankrupting, and while the punishment was apparently inflicted by deserting Republican voters, there was nothing in the returns to suggest they were gone forever to the Democrats.

title: Your Move, Parker Brothers
description: some challenges to its sales record. Milton Bradley, for one, claims that Yahtzee, published by its E. S. Lowe Division, now outsells Monopoly on a yearly unit basis. In 1973 four million Yahtzee sets were sold, according to the company. That is 500,000 more than Monopoly. Yahtzee sales now total 30 million compared to Monopoly's 80 million, but Yahtzee is about 30 years younger than Monopoly. Monopoly is slightly more than 40 years old and the idea is probably about 70 years old, for a similar game, the Landlord Game, was being played in the United States around 1904. But backgammon, a game that is 4,000 years old and originated in Egypt, keeps emerging periodically. A conservative estimate places the current number of backgammon players at 250,000, and backgammon tournaments have also started to flourish. Like checkers and chess, two other perennial favorites, backgammon is part of the public domain  the boards and markers used in playing it can be made by anyone (brand name games such as Monopoly are copyrighted and published by only one company).

title: Criminals At Large
description: The name in large type is Telly Savalas. In much smaller type, on the spine, is the name of Victor B. Miller. He happens to be the author of the first two of the Kojak series, based of course on the television series in which Savalas stars. The titles are SIEGE and REQUIEM FOR A COP (Pocket, $1.25 each).

title: Boom in Offshore Oil Rigs
description: BEAUMONT, Tex.Towering 20 stories above the water on thick, gray legs, the offshore oil rig. Pat Rutherford Sr. resembles nothing so much as a giant, rectangular elephant.

title: A City Raises Police Pay If Crime Rate Goes Down
description: Assumption Held Incorrect

title: U.S.C. Pins 3410 Defeat On Stanford
description: STANFORD, Calif., Nov. 9 (AP)  Southern California's Anthony Davis rushed for 119 yards and two touchdowns today and added a touchdown pass, leading the Trojans to a 3410 victory over Stanford and into first place in the Pacific8 Conference race to the Rose Bowl.

title: VOTING SHIFT SEEN IN ORANGE COUNTY
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 There are indications that Orange County, long stereotyped as a citadel of stanch conservatism, may be modifying its political image.

title: Democrats Drafting Monmouth Changes
description: FREEHOLD  By winning two seats in the election last Tuesday and one last year, the Democrats have gained their first majority on the fiveman Monmouth County Board of Freeholders in halfcentury.

title: Great Expectations
description: BETTY CROCKER'S COOKBOOK. (Bantam $1.95.) One of the most popular of kitchen companicns, available in paper covers for the first time. 625,000 copies.

title: FORD CRITICIZED ON POCKET VETO
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9President Ford violated a Federal Court ruling by attempting to pocket veto three bills while Congress was in recess for the 1974 political campaign, Democratic critics on Capitol Hill believe.

title: Ida Margrethe Loventzen Married to Erik NilsenMoe of Norway
description: The marriage of Ida Margrethe Lorentzen, daughter of Oivind Lorentzen Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Evelyn Byrd LaPrade Lorentzen, to Erik Martin NilsenMoe, son of Halfdan NilsenMoe of Oslo, Norway, and the late Metha NilsenMoe, took place yesterday afternoon.

title: Favorite Triumphs In Jersey
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., Nov. 9 Bombay Duck, the 6.5 favorite, won the $28,600 Shrewsbury Stakes at Monmouth Park today, holding off the fastclosing Talc by threequarters of a length before a crowd of 13,747.

title: CENSORSHIP FOES AHEAD ON GRADES
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind. Nov. 9 (AP)Students opposed to. book censorship generally receive higher grades in school than the procensorship minority of the nation's teenagers, a Purdue University survey has found.

title: Correction Officer Is Shot In Foiling Holdup of a Bar
description: An offduty city correction officer apparently foiled the holdup of a bar and grill in Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant section last night, but in an exchan:e of at least 10 shots he and another patron were wounded by the holdup men, the police said.

title: Georgia's Vote: A British View
description: ATLANTAIt's all a far cry from the hustings in Britain. Ronnie Thompson, gospel singer and Mayor of Macon, winding up his speech to Atlanta's Kiwanis Club. He has succusfully (;ompete,1 with the piped music that has played throughout ais address, and in the audience all the businessmen are still awake. They are pale, male and middleaged and the area between hairline and collar is only pink, not red; though these may be Republicans, they are not the kind to respond to the rabblerousing populism that wins elections in Macon.

title: League Lead Taken By Port Washington
description: Undefeated Port Washington pulled ahead of the field in Nassau Conference III yesterday, defeating Herricks, 390, while two other contenders, Mempham and Calhoun, were losing to teams that began the day sharing last place. Mempham was upset, 207, by Long Beach while McArthur stopped Calhoun, 126.

title: Emily Whitney Rewed
description: Emily Taussig Whitney, window of Henry Wadsworth Whitney, was married yesterday afternoon to William Albert Sherman, a widower. Both are of Newport, R. I., where the Rev. Edwin Bailey of St. George's Episcopal Church there performed the ceremony at the bride's home. Her first husband was a trust officer of the City Bank Farmers Trust in New York, which became the First National City Bank. Mr. Sherman is retired from the Industrial National Bank of Rhode Island.

title: Council Sessions Scheduled
description: The City Council will meet at 1:30 P.M. next Thursday in City Hall. In addition, its Committee on Finance will meet at 10 A.M. on Thursday to discuss several capitalbudget changes, and its Committee on Standards and Ethics will meet at 10 A.M. Friday on an agenda not yet announced. Both committee meetings will be at City Hall and will be open to the public.

title: G.M. Warns of Danger in Use of Baby Safety Seats
description: DETROIT, Nov. 9The General Motors Corporation has temporarily stopped production of its baby safety seat because of a possible hazard to infants, when the seat is used outside a car.

title: LETTER
description: We, 33 dancers of the Harkness Ballet, disagree most emphatically with Clive Barnes's decree that the Harkness Ballet is not worthy of assistance or, for that matter, existehce [The Harkness Doesn't Deserve to Go on Welfare, Oct. 20].

title: Unbeaten Elis Rout Penn Team 3712
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9Yale's undefeated football team moved a step closer to the Ivy League championship today with an easy 3712 victory over Pennsylvania at Franklin Field.

title: Terror on Road to War
description: PARISAn enormous change for the worse in ArabIsraeli peace prospects occurred between Henry Kissinger's October and November whirls through the Middle East. In October he sought to prevent an Arab summit from naming Yasir Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization to replace King Hussein as the voice of West Bank Palestinians. That effort failed.

title: BRIDGE
description: If there were a prize for the worst bid of the year, there would be a great many excellent entries, and the judges would have an impossible task. More interesting and more practical would be a prize for the worst bid, or series of bids, that hit the target. And in that more limited area North's performance on the diagramed deal played last month would get my vote.

title: Democratic State Unit Chooses Delegates to Charter Convention
description: ALBANY, Nov. 9After considerable squabbling, the Democratic State Committee elected here today 26 atlarge and 29 alternate delegates to the party's national miniconvention that will meet in Kansas City, Mo., from Dec. 6 to 8 to write the party's first national charter.

title: The Last
description: Our third and final lettuce crop of the season is ripe and we will be eating fresh garden salads at least until Thanksgiving. It always surprises me when friends wonder how we manage to grow greens so late in the year.

title: U.S. Experts Aid Hungary In CornYield
description: Units of 2,700 Acres Yields Climb Steadlly An American System

title: Pressure on Pretoria
description: In thanking the United States, Britain and France for saving South Africa from expulsion from the United Nations, Prime Minister Vorster made an assertion that must not go uncorrected. He said the three allies had cast their vetoes in South Africa's favor to block the expulsion resolution in the Security Council.

title: Dartmouth Defeats Lions by 210
description: HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 9Unaccustomed to a losing record at this time of the football season, Dartmouth faced a team today that was  Columbia. Custom and Dartmouth won out, 210, as Columbia suffered its second shutout in a row.

title: Tips on Grabbing Your Own Caboose
description: Should you want to buy a railroad car, write to the purchasing department of the nearest railroad and ask to be notified when one comes up for sale. Here are some of the people who can help:

title: Colonels Balance Overwhelms Nets
description: special to The New York Time LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 9 Round one of this season's battle of American Basketball Association heavyweights went to the Kentucky Colonels over the New York Nets tonight at Freedom Hall, 10397.

title: Bridges
description: The function of bridges, Christian Barman said, is the starting of a stream of human traffic hitherto impossible. He went on to explain the power that can lie within these static structures. Had there been no site for a medieval span between Wapping and Charing Cross, the city of London would never have existed.

title: ELECTRIC LIGHT TIES STRINGS TO ITS ROCK
description: Apart from the usual rock lineup the Electric Light Orchestra also carries a small compact string section. Thus are the battle lines drawn, and if the result is not exactly Elvis bludgeoning Mantovani, the sound produced by the group at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday was an interesting contrast in styles. Occasionally pretentious, It was always thrust at the audience with much energy.

title: Silvermans Have Child
description: A daughter was born Oct. 9 to Mr. and Mrs. Fred Silverman of Riverdale, the Bronx, at the Hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx.

title: Hayes Still in Running
description: St. Francis Prep will meet Iona Prep today for first place in the City Division of the Catholic Schools Football League. Each has 41 wonlost marks in the league and the contest at St. John's University will decide who plays Holy Family of Huntington, L. I., in the crossover game between firstplace teams in the two divisions. The crossover, addition to the league this season, will have teams from the Long Island Division playing host to the City Division school in the corresponding spot in the standing.

title: Ranchers, Filling Winter Larder, Get Year's Inflation All at Once
description: LARAMIE, Wyo.Dean Otte wheeled his flatbed truck up to the back door of the Ideal Food Market and began loading groceries as Mary Wood, the store manager, checked them off.

title: Princeton Looks To Bicentennial
description: PRINCETON The Princeton community, according to Anne Reeves, president of the Arts Council of Princeton, is making ambitious plans for a rich cultural billboard to honor the nation's Bicentennial. The billboard will include opera performances, ballets and theatrical presentations.

title: 2 Former Milk Executives Start Their Prison Terms
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 9 (AP)  Two former top executives of Associated Milk Producers, Inc., have begun serving terms in Federal prison for illegal election campaign contributions.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Westfield Beats Montclair And Avenges Upset of 73
description: Westfield's unbeaten team gained revenge over Montclair yesterday with a 25.6 victory before a crowd of 8,000 in Westfield.

title: New Angola Clashes Hinted at by Aides Of 2 Guerrilla Units
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Nov. 9Warnings of renewed guerrilla warfare in Angola were sounded here today by officials of the two principal guerrilla movements active in the Portugese territory.

title: Cost of New Carpeting Is a Senatorial Secret
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI)  Senatorial shoes will tread 9,040 yards of plush new blue and white carpeting when Congress reconvenes on Nov. 18. The carpeting is being installed while members are away for their monthlong election recess.

description: Sabres Trim Scouts. 61 North Stars Win by 75 Racers Beat Aeros, 54 Canadians win on Rally Penguins Beat Seals

title: SPOTLIGHT Selling Cars That Don't Sell:
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  In August of 1973 Ron Kelly, whose youthful dream had been to become an attorney, celebrated the move of his Stamford Motors, Inc., FordLincolnMercury automobile dealership from an old dilapidated building into a brand new, $2.5million facility near here.

title: Budd Builds on Autos
description: TROY, Mich.Can a company whose bestknown product is railroad passenger cars find health and happiness as one of the biggest suppliers to the automobile industry?

title: Concerts for the Shopper
description: In an effort to bring music to workers, shoppers and students in the Jamaica section of Queens, the Register/Jamaica Arts Center is sponsoring a series of afternoon concerts.

title: Decay Irks U.S. Troops In Okinawa
description: NAHA, OkinawaThe marines training in the rugged Okinawa catch, strip, roast, and eat snakes. They climb down the sides of steep cliffs on ropes, maneuver through the heavy brush under a tropical sun and sleep in orange clay turned to mud by frequent downpours.

title: Rains in SubSahara Area Raise Hopes for Good Harvests Soon
description: DAKAR, SenegalThe countries below the Sahara that suffered from catastrophic famine as a result of drought for the last two years, are enjoying a normal autumn rainy season that promises reasonable harvests in the weeks to come.

title: Democrats See a New Era in Suffolk
description: HOLBROOK  Sometime last Tuesday night, after election returns assured that Henry F. O'Brien, a Democrat, had scored an upset victory over District Attorney, Henry G. Wenzel 3d, the incumben Republican, an exhilarated Dominic Baranello, the Suffolk Democratic chairman, yelled out to his party followers:

title: Ashe Downs Vilas, Okker Beats Borg
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 9 (AP) Arthur Ashe and Tom Okker reached the final of the $100,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament today.

title: Interest in Thanatology Rises
description: EAST ORANGEInterest in thanatology, the description, theory or doctrine of death, is on the rise in New Jersey.

title: SCHOOL MEASURE BEATEN IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Nov. 9Antibusing sentiment soundly defeated this week a reform referendum measure to abolish the Boston School Committee.

description: College Football Scores

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: Capital investment by industry in 1975, estimated by McGrawHill Publications at a record $125.38billion or per cent over estimated 1974 spending will not significantly strengthen the economy. The gain will be washed out by inflationary equipment and construction costs. A coal strike will cause production losses and labor layoffs in other industries immediately, according to a Government task force.

title: Giants Vs. Jets: Johnson Fractures Hand
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 9An 11thhour injury to Ron Johnsona broken bone in his right handproduced another element of uncertainty and drama for tomorrow's 1 P.M. GiantsJets kickoff at Yale Bowl.

title: GULF LAND BOUGHT AS CRANE REFUGE
description: The lastknown colony of a rare and endangered species of sandhill crane on the Mississippi Gulf Coast has just won a race against developers bulldozers.

title: Holmes (Hooray!) Will Foil Moriarty (Hiss!) Once Again!
description: It is now 87 years since Sir Arthur Conan Doyle created the Ultimate Detective in a short story entitled A Study in Scarlet, and it is almost 75 years to the day since the American actor William Gillette stepped onstage at New York's old Garrick Theater to star in Sherlock Holmes, a play he himself had fashioned from an unsuccessful dramatization by Doyle. Since then, Sherlock Holmes has been the subject of at least 30 different stage presentations, including a Broadway musical and a ballet, not to mention radio plays, TV series and more than 150 films. And Holmes lives on to the present day. An elaborate, Royal Shakespeare Company revival of Gillette's play opens Tuesday at the Broadhurst after a long run in London and a highly successful fourweek stand at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D. C.

title: Miss Dwyer Plans Bridal
description: Maureen Ellen Dwyer, a firstyear student at the Fordham Law School, and David Pentland Stewart, a lawyer with the New York firm of Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine, plan to be married Nov. 23.

title: HANOI SAID TO CUT ITS FORCE IN LAOS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 2 North Vietnam is believed to have slightly reduced its troop strength in Laos and shifted most of its remaining military men in the country to administrative and logistical duties.

title: Clarkstown South Foils Upset Bid
description: Clarkstown South got the biggest scare of its championship season yesterday, but escaped with a 1513 victory over a Tappan Zee team that has won only one game. Billy McDonald, Rockland's top scorer, rushed over with the decisive extra points to give the Vikings their eighth straight victory.

title: Gen. Dayan to Talk at Upsala Tuesday
description: EAST ORANGE  Gen. Moshe Dayan, Israel's former Minister of Defense, will srpeak at Upsala College Tuesday night.

title: The Fattest Cat
description: When it comes to political spending, trade unions have, developed into the fattest of fat cats in this postWatergate period. The upward of $5 million contributed by unions to their 1974 Congressional favorites90 per cent of them Democratsis only the visible part of their investment. No less important is the largescale manpower and other untabulated services they muster in support of unionbacked candidates.

title: Miss Seldis Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Seldis of Massapequa, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Seldis, to David Gary Leibowitz. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Lebowitz of West Hempstead, L.I.

title: SOVIET REDS SEEK WORKER MEMBERS
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 9A new intenet directive of the Soviet Communist party has called for intensifying the drive to recruit new members among bluecollar workers, especially in the younger generation, according to Soviet sources.

title: Arrest in Philadelphia Theft
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that Dennis Wilson, 29 years old, of Philadelphia in connection with a North Philadelphia hank holdup in which three gunman escaped with about $74,000 after holding a bank manager's family hostage.

title: New Curbs on Thermal Pollution Could Be Costly to Utilities
description: TRENTON  Utilities charged with thermal pollution of New Jersey waters will be facing a tough, new policy this week.

title: British Trade Group in Cuba
description: MIAMI, Nov. 9 (AP)A 23member British trade mission is in Havana for meetings with high officials of Premier Fidel Castro's Government.

title: DeLury Faces ReElection Challenge
description: John J. DeLury, who has headed the 10,700member Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association since 1938, is being challenged in the union's election by an opposition ticket headed by Frank Farella, a sanitationman for 15 years and a shop steward from Brooklyn.

title: City Agrees to Pay $384Million for Water Tunnel Initially Set at $100Millionj
description: The city has reached tive agreement with a conIsortium of contractors to pay a total of $384million for work originally budgeted at slightly more than $100million on the biggest construction project in New York's historythe Third Water Tunnel a 13.7mile conduit that will connect with the watersupply system for all five boroughs.

title: Radio Code Led  F.B.I. to Oregon Couple Charged in Blast Threat
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 9Federal Bureau of Investigation agents used a direction to seek out radio code messages blown on a duck call to them to a couple arrested in connection with a $1million extortion plot, the agency said today.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: Nov. 13Westchester Sports Car Club meeting at Colonial Tavern, Hawthorne, N.Y., 8:30 P.M. Interested persons are welcome, Former members are asked to communicate with club concerning 25th anniversary celebration on Dec. 7. Information: Mary Minkon, phone (914)769.9314 or Ed Luiso, phone (914)6646788.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The midHudson Valley city of Newburgh remained calm after two days of racial disturbances that prompted officials there last Thursday to impose a fiveday 8 P.M. to 6 A.M. curfew. Since the trouble began, at least 23 persons have been injurednone seriouslyand about 25 have been arrested on a variety of charges. The cause of the violence was a fight last Monday evening between black and white teenagers at a rockband contest at the Newburgh Free Academy, a local high school. Opinions were split on whether to lift the curfew, imposed during the second night of sporadic rockthrowing and looting in the city's predominantly black northeast section. Black community leaders were demanding its repeal, but many whites favored its continuation. The curfew is to expire on Tuesday, under present regulations.

title: Thousands Take Heart Tests
description: SpedIal to The New York Tims NEWARKMore than 2,400 men between the ages of 35 and 57 already have been screened in the first six months of what is said to be the most ambitious heart attack prevention program ever undertaken in New Jersey. Those who are found to be qualified for the project, a sixyear study, will be asked to volunteer at no cost to themselves.

title: Threat of Plant Closing Stirs Worry and Protest in Detroit
description: DETROIT, Nov. 9  The Chrysler Corporation and Imperial signs slowly materialize in the distance, and the old eightstory factory grows and grows until it finally dominates the skyline of Detroit's East Side with a kind of roughedged majesty.

title: H. S. Jalli Is Fiance of Irene M. Melczer
description: Irene Mary Melczer, graduate assistant at Kean College of New Jersey, and Harinderbir Singh Jalli, who will receive a second master's degree from Rutgers University in January, plan to be married next summer.

title: Sunday Observer
description: The economic history of the modern age begins with the Crash of 1929 when stockbrokers jumped out of skyscrapers. The country learned its lesson, tore down the old skyscrapers and put up new ones with windows that couldn't be opened so that today stockbrokers have to be content with moving to smaller apartments.

title: State Faculties Seeking Right to Moonlight
description: TRENTONThe faculties of New Jersey's public colleges have gone before the State Supreme Court in their effort to seek the right to hold outside jobs without restrictions. The dispute has raised issues of broad public policy that the court is expected to settle in the near future.

title: Haunts And Hunts
description: Most authors realize that their ability to evoke the intensity of adolescent emotions offers a unique opportunity to generate suspense rooted in emotional conflict rather than in external events. But representing the stormy emotions of adolescence is no easy task, and the talent emerges only fitfully in the eight suspense novels reviewed today.

title: Bucks Trade Allen, Get Jim Price
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 AP)The Los Angeles Lakers announced late last night that they had traded Jim Price, a guard, to the Milwaukee Bucks for Lucius Allen, also a guard, in a straight player deal.

title: 2 PublicTV Outlets Planning to Expand
description: TRENTONWhile efforts to obtain a major commercial television station for New Jersey continues, two publictelevision outlets have announced plans to open new facilities in the state.

title: TEAMSTERS LOCAL TERMED IN CHAOS
description: SALINAS, Calif., Nov. 9The teamster union's first farm workers local, chartered here amid considerable ballyhoo in June, has fallen into chaos, according to one of its charter members and principal organizers, who was dismissed by the union last week.

title: Hussein Prepares to Sever Ties to West Bank
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 9King Hussein of Jordan was given power today to rule without Parliament for one year to reorganize his kingdom.

title: 2 Blue Goals in 3d Beat Islanders, 42
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9 (AP)Garry Unger drove home his own rebound 21 seconds into the final period and Barclay Plager added the final score as the St. Louis Blues beat the New York Islanders, 4.2, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: Midgets, Peewees and Junior Peewees give their all
description: The field in Eastchester, N. Y., is 100 yards long and 50 yards wide; the officials dress in the customary caps, striped shirts and knickers; several hundred enthusiasts occupy the stands, and on the nonartificial turf the opposing teams hunker down for the snap from center. The play rolls toward the sidelines; the hopefully unstoppable collides with the grudgingly movable in a clatter of polyethylene, viscose fibers, rubber and flesh. Humanity thumps the ground. The referee signals first down and 10. A replacement janizary receives detailed orders from his coach. What I want you to do, John, is go out there and tackle the guy with the ball.

title: Plan to Redraw School District Lines Is Protested in Some Brooklyn Areas
description: The possibility that community school district lines may be redrawn is being viewed with alarm in most parts of Brooklyn, although residents of a few neighborhoodsnotably East Flatbush and Brooklyn Heightssay they would welcome such a step.

title: Inventories: Uncertain Signs of Cutback
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co. has announced that its inventories are too high, and it is cutting them back. During October, according to a recent survey, more purchasing agents said they were reducing their materials inventories than building them for the first time since early 1972.

title: Senator Buckley Begins Tour Of Soviet at Moscow Synagogue
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 9Senator James L. Buckley flew into Moscow today, drove immediately to the main Moscow synagogue, and found Jews anxious about the details and implementation of the SovietAmerican agreement to ease restrictions on emigration.

title: Dartmouth Soccer Victor
description: HANOVER, N. H, Nov. 9Dartmouth scored late in the first half and added two more goals in the second half to take a 3.0 victory from Columbia in an Ivy League soccer game on Chase Field today.

title: Weakened Support
description: WASHINGTONThe heavy Democratic gains in Tuesday's elections present the Pentagon with new and particularly troublesome problems in getting what it wants out of the Congress.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Prospecting for gold here may never reach the frenzy that it once did in California or Alaska, but it's getting pretty lively.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: F. E. Masland Jr., in suggesting in a recent letter that what this nation needs are far more managers in government, implies that our problems are technical and managerial and would be readily solved if only the proper technological knowhow were applied. This knowhow, he assumes, is in the hands, and heads, of the managerial and technological elite, and it is to them that we ought to turn for solutions.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Paul Smithers Case
description: To the Editor: Thank you for the article on young Paul Smithers. I had a different impression of Canadian whites as opposed to American whites.

title: Port Authority Has Fallen on Hard Times
description: The giant Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, long one of the wealthiest, most powerful and most active public agencies in the world, has entered a period of difficulty unparalleled in its more than 50 years experience.

title: Wendy O'Brien Sets Marriage
description: Wendy Ellen O'Brien and Jeffrey Clay Sharts, students at Skidmore College, plan to marry next month. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents. Mr. and Mrs. Hubert F. O'Brien of Short Hills, N. J. Mr. Sharts is a son of Mrs. Raymond Ellis of Green Village, N. J. and Paul Sharts of Winter Park, Fla.

title: S.E.C. Busy As Builders Abroad Push Condo Sales
description: And now, the Europeans are getting increasingly into the business of offering resort rental condominiums to American buyers.

description: With the patient but scary tactics that have marked his victories, the great Forego barreled down the Aqueduct stretch yesterday and captured the long, long Jockey Club Gold Cup.

title: NINE PERSONS KILLED IN TEXAS CAR CRASH
description: LONGVIEW, Tex., Nov. 9 (AP)  Nine persons were killed today when their car left Interstate 20, careened through an overpass guard rail and landed upside down 50 feet below.

title: WASHINGTON BLAST HITS O.A.S. BUILDING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) An explosion today damaged the headquarters of the Organization of American States just three blocks from the White House, the police said.

title: Jenkins, Idle Dice, Roll Up 3d Victory
description: Rodney Jenkins continued onward and upward at the 91st National Horse Show last night by riding Idle Dice to victory in the $2,000 Gamblers Choice Stake for open jumpers.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: No Grouse Taken, but Hunters Bag 4 Woodcock
description: DORSET, Vt.Throughout the warm, gray day, ruffed grouse, or partridge as they are often called in northern New England, thundered away through the thick cover, sometimes never seen and always escaping unscathed.

title: Republicans: Only 1 Horse So Far, and He's Limping
description: WASHINGTONDespite the devastation it suffered at the polls, the Republican party still holds the single most important prize in American politics the White House. The question now is whether the party can hang on in 1976. The historical record offers little clear guidance.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Why honor, and truly pander to, one Literary Bum? Much less two?

title: Morristown Victory Paced by 3 Backs
description: Rick Sofield, Morristown's talented quarterback, scored two touchdowns yesterday and passed for a third as his team cleared another hurdle on the way to an unbeaten season with a 350 victory over Livingston in Livingston. Sofield opened the scoring with a 71yard run in the first quarter. He also scored on a sneak from the 2 and

title: James Kahrs Fiance Of Sheila A. O'Shea
description: Sheila Anne O'Shea, assistant dean of students at St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, and James Richard Kahrs, a member of the faculty at the Holy Family High School in Huntington Station, LI., plan to be married Dec. 28. Mrs. John F. O'Shea of Brooklyn has announced her daughter's engagement to the son of Mrs. Richard Kahrs of Westbury, L,I., and the late Mr. Kahrs.

title: Tass Assails Calley Release
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 9 (Reuters)Tass, the Soviet press agency said tonight that the release of William L. Calley Jr., who was convicted of killing 22 Vietnamese in Mylai in 1968, demonstrated the leniency of American courts to a war criminal.

title: Soft City
description: Jonathan Raban's Soft City is the first good picture of the quiet, rather private world of London's middleclass young. It aspires, however, to be something more: a picture of what all city life shares with this special milieu. Raban believes that all city cultures arise from the fleeting, contrived masks which people are prone to wear when in a milieu of strangers. Unlike the small town, where a person is a known and fixed quantity, the city is a place where you can assume a pose without easily being found out. In Raban's words, most people are hidden most of the time, their appearances are brief and controlled, their movements secret, the outlines of their lives obscure.

title: And Arafat Is Pleased To Take the Responsibility
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, was interviewed last week by Juan de Onis, New York Times correspondent in Beirut. Mr. de Onis was asked submit questions in advance and in writing; these are excerpts from the questions and answers:

title: Brookdale Showing To Aid Vietnamese
description: LINCROFTJoy of the Arts, an indoor arts and crafts exhibition for the benefit of the VietnameseAmerican Children's Fund, will be held next Friday, Saturday and Sunday at Brookdale Community College on Newman Springs Road.

title: New In Paperback
description: For four decades Isaac Bashevis Singer has been spinning tales, largely in Yiddishlanguage publications. This, the sixth collection of them to appear in English translation, won last year's National Book Award for fiction. The two dozen stories in, A Crown of Feathers are representative of all his work and demonstrate why he has won a large following of readers outside his own tradition. The settings range from Singer's native Poland and Israel to America. The principal characters are Jews, yet the themes are universal: the conflict of good and evil, the joys of sex, the gaps between generations. Singer's gusto gets all the fun out of the absurd, his humanity keeps the, tragic from becoming morose.

title: Dr. Susan Abrahams, Virologist, Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Abrahams of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Susan Jane Abrahams, to Ronald Edward DePetris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil F. DePetris of Southampton, L.I.

description: What is the most difficult shot in golf?

description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Outlook Is Bleak For Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITYA sense of gloom and despair has settled over The Playground of the World, which wanted so much to see conventioneers and tourists playing at casino gaming tables.

title: Dave Anderson The Rivalry That Isn't
description: In the beginning, the rivalry was naturalthe oldmoney Giants against the nouveau riche Jets for the pro football supremacy of New York's subways and suburbs. It was the type of rivalry that sports needs, and that a city needs, the type that can break up bars, or even homes. But instead of nourishing that rivalry, the National Football League schedulemakers The Times starved it. Until today's game in the of Yale Bowl, the Giants and Jets played once when the result counted in the standing. That was back in 1970, the first season that the merger was reflected in the N.F.L. schedule. The Giants won, 2210, in case you've forgotten. Most people have. The rivalry, doesn't really exist now. One of New York's most conscientious pro footballphiles proved that when he was asked if he was going to the game.

title: Concert: Foldes Returns
description: Andor Foldes, the Hungarianborn pianist, was a frequent performer here between 1941 and 1956. They were years in which he was a champion of the music of contemporary composers, particularly that of his countryman Bartk. After an 18year absence, he returned for a recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night. Now, in his more mature years, he is settling for traditional works. His program was Mozart's Sonata in C (K. 330), Schumann's Kinderscenen and Beethoven's Moonlight and Pathtique sonatas.

title: Glenn for President Club
description: NEWARK, Ohio, Nov. 9 (AP) A Newark realtor has legally reserved the name, John Glenn for President Club No. 1, but he says that the proposed candidate's staff has disavowed the move. He is Albert L. Spillman, who reserved the name in a filing with Secretary of State Ted W. Brown.

title: Law of the Sea' Is U. N. Theme
description: new international law and inspire cooperative global action. In the concept he envisioned, resources beyond nation's territorial waters would be the common heritage of mankind and under new international control for the benefit of all, particularly the developing nations.

title: State Library Group Discusses Obscenity
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Nov. 9With the passage of a revised obscenity law by the New York State Legislature on Sept. 1almost 200 years after the Bill of Rights  freedom of speech is still a hot issue at the New York Library Association's 81st annual convention, ending today at the Concord Hotel.

title: As in Boulder, Madison, Cambridge, Ann Arbor and other university communities, the goal in Austin is to live well
description: AUSTINAmerica may be developing a sort reverse Gulag Archipelago in its midst. There is chain of societies across the nation linked to one another but having little relation to the areas surrounding them. The camps in this archipelago have names like Boulder, Madison, Ann Arbor, Cambridge and Austin. They are university communities.

title: Young Essex Riders Revive the Glory of the Cavalry
description: WEST ORANGE  When 17yearold Second Lieut. Nicholas Albano gives the command, the equestrian drill team jumps through a formation of flaming poles.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Richards of Mantoloking, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Marcy Richards, to Steven Morris Hartig, son of Albert Hartig of Greenwich, Conn., and Brownsville, Vt., and the late Mrs. Joyce Beeman Hartig.

description: TRENTON, Displaying a highly selective and studied approach to voting, New Jersey residents demonstrated last Tuesday that they would not tolerate large new government spending, except to preserve the state's environment.

Orton award for his work in the field of dyslexia, a disturbance of the ability to read. He received the award at a congress sponsored by the Orton Society and the Mayo Clinic.

description: Members of Long Beach's City Council will henceforth be elected to terms of either two or four years in a system designed to provide continuity in government and give greater independence to those elected.

description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9Los Angeles will celebrate tomorrow the 10th anniversary of the Music Center, the threebuilding complex that has become the focus of the city's cultural life and helped to start a revival of the city's central core.

description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 (UPI) Attorney General. William B. Saxbe's call for deportation of more illegal aliens is declaring open season on all Mexicans, a Chicano activist leader maintains.

description: DOVER, Del., Nov. 9State Representative Marcelo Rispoli, Democrat of Wilmington, has been indicted on two counts of political interference in state hiring practices by a New Castle County grand jury.

description: 1 HOW TO BE YOUR OWN BEST FRIEND, by Mildred Newman and Bernard Berkowitz. (Ballantine, $1.50.) Some serious psychoanalysis couched in a cloying QandA format.

description: The stock market moved in an irregular pattern last week but managed to finish slightly higher in fairly active trading.

title: Britain Faces Coal Crisis And Winter Power Losses
description: LONDON, Nov. 9British coal miners, who played a central role in toppling the Conser vatives earlier this year, are locked in another battlethis time with the new Labor party Governmentthat could lead to more power losses this win ter.

title: Urban Unit to Hear Westinghouse Aide
description: EAST BRUNSWICKSome 400 businessmen, community leaders and guests from throughout Middlesex County are expected to attend an Equal Opportunity Day luncheon here Thursday. It will be held at the Ramada Inn on Route 18.

title: P. A. Meisels Fiance Of Miss Bulgarelli
description: Mr. and Mrs. Victor Buigarelli of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and Caracas, Venezuela, have announced the engagement of their daughter, SiMonetta Bulgarelli, to Peter Alexander Meisels. son of Nancy Meisels of New York and Dr. Morton Meisels of Bedford Hills, N.Y.
