title: The Lubavitchers believe it takes only a little stoking to ignite the spark religion in every Jew
description: According to a prominent Orthodox rabbi, nothing is so revolting to the thirdgeneration American Jew as the sight of his Hasidic brethren on the street. With their Yiddish accents and East European clothing, the story goes, they remind him something he had a nose job to forget.

title: Admetus, $64, Triumphs in International; Desert Vixen Second, With Dahlia Third
description: LAUREL, Md., Nov. 9The French flag flew from the winner's circle for the $150,000 Washington D. C. International today, but it marked the victory of Sir Michael Sobell's Admetus, rather than by the heavily favored Dahlia.

title: Candidates To Confront Crackdown On Finances
description: Special to The New York Times TRENTON  The state's Election Law Enforcement Commission is getting ready to crack down hard on those candidates who fail to comply with regulations on public disclosure of campaign finances.

title: Democratic Votes Sweep Across Nation's Suburbs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9Suburbs. Station wagons. Shopping centers. Crabgrass And Republicans.

title: Undemocratic Process: Too Few Vote, Too Few Can Run
description: WASHINGTONOn the surface, Tuesday's elections appeared to be a great popular uprising. Women, blacks and other minorities, environmental and consumer advocates and reform candidates were elected in record numbers. Mossbacks who seemed to have lost step with their constituents were swept out of offices. An oftencited example was Representative Earl F. Landgrebe, Republican of Indiana, who for years had opposed Federal aid against the wishes of his own district.

title: 5 INDICTED IN SOUTH IN STATION SEIZURE
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov, 9 (AP)Five persons have been indicted in the Oct. 12 radio station takeover during which appeals for insurrection were broadcast.

title: Gurney's 75 Plans Await Rule Changes
description: Daylight saving time is ended and nights are long and this is the time of year to think about next year. Dan Gurney, for one, isn't finding it easy.

title: Burnham Of Chicago
description: Interest in American eclectic architecture, a nasty and unmentionable subject 15 or even 10 years ago, continues to grow. No doubt, this is due in part to the fact that so much has been written about the modern movement that scholars are forced to turn elsewhere for fresh subjects. But this growing interest also reflects a serious belief that the eclectics who picked and chose styles from the past often produced a more humane and decent architecture than their contemporaries in the developing modern movement of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Until recently architectural scholarship was utterly disdainful of the eclectics; now it is beginning to look at these less innovative, but perhaps equally important, architects with a more respectful eye.

title: Three Weeks in a MadeforTV Film Factory
description: Since that night in October 1964 when NBC experithentally telecast in prime time a brand new twohour movie called See How They Run, motion pictures made expressly for television audiences have proved to be one of the more mutually profitable products of the relationship between Hollywood and the TV industry. Initially dismissed by critics as ersatz, these madeforTV films have steadily elbowed aside situation comedies and dramatic series to garner sizable shares of primetime audiences each week on all three networks.

title: Radio
description: Friday Tuesday Wednesday Saturday Today: Leading Events Monday The Week's Concerts Thursday Today

title: Exodus of Soviet Jews DOwn 37% From 1973
description: GENEVA, Nov. 9 (Reuters) Emigration of Jews from the Soviet Union to Israel declined by 37 per cent in the. first 10 months of this year compared with the same period of 1973, a spokesman for the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration said here this week.

title: Doctor Asks Him to Attempt to Loosen Lung Secretions Breathing Device Used
description: LONG BEACH, ?, Nov. Former President Richard M. Nixon is und'r his doctor's orders this weekend to cough as hard as he can, despite the pain r in the side this causes him, in an effort to clear up his pneumonia.

title: Exeter Tops Andover
description: ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 9 Last Tuesday, 10 Andover students raided Exeter's campus radio station in upcountry New Hampshire. They held the student disc jockey there at bay while they played a threeminute tape extolling the prowess of the Andoverians football squad. The tape was designed to strikeo fear in the ranks of Andover's rivals. Announced at Exeter as production of Radio Free Prep School, the tape apparently only served to whip up the determination of the Big Red's players. This afternoon in the 94th struggle between the schools, Exeter won, 287.

title: LETTERS
description: In his interesting harkback to Berlin's cabarets in the 1920's (Are We as Nude, Even Lewd, as Brazen Old Berlin?, Oct. 27), Percy Knauth writes about that most prominent of literary and political cabarets, the Kabarett der Komiker, and infers that it was swept away with the rest when the Nazis came into power in 1933.

title: KISSINGER ENDS 18DAY JOURNEY HOPEFUL OF GAINS; Secretary Said to Foresee Progress With Russians on Strategic Weapons; REPORTS TO FORD TODAY; Outcome of Mideast Talks Expected to Open Way to Further Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9Secretary of State Kissinger returned home today, hopeful that his 18day, 27,000mile trip had opened the way to further strategic arms limitation agreements with the Soviet Union and stepbystep peace moves in the Middle East.

title: Theater
description: LONDON Peter Nichols Is a playwright who knows the value of the double take. An interviewer who visits his demure house in London's Georgian district of Blackheath is greeted by a gaunt, silverhaired figure who for some reason resembles an offduty bishop. It takes a second look to realize that the effect comes from Nichols's actorishly smart matching purple sweater and corduroy trousers. On his hall table stands an elegantly latticed white china receptacle into which one might casually it toss newspapers or letters. A second glance reveals that it is in fact a net undershirt Tendered in porcelain. Over it hangs an expensivelooking modern collage. Look again; its richly colored fragments of fabric are the remains of an ancient pair of trousers with the pockets turned inside oasta typically suspicious, doubleedged Nichols joke about success.

title: HARTKE SAYS HUNGER IS THREAT TO PEACE
description: Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, said here last night that the United States should fear the effects of widespread hunger, and the threat it poses to world peace, as it once feared the threat of a nuclear holocaust.

title: If?
description: It is with pleasure and kudos that I announce the publication of the third and final volume of the REFERENCE GUIDE TO FANTASTIC FILMS: Science Fiction, Fantasy, and Horror, by Walt Lee. A gigantic work, the product of a quartercentury of meticulous research and scholarship, the Guide lists thousands  somewhere between 7 and 10, I would judge of films, with a surprising amount of data on each. In addition, there is a section called Problems and one called Exclusions, each a long alphabetical listing, to answer in advance queries if or why this or that film was or was not included in the body of the work.

title: Badillo Urges Hearings on BilingualEducation Program Here After Shanker's Criticism
description: Representative Herman Badillo called last week for public hearings on allegations made by Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, that New York City's bilingual education program was not being properly conducted.

title: DR. SHERBURNE COOK
description: PACIFIC GROVE, Calif., Nov. 9 (UPI)Dr. Sherburne Friend Cook, emeritus professor of physiology at the University of California at Berkeley, died on Thursday of cancer. He was 77 years old.

title: Back Gains 310 Yards In South Shore Romp
description: South Shore unveiled its version of pro football's Mack Herron yesterday in the person of Mike Drummond, a senior halfback. Drummond, hurt against Madison last Sept. 28 in South Shore's first game, ran for 310 yards in 20 carries as he led his team to a 62.0 triumph over Wingate.

title: KARPOV, KORCHNOI DRAW 20TH GAME
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 9Anatoly Karpov came into the Central Chess Club this afternoon, made six perfunctory move and offered a draw in the 20th game of his final Candidates Match for the world championship with Viktor Korchnoi. Korchnoi immediately accepted.

title: Soma Golden, Reporter, to Be Bride of William Behr
description: Soma Suzanne Golden, a reporter for The New York Times, and William Alexander Behr, a graduate student in psychiatric social work, plan to be married on Thanksgiving Day at the home of the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin E, Golden of Washington.

title: ROBERT BYRNE
description: Alexander Koblentz, Mikhail Tal's trainer for many years, recently told me, It is really a pity that Mischa did not win the return match that enabled Botvinnik to recover the world championship in 1961. Tal always played like a real champion, creating more exciting games than anyone.

title: Arrest Ends Assassin Hunt
description: DENVER, Nov. 9 (UPI) The police said today that the arrest of Thomas Creech, 24 years old, in Idaho yesterday in two slayings had ruled out the possibility that he was in Denver as an assassin hired to kill Senatorelect Gary Hart, Democrat of Colorado.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Future Social Events
description: Nov, 13New York will be piping hot this week because, today through Saturday, it's Scotland Week, and besides all the private parties celebrating it, there'll be bagpipes skirling and kilts whirling in our parks and plazasLincoln, General Motors, Rockefellerand so many restaurants serving Scottish specialties that you can probably get haggis in the Stage Delicatessen, The highlight of it all is the Fourth Scottish Ball at the Plaza Hotel, which has settled into a fine formula of fun and pageantry. You also help the AmericanScottish Foundation bring that castleintheair, Scotland House, closer to terra firma. The guests of honor will be led by the Earl of Mar and Kellie, Hereditary Keeper of Stirling Castle (that's a lot of housekeeping) and his Countess; Lord MacDonald, High Chief of Clan Donald, and Lady MacDonald of MacDonald; the Earl and Countess of Elgin and John F. Smith, the Lord Provost (Mayor) of Aberdeen and the Lady Provost. The evening starts with whistlewetting in the Terrace Room before you are piped into the Grand Ballroom for dinner and dancing with Emery Davis conducting. A flavorsome Scottish product, Teacher's Scotch Whiskey, is the ball's sponsor. Tickets, $60 a person, from Ruth Nicholson, 130 East 63d Street. Lady Malcolm DouglasHamilton is president of the beneficiary.

title: Sooners Crush Missouri
description: STATISTICS OF THE GAME STATISTICS OF THE GAME California Triumphs, 5226 STATISTICS OF THE GAME Okla, State on Top Nebraska 2313 Victor STATISTICS OF THE GAME

title: Female Friends
description: In two novels now, the British playwright and novelist Fay Weldon has created a remarkable assembly of women, ram pant against a field of the exasperating parents they rebelled against but learned too well from, and the husbands and lovers whom they allow to make their lives a kind of unbearable yet marvelous madhouse. Their vintage is preliberation, but the fact that Weldon women are often passive victims of their femaleness is never the defining element of their characters: they are insistently, even riotously, alive.

title: Miss Cooper, Actress, Plans a June Wedding
description: Sandra Marie Cooper, an actress and choreographer, plans to be married in June to Paul ReindlSchweighofer of Vienna, who is in Basel, Switzerland, as stage manager and technical director for the Schweizer Tournee Theater there.

title: Paperbacks
description: Fernand Braudel is one of the greatest living historians. His reputation was made in 1949 by one bookThe Mediterranean and the Mediterranean World in the Age of Philip II. (Recently published in an excellent English translation, it is available so far only in a twovolume hardcover edition from Harper & Row at $35 the set) This work made its impact partly by its vast scope; it carried the reader away from national or sectional history, but even more by the philosophy that underlay it. That philosophy was not new it had already been practiced in France by Lucien Febvre, who founded a historical review, the Annales, to propagate and illustrate it. Since the death of Febvre, Braudel has been the undisputed leader of the Annales school, whose influence has been felt by every serious historian.

title: Anorexics look like gorgeous waifs, but they may be simply trying not to grow up
description: No one can prove itthere are no statisticsbut the incidence of anorexia nervosa, once thought an extraordinarily rare condition, seems to be up. Simply described, anorexia nervosa is willful selfstarvation, sometimes to the point of death.

title: David Mahood, Jennifer Beach Wed in Darien
description: Jennifer Katherine Beach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Holbrook Beach of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon in Darien to David Edward Mahood. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mahood of Watchung, N.J.

title: Rhode Island Guard Ordered to Hospital As Striker Is Killed
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 9 (AP)Gov. Philip W. Noel ordered 86 members of the state National Guard today to assist in support services at the Rhode Island Institute of Mental Health in Cranston, while hospital workers remained on strike.

title: Music Aimed at Children
description: They squirmed and danced in their seats, letting the music move their bodies. When they were bored, they chatted to each other or fell asleep. But when they were happy, their laughter and applause filled the goldandwhite opera house at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Madison Presbyterian Tops Fund Goal by $200,000
description: Madison Avenue Presbyterrian, one of the city's bestknown Protestant churches, announced last week that it had topped by nearly a quarter million dollars its fundraising goal or $1.2million. It was the largest sum raised by the church in its 75year history.

title: Flim; My films are filled with disgust of sex, life, everything. (Ralph Bahshi); The RRated Cartoon World Of Ralph Bakshi (Bambi It Ain't)
description: The Ratings Board hates me. They give practically everything I do an X. They don't trust me. They don't trust this kid off the Brooklyn streets who dares to have a mind. He's a Brooklyn kid, so everything he does on the screen must be dirty. Well, they're out of their heads. And they call me erotic. I'm about as erotic as Adolf Hitler! My movies are antierotic. I hate sex. I always have. My filMs are filled with disgust of sex, life, everything,

title: Wolf pack Defense Holds in 2d Half
description: RALEIGH, N.C. Nov. 9 A senior fullback, Stan Fritts, ??? for one touchdown and passed to Pat Hodance for another today and the North Carolina State defense halted two potential Penn State scoring thrusts in the second half as the Wolfpack upset the sixthranked and Cotton Bowlbound Nittany Lions, 127.

title: The World
description: Henry Kissinger's salvage mission, to try once more to turn truce into peace in the Middle East, has begun with modest reports of progress but amid a deepening sense that another round of war may be ahead.

title: SpecialInterest Funds Fail to Win Some Elections
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9Big money from special interest groups was unsuccessful in number of key elections Tuesday.

title: Jews and American Politics
description: At one point during the 1972 election, George McGovern walked into delicatessen in New York's Garment District and ordered chopped chicken liver with milk. Heads turned. Eyebrows were raised. The waitress tried to explain that, uh, you don't have chicken liver with milk, Senator. But McGovern just smiled his awkward South Dakota smile and insisted on the milk. A young New York campaign aide rolled his eyes and murmured to reporter: Well, there goes New York.

title: SOVIET SEES IMPACT OF U.S. VOTE RESULT
description: MOSCOW; Nov. 9In a second, delayed look at the American midterm elections, Pravda has conveyed a subdued warning to its readers that the results could have an impact on foreign policy issues affecting the Soviet Union.

title: The Trip of Aniara
description: I experienced a nice coincidence a few weeks ago. I'd placed a recording on the turntableColumbia Masterworks MS 7176, featuring Ormandy; Bernstein and others in music for armchair astronauts. On the flip side, my friend and neighbor Werner Janssen conducts a suite from KarlBirger Blomdahl's opera Aniara, based on the poem by Harry Edmund Martinson. I chose Aniara.

description: Monmouth Jockeys

title: Why So Many Camera Lenses?; Electronic 35
description: reflex (SLR) type 35mm camera, since a great majority of the lenses made today are designed for use with these cameras. SLR's not only offer easy lens interchangeability, they also enable the photographer to actually see through the lens while focusing and composing. Thus, in a direct way, the SLR camera is an extension of the photographer's eye and by using lenses with different optical characteristics his or her vision can be extended and amplified in interesting waysand therein lies the answer to the second question: What can these lenses do for the photographer? Lenses for SLR cameras can be divided into five basic categories: normal lenses, wide angles, longfocus or tele lenses, zoom lenses, and macro lenses.

title: Television This Week
description: 11:00 A.M. (2) CAMERA THREE. A profile of the 77yearold British sculptor Henry Moore. Part one of a twopart series.

title: Program to Weigh Slaying of Kennedy
description: CAMDEN  Who Killed J.F.K.?, an audiovisual presentation questioning the findings of the Warren Commission on the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, will be presented at Rutgers University here Thursday night.

title: What's Doing in BUDAPEST
description: BUDA AND PESTTo set things straight, that is Buda on the hills of the Right Bankresidential, green, laden with historylooking down across the Danube at Pest on the Left Bank, flat, urban, choked with traffic and people. Not until 1872 did the two come together, with a third section, Obuda, to make Budapest. Today it is a city of two million. One out of every five people in Hungary lives in Budapest. There is nothing as big between Paris and Moscow unless you swing north to Berlin or south to Rome. Officials in at least three Eastern European capitals have told me their city is the Paris of the East. Budapest really is; the lights burn bright and automobiles have to find parking places on the sidewalks. But it's also the Los Angeles of the East: smog.

title: Navy Launches First of 30 Patrol Hydrofoil Missile Ships, Opening New Era
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 9Pegasus, the first of a revolutionary new class of Patrol Hydrofoil Missile ships, was launched here today.

title: GOVERNMENT URGED TO STEP UP RAIL USE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) Less than onehalf of 1 per cent of Government travel in fiscal 1974 was by train, although the Government has made a commitment to save railroad passenger trains, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

title: Thomas Takes A Fresh Look At Beethoven
description: Every generation of musicians has to discover its own way of looking at music. Without that it cannot interpret the works of the past with any conviction. For some the discovery may be merely in terms of traditional concepts. For others it may be a new, radical approach. For still others it may be a process of rediscovery through forgotten or ignored ideas. Last week, this column took a look at Sergiu Luca's arrival at his own approach to Bach's unaccompanied violin literature, which was through a reexamination of instrumental means. This week the parallel subjects are Michael Tilson Thomas and Beethoven. The conductor of the Buffalo Philharmonic is bringing his orchestra, assisted by the Rutger University Chorus, to Carnegie Hall next Sunday afternoon to present some of Beethoven's music in the light of his own understanding of what the compowanted.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: LEAVING HOMEDavid French's drama about a mother, father and two sons locked In infrafamily warfare. Directed by Charles Marren. At the Riverside Church. Opens Tuesday.

title: Milltown Vote Provides Some Surprises
description: MILLTOWNThis Middlesex County town was in a class by itself last Tuesday. Unlike the political results in just about every precinct across the country, Milltown proved an exception by coming up with a number of surprises in the sixway battle for two Borough Council seats.

title: Back at the MetAfter 18 Years
description: On Friday night there will be a homecoming at the Metropolitan Opera. Midway through the first act of the new production of Janacek's Jenufa one of the greatest singingactresses ever to honor the Metropolitan stage will return to the company where she made her debut nearly 33 years ago, and where she has not sung since 1956.

title: Greeley Gets Its
description: Revenge

title: A Caboose Rolled By, and We Grabbed It
description: GAYLORDSVILLE, Conn.  In October, 1971, just after we moved the Gaylordsville railroad station 1,000 yards down the Penn Central's tracks and turned it into a home, a friend decided that we needed a caboose. Pointing to the far end of our property, beyond where my husband, Cle, had staked out a place for a pool, he said that we ought to have a caboose out there for a bathhouse.

title: John Fowles's linear art
description: It is strange that a novelist as imaginative, as literate and as ambitious as John Fowles should be content to write within the canons of conventional textbook realism. Of the four stories in The Ebony Tower, three are simple, linear structuressituation, complication, resolutionthe incidents rationally linked through the probable interactions of probable characters, the action and theme neatly illustrating each other. Shades of Somerset Maugham. The fourth story is somewhat more openended and covetsa picnic in the country that ends in a disappearance and, by implication, a suicide: one has to draw the connections for oneself and see the sudden gathering storm at the end as an epiphany but this is a technique that Joyce was practicing in Dubliners in 1906 and that is still being practiced, from week to week, in the pages of The New Yorker and elsewhere.

title: Cleveland Press Shuts Down After Strike at Rival Paper
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 9 (Reuters) Cleveland was without daily newspapers today as The Cleveland Press suspended publication. A strike by the Newspaper Guild has closed the Cleveland Plain Dealer since a week ago Thursday and a strike by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has stopped the distribution of outoftown newspapers in the city for the last two weeks.

title: British Tell How They Learned Nazi Secrets
description: One sunny morning in 1940, Col. Steward Menzies of Britain's Setret Intelligence Service sent four slips of paper to the British Air Ministry. Their contents were prosaicroutine personnel changes in the German Luftwaffe.

title: From soaring statements to shoddy mediocrity
description: The public building that serves and symbolizes the institutions of government has always striven for dignity, monumentality, a suggestion of art and an indication of the nobler aspects and ideals of man. On it did, until recently. One look at most of today's public buildings suggests that somewhere on the way from the 19th to the 20th century a lot of values got lost. Symbolism, as a suggestion of the finer qualities of mind, character or construction, is a thing of the past. Or looked at another way, symbolism is there all right, saying a lot of things about us that we might rather not hear.

title: Pay Wins in the Profit Shareout;POINT OF VIEW
description: During a nationwide broadcast an the evening of Jan. 19, 1946, in the midst of the United Auto Workers fourmonth strike against the General Motors Corporation, Walter Reuther, the union's president, said:

title: Terrorism in Argentina
description: Long before she assumed the presidency on the death of her husband, Isabel Martinez de Peron said she aspired to be a factor for reconciliation among Argentines, and especially among Peronists. Despite that lofty objective, Argentina during her three months in office has drifted rapidly toward, civil war, fueled in large part by an escalating campaign of murder and terror waged against each other by Peronists of left and right.

description: World Hockey Ass'n Amer. Basketball Ass'n Nat'l Basketball Ass'n Nat'l Hockey League

description: CLIFTON Representative Robert A. Roe charged last week that bungling and indecision by Federal officials had prevented this city from acquiring 25 acres of land used by the Department of Agriculture that Clifton wants for development as a civic center.

title: World News Briefs
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 9 (AP)President Hugo Banzer's Cabinet resigned today after the military had called for a new Government and the indefMite postponement of elections. The new cabinet is not expected to differ much from his old one.

title: DR. ALFRED H. IASON
description: Dr. Alfred H. Jason, a specialist in the surgical repair of hernia, died Friday of cancer in New York Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 175 East 74th Street.

title: 3 CATHOLICS DIE IN ULSTER FEUDING
description: BELFAST, Northern ??? Nov. 9Three Roman Catholics were killed and two Protestants injured today and late last night in a series of revange shootings in the Belfast area following one of Ulster's most violent weeks in many months.

title: Rutgers Trounces Lafayette, 35 to 0
description: Team officials did not know if he would be ready for the Dec. 16 Liberty Bowl.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: American cities and American roads are the two benchmarks of 20thcentury American civilization. The expressways that lead in and out of cities have profundly affected their growth and decline. They have also made the suburbs possible. Highways have created the contemporary cultural pattern of rapid personal mobility. Their routes have changed the landscape and cityscape with traumatic impact. In the process they have engendered controversies and crises that have led to a startled awareness of the highway as environment. Today highways are prime, dramatic examples of the relatively new concept of environmental design.

title: News of the Screen
description: A dramatization of the life of James R. Hoffa, the former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, is scheduled to be filmed by Robert Conrad. The actor, who played in The Wild Wild West TV series and in movies including Young Dillinger and the forthcoming Murph the Surf, said that he had acquired rights to produce the feature and play. Mr. Hoffa after a lengthy conference with the exlabor leader.

title: Food
description: Certain dishes have a special appeal not only because of their inherent excellence, but because of a certain novelty in presentation. The Swedish pork roast with the jawbreaking name of plommonspckad flskkarr is a delectable example. In English it is a pork loin stuffed with pitted prunes. The technique of stuffing the meat is simple enough, although it may seem a trifle tedious to some. Like most roast pork dishes, this one goes admirably with pured potatoes or a pured blend of potatoes and celery root.

title: Penn Central and City Plan Cleanup
description: The Penn Central Railroad and the City Department of Sanitation are in the process of working out an agreement to clean up the rail tracks that run through the Bay Ridge, Bensonhurst, Borough Park, East Flatbush, Flatbush, East New York and Ridgewood sections of Brooklyn. The entire run is known as the Bay Ridge Line.

title: A Medieval French Village, Circa 1974
description: cAN modern man survive for 24 hours or more under medieval conditions? Its not the sort of problem a traveler often faces: 'The tourist's world has no shortage of ruined castles, timeworn pilgrimage sites and gothic inns. But usually there is a way out at the end of the sightseeing daya lively entertainment district, a movie, at the very least a shopping street for local products and souvenirs.

title: UNICEF Meeting Produces Pledges Totaling $62Million
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 9 (Reuters)  The United Nations Children'S Fund has raised nearly $62million from its first pledging conference.

title: DANCE VIEW CLIVE BARNES
description: It was June 24, 1967. I was in Leningrad for the first time. For ballet lovers, Leningrad and the Kirov will probably always remain St. Petersburgh and the Maryinsky Theater in our secret hearts. When you approach the Kirov school, the guide book tells you that you are walking down Rossi Street. But the shadows of the past remind you that it is really called Theater Street, the name Karsavina even gave to her autobiography.

title: Big Queens Project to Open in January
description: North Shore Towers, a 33story rental complex that straddles the QueensNassau county line on the site of the former Glen Oaks Country Club, will be ready for occupancy in January.

title: Fordham Extends Hamilton's Slump
description: Fordham kicked its first successful field goal in three years, then went on to extend Hamilton's losing streak to 20 games, going back to 1972, with a 1613 victory yesterday at Jack Coffey Field.

title: FILM VIEW VINCENT CANBY
description: As reflected in good movies and bad, serious ones as well as forthrightly foolish, New York City has become a metaphor for what looks like the last days of American civilization. The metaphor is there for all to see in Ivan Passer's gently chaotic comedy, Law and Disorder, which is about a team of bumbling auxiliary policemen, in Michael Winner's vicious Death Wish, in Joseph Sargent's cheerful underground caper movie, The Taking of Pelham One Two Three (in which an IRT subway train is hijacked), and in any number of cop movies, from Sidney Lumet's angry, obsessed Serpico to the nonsense of something like The Super Cops. It's even there in a farce of the order of Barbra Streisand's For Pete's Sake.

title: Filipino Claimant of Islands In South China Sea Seized
description: MANILA, Nov. 9A Filipino educator and sea captain who is pursuing a 20yearold claim on a group of islets in the South China Sea northeast of the Spratlys has been detained by the Philippine Government.

title: Expert Fears Alaska Oil Line
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  A Rutgers University professor, who. also is an internationally known expert on Arctic soils, is predicting that all hell's going to break loose on Alaska's north slope within five years after hot oil starts flowing through the transAlaska pipeline.

title: A.E.C. Files Show Effort To Conceal Safety Perils
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9Atomic Energy Commission cuments show that for at least, the last 10 years the commission has repeatedly sought to suppress studies by its own scientists that found nuclear reactors were more dangerous than officially acknowledged that raised questions about reactor safety devices.

title: Athletic Scholarships Yes, Academic Scholarships No
description: If I were a college president, l would recruit athletes, not scholars. I would give grantsinaid for sports, not for academic achievement The scales in education have been tipped too much in favor of the intellectual. It is time to raise our level of consciousness about the importance of sport and play.

title: Music: Ana Trenchi de Bottazzi Plays
description: Ana Maria Trenchi de Bottazzi is an Argentine pianist of Italian descent who studied in Argentina, America and France and taught in Japan before moving to Long Island. Yesterday afternoon in Town Hall she gave a most impressive recital in which she sounded at her very best in German music.

title: Book Ends
description: Teen Dreams. There have been a lot of words written about rock but the first book to express the subliminal content of the music in pictures is Rock Dreams, a collection of combined photographs and paintings in full color by a Belgian artist named Guy Peellaert. The paintings, on which Mr. Peellaert labored for three years, are a stylistic melange of camp, kitsch, pop art and even a little Norman Rockwell, if you can imagine a stoned Norman Rockwell (may The Saturday Evening Post strike us dead for that thought). Using his own dreams in some cases, Mr. Peellaert has draped the private lives and public images of a galaxy of rock stars from Bill Haley to Marc Bolan in fantasy, Rock Dreams unlocks the collective subconscious of the rock fan, spewing out an iconography of rocka pantheon of heroes and heroines swimming in the floating world of changing fads. There is Elvis Presley (in a bathing suit) kneeling before an image of the Virgin, thanking her for the success of Crying in the Chapel, Frankie Avalon and Annette Funicello at a beach party, the Beatles having tea with the Queen, the Rolling Stones in Nazi uniforms entertaining prepubescent girls. Mr. Peellaert ranges from parody of Pat Boone's whitebuck wholesomeness to a sick joke (Stevie Wonder as a blind beggar in front of the Apollo Theater) to a stark picture of Janis Joplin sprawled on a bed in an empty room. The book also works as a history of rock, graphing the divagations of taste; a text by the English rock writer Nik Cohn effectively mixes myth and memory.

title: BIAS IS CHARGED IN BOOK REJECTION
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 9The authors of a new textbook on Mississippi history have charged that their book was rejected for use in public schools because of racial bias. The book depicts, to a greater extent than texts now in use, the black experience in Mississippi, including the civil rights struggle of the nineteensixties.

title: Nuclear Plant to Proceed
description: BANGOR, Me., Nov. 9 (AP)Central Maine Power Company said Thursday it had decided to go ahead with plans to build a nuclear generating plant at Sears Island.

description: Horse Show Calendar Aqueduct's Gold Cup Chart Roosevelt Raceway Results Aqueduct Jockeys

title: Met Squash Racquets
New &Novel
description: In this suspense bonanza, Berkely Mather has melted down the scenarios for at least three novels and poured them into one jumbo entertainment. Number one tells how Lieut. Charles Wyndham, while commanding an Indian Army outpost on the Afghanistan border, manages to get himself cashiered for armed robbery and murder. It isn't easy. Two depicts prison life on the Andaman Islands, where Wyndham is sent after conviction. And from which he escapes in an outrigger canoe after such complications as you wouldn't believe. Three deals with his new identity, or two new identities. One as a probationary foreman in the Kola gold fields. And the other as a dacoit, or bandit, in cahoots with indigenous hoods who have practiced their art for centuries. Wyndham's big heist, which has something to do with his experience in the gold mines, is a spectacularly appropriate finaleA roomy, old fashioned adventure novel, rich in atmospherics and action.

title: IVORY JOE HUNTER, BLUES PIANIST, 63
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 9 (AP)Ivory Joe Hunter, composerpianist of country, blues and popular songs died of lung cancer yesterday in a hospital here. He was 63 years old.

title: Chapman, a Driver, Fractures Arm
description: WESTBURY, L. L, Nov. 9 John Chapman, who led the drivers in victories at the Roosevelt Raceway summer meeting, fractured his right arm in a freak accident at his home here yesterday morning and will be out indefinitely.

title: CRITICS REBUTTED BY NURSING AIDE
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 9Wiley M. Crittenden Jr., president of the American Nursing Home Association, has defended the use of Medicare and Medicaid funds by delegates attending a sixday convention in Waikiki.

title: Ferraro Seeks Airport Office
description: subject of Congressional hearings more than two years ago. But despite widespread awareness of the extent of the criminal operations, the District Attorney's office asserts that crime is still thriving at the airport.

title: Bribes Still Cement Construction
description: New evidence of largexcale corruption involving every phase of the construction industry in New York City apparently has been uncovered again in a twoyear investigation, and is being prepared for presentation to grand juries. In a major change from past investigations, bribe givers as well as takers will be involved.

title: Park Service Defends Its Peters Valley Record
description: Special to The New York Times COLUMBIAAnyone who wants to look at the record would be unable to deny that the National Park Service has done more than its fair share for Peters Valley, asserted Park Superintendent James McGlocklin, who has his headquarters in the Warren County community.

title: New Look for Murray Hill
description: MURRAY HILLThere's a new view for commuters at the railroad station here. A cluster of buildings about 25 feet from the ErieLackawanna tracks are being converted into a picturesque shopping complex.

title: INVESTING
description: In the froth of a bull market, milliondollar ideas are as welcome as budding trees in springtime. But when the bears take over, ideas that seemed like sure winners palllike falling leaves.

title: Marjorie Kirk Wed to Writer
description: Marjorie Katharine Kirk, daughter of Mrs. William. Kirk of Freeport, L.I., and the late Mr. Kirk, was married here yesterday afternoon, to Richard E. Aultman, an author and a freelance writer, of Westport, Conn. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Aultman of Moline, ill.

title: Poly Prep Still Master of St. Paul's
description: Poly Prep Still Master of St. Paul's

title: Elizabeth Is Urged to Improve Traffic
description: ELIZABETH  Sixtyone recommendations for improvng the flow of traffic here were put forth in a major study recently completed by Richard P. Browne Associates of Wayne. The study was commissioned by the state's Department of Transportation.

title: A PopArt Star Finds New Inspiration in Matisse
description: Once called by a critic the worst artist in America, Poppainter Roy Lichtenstein seems to have graduated lately to an honored emeritus status. That dubious label, like the onceflourishing Pop movement itself of a decade ago, has pretty much disappeered into thin air. The days of Pop stardom, frenzied loft Parties, zany happenings and maximum coverage by the media are a thing of the past'Both Lichtenstein and his art, which was derived from comic strip cartoons and blatant commercial advertisements, have moved on to quieter, more cultured pastures.

title: JeanAlice Uehlinger Engaged To Richard H. Cowan, Editor
description: JeanAlice Uehlinger, a candidate for a Master of Divinity degree at the Episcopal Divinity School in Cambridge, Mass., will be married to Richard Huston Cowan, editor of Animals magazine and director of public information for the Massachusetts Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

title: Ventnor to Vote on Its Aluminum Boardwalk
description: VENTOR  After experimentally treading a 500foot aluminum section of their boardwalk, Ventnor residents will have an opportunity to determine whether they like it or would rather stay with the traditional wooden walk.

title: Headliners.
description: Bill Edwards was a legend on the campus of Davidson College in Davidson, North Carolina. Stories of his exploits both on the campus, as a member of the class of 1953, and later as a real estate pioneer and a researcher on a zero gravity platform, were recorded with awe in the college alumni bulletin. When it was reported that he had died under mysterious circumstances while investigating a drug ring in 1973, he was honored with a plaque and a photograph that hung on a memorial bookdrop in the college's new brary. Like many other legendary heroes, though, Bill Edwards never really existed. Last week, members of the class of 1953 revealed that they had concocted the story of Bill Edwards. The photo and plaque are being removed from the library.

title: VOTER VIEWS VARY ON ENVIRONMENT
description: Rapid Transit Rejected See No Benelits For Nuclear Plants Bond Issues Are RejectedLand Preserves Backed

title: Notes: The Russians Develop a Games Plan
description: I T seems a long way off, but 1980 is already starting the Soviet Government and its tourist officials in the face. The Olympic Games will be held in Moscow that yeara fact that was very much on the minds of the Russians at the recent United StatesSoviet conference in Moscow on the future of travel between the two countries. Among major issues: the absence of Soviet hotel reservation systems; a reluctance to cooperate with Americans in the running of hotels Americans want to build; a serious shortage of labor and materials available in the Soviet Union to build tourist facilities.

title: Television may finally have devised the electronic equivalent of the hash brownie, (John J. O'Connor)
description: There was no reason to suppose that it would be a Monday any different from any other Monday. In fact, it promised to be worse than usual. I had a dental appointment. On the morning street, the men all wore platform shoes and the women looked adulterated. At the dentist's, I was manacled, stoppered and accused of plaque. Plaque, I was told, is a sticky, almost invisible film of living bacteria. You can't just brush plaque away. Your mouth produces 1 quarts of saliva a day, washing the bacteriaridden plaque into every tiny crevice of your teeth and gums, where it will rot you. I was ordered to take some sort of tablet that would turn my teeth red and then to spend approximately six hours a day in front of a mirror bristling and flossing. Upon my release, the dentist said: Going to watch the wedding tonight? Marriage, I replied, is a form of vegetarianism. I am not chummy with those who add to paranoia.

title: Furnaces Will Roar Again at Roebling Steel Plant
description: Spectei to The Neu York Times ROEBLING  Furnaces at fhe sprawling, old C.F.&I. steel pliant will start melting scrap again this week after standing idle for five months. Also back at work will be at best 100 of the 1,400 people who were laid off in June, when the facility was closed for lack of a buyer.

title: Wesleyan Bows, 3516, To Williams
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 9Williams took a 21.0 lead in the first half and went on to beat Wesleyan, 3516, in a Little Three football game today.

title: Mismanagement Reward

title: Refugees in Cyprus Camp Wait Grimly to Go Home
description: XYLOTYMBOU, CyprusThe fire truck rolled into the dusty tent camp that covers the soccer field. As the bell clanged dozens of women scurried over with their buckets and cans, hoping for an extra ration of water before the truck ran dry.

title: Crimson Subdues Princeton, 3417
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 9 Harvard scored first, last and most often in defeating Princeton, 3417 today. Both sides displayed some brilliant offensive football but the Tigers ran out of gas in the second half and could not keep up as Harvard won its fifth Ivy League game.

title: Harvard Six Upholding Strong Tradition of Ivies
description: Although it is No. 1 in Academics, the venerable Ivy League rarely cracks the top 10 in the collegiate sports world. The Ivies are super in their esoteric specialties like squash racquets, fencing and polo, but it has been zany a year since Chuck Bednarik's Penn Club was the last national Ivy football power in the late nineteenforties.

title: news of the Stage
description: Represented in recent seasons by such mystery thrillers as Veronica's Room and Sleuth, the producer Morton Gottlieb is now moving to comedy. He has acquired Same Time Next Year, by Bernard Slade, a Canadian playwright who lives in Hollywood, where he had been writing for television.

title: IMPACT OF STRIKE ON MINERS EASED; Thousands Take Advantage of Day's Overtime in Face of Weeks Off the Job
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The lure of timeandhalf pay attracted thousands of miners to report for overtime work today and softened the immediate impact of a national coal strike, which has become inevitable.

title: Open Burning Banned
description: ALBANY, Nov. 9 (UPI) A ban on all open burning was imposed in a 25county area of upstate New York today because of air stagnation in the region. The ban, imposed by the State Department of Environmental Conservation at 1 P.M., encompassed most of Central and Western New York on a line from the Binghamton and Syracuse areas west, a department spokesman said.

description: OLD WESTBURYWaldron Harris hoped for good things when he entered college at the age of 48. But a champagne reception was a little more than he anticipated.

description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 9 Lehigh scored 31 points in the second quarter today while defeating Davidson, 536, before 7,000 fans.

title: 2D PRIEST TO SEEK REFORM IN HOUSE
description: DE PERE, Wis., Nov. 9The Rev. Robert J. Cornell, who became last Tuesday the second Roman Catholic priest elected to Congress, is a 54yearold political science professor who hopes to work for economic and welfare reforms.

title: Custom Homes in Jersey Awe a Swedish Tour
description: RAMSEY, N. J.We all know that houses of natural wood in wildly geometric designs are as native to Sweden as Ingmar Bergman.

description: DOG SOLDIERS, by Robert Stone. (Houghton Mifflin, $8.95.) A strong, frightening novel about an exMarine smuggling heroin which ignites flashpoints between the war, the counterculture and drugs.

description: CHICAGO, Nov. 9They are all ages and professions. Some are housewives, some are lawyers, some are students, and some are ad men, policemen and artists. But all have a common linkthey collect old jukeboxes.

title: GERMANS PONDER TYPHOID MYSTERY

description: ELLERANDERMOSEL, West GermanyFor a real Moselle drinker, there are no bad years, said Franz Trimborn, owner of the largest winery in this town of 650 people, half of whom make. or sell the famous white liquid that bears the name of the serpentine Moselle river, which twists its way through the two Germanys, France and Luxembourg.

title: Five Grain Dealers Dominant in a Hungry World
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn.In this year of increasing concern over world food supplies, the international grain trade has become even more of a frantic logistics game in which the winner is the company whose intelligence gathering, communications, transportation and intuition are better than its competitors.

title: And on the Right, Wallace and Reagan
description: WASHINGTONNo sooner were the election results in than Democrats started searching for dark clouds behind all the silver linings. There may be a certain illogical obsession in the anxious lookingovertheshoulder on a big race won. Certainly few national Democrats would trade their overall position after Tuesday with the Republican party's. But looking toward 1976, as all politicians do now, 1974 underlined the Democrats shortage of national leaders.

title: CARAMANLIS SEEN AS STABLE FACTOR
description: PIRAEUS, Greece, Nov. 8The welldressed middleaged woman ordered a rich sweet and said that she would vote for Premier Constantine Caramanlis's party in the parliamentary election Nov. 17.

title: Taft Girls in Sports: A Life Style Improved
description: WATERTOWN, Connecticut, Nov. 9Taft was founded as a New England preparatory school for boys in 1900 by Horace Dutton Taft, brother of William Howard Taft, who later became President of the United States. The biggest event in Taft's history took place 71 years later, as was the case with many traditional New England boarding schools. It let in girls, not without some foreboding.

title: Nancy Landorf Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Floyd R. Landorf of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Lee Landorf, to Steven Henry Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kaplan of Munster, Ind. The future bride is an alumna of Washington University in St. Louis. Her fianc, who received a bachelor's degree cum laude at Washington is attending its Law School. His father is a wholesale tobacco distributor. Mr. Landorf is vice president of Sam Landorf & Co., manufacturer of children's wear.

description: Armistice Day, first celebrated at 11 o'clock on the 1 1 th day of the 11th month in 1918 and renamed Veterans Day in 1954, is being celebrated twice this year in two different months.

title: C. W. Post Beaten By So. Connecticut
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., Nov. 9 Southern Connecticut State rallied for two fourthquarter ttouchdowns to defeat C. W. Post, 14.13, today.

title: John Walker Knew ArtEven If He Didn't Love It
description: When a prominent figure publishes his memoirs, there is always a chance that he will let his hair down. Not John Walker, who retired in 1969 as director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington. D.C. In his recently published SelfPortrait with Donors: Confessions of an Art Collector, Mr. Walker remains perfectly coiffed from the first to the last word, The attentive reader may even catch him, from time to time, patting a stray lock back into place.

title: F. and M.Wins,4028 From Moravian

description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov.9 (UPI)  Senator James B. Allen, Democrat of Alabama, pledged today to use the filibuster against what he termed liberal spenders in the new Democraticcontrolled Congress.

title: Middlesex College Plans a Food Parley
description: EDISON A Chance for Change at the Supermarket, a oneday conference devoted to public issues surrounding the supply, quality, safety and price of food, will be held at Middlesex County College Tuesday.

description: EAGLE BAY, N. Y.Indians encamped on stateowned land near this Adirondack Mountain resort community have called upon the White House to intervene in a conflict with state authorities that began as a landclaim dispute but became complicated last week by the shooting of two white persons near the camp.

description: The city's Health Commissioner has told Mayor Beame that a growing surplus of municipal hospital beds in the Bronx will cost the city at least $108million a year in withheld state laid because of inefficient operations and excessive costs.

description: BrooklynRetrospective exhibition by Martin Rosenthal, through this month, today, 2 to 5 P.M. and Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M., Brownstone Gallery, 76 Seventh Avenue.

description: MONTCLAIRThe 94th anniversary of St. Mark's United Methodist Church, Elm and Fulton Streets, is being celebrated through Nov. 22.

description: The teams with the longest losing streaks in the county met yesterday and the longer one of 33 games, held by Wyandanch, ended when the Warriors beat Stony Brook, 16.2.

title: Lawrence Finkelstein To Wed Miss Salwin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hafrold Salwin of Silver Spring, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Salwin, to Lawrence Finkel stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Finkelstein of Manhasset, L.I.

title: Mr. Ford On His First 100 Days
description: WASHINGTON

title: MUSIC VIEW HAROLD C. SCHONBERG
description: At the turn of this century, verismo was very much in the air. Such operas as Cavalleria Rusticana (1890) and Pagliacci (1892) had delighted and even (in those more innocent days), startled audiences with their realism and and everydaylife approach. La Boheme in 1896 represented a more lyrical kind of verismo, but it was verismo nevertheless. Charpentier's Louise was not only verismo; it also had a plea for free love and socialism. Scandale! And in Bohemia at that time, Leos Janacek was working on Moravian verismo. The opera was named Jenufa, and it will be coming to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday after a 50year absence.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: PRESDENT FORD campaigned in 20 states this fall, warning that a Democratic landslide would mean a legislative dictatorshipbig spending, wild inflation, and other evils. Last Tuesday the Democrats had Republicans promptly forgot the dictatorship and put the onus on the victors to solve the country's intractable problems of inflation and recession, andjust as proMptlyseveral leading Democrats accepted the challenge. Minnesota's Senators Walter Mondale and Hubert Humphrey admitted that if the new Congress, with its enlarged Democratic majorities, could not come up with solutions, their party would be trouble in 1976.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery cumber yesterday was:
Shoot Em Up!
description: When I was a kid and reading Max Brand, Zane Grey and any other Western I could get my hands on, I owned a longbarreled revolver that shot disc caps. After six shots, I had to break open the gun and reload, an authentic touch that got me kilt a lot more times than necessary in the cornfield behind Bush's dairy barn. While I replaced cap wheels, guys with 50shot automatics kept blazing away. But I didn't care. I knew I was realWest right down to my redhot holster, cut down for quick draw, the tip tied to my leg. I learned that in a book called RedHot Holsters.

title: BENTSEN TESTING POLITICAL WATERS
description: HARTFORD, Nov, 9You have to learn to sleep fast, fly the red eye special, said United States Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen Jr. of Honston, as he hurried toward the head table at a banquet honoring him here last night.

title: CHINESE PROMOTE JOB ENTHUSIASM
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 9Top commanders of the People's Liberation Army and officials of the Communist party, in a new campaign to promote socialist enthusiasm among workers, have been showing up in freight yards throughout China to load and unload trains.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States delegation at the World Food Conference in Rome, under pressure from Congressional advisers, proposed resolution urging the reduction of nonagricultural uses of fertilizers. A critical fertilizer shortage was said to be partly responsible for hunger this year in southern Asia. About 15 per cent of the fertilizer used in the United States is applied to lawns, golf courses and cemeteries. That amount would have been enough to add two million to three million tons to India's wheat crop this year, specialists at the conference reported. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: BOOK FOE PLEDGES SEPARATE SCHOOLS
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 9 (UPI)A preacher told flagwaving protesters at a rally today that they would start their own school system if controversial textbooks stayed in Kanawha County classrooms.

title: By Milton S. Gwirtzmun
description: Though the President is Commander in Chief, Congress is his commander; and, God willing, he shall obey. He and his minions shall learn that this is not a Government of kings and satraps, but Government of the people; and that Congress the people.

description: The Knicks have the metropolitan area to themselves this week, facing the Cleveland Cavaliers on Thursday at Madison Square Garden and following with a Saturday game against the Seattle SuperSonics. The Sonics will introduce New Yorkers to their 7foot4inch rookie center, Tom Burleson. They also have Spencer Haywood. The Nets continue on the road, playing Kentucky, Memphis and Utah in games to be televised here.

title: Food Is the Immediate Crisis, but There Are Many Others
description: The world food conference in Rome, whatever it achieves, at least marks a new stage in human affairs. Famine here and there is recorded as far back as the Bible. What is new is the potential for food shortages not confined to particular places and times: a permanent crisis threatening hundreds of millions in large sectors of the globe. That is the dark prospect that has brought representatives of more than 100 countries to Rome.

Most are specialists whose owners have elected to remain lightfooted, trim and flexible.

description: The speakership of the Assembly, one of the most powerful posts in state government, will shift from Montauk to East Flatbush as a result of the Democratic tide that swept through the state in last Tuesday's election.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Next Friday, Nov. 15, is the start of the Mint's official orderacceptance period for the packaged threepiece sets of 40 per cent silver Bicentennial coinsthe quarter, halfdollar and dollar. Both of the Mint's standard types of strikingsproof and uncirculated  are available. The threepiece proof coin set is priced at $15; the threepiece uncirculated coin set costs $9; both prices include packaging and insured mailing.

title: Jill Schneider Engaged
description: Ira Schneider of Plainview, LI., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Jill Cindy Schneider, to Roy M, Bordenick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Bordenick, of Silver Spring, Aid, MisS Schneider, daughter also of the late Mrs. Schneider, is a senior at the University of Maryland. Her fiance, an alumnus of Park College in Kansas City, Mo., is doing graduate work at Columbia University.

title: Epilogue
description: I jumped as high as I couldand the ball hit the center of pocket in glove (I had a death grip on it) at no time did I lose possession of the ball. Thus, the truth about one of the mostdisputed plays in World Series history has finally been disclosed and by the only man qualified to do so Sam Rice. For the last 49 years, there has been some doubt whether the Washington rightfielder did indeed catch a long homerbound drive while tumbling into the bleacher seats during the 1925 World Series between the Washington Senators and the Pittsburgh Pirates, Rice, a Hall of Fame member, would never say unqualifiedly that he had made the catch, but in 1965 put his testimony in a letter that was to be opened only after his death. Rice died Oct. 13, and last week the letter was opened.

title: KEY ROLE IN HOUSE IS SEEN FOR TEXAS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9When the 94th Congress is organized in January, Democratic Representatives from Texas will apparently assume the chairmanships of six standing committees in the House to give unparalleled power to a delegation from one state.

title: Greenwich, McMahon Set Title Stage
description: Greenwich and Brien McMahon of Norwalk routed their opponents yesterday for identical 90 wonlost records entering their showdown next week in Norwalk to decide the Fairfield County Conference Western Division champion.

title: Risks for Executives on Loan
description: WASHINGTON  A businessman considering whether to spend a year with the Government under the Presidential Interchange Program might examine the experience of Robert C. Bowen, a 35yearold middlelevel executive at the Phillips Petroleum Company.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I regularly attend the New York City Real Estate Department's auction sales, and I frequently notice West Harlem properties that are in good condition but do not attract any bids.

title: Caso, In Defeat, Looks to Future
description: MINEOLAReflecting late last week on his unsuccessful race for Lieutenant Governor, Nassau. County Executive Ralph G. Caso said that he had been somewhat surprised by his loss, but that he felt he had gained considerably from his experience as the running mate of Governor Wilson.

description: First Lay President Steps at Marymount Educator Had Established Upward Bound Program

title: Jazz: A Lively Mixture of Armstrong
description: The New York Jazz Repertory Company, which stumbled through its first season last year, started off its second season on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall with a program based on Louis Armstrong's work in the nineteentwenties that could serve as a model of imaginative, entertaining, informative and rewarding jazz programing.

title: College Day Is Set at Shopping Center
description: GARDEN CITY  The Roosevelt Field Mall will be the center of college recruitment activity on Friday and Saturday as College Day on Long Island will be offered to high school juniors, seniors, their parents and those attending twoyear community college on Long Island. College admissions counselors will be at the Mall from 10 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. on both days.

title: Museum Backdrop For Antiques Show
description: MILLVILLEThe Cumberland County Historical Society will hold its sixth annual Antiques Show, here this week. The four day event, to be staged in the Glass Museum, will open Thursday night with a preview at the museum, a repository reflecting milestonesiin the nation's pioneer glassmaking industry.

title: Dobryznski Stars in State Meet
description: KINGS PARK, L. I., Nov. 9 Dave Dobryznski of Syracuse shattered the course record as upstate runners captured eight of the nine titles today in the state intersectional crosscountry championships at Sunken Meadow State Park.

title: 2 New S.I. Ferryboats Ordered at $28Million
description: The city, with the aid of $22.4million from the Federa Government, will replace the two oldest Staten Island ferryboats, the Mary Murray and the Miss New York. Both were built in 1937.

title: Sexless Sunsets A Smash
description: THE house lights dim and a hush descends; the spotlight picks out a lone figure at the microphone in stage center clad in gray slacks and a Mitteleuropa blouse. Good evening, ladies and gentlemen, he says. I'm Jonathan Hagar, and in case you're wondering why I'm wearing this outfit, it's to help put you in the mood for the travel film I'm about to present, The Romance of Rumania' Soon, a striking color photograph of a waterfall fills the screen accompanied by the strains of Smetana's Moldauand a chorus of 000h's and aaah's from the audience. Then, almost immediately, deafening applause.

title: U.S. Judge Reverses a FlagContempt Conviction
description: A Federal judge has over turned a Criminal Court conviction of a Madison Avenue artgallery owner for casting contempt upon the American flag by a display of flagdraped sculptures.

title: BESSIE B. STITT
description: GANANOQUE, Ontario, Nov. 9Bessie B. Stitt, widow of Rutherford W. Stitt, a mill estimator, died here yesterday. She was 90 years old, She is survived by a son, Robert W. Stitt, ???copy editor of The New York Times, and two grandchildren.

title: HARRY L. COOPER
description: Harry L. Cooper, founder and former chairman and president of the Cooper Textile Mills of Wycombe, Pa., now part of DeeringMilliken, Inc., died yesterday at his home in Elkins Park, Pa. He was 79 years old.

description: Deaths

title: Adelphi's  Theater Stresses Flexibility
description: GARDEN CITY  Square, brick, nearly windowless, the new $1.3million building in the center of the Adelphi University campus could not appear more prosaic. But, in fact, it is prepared to house some of the farthest flights of fancy imaginable.

title: Grand Dame of Resort Inns Is Torn Down
description: SOUTHAMPTONThe Irving Hotel, the grand dame of South Fork resort inns, went the way of the bulldozer last week.

title: Lung Cancer Death Rate Rises Among Women
description: Lung cancer has become the third leading cancer killer of women in this country, according to new data from the American Cancer Society.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday wad:

title: Stony Brook Will End Housing for Married Couples in Fall
description: STONY BROOKOn  campus housing for married students at the State University Center here will be discontinued next fall, according to a letter circulated by the housing office.

title: U.S. Steel Workers Gain Pact to Reduce Pollution
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 (AP) United States Steel Corporation and its employes at the nearby Clairton Coke Works have announced the signing of the industry's first unioncompany contract to reduce pollution.

title: Aid as an Expression of Faith
description: By some standards, the aid disclosed last week from the American Friends Service Committee to the Communistled Pathet Lao in Laos was modest, almost quixotic: three portable sawmills valued at about $10,000, and a twomonth course in operation and maintenance.

title: POLLUTION CURBS PRESSED IN CHINA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 9On a recent visit to China, Maurice F. Strong, the director of the United Nations Environment Program, was, invited to observe a gaggle of geese on a small pond outside a petrochemical complex.

title: A French Marxist explains the mysterious Near East
description: No book could be more timely than this one. It originally appeared in 1966 in France, but to the scared inflationridden Western consumer of today Islam and Capitalism, making no particular mention of O.P.E.C. or of Arab patio  dollars, dispassionately and clearly links the two halves of its title. For despite generations of specialpleading Orientalists, there is neither an esoteric Islamic attitude to capital nor a secret threat to world monetary order now that a handful of Islamic nations have such unprecedented wealth. Islam and capitalism can and do coexist, as do Christianity, Judaism, Buddhism and capitalism.

title: Harpo, Garbo and Gable For Rent
description: Back in 1947, when I sat through four complete showings of Captain from Castile in the Brockton Theater, I had no idea that 27 years later I would be sitting in my own basement watching the same 20th CenturyFox HispanicAztec folderol, marveling anew at the length of Senor Tyrone Power's eyelashes and wondering how on earth Seilorita Jean Peters managed to get into movies, let alone snag Howard Hughes.

title: You Don't Have to Call In a Plumber
description: Of all minor home repair problems none are probably more annoying than that of a toilet tank that doesn't flush properly, or one that is exceptionally noisy in operation. Yet, making the needed repairs is almost always a fairly simple task that involves either making a few adjustments, or replacing a few inexpensive parts with new components that are widely available in most well stocked hardware stores and doityourself home centers.

title: Faraday Nye Burditt Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Faraday Nye Burditt to Manuel de la Cmara Hermoso has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Frederic Burditt of Bedford Hills, N.Y. Her fianc is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel de la Cmara Alvarez of Madrid.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Herbert von Karajan is an enigma. About his superstar status in the music world there can be no doubt: The instant he appears on the podium, still sleek and athletic at 66, audiences instinctively respond to his magnetic presence and the spell he weaves over an orchestraonly Callas, Horowitz and Bernstein command the kind of personal mystique that surrounds Karajan. And yet no comparable musician of our era has ever had his musical esthetics so consistently challenged. In fact, to anyone who reads serious record criticismthe only way to get a steady bead on the conductor these days since his appearances in America are infrequentit might seem downright perverse for the international music community to hold him in such awe.

title: Growing Up
description: By Dr. William A. Block. 304 pp. New York: Fawcett/Crest. $1.50. What Your Child Really Wants To Know About SexAnd Why How We Become Alive, Are Born, and Grow. By Karl de Schweinitz. Illustrated. 54 pp. New York: Collier Books. 95 cents. What to Tell Your Child About Sex Prepared by The Child Study Association/WelMet Incorporated. Illustrated. 141 pp. New York: Pocket Books. $1.50.

title: Music in Review
description: Joseph Smith, a pianist on the faculty of the Mannes College of Music since 1969, made what he labeled his formal New York debut Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Smith started stiffly, dispatching Faure's Nocturne in D flat (Op. 63) and four of Schumann's Novelletten (Op. 21) sensibly if without the finest touch or the most fluent control imaginable. But with an exuberant Toccata Franaise by one of his former teachers, Seymour Bernstein, Mr. Smith came into his own, and the second half of the program  Schumann's Forest Scenes and the Griffes Sonatawent much better.

title: Aftermath
description: Martin Bonnann, the head of Adolf Hitler's Reich Chancellery and, during the last years of the. Nazi era, perhaps the most powerful man in the Nazi party after Hitler himself, was a strangely faceless, almost obscure figure. Professor Hugh TrevorRoper, the author of The Last Days of Hitler, called him a molelike creature, who seemed to avoid the glare of daylight and publicity. Hitler's chief of intelligence, Walter Schellenberg, concentrating rather on Bormann's external appearance, thought that he resembled a pig in a potato field. At the end ofthe Second World War Bormann disappeared in the ruins of Berlin during the final stages of the futile Nazi defense of the old Reich capital against the Red Army. Although generally presumed to be dead, he was sentenced to death in absentia by the international war crimes tribunal at Nuremberg on Oct, 1, 1946. For nearly 30 years since then the circumstances of his death, or survival, have remained shrouded in mystery.

title: Showing of Dogs in Australia Dominated by Amateur System.
description: The dogshow sport in Australia is much more of an amateur venture than in the United States. Whereas America has many professional handlers, American judges receive fees of $100 to $450 a show, and in some cases the stewards are compensated, Down Under there are no more than a helfdozen professional handlers, and they work for a pittance. The standard fee for a judge is $75 and the stewards receive no pay.

title: Palone, Army Soccer Coach, Is Busy With Other Sports, Too
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 9Joe Palone rushed into the tiny office in the Gymnasium Building, tossed his baseball cap on the same desk, put his feet up to relax for a moment and started to talk about his duties, at the United States Military Academy. I was teaching volleyball, said Palone, the man with the longest tenure of any of the Army's present coaching staff. And that's not the only thing I do here. I teach boxing, basketball, golf and soccer, of course, he said looking at his watch.

title: A. R. Paterson Jr. Weds Miss Pityo
description: Kathleen Ruth Pityo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Pityo of Longboat Key, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon in Sarasota, Fla., to Arthur Renwick Paterson Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Paterson of Chatham, N. J. The ceremony was performed at the Far Horizons, a resort, by the Rev. John La Motte of the First Presbyterian Church in Sarasota.

title: Bianca S. Chronowski Is Engaged
description: Bianca Syra Chronowski plans to be married in June to John Paul Trouche, who is in his second year at the University of Virginia Law School.

title: Miss Herzog, H. H. Grimmett Plan Marriage
description: Katherine Ann Herzog, a candidate for the Master of Theological Studies degree at the Harvard Divinity School, plans to be married next month to H. Hill Grimmett, who received a Master of Divinity there.

title: VENEZUELA LOOKS TO MINERAL AREA
description: CIUDAD GUAYANA, VenezuelaThis is the future of Venezuela, a 30yearold mechanical engineer said, and so I'm going to stay.

title: Jewish Leader Protests Talk by Scali With Arab
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9As the Palestine debate at the United Nations draws near, the chief American delegate John A. Scali, has been meeting with spokesmen for local Jewish and Arab groups, and causing some controversy.

title: Late Army Rally Beats Air Force
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov.  Army's scrappy football team stormed nearly the length of the field in the final Minute and 20 seconds today to beat the United States Air Force team, 17.16, before 42,521 fans, the second largest crowd to watch a game at Michie Stadium in Army history.

title: Rail Bond Loss Tied To 'Credibility Gap'
description: TRENTONFailure of the state's voters to approve a $100million bond issue designed to aid New Jersey's ailing railroads has been attributed to a lack of sufficient understanding by the electorate and to a carryover of the historical credibility gap of the Department of Transportation.

title: W. E. Allan Weds Barbara Kwetz
description: Barbara Ann Kwetz, a senior planner with the Lower Pioneer Valley Regional Planning Commission in West Springfield, Mass, was married yesterday afternoon to William Edward Allan, a territory manager with the Burrough Corporation in Springfield.

title: Computer Advice Tells Cards To Rush First and Pass Later
description: Why are the St. Louis Cardinals suddenly a power team in the National Football League? The Cardinals, mired in mediocrity for years, play the Minnesota Vikings in tomorrow's Monday night football game and they are something to behold, victors in seven of eight games this season. They went from mediocre to magnificent in a hurry.

title: Brown Wins in Soccer
description: PROVIDENCE, Rd., Nov. 9 Brown took advantage of two goals early in the game and held on to defeat Cornell, 2.1, in a soccer game today. The Bruins, 10thranked nationally, have an 111 won lost record.

title: Jill Leslie Woolman Fiancee of Teacher
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Woolman of Albany have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Leslie Woolman, to Norman Frederick Sanders, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Sanders of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for January.

description: Chart of Laurel's Feature

title: Beall Said to Be on List
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 (AP)United States Attorney George Beall, who led the investigation of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, says he is on a list of possible successors to Henry E. Petersen as Assistant United States Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's criminal division. Mr. Beall said yesterday that he agreed to be listed during a conversation with Mr. Petersen this week.

title: Lincoln Park Girds for Floods
description: LINCOLN PARKA new two  way communications and earlywarning system for flood emergencies and other disasters has been established here by Edwin H. Polansky, the borough's Director of Civil Defense.

title: Beth Culligan to Be Wedin April To Frederick Carl Hoefer Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. John W. Culligan of Glen Rock, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Rita Culligan, to Frederick Carl Hoefer Jr., of North Bergen, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoefer of Wabash, Ind.

description: June Mayer and Dr. Paul Schlueter of. Elizabeth, N.J., members of the English faculty at Kean College in Union, N.J., were married yesterday, afternoon in Cranford, N.J.

title: WESTPORT FIRE DOES $1MILLION DAMAGE
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 9 (AP)Firefighters battled for two hours tonight before bringing under control a smoky fire that caused at least $1million damage in a downtown block of stores and apartments, officials said.

title: Best Seller List
description: General

title: Winter in the Blood
description: James Welch is a 34yearold American Indian (Blackfeet and Grosventre). Last year he published a collection of poems, Riding the Earthboy 40, and now this first novel, the third volume in Harper & Row's Native American Publishing Program. Welch says, in a jacket note, I have seen works written about Indians by whites  but only an Indian knows who he is. And three of the six jacketencomiasts insist upon the book's special value as inside news of Indian life. A small part of its value may well be that, but to stress the Indianness of Welch or his novel is to indulge in the same obfuscatory inverse snobbery with which some black writers and journalists have recently burdened their work. (The oppressed can hardly be blamed for reluctance to admit that their oppressors have indeed understood themand continued to oppress.)

title: Letters: Bus Odyssey From Coast to Coast
description: To the Editor: M. R. Fogelman's article, Learning to Love the Bus on a CrossCountry Odyssey (Travel Section, Oct. 27), should have been written by me. I have always considered myself the maven of Greyhound crosscountry travel, having made two complete solo round trips in a yearall solid daynight busingto visit my husband during his Army stint.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Western Electric, the manufacturing and supply division of American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has entered a contract to buy a 66acre site near Suffern, N. Y., on which it plans to erect an 870,000squarefoot materials management center.

title: U.S. URGES A CLUB ON FERTILIZER USE EXCEPT FOR CROPS; Asks Rome Conference for Global Restraint to Help Asia Grow More Food; POPE CHIDES DELEGATES; Supports Urgent Campaign Against Starvation, but Not by Birth Control; FERTILIZER CURB IS URGED BY U.S.
description: ROME, Nov. 9The United States delegation, under pres sure from Congressional advis ers, proposed a resolution today at the World Food Conference urging that the nonagricultural use of fertilizer be reduced to ease a critical shortage in hungry South Asia.

title: Israel Devalues Currency To Meet Economic Crisis
description: TEL AVIV, Sunday, Nov. 10 The Israeli pound was devalued today, and other measures were taken by the Government to meet a serious economic crisis.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Residents of Grand Junction, Colo., got the disconcerting news some years ago that many of their homes had been built on top of radioactive wastes from a uranium mill and that the radioactivity levels were unsafe. In 1971, the Government reversed itself and said it might be able to help these people.

title: Going It Alone: The Maiden Voyage of a MiddleAged Housewife
description: A N admirer of Doris Lessing's Summer Before the Dark, I was especially grateful to her this year when I went, alone, on my maiden voyage as a married woman across the continent. Lessing had effectively stripped down my baggage with her pointed passages about how little attention anyone pays to a middleaged woman unless she is a walking clothes horse. Having noted my increasing invisibility, with the onset of my own summer before the dark, I decided to go the whole hog on my trip to California and be a walking frump; it was the only way I could see to cut my losses, psychic and financial. I packed a few old polyester pantsuits, two pairs of jeans and one passable cocktail dress.

title: Housing Is Fought in Bayside
description: Bayside residents who oppose a planned 11building housing complex have discovered that they must challenge a section of the zoning law as well as the plan's backers.

title: Kings Point Beats N. Y. Tech, 247
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 9  Led by the rushing of Brian Streaser and Paul Brown, the United States Merchant Marine Academy swept today to its third straight victory, 247, over the New York Institute of Technology.

description: The human composition of the American business scenewhat kinds of people work in what kinds of jobs and for how muchhas been visibly shifting during the 18 years since the Federal Government outlawed race and sex discrimination in employment.
