description: SADDLE RIVER  The Saddle River Country Day. School hopes, to raise $100,000 in a fivehour auction pp be held Friday night at the Ramada Inn in nearby Montvale.

title: 209 Convicted Under Strict Drug Law
description: At least 209 persons have been convicted throughout the state of drug felonies carrying mandatory life sentences in the 14 months since former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's toughened drug law took effect. Such cases mandate minimum terms of one to 15 years in prison with life parole in case of release.

title: FINE BACH CONCERT
description: A quietly moving performance of Jesu meine Freude was given by the Dessoff Choirs at Town Hall on Friday night at the conclusion of program devoted entirely to works by Bach.

title: Ford Is at Camp David For an Active Weekend
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Nov. 9 (AP)President Ford, here with his family for the weekend, went swimming today, played tennis, watched football on television and did some paperwork.

description: LONG BRANCHThe twoweek school strike here has ended, but teachers and the Board of Education already realize that the newest controversy between them will erupt this week, when normal classes are scheduled to resume.

title: FORD INFLATION PLAN TERMED TOO NARROW
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (Reuters)John E. Sheehan, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the Ford Administration's proposals did not go far enough in combating inflation.

title: The Spoiled System
description: The U.S. Civil Service Commission was established in 1883 to end the spoils system, which threatened to render government ineffective. Since then, civil service reform has concentrated on corruption and political patronage. But, according to Robert G. Vaughn, one of Ralph Nader's Raiders, Important as these problems may be, they are secondary to the abuses flowing from the enormous power collected in the executive branch and in the Federal regulatory agencies. The result is the development of a new spoils system.

title: What the New Governors Are Now Up Against
description: changing state government, Mr. Carey might well take a glance across the Hudson to the politically battered administration of Governor Byrne.

title: New Yorker Heads Salvation Army
description: Commissioner William E. Chamberlain was installed Friday night as National Commander of the Salvation Army in the United States. His wife, Mrs. Chamberlain, was installed at the same time as National President of the Army's women's organizations.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Vosburgh of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ellen Vosburgh, to Dr. Dan Charles Omohundro, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Alfred Omohundro of Newtown Square, Pa.

title: Semipro Football: Few Fans, Many Aches, Great Gratification
description: The play called in the huddle is strong right, 26 straight. We line up and listen for the count. Crouched over the ball is a mailman. On the second hut he lifts the ball back to an accredited transcendental meditation instructor. He steps to the right and hands off to an art director, who lunges for a hole opened with a doubleteam block executed by a junior executive and a police officer. The defensive end Is kicked out by a meat cutter.

title: Tapestry Weaver Star of Art Show
description: CLINTON  The dividing line between art and crafts can be either narrow or a vast abyss, depending on whether the creator of a given object is possessed with a real esthetic sense or merely manual skill.

title: Nevelson's Art Shown on Island By DAVID L. SHIREY
description: GREENVALE  Visitors to the C. W. Post Art Center Gallery may discover that the richly entrancing imagery of Louise Nevelson's art inspires a panoply of poetic thought. Most Nevelson buffs have linked the artist's works with such images as the altars of medieval cathedrals or Indian totems that suggest the presence of a powerful deity.

title: Ex Nun at L.I.R.R.Throttle
description: A Dominican nun and a teacher for nearly half her life, Maureen Shoreys changed careers with a vengeance. For almost five months now, the 38yearold former nun has been at the controls of a diesel locomotivethe first female engineer trainee on the Long Island Rail Road.

description: The city's Budget Director has scuttled a federally financed program that would have provided Brooklyn residents with instant information on how the city, state and Federal governments function and how and where to get services from government and voluntary agencies.

description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Maslow of Scarsdale, N. Y., on Oct. 21 at Mount Sinai Hospital. The child, the couple's fourth, has been named Victoria June.

description: Dr. and Mrs. James A. Gribbin of Trenton and Beach Haven Terrace, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Elizabeth Gribbin, to Dr. Ivor Seager Smith, son of Dr. and Mrs. R. Bryan Seager Smith of Bromley, England.

title: Study Reflects Dip In Earning Power By RICHARD PHALON
description: HACKENSACK  Although pay scales are rising, almost everyone is being whipsawed by inflation and whitecollor clerical workers are generally having a harder time of it than either skilled or unskilled bluecollar workers.

description: A shooting war that was waged fitfully among South, Brooklyn mob members come to an end, according to throughout the summer has taw enforcement officials in Federal, state and city agencies.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9A nationwide private and Federal search Is under way for the man who has illegally sold about 30,000 unauthorized editions of J. D. Salinger's early works during the last few months.

title: Paterson Kennedy Triumphs on Kick
description: Unbeaten Paterson Kennedy, playing the best football in its nineyear history, scored in spectacular fashion yesterday for a 7.6 victory over Essex Catholic at Untermann Field in Newark.

title: Bruins Surge Led By Beatrice
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 9 (AP)  Pete Beatrice passed for one fourthperiod touchdown and set up another with a 41yard run and Brown hung on for a 168Ivy League upset victory over Cornell today.

title: NeilN. Christie Marries Anne Dowd in Scarsdale
description: The Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church was the setting in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Anne Isabel Dowd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hector G. Dowd of Scarsdale, to Neil Norton Christie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Christie 3d of Larchmont, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dermot R. Brennan.

title: AIRPORTRAIL LINK IS STILL PLANNED
description: Plans for a rail link between John F. Kennedy International Airport and Pennsylvania Station are being pursued without letup even though other links to the airport have run into new and conceivably fatal delays, David L. Yunich, head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said last week.

title: Ishmael Reed's shrewd eye, mean ear and nasty tongue
description: Whoever called him Ishmael picked the right name. His hand is against every man'sand every woman's, too. Or so it seems. He is a black Juvenal a man to whom satire comes as naturally as breathing. And, like Juvenal, he might well ask who could consider the last decade and not he a satirist. Especially if he concentrated on the San Francisco Bay area. So Ishmael Reed is a black satirist, which is not exactly the same thing as a black humorist. Oh no. Though his prose wickedly parodies everything from street talk to academic rhetoric, he is not to be confused with those who use their own cleverness as a shield against the ugly world. Ishmael Reed is a committed man, a satirist with a specific point of view. Beneath that funky facade beats the heart of a preacher.

title: The Witches Flowers
description: The maple leaves are down, the oak leaves are leathery in texture and color, and the tamaracks stand like golden flames in the damp hollows, And now, deep into autumn, the witch hazels come to bloom.

title: Williams Triumphs In P.S.A.L. Event
description: DeWitt Clinton, a school known more for sprinters than distance runners, won the Public Schools Athletic League citywide crosscountry championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

title: Robin Lynn Is Wed To L. S. Blumberg
description: Robin Anne Lynn, program coordinator of the Smithsonian. Institution's traveling exhibition service in Washington, was married here last evening to Lawrence Saul Blumberg, a lawyer with the Federal Trade Commission's Bureau of Consumer Protection in Washington, Rabbi Michael Robinson performed the ceremony at the Pierre. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Lynn of New York, where her father is a first vice president of Wertheim & Co., Inc., and a partner in Wertheim & Co., investment bankers. Mr. and Mrs, Gerald Blumberg of Yorktown Heights, are the parents of the N.Y.,ridegroom, whose father practices law here.

description: FORT WORTH, Nov. 9 (AP) Carter Publications, Inc., announced yesterday the sale of The Fort Worth StarTelegram and radio stations WBAPAM and KSCSFM to Capital Cities Communications, Inc., of New York.

title: Police Slay Man in a Gun Battle After He Wounds Boy in Bronx
description: A 37yearold man was shot and killed in a hail of police gunfire early yesterday morning after allegedly shooting and critically wounding one of several teenagers in front of Bronx bakery and apartment house.

title: Pressure on City's TouristClass Hotels Grows
description: The city may soon lose more of its standard touristclass hotels, a declining species in recent years. Many of those that have not already closed or converted to apartments are operating at a loss, squeezed between declining business and the soaring costs of fuel, labor and taxes.

title: Ellen Glick Fiancee Of Hyman Kapito
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Glick of Laurelton, Queens, and North Miami Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Lynn Glick, to Hyman Louis Kapito. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Kapito of Monticello, N.Y.

title: Vatican Envoy Will Conduct Talks on Ties with Poland
description: ROME, Nov. 9The Vatican has announced the appointment of Msgr. Luigi Poggi, a special, Vatican envoy, to head a group that will discuss normalization of church relations with Communist Poland.

title: Nancy E. Fuchs, Seth F. Kreimer To Wed in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Victor R. Fuchs of Palo Alto, Calif, formerly of Roslyn, L. I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ellen Fuchs, to Seth F. Kreimer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hillard Kreimer of Pittsburgh.

title: CHILDCARE STUDY CRITICIZES STATE
description: A task force of specialists that studied problem children here for three months this year, has issued a report attacking the State Department of Mental Hygiene for refusing to accept children in need of treatment and, for discharging children froth psychiatric facilities before they were ready to leave.

title: Oil Bartering
description: to the Financial Editor: In the end, Arab nations will be forced to demand goods and services, and only these as payment for their oil. They cannot afford to earn money and let it accumulate in banks. It must be kept in mind that the Arabs will not continue to swap oil, whose value tends to appreciate, for currency balances, which tend to depreciate.

title: Marc Bergman to Wed Marlene Adoff
description: The engagement of Marlene Adoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Adoff of Yonkers, to Marc A. Bergman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Manny Bergman, also of Yonkers and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Bob's has been a neighborhood family restaurantthe specialty is Neapolitan food for almost a halfcentury. The hosts, Frank and Ralph Costello, who are usually busy cooking in the kitchen, are nephews of the original owner, Robert Esposito, who gave his name to the place and whose portrait hangs in the dining room.

title: On Goa's Beaches: The Pursuit of Joy
description: GOA Is pretty close to being one of those tropical paradises of sunshine and palmfringed beaches that are the staples of tourist folders and South Sea Island romances; it is also pretty close to an ideal setting for the thousands of freaks who converge on this coastal area of India 250 miles south of Bombay during the Christmas holidays. They begin to trickle onto the beaches during October, a few at a time; by November the trickle has increased to maybe 30 or 40 new arrivals every day, and by Christmas they are hitting the beaches by the hundreds.

title: Tokyo String Quartet Returns
description: The Tokyo String Quartet returned Friday night to begin another series of concerts at Carnegie Recital Hall, and apart from a new second violinist, all was pretty much as before.

title: Jamaica Site Likely For a New Hospital
description: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation is expected to vote next Thursday to build the new Queens Hospital Center on a site in South Jamaicaresolving a nearly twoyear controversy in the borough.

title: Letters
description: In their benighted adherence to obsolete conventions, my foreparents have clung for generations to the surname Bulman. I now realize that we should be calling ourselves Bulone or Bulperson or perhaps, for greater elegance, Toreador. Actually, I am personfully trying to repress the annoyance aroused in me by your dissemination of the McGrawHill Book Company's guidelines for equal treatment of the sexes ( Man Memo From a Publisher, Oct. 20). I like the English language the way it was in the olden days, and I resent and distrust the view that all differences between the sexes should be suppressed. Women's liberation has liberated no one, but it has taken the grace and the fun out of life.

title: MITCHELL, IN CITY, TESTIFIES FOR U.S
description: Tickets Doubled Traffic Monitored Check Finds Millions Seen to Exceed 55M.P.H. Limit

title: After Working At the Office All Day
description: When David Cullen gets home from his office, he relaxes with plants. Not just any plants, but miniatures, plants so tiny that he can hold several of them In one hand.

title: CHILDCARE STUDY CRITICIZES STATE
description: A task force of specialists that studied problem children here for three months thi's year, has issued a report attacking the State Department of Mental Hygiene for refusing to accept children in need of treatment and for discharging children from psychiatric facilities before they were ready to leave.

description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 (AP)Two men who gave prosecutors evidence against former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew are scheduled to be arraigned in United States District Court Monday on tax charges involving alleged kickbacks to Mr. Agnew.

title: Congress Will Be Fighting Ford, Itself Or Maybe Both
description: WASHINGTONThe day after the Democrats won major victory in the Congressional elections, Carl Albert turned to Mike Mansfield and described the result as mixed blessing. Mr. Mansfield nodded, in sympathetic agreement.

title: New Hearing for Chenault
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 9 (UPI)Marcus Wayne Chenault, sentenced to die in the electric chair for the murder of Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr., will be given a hearing on his motion for a new trial in Fulton County Superior Court Nov. 18.

title: Barbara Koller to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Jerome Koller of Maplewood, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Lee Koller, to John Matthew Huston, son of Charles Huston and Eva Huston, both of Libertyville, Ill. Miss Koller and her fianc, graduate students at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, plan a May wedding.

title: Unbeaten Brick Makes East Brunswick Victim
description: Brick Township continued its drive toward an unbeaten season yesterday with a 218victory over East Brunswick in East Brunswick.

title: REPUBLICAN GAINS IN ALASKAN RACE
description: ANCHORAGE, Nov. 9 Jay Hammond, a Republican, took a 499vote lead today over William A. Egan, the incumbent Democratic Governor, in Alaska's gubernatorial election, still undecided after four days of ballot counting.

title: STAGE. VIEW WALTER KERR
description: I must say I hate what they've been doing to farce lately. They're either putting it in all the wrong places or else taking it seriously. Perhaps there's a philosophical bias at work here. We've been told over and over again that life is farce, that reason has departed us and lunacy become our lodestone, that tragedy can't exist today because what's sad is much too funny. You've heard the argument, from absurdistri onwards:or backwards. Or perhaps the trend isn't philosophical at all. Perhaps our stage directors can't tell Mack and Mabel from Medea and are simply making a horrendous mistake.

title: Philanthropist Is Honored
description: Arnold Schwartz, a retired business man and philanthropist, was honored last night at a Presidential Tribute Ball held at the Americana Hotel by the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn. Mr. Schwartz became president of the medical center in 1968. Mayor Beanie, presented Mr. Schwartz with a citation on behalf of the city.

title: Send in the Clowns
description: TOKYOIf you're an American baseball player in the twilight of your career wondering if there is gold in the hills of Japan, the best advice you can get before heading for the Far East is: Don't. That Is, don't go if you think the Japanese are soft touches who will pay any amount of yen for the dubious privilege of watching you importbaseball to their shores.

title: Gracia Captures C.U.N.Y. Title Run
description: Fernando Gracia, an 18yearold freshman from Lehman, outpaced a field of 56 runners from eight City University of New York senior colleges yesterday as he led the Herbert H. Lehman College harriers to the C.U.N.Y. cross  country championship at Van Cortlandt Park.

title: Brooklyn College Tops F.D.U., 146
description: Brooklyn College intercepted six Fairleigh Dickinson passes and defeated the Knights, 14.6, yesterday at the Brooklyn College field. Ed Conroy, a fullback, ran 43 yards for a touchdown for Brooklyn in the final period.

title: TV VIEW
description: Sometimes, in the massive blur of television programing, a program pops up on the screen and, for a variety of reasons, it seems to defy commentary. For one uninteresting example, take The Mac Davis Show, a bit of fluff concocted for NBC this past summer. Dutifully, as is my custom, I sat through the first episode in a network screening room. Mr. Davis, in pretty flowered shirts open to the navel, sang a few songs, attempted a few jokes and maintained a steady level of utter sincerity.

title: Pardoning of Nixon Spurs Many Pleas By U.S. Prisoners
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon has resulted in a boom in applications for commutation of sentence from Federal prisoners who think they have suffered enough.

title: Civil Service Panel Acting To Insure Merit Promotion
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 9 (AP) The Civil Service Commission has announced that it is taking steps to assure merit promotion of Federal employes.

title: At Last, the West Bank Is Not Hussein's Worry
description: AMMANJust 36 hours after his return from the Arab conference at Rabat, King Hussein of Jordan flew to the Red Sea resort of Aqaba for a weekend of relaxation. The occasion was the 15th annual International WaterSkiing Championships, and the King, an avid skier, was an enthusiastic host.

title: Bergenfield Stays Unbeaten
description: Craig Nielsen ran for a pair of fourthperiod touchdowns to snap a 1212 deadlock and give Bergenfield (70) a 2612 victory over Clifton at Clifton.

title: Proper Use of Spices Key to Indian Cooking
description: While Indian cooking depends heavily on spices, it is the careful use of these magic ingredients that can render the various specialties of the subcontinent pungent or peppery, fragrant or soothing. Spicing is both science and art.

title: Tottenville Beats Tech, 146
description: Brooklyn Tech outrushed and ottpassed Tottenville yesterday, but the Staten Island school won the game and advanced to the semifinal round of the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs with a 14.6 victory at New Dorp Fields.

title: Laser to Flash Olympic Flame
description: LONDON, (Reuters)  The Olympic flame for the 1976 Games in Montreal will be flashed across the world in bounced off a satellite.

title: U.S. Steel  Workers Gain Pact to Reduce Pollution
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 (AP) United States Steel Corporation and its employes at the nearby Clairton Coke Works have announced the signing of the industry's first unioncompany contract to reduce pollution.

description: Acrostic puzzle

title: Barge Explodes Off S.I.,Igniting Blaze and Shattering Windows
description: An empty gasoline barge exploded at a pier in Port Richmond, S. I., shortly before 8:30 last night, shattering windows in the neighborhood, sending out shock waves felt for miles and igniting a twoalarm fire on two other barges.

title: Lana Jacobs Fiancee  of Porter L. Hovey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Jacobs Jr. of Lincoln, Neb., have announced, the engagement of their daughter, Lana Jacobs, to Porter Lamson Hovey. He is the son of Mrs. Armene Norris of New York and Willard P. Hovey of San Marino, Calif.

title: Deerfield Outburst Defeats Choate, 28 to 7
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., Nov. 9In the 56th meeting of Choate and Deerfield, both undefeated this year, Deerfield exploded for 21 points in the final period to crush Choate, 287. Choate has now won 25 in the series, Deerfield 21, and there have been 10 ties. Deerfield's star running back, Ralph Polillio, notched two touchdowns on runs of 10 and 30 yards, John Flynn dived in from a yard and Mike McIntyre had a 72yard pass play with Carl Leone to round out the winners scoring.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 10. (UPI)Lee Trevino, following a sixoverpar 77, stormed off the Royal Melbourne Course at the end of a $65,000 golf tourney today and promised never to come back.

title: Great Neck Divided by Effort to Oust School Chief
description: GREAT NECK, LI., Nov. 10 It has come to this in Great Neck: At a recent barmitzvah reception, the hostess seated her guests not by family ties or by friendship, but by which side they took in the raging power struggle over the school superintendent.

title: LONDON ADAMANT ON ULSTER FORCE
description: LONDON, Nov. 10Despite rising despair in England ever the trophies in Northern Ireland, the British Government has no intenton of moving to pull British troops out of the province or yielding to demands for setting a date for withdrawal.

title: Democratic Dispute, Before High Court Today, Parallels Burger Case of 1952
description: WASHINGTON, Nev. 10The first case to be argued before the Supreme Court tomorrow is likely to sound hauntingly familiar to Chief Justice Warren E. Burger.

title: LODI FIRE SWEEPS ONE ENTIRE BLOCK
description: A spectacular fire that raged for seven hours in the downlown area of Lodi Over the weekend engulfed a whole block, destroyed several busi nesses and forced the removal of more than 200 people from their homes before was brought under contol.

description: Shipping/Mails

title: PARTTIME CABBY IS SLAIN IN QUEENS
description: A 71yearold retired taxicab driver working weekends to make some extra money, was shot and killed in his cab, apparently in a holdup, in Astoria, Queens, late Saturday night.

title: Jets Doon Giants On Ivan Namath's Pass In Overtime,2620
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov.Joe, Namath delivered under fire again today, this time in suddendeath, overtime with a 5yard touchdown pass to. Emerson Boozer that gave the Jets tory over the gaints.

title: Karajan Returns, a Great Legend Intact
description: Herbeit Von Karaian, who has not visited these shores since certain Wagnerian dolings at the Metropolitan Opera some years ago, arrived With full panoply in Carnegie, Hall on Saturday evening. He conducted his own orchestra, the Berlin PhilharMonic, in a pair of Brahms symphonies Nos. 4 in E minor and 2 in D. The, program may not have been the most imaginative, but the performence did did no harm at all to the Karajan legend or mystique.

title: Taxi Industry Split By Dispute on Future
description: New York's taxi industry, beset by inflationary economics that have sent fares up and the quality of service down, now finds its various factions engaged in angry struggle in which the traditional structure of the businessmore a necessity than a luxury in the city's Mass transportation systemis being questioned.

title: About New York A Carrousel With Class
description: Joe and Charlie were at it again, doing their job, and doing it with a style that has made them celebrated, that has added to the gaiety of the city and over the years has made their feet hurt. Moreover, Joe has lost some of his hearing, and Charlie pas varicose veins in his right leg. Joe and Charlie have the franchise for the carrousel in Central Park.

title: PROF. HERBERT WEST OF DARTMOUTH DEAD
description: Herbert Faulkner West, professor emeritus of comparative literature at Dartmouth College, died Saturday in the Veterans Administration Hospital in White River Junction, Vt. He was 76 years old.

title: N.Y.A.C. Victor in Rowing Here
description: The New York Athletic Club's champion scullers turned to sweep rowing and easily won the elitefourwithcoxswain event of the Veterans Day regatta at orchard Beach Lagoon, the Bronx, yesterday.

description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Ya. Nov. 10 (UPI)A convicted ariplane hijacker Who escaped from Federal prison was killed in a shootout with Federal agents last night, and a companion was arrested.

title: Medical Student Liked His Summir's Ordeal
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 10 Dennis Jahnigen spent his summer vacation gasping for air, feeling nauseated, enduring a continual headache and belowfreezing temperaturesand enjoyed every minute of it.

title: Trade Center at Issue
description: Theodore W. kheel, critic of the Port Authority, is proposing that the World Trade Center be turned over to Private operators, in a report to Mayor Beame. He said the authority could overcome its financial problems by doubling the tolls on its bridges and tunnels. Page 49.

title: OnceThriving Urban Coalition, Short of Funds, Pares Its Staff
description: The New York Urban Coalition, begun seven years ago as a social crusade, once had a budget of nearly $5million. It is now down to $2.8million.

title: Episcopal Diocese Celebrates 100th Year
description: SOUTH ORANGE, Nov. 10More than 4,000 members of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark converted Seton Hall University's gymnasium into a cathedral here today as they celebrated the 100th anniversary of the founding of their diocese.

title: DRAPEAU REELECTED MAYOR OF MONTREAL
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 10 (AP)Montrealers reelected Mayor Jean Drapeau to a fifth fouryear term today over four other candidates.

title: L.I Politicians Await Corruption Studies
description: Possibly the greatest political peril to city, county and town Administrations is tip election of a Distrfet Attorney of the opposite party, patticularly in this era of Watergate and the renewed emphasis on integrity in government. That's why two of the more significant results last Tuesday, politicians of both major parties agree, were the elections of Democrats as District Attorneys in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, where Re; publican administrations at the town and county level have nurtured the most powerful G.O.P. organizations in the state and beyond.

title: City May Name Street in Harlem for Powell
description: A bill to change the name of Seventh Avenue north of Central Park to Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard, in honor of the Harlem Congressman who died in 1972, will come before the City Council on Thursday.

title: HighCost Transit Delay
description: In 1951 the voters of this state empowered New York City to exceed its constitutional debt limit by a halfbillion dollars so it could finally go ahead with the building of a Second Avenue subwaya project that even then had been high on the matstransit priority list for two decades. In the next six years the city proceeded to borrow the $500 million in exempt funds but not one dollar was spent on the new: subway. All the money went for improvements in the existing subway system.

title: Work Democracy Tested At Scandinavian Plants
description: KRISTIANSAND, NorwayWhen the huge paper machine broke down at the Hunsfos mill here not long ago, the workers reacted quickly. One took over the control panel. The others, their hands darting in and out of the rollers, made some intricate adjustments. And in a few minutes everything was running smoothly again.

title: A.T.&T. and Xerox Plan Issues Totaling $1Billion
description: The corporate bond market, moving aong on the momentum of one of its best rallies on record, will be tested this week with offerings that total $1billion alone for two giant companies  American Telephone and Telegraph Cornpang and the Xerox Corporation.

description: BERLIN, Nov. 10The President of West Berlin's highest court was shot and killed tonight by a group of men believed to be leftwing extremists.

title: Royal Family Guarded.
description: LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP)The British royal family participated in Remembrance. Day ceremonies today honoring the dead of two world wars, as, the police kept a tight guard against terrorist bombings. They mingled with the crowds and watched from roofs as Queen Elizabeth, her husband, Prince Philip, Prince Charles and others attended the ceremony in Whitehall. More than 20 persons have been killed in bombings in England in the last year.

title: Ashe Wins By 62, 62 In Final

title: Theater: Death and Life
description: We all have to face itthe death that will one day be ours coming to someone else, someone near, dear and helpless. It is the inevitable unfairness of death that appalls. The littleness of it, the regularity, the pure simple banality of a dying moth struggling against the final window pane and looking for the last time at blue skies. A sad but ordinary business.

title: End of College Boom
description: For higher education in New York State, the period since World War II has been one of uninterrupted expansion. Now, according to a report issued by the Board of Regents last week, the boom is over. The Regents expect the number of undergraduates studying in the state to drop as much as 14 to 23 per cent by 1990, and they predict that the decline will jeopardize the existence of as many as 80 private colleges. News Analysis.

title: Jordan Is Said to Arrest 3 Officers in Hijacking Investigation
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 10The Jordanian authorities have detained three army officers and are questioning them in connection with a secret organization in the armed forces and the hijacking last Wednesday of a Jordanian airliner, according to travelers arriving from Amman, the Jordanian capital.

title: 1577 Silver Coin May Be Clue To Site of Drake's Coast Fort
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10A tiny silver coin bearing the likeness of Queen Elizabeth and dated 1577 that was found in the excavation of an Indian village north of here may prove an important clue in solving the mystery of Sir Francis Drake's missing California fort.

description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 10 Having shown some of their unappreciated strength to the people of Southern California Friday, the Knicks revealed one of their weaknesses to Bay Area spectators klast night while losing to the What State Warriors, 9793. What they display to Oregonians in Portland on Tuesday, when this trip comes to an end, remains to be seen.

He is a fine singer in today's mold, with an engaging personality and obvious musical training.

description: ATLANTA, Nov. 10Well, said the embarrassed waitress at one of Atlanta's more popular steak houses as she diffidently handed a customer a package of sugar from an apron pocket, we don't keep sugar on the table any more.

title: A Global Survival Pact Among Nations Is Urged
description: ROME, Nov. 10A Columbia professor who helped launch the United Nations World Food Program more than a decade ago has called for a new program of cooperation in food ana energy as part of a mutual survival pact between developed and developing countries.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fire marshals searched yesterday to determine what had caused the Saturday night explosion in an empty gasoline barge at a pier in the Kill Van Kull off Port Richmond, S.I. Windows in the neighborhood were shattered and a twoalarm fire ignited two other empty barges. A Fire Department spokesman said the gasoline barge had just been unloaded. No injuries were reported in the blast, which occurred at the site of the Reinauer Transportation Company, 1983 Richmond Terrace, about a half mile east of the Bayonne Bridge.

title: Lives of Cypriotes Bogged
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus Every day, 15 or people line up outside the door, clutching pictures of husbanda and fathers, brothers and sons. The men in the photos have not been heard since Turkish troops overran the northern part of Cyprus in August.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Nov. 4 editorial NearBankrupt City underscores many of the points which we, as Mayor and Comptroller, have stressed with increasing urgency in recent public statements. While we agree that your catalog of worrisome fiscal problems should have positive value in producing public understanding of the city's budgetMaking dilemma, your unfortunate use of the word bankrupt may create unwarranted fears for the safety of their investments among the city's bondholders.

title: The New Normal Princeton

title: Laura Jarett Married to Glen Gross
description: Laura Rea Jarett, a candidate for a doctorate in clinical psychology at New York University, and Glen Arthur Gross, a doctoral candidate in public policy analysis at the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday afternoon. title: 'Lenny,' With Dustin Hoffman, Is One --Fourth Brilliant
description: "Lenny," Bob Fosse's film version of Julian Barry's Broadway play about the life, assorted trials and death in 1966 of Lenny Bruce, looks to be about three-fourths dramatized biography and one-fourth recreated stage performances.These scenes trace Lenny's progression from the early nineteen-fifties, when he was a strip-joint comic (Customer: "Do you sell alligator shoes?" Salesman: "What size does your alligator wear?"), to Lenny's last exhausted years, when, after successive police busts for drugs and obscenity, he had reduced his nightclub act to obsessive readings from the court records.This one-fourth of the film is so brilliantand so brilliantly acted by Dustin Hoffmanthat it helps cool one's impatience with the rest of the film, which is much more fancily edited and photographed but no more profound than those old movie biographies Jack L. Warner used to grind out about people like George Gershwin, Mark Twain and Dr. Ehrlich. In movies, now as then, genius is principally defined by the amount of time spent dealing with disappointment."Lenny," which opened yesterday at the Cinema One, has the advantage of being able to present a lot of the original Lenny Bruce material, even the material that just a few years ago got him arrested here and in San Francisco. The movie also has an advantage in that much of this material still has some shock value in its dependence on rude 4-letter and 10-letter words and on rude allusions to sacred events (the Crucifixion) and sacred people (Eleanor Roosevelt, Pope John XIII).However, "Lenny" is never very precise about what happened to Lenny or why. Unless you've read the Albert Goldman-Lawrence Schiller biography, "Ladies and Gentlemen, Lenny Bruce!!" you might get the impression from the film that the desperation of Lenny's last years, as well as his death, were the exclusive result of harassment by the police and the courts and that Lenny had no role in his own collapse.Ironically the form of the movie only serves to emphasize this fuzziness. Mr. Barry's screenplay is in the shape of a series of overlapping interviews with Lenny's former wife, Honey (Valerie Perrine); his mother, Sally Marr (Jan Miner), and his agent (Stanley Beck), which, in turn, cue in the flashbacks.These interviews are full of phony, simulated cinma vrit-type irrelevancies in speech and manner that you never for a minute believe, any more than you believe that Lenny was just a sweet brilliant fellow who had some hard luck.The movie makes no point of Lenny's terrible childhood or his ambivalent feelings toward his father. His mother, the sometimes nightclub comic and emcee, is, as played by Miss Miner, a good deal less bizarre than Portnoy's, and Honey, as played by Miss Perrine, is about as voracious as a Goldilocks with a big habit for porridge.Honey's affairs with other women, accepted and sometimes encouraged by Lenny, are touched upon so gently as to seem of little imporance, as is Lenny's dependence on drugs, taken in such massive doses that he seems to have been a mental as well as physical wreck toward the end.Such vagueness, probably prompted by the producer's necessity to have the legal approval of both Honey and Sally Marr, denies the actors a lot of material that would have enriched their performances. Mr. Hoffman is such an interesting actor that he goes a long way toward filling in the gaps, but the others are not so fortunate. Miss Perrine is immensely effective in individual scenes but the character remains a cipher. Miss Miner is the gold-hearted stereotype.Mr. Fosse, the director of "Cabaret," is also inhibited here. The production, photographed in glorious black-and-white, has a fine, seedy look but this, after all, is just more description. Was Lenny truly some kind of mad prophet or simply an accidental product of his times, which, though he died in 1966, were really the gung-ho nineteen-forties and the uptight fifties? It's to the film's credit that it raises this question, though it doesn't supply us with much information with which to answer it.

title: Dave Anderson
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 100n the small stand outside the Yale Bowl today, a sign advertised New Yorkstyle pretzels. Before the game began, that was also an appropriate description of the Jets and Giants who had won three of 16 games during the current National Football League season. But somehow, as if playing from the memory of the glory that once framed each franchise, the Jets and the Giants turned into fancy pastry before the eyes, some bloodshot, of 67,740 spectators. There were no interceptions, no fumbles lost. No defense to speak of, either. One loud loyalist of the Giants once shouted deefense, deefense, but nobody bothered to form, a chant. Perhaps they were to enthralled by Joe Namath and Craig Morton, pastry chefs dueling with whippedcream guns. Morton had the Giants ahead, 2013, but then Namath, on a bootleg to his left, scored on a 3yard hobble that took perhaps three minutes. In the suddendeath overtime, the Jets quarterback flipped a pass to Emerson Boozer for a 5yard touchdown and 2620 victory. It was a reminder to New York devotees that pro football can be beautiful.

description: SEATTLE, Nov. 11 (UPI) The Coast Guard icebreaker Staten island will be decommissioned at Pier 90 in Seattle Friday after 33 years of service with both the United States and Soviet Navies. Built for the United States Navy, the icebreaker was delivered to the Soviet Union under a lendlease program in 1944.

title: KISSINGER WILL GO TO PEKING NOV. 25
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11Secretary of State Kissinger will fly to Peking for four days of consultations with Chinese leaders on Nov. 25, one day after the conclusion of President Ford's meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader.

title: Unnecessary Strike
description: A spreading pall of idleness began falling over the already sick economy with the formal start last night of national coal strike. The initial layoffs of workers in tributary industries were small, confined for the most part to traincrews on coalcarrying railroads, but the Vital will rise sharply if the tieup goes beyond the two or three weeks that now seem its irreducible minimum.

title: More Inexpensive Natural Gas For Utilities Ordered by Court
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11 (AP) The Federal Power Commission has been ordered to allow more cheap natural gas to go to public utilities, an action that could reduce the cost of electricity in the eastern half of the United States.

title: GERMANS ORDER EXTRA SECURITY
description: BONN, Nov. 11The 30 to 40 radical leftists in the BaaderMeinhof gang have succeeded, through a hunger strike in which one of them died Saturday, in dramatizing their twoandahalfyear pretrial imprisonment.

title: Market Place The TruckingProfit Squeeze
description: Toward the end of 1973, it appeared that the nation's trucking industry was headed for deep trouble as a result of the fuel crisis.

title: Confidence in Premier Caramanlis Appears to Be Key Issue in Greek Election
description: ATHENS, Nov. 11With less than one week remaining until the Greek national elections, the biggest issue appears to be whether voters have confidence in Premier Constantine Caramanlis.

title: U.S. Court Blocks Texas Prosecution Of Coop Lobbyist
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11 (AP)  A Federal appeals court blocked a Texas judge today from mounting a special Prosecution of the Government's prime witness against John B. Connally, onetime Presidential aspirant.

title: A Maximum 25Cent bus Fare Proposed
description: TRENTON, Nov. 11 The State Department of Transportation proposed today that the Byrne administration institute a maximum 25cent bus fare for passengers as well as free rides for the elderly on all intracity bus service in New aro finance the proposal, Transportation Commissioner Atlan Sagner suggested that the state subsidize the bus lines in the amount of $60million, to be supplemented by $10million from the state's 21 counties.

title: Hayes Keeps Bad Loser Tag
description: Woody Hayes staged one of his typical losing postgame performances Saturday when his Ohio State team was upset by Michigan State, 1613, in the season's biggest surprise. The Buckeyes coach stormed off the field and took a swipe at someone on the way. He threatened one reporter after the game by saying, I'm going to put my fist down your  throat!.

title: Swedish Auto Plant Drops Assembly Line
description: trade unions fought for and won passage of a series of laws that put severe limits on the importation of foreign labor. At, the same time absenteeism and turnover have been going up steadily since 1965 among Swedish workers. Indeed, turnover is now running at a rate of about 30 per cent.

title: Dollhouse Furniture: Bits and Pieces, Odds and Ends
description: It was almost inevitable that Maria Posada would get around to making dollhouse furniture.

title: Burma's Courts Get A Community Flavor
description: RANGOON, BurmaThey may have pedaled bicycle rickshas for a living, planted rice or served as clerks in Government offices. Whatever they did, so long as they were never lawyers, they are qualified to serve as people's judges in a revamped judicial system that is charged with dispensing socialist justice in Burnie.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Hockey, Basketball Standings

title: Providence Harriers Win
description: BOSTON, Nov. 11 (AP)Michael O'Shea of Providence College set a Course record today in leading his team to the New England crosscountry championship. O'Shea completed the fivemile course at Franklin Park in 23 minutes 31 seconds, beating th pievious record of 23:37 Set by Arthur Dulong of Holy Cross.

title: Bradley Hainmond Jr., 51, Marketing Consultant, Dies
description: Bradley. B. Hammond Jr., a marketing consultant, died Saturday in a boating accident in Ossining, N. Y. He was 51 years old and lived on Lodge Road in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Economic Decline Is Key Topicin in Britain
description: LONDON, Nov. 11Everywhere in Britain these days the talk is of economic decline. Nearly everyone, from housewives fighting inflation to stockbrokers fighting for their livelihood, seems to believe the country faces its most difficult period in years.

title: Jets Accentuate the Positive
description: The Jets will practice this week not in Hempstead but in Euphoria. Undoubtedly they will remain, all week on the high induced by their stunning conquest of the Giants.

title: The Opera
description: NEWARK, Nov. 10Birgit Nilsson and Placido Domingo have never sung Turandot together at the Metropolitan Opera, but they did so tonight at Symphony Hall here, with predictably exciting results.

title: United Parcel Threatens to halt Operations Nov. 20
description: on that Pomt.

title: SIX STATES AWAIT ELECTION RESULT
description: The results of elections in sh states remain in, doubt pending recounts. The Veterans Day holiday observed in many states yesterday delayed soma checks.

title: MICHAEL GOLDENBERG
description: Michael Goldenberg, an assistant branch librarian of the Brooklyn Public Library and former children's librarian, died yesterday of a heart attack in Trafalgar Hospital. He was 38 years old and lived at 40 Clinton Street, Brooklyn.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Ohrbach's has come a long way, baby. Back in the Depression and the war years, there was the exhilarating rough  and  tumble of the Union Square store, when shoppers shoved their way past Ida, the pretzel vendor outside its door, and pounced on tables helterskelter with bargains. Those who were teenagers during the Depression remember the joys of finding a tulle prom dress for $5 and highheeled shoes for next to nothing.

title: A Brief Parade and Rites Mark Veterans Day Here
description: The 26th Army Band and the John Philip Sousa Post 1112 Band stepped out as proudly and played as stirringly yesterday as if hundreds of thousands of people had lined the Fifth Avenue parade route to welcome a victorious army home. But, in fact, only a few hundred spectators stood along the avenue to watch the Veterans Day parade.

title: Convention Center Builders Told To Consider Raising Own Funds
description: The Beame administration has suggested that the developers of the $200million convention center along the Hudson River west of Times Square consider the possibility of floating a bond issue to raise construction funds as a hedge against the city's capital budget squeeze.

title: Bank Plans Cairo Branch
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the nation's fourth largest hank, has been granted approval by the Egyptian Government to establish a branch in Cairo.

title: How the Parcel Strike Hits the Retailer and His Customers.
description: Week and in some isolated cues more than that.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A threejudge Federal panel struck down as unconstitutional the state's requirement of a 75day waiting period for those who voluntarily left their jobs to qualify for home relief or aid to families with dependent children. In the view of the court, the State Legislature erred when it set up regulations on the presumption that poor people left jobs for better benefits on welfare.

title: For von Karajan, the Truth Is Nowhere
description: Herbert von Karajan, still icily iely handsome at 66 years of age, has long been one of the world's most honored conductors. Yet his reputation in America lags behind his reputation in Europe.

title: Expert on Ulcers Led Mount Sinai Medical Board
description: Dr. Ralph Colp, a surgeon who was president of the medical board of Mount Sinai Hospital from 1950 to 1954; died there yesterday. He was 81 years old and lived at 100 West 57th Street.

title: JACKSON PROPOSES ENERGY COUNCIL.
description: LONDON, Nov. 11Senator Henry M. Jackson proposed tonight that oilconsuming nations establish a Special Council of Economic and Financial Ministers, to take dramatic steps to meet the energy crisis.

title: Little League Series Bars Foreigners
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Nov. 11The Little League world series, which has been won the last four years by teams from Taiwan, will be limited in the future to teams from the continental United States.

title: CONVICT LOSES SUIT FOR CONJUGAL VISITS
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected a prisoner's contention that his constitutional rights were being violated because he was not allowed conjugal visits while in jail and because he needed such visits as a medical treatment for alleged homosexual tendencies.

title: Theater: Love for Love
description: Theater: Love for Love

title: Concert
description: When a performer has finally reached the upper rungs of fame, what then? Some simply hold on tight and try to play it safe, repeating over and over the same few works that brought them attention. Eventually even their fan clubs lose interest in that. A few artists, such as Alicia de Larrocha, seize on fame as a means to continue growing.

title: How the Parcel Strike Hits the Rstailer and His Customers
description: For Papilion Ltd.; it has meant having to ship a single $140 dress in a parcelpost package instead of five to 10 at a timebecause phstal service iusurtmce only goes up to $200.

title: Vikings Topple Cards For 7th Victory, 2824
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11The law of averages and the persistence of Francis Tarkenton caught up with the St. Louis Cardinals here tonight as the Minnesota Vikings beat them, 2824. One of the features of the remarkable St. Louis success this season, which had brought seven victories in eight games, was the relative absence of the turnoversmeaning fumbles lost and passes intercepted.

title: Justices Hear Illinois Democratic Delegate Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11An attorney for Mayor Richard. J. Daley of Chicago and ale, of of his political allies told Supreme Court today that Illi nois could legally send to jail 59 antiDaley Democrats for paiticipating in their party's 1972 national convention as delegates.

title: Sindona Blames Westminster for Certain Losses
description: MILAN, Italy, Nov. 11 (Reuters) Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, has alleged in documents lodged wit a Milan Court that losses on certain large foreignexchange operalions undertaken by Banca Unions, S.P.A., and Banca Privata Finanziaria, S.P.A., should be attributed to the International Westminster Bank, Ltd.

title: 10MONTH LOW HIT BY BRITISH POUND
description: LONDON, Nov. 11  The British pound toppled to a 10month low against other major currencies today in anticipation of new budgetary measures that the Government is scheduled to announce tomorrow.

title: Ore Discovery in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 11 (AP) The biggest iron ore de Posit in the Soviet far east has been found in the basin of the Uda River, Tass, the Soviet press agency reported today. A Tass dispatch from Khabarovsk said millions of tons of ore are hidden in the earth. The deposits have been found also near the coast of the Sea of Okhotsk and near convenient bays from where the ore can easily be shipped.

title: Concert
description: The special sound and ensemble personality of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra would be welcomed in many, kinds of music, of course. But its peculiarly Germanic qualities seem especially apt for that peculiarly Germanic composer, Anton Bruckner, and partly for that reason, the orchestra's account of Bruckner's Eighth Symphony on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall (which comprised the entire program) was a wonderfully memorable one.

title: Thieves Choose the Sugar
description: VISALIA, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP)  Burglars ignored money and soft drinks at the Rex Bottling Company but hauled off 500 pounds of sugar the police said today.

title: United Brands Reports Net Loss for Quarter
description: The United Brands Company, whose operations include the United Fruit and John Morrell meat packers plunged deep into the red in the third quarter with a net loss of $47.2million.

title: PATERSON TO STUDY BRIDGES FOR FLAWS
description: PATERSON, Nov. 11 (UPI)Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer announced today an engineering firm had been hired to examine five countyowned bridges into Paterson after structural flaws and gaping holes were found in the supports of two other bridges. Mayor Kramer said the examinations would be carried out by Ian Associates of Hawthorne and the $5,500 bill for the study would be sent to officials of Passaic County. The examinations will determine if the other bridges are deteriorating, the Mayor said.

title: Study Finds 10Year Drop ire U.S. Aid for Research
description: In none of the West European countries or Japan, over the last decade, has there bean a drop in cormmitments to research and development comparable to that in the United States, according to an analysis by the man who formerly bore chief responsibility for such efforts in France.

title: MRS. WALTER W. IRWIN
description: Anita Wilson Irwin, widow of Walter W. Irwin, a lawyer who was an early executive in the film industry, died yesterday at 4 East 66th Street, where she had lived for many years with her younger sister, Mrs. William Randolph Hearst Sr., widow of the publisher. She was 96 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Leaders n the turkey ndustry yesterday gave President Ford two frozen turkeys for Thanksgiving and threw in a gift to the American consumera prediction that the price of turkeys this Thanksgiving will be down 20 to 25 per tent.

title: Site for Dump Stirs Putnam County Dispute
description: CARMEL, N.Y., Nov. 11The Carmel town dump rises in soggy and stinking majesty over Route 6 just south of here, resplendent in moldering rust and rot, a gathering point for rats and scavenger birds.

title: Music
description: Dvorak's Requiem (Op. 89) is hardly a war horse, yet for no obvious reason it seems to be turning up relatively frequently these days. Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall it turned up again, in the secure hands of Antal Dorati and his National Symphony Orchestra.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: Biologist Is Buried at Sea After Virgin Islands Death
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. I., Nov. 11 (AP)A New Hampshire marine biologist who apparently fell to his death in the Virgin Islands has been buried at sea near St. Thomas.

title: UNICEF Cards Available
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 11The United States Committee for UNICEF announced today that, while the United Nations is closed to the public, UNICEF greeting cards can be obtained at the committee's office at 332 East 38th Street and at other metropolitan locations given on request by calling MU 51300.

title: W.F.L Finds Itself Short Of Food and Clothing, Too
description: Players on at least four World Football League teams haven't been paid lately. One teem is begging for food, and another is mising a set of uniforms.

title: John W. Davis,Educator And Diplomat Honored
description: John W. Davis, the 86yearold educator, diplomat and civil rights activist, was honored last night at a dinner in the grand ballroom of the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: A's Conquer and Divide: Series Shares Are $22,219
description: Winning the World Series was worth $22,219 to each member of the Oakland A's who was voted a full share, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: JAMES L. SKERRITT
description: James Lewis Skerritt, a retired New York lawyer who had specialized in trust and estate cases, died Saturday here. He was 76 years old and lived at 1125 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: STRIKES IN FRANCE WILL CURB SERVICES
description: PARIS, Nov. 11 (Reuters)Electricity and gas cuts, reductions in hospital and socialsecurity services and yet another radio and television stoppage loom this week as strike action across France intensifies.

title: Advance P.L.O. Contingent Is Rushed to WaldorfJ.D.L. issues Threat
description: The United Nations headquarters was like a citadel awaiting a siege yesterday as the first contingent of the Palestine Liberation Organization arrived in the city for the Geneeral Assembly debate on Palestine, Which begins tomerrow.

title: Science Foundation Scored By Proxmire on Planning
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that the National Science Foundation spends tens of milof dollars without coordi nating their work with other Federal agencies.

title: ROBERT SIMPSON, 82, TRACK COACH, DEAD
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 (AP) Robert Simpson, a former track star at the University of Missouri and coach of the first combined United States armed services team, died yesterday. He was 82 years old.

title: Busing and Integration
description: The schoolbusing issue is moving to a critical impasse. Opposition to busing has been building upbuilt up deliberately might be a more accurate description  since former President Nixon discovered and exploited the issue's political potency.

title: Ford Panel Spurs Action On AntiInflation Pledges
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11President Ford's Citizens Action Committee to Fight Inflation moved today to set up voluntary, grassroots antiinflation programs across the nation and warned that mandatory wage and price controls would almost inevitably follow if voluntary action failed.

title: New Turn in Oil Prices
description: ABU DHABI, Nov. 11for the first time since the sharp I rise in oil prices began two years ago, three producer countries have broken the united front of the oil exporters cartel on the socalled posted price system.

title: For American Women Working in Japan, Being a Foreigner Helps
description: TOKOY  They star on television, work as lawyers, hustle drinks in bars and study, karate. But they usually find one thing in commonin Japan, American women are treated more as, foreigners than as women.

title: KREISKY, AT U.N., URGES MODERATION
description: KREISKY, AT U.N., URGES MODERATION

title: Nations Cup Won by U.S. Riding Team
description: The United States Equestrian Team, with a perfect performance in Madison Square Garden last night, triumphed in the Nations Cup.

title: Supreme Court Refuses to Hear Haldeman Plea on CoverUp Indictments
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Shpreine Court removed today the last obstacle to continued prosecution of the Watergate fiverup case by refusing to hear a major legal objection raised by H. R. Haldeman, one qtthe defendants.

title: JERSEY P.U.O HEAD TARGET OF INQUIRY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 11  The state's investigation, of alleged political corruption and mob influence in New Jersey's garbage industry has begun to focus on charges against Anthony J. Grossi, president of the State, Board of Public Utility commissioners.

title: 2 Queens Districts Plagued by Thefts Of Auto Radiators
description: A wave of automobileradiator thefts is plaguing car owners and the police in the Forest Hills and Kew Gardens sections of Queens.

description: News Summary and Index

title: Illness of Infants Laid To Smoking of Parents.
description: LONDON, Nov. 11, (Reuters)The chances of children getting pneumonia or bronchitis in the first year of life nearly double when both parents smoke, a group of medical scientists has warned.

title: HOWARD B. WILLIAMS
description: Howard B. Williams, a vice president and design director of The Sea Pine Company of Hilton Head Island, S.C., and a former interior designer here, died Friday of a heart attack at Hilton Head Island. He was 54 years old and lived in Hilton Head.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said yesterday it had been advised over the weekend that the Jamaican Government was not planning a tender offer for shares of Kaiser or the Reynolds Metals Company.

title: U.S. UNIT SEEKS DATA ON AEROSOL REFUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that it had asked 250 of the nation's largest aerosol spray makers to tell how consumers are bing invited to request refunds for products containing the cancercausing chemical vinyl chloride.

title: Terms Are Due Today on Big A.T.&T. Financing
description: Underwriters will set ientative terms late today on a $600million financing by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in what ranks as the largest straight debt borrowing on record.

title: Cuban Exiles March To Protest the Plan For Castro Detente
description: UNION CITY, N. J., Nov. 11 (UPI)Thousands of chanting, flagwaving Cuban refugees from at least 35 organizations marched through this city in orderly fashion to protest a proposed dtente with Fidel Castro's Government.

title: Movement in Rome
description: When Secretary of State Henry Kissinger spoke Rome in moving and somber tones about the world's food Plight, his speech was long on proposals for organizing international efforts to combat the crisis over the next several years but short on specifics about what the United States intends to do to help feed the world's hungry over the, next few months.

title: Philadelphia Victor
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11Philadelphia scored a 42 victory over the Leamington Club of Warwickshire, England in court tennis today. The British wind up their tour Wednesday at the Boston Racquet and Tennis Club.

title: Society's Warehouses
description: There are dark corners in America where people are trampled, broken and forgotten. The saddest of these and the most demeaning to our societyare those institutions, paid for and run by the public, where people are stashed away for the safety and convenience of the rest of us and then left to rot untouched by the collective conscience of the community. Attica and Soledad turned flickering attention toward the prisons but few have cared to look at those huddled in the rotten crannies of America's public mental institutions.

title: World Food Parley Looking to U.S. For Half of Emergency Aid
description: ROME, Nov. 11Half of the additional food supplies needed to stave off widespread famine will have to be found in the United States, an official of the World Food Conference secretariat said today.

title: Ryder System Omits Payout
description: Ryder System, Inc., announced yesterday in Miami that it would not pay a regular quarterly dividend in January, 1975. Last January Ryder paid a quarterly dividend of 7 cents a share of common stock. In October, 1974, the company paid a quarterly dividend of 10 cents a share. James A Ryder, chairman, said that the dividend was omitted to conserve cash during a period of extremely high interest costs.

title: South Africa Colored Group Criticizes Veto of U.N. Move
description: CAPE TOWN, Nov. 11Leaders of South Africa's two million people of mixed race today criticized the Western powers recent veto of the move to oust South Africa from the United Nations.

title: CAHILL DEFENDS PORTUNIT STAND
description: PRINCETON, Nov. 11Former Gov. William T. Cahill today defended his efforts to effect a greater involvement of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in mass transportation during his term in office.

description: A wave of automobileradiator thefts is pittguihg car owners and the police in the Forest Hills and Kew Gardens sections of Queens.

title: Books of The Times
description: What possessed me:443 read Thomas Wiseman's The. Money Motive, a somewhat thin and derivative study of the depthpsychology of financial dealings? Partly I was intrigued by the notion of novelist's exploring this subject (Mr. Wiseman, who was raised in Vienna And now lives in England, is the author of four novels, as well as a play and a history of films). Partly I was hooked by the dustjacket comeon  What you unconsciously reveal about your desires and fears every time you handle money, or talk about itas would anyone else who feels deep desire andifear (and these days, who doesn't?) every time he handles money, or talks about it. And partly I was attracted by Mr. Wiseman's introductory announcement, that Attempting to go beyond (Freud's) anal theory [of why human beings, hoard money], found that Melanie Klein's explanation of primal greed, as she observed and analyzed it in young children, revealed a whole spectrum of meanings behind the acquisitiveness and poisessiveness expressed in moneymaking. For it looked as though. Mr. Wiseman, would go beyond the popular psychological clichds.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Thomas P. F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art; Richard D. Aurelio, former Deputy. Mayor, and J. James Akston, director of the Art Museum in Palm Beach, Fla., have joined the board of The Lambs, the centuryold theatrical club, which Is being reorganized under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: CLOTHING IMPORTS PROTESTED HERE
description: About 10,000 people jammed East 62d Street yesterday as members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America across the nation protested the importing of cheaply produced foreignmade apparel. The importts, the union says, have resulted in loss of about 11,000 American jobs in the last four years.

title: Gerald Eskenazi
description: No player is an individual, growled Fred Shero four years ago. Hockey is a team game and the players must conform. He Was talking as the new coach of a groveling team called the Philadelphia Flyers, another joke in the City of Brotherly Love's sports stories. Mustaches, long hairnever, shouted Shero his closecropped hair virtually bristling. In addition to hair being nonconformist, Shero had another reason: The players could catch cold if they leave their dressing room with their long hair wet. One year later the Flyers had hair. Cowboy Bill Flett looked as if he were trying out for the lead in a Passion Play. Bobby Clarke looked like a toothless Shirley. Temple. Flyer personnel had all sorts of hair, from Flett's beard to the goatee worn by the team's optometrist.

title: TO EXTEND STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The likely duration of the national coal miners strike was stretched from two weeks to at least three today by the failure of industry and union negotiators to approach a final settlement on a new contract.

title: Pennsylvania's U.F.O. Just a Flash in the Pond
description: CARBONDALE, Pa., Nov. 11 (AP)An old railroad lantern glowing underwater in a silt pond near an abandoned coal breaker kept this rural eastern Pennsylvania community talking of unidentified flying objects over the weekend.

title: S. E. C. PROPOSES NEW CAPITAL RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Securities and Exchange Commission suggested for comment today a series of revisions in its proposed net capital rule designed to measure the liquid ity and financial responsibility of brokerage firms.

title: DIVESTING PLANS ON AVIS OPPOSED
description: At a hearing in the Federal District Court in Hartford yesterday, Avis. Inc., opposed the plans of both the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Justice Department for divestiture of I.T.T.'s 52 per cent interest in Avis. However, the parties did agree on the appointment of Kenneth Emerson Frantz, an assistant professor at Boston University's School of Management and Fiance, as trustee to dispose of I.T.T.'s interest in Avis in compliance with a 1971 Federal Court ruling.

title: People in Sports Bugner, Ellis Fight for Title Shot
description: Britain's Joe Bugner, the European heavyweight champion, needs an impressive victory over Jimmy Ellis of Louisville tonight in their fight at Wembley Pool, London, to rate a shot at the world title held by Muham mad Ali. But Ellis has similar and conflictingaims.

title: Beame Asks State to Construct 15,000Seat Arena in Brooklyn
description: Mayor Beame formally proposed yesterday that the  New York State Sports Authority consider building a 15,000seat indoor arena in Brooklyn.

title: House Mace Is Back After Being Repaired
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP)  The 135yearold mace, symbol of authority in the House of Representatives, has been returned to the Capitol after being repaired at the Smithsonian Museum.

title: Crafty Khale Big A Victor
description: Bobby Dotter did the right thing in switching dates for Mrs. Nelson Asiel's Crafty Khale. The trainer had the 5yearold son of Crafty Ad miral entered for the Jockey Club Gold Cup last Saturday, but thought better of it. In stead, he put Crafty Khale in the $58,150 Stuyvesant Han dicap at Aqueduct yesterday; Dotter's judgment was per feet.

title: COPIES OF LETTERS FOUND IN BOMB PLOT
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 11 (UPI)Carbon copies of the J. Hawker letters involved in a $1million extortion plot against the Bonneville power Administration have been found in the home of a young couple charged with sending one of them.

title: Violence on Wane In Angolan Capital After 50 Are Killed
description: LUANDA, Angola, Nov. 11This city's vast slum sections were calm late tonight after a day and night of violence that took more than 50 lives.

title: 1,000 at White House $eek
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) About 1,800 family members and supporters, demonstrated near the White House today seeking to Persuade the administration to demand an accounting of servicement not accounted for in Southeast Asia.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 11Parimutuel clerks at Roosevelt Raceway said tonight that they would go on strike tomorrow unless the track met their demands, to increase the work force. After meeting with their membership, union officials told raceway executives that they would call a strike at 3 P.M. tomorrow if more clerks were not assigned to the mutuel windows.

title: Little League Series Bars Foreigners
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Nov. 11The Little League world series, which has been won the last four years by teams from Taiwan, will be limited in the future to teams from the continental United States.

title: Political Academy Writes Report on Rockefeller Gift
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Academy of Political Science is preparing a statement at the request of the Senate Rules Committee and the House Judiciary Committee concerning the $89,952 gift from Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller to the academy and the academy's publication last May of a book lauding Mr. Rockefeller's governorship.

title: Israeli Delegate Is Pessimistic Over the U.N. Debate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 11Israel's representative at the United Nations, Yosef Tekoah, said today that the cards were stacked against his country in the forthcoming General Assembly debate on Palestine.

title: Cuban Refugees Protest Plan for Detente With Castro
description: UNION CITY, Nov. 11 (UPI) Thousands of chanting, flagwaving Cuban refugees from at least 35 organizations marched through this city in orderly fashion today to protest proposed dtente with Fidel Castro's Communist Government.

title: DEFENSE PRESSES PLEA OF INSANITY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 11The defense for Dr. William R. King, the former staff psychiatrist at Trenton State Prison who is charged with trying to arrange the murder of his former Wifa and two of her relatives, produced two psychiatrists today, who said that Dr. King was insane at the time.

title: Mondale Asks Moscow to Show Restrain in Economic Turmoil
description: Moscow, Nov. 11Senator Walter F. Mondale cautioned a select Soviet audience today that Soviet American trade would suffer if Moscow tried to take advantage of the current disarray in the West.

title: Business Records
description: Chapter XI petition for an arrangement by: C. J. I. INDUSTRIES INC., 396 Fifth Ave., N.Y, Sinned by Allan H. Rower, president. Liabilities $2,115,024; assets 52,763,222. The concern is a converter, jobber, and supplier of textiles and other fabrics. Other corporations controlled or held by petitioner are Cyndy Joy Industries, Inc.; Jacob Yarns, Inc. and Flispun Yarns, Inc. Bruce Jacobs is vice president.

title: People and Business
description: A West German monetary expert is looking toward increased exports to oilproducing countries as the best way for the industrialized world to solve balanceofpayments problems caused by higher oil prices.

title: Bridge: Washington Bids to Become Home of the, Top Players
description: In the years before World War II, there was little doubt that the strongest cities in terms of bridge ability were New York and Philadelphia. In postwar years, Philadelphia declined, and the strongest challenges to New York came from Los Angeles and Dallas.

title: PRESIDENT AGREES TO ALLOW ACCESS TO NIXON RECORDS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The White House formally agreed today to let Henry S. Ruth Jr. the special Watergate prosecutor, have access to all of former President Richard M. Nixon's records that relate to cases under investigation.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For hihg tide at Jones Inlet (Pt. Lookout), deduct 19 min, from Sandy Hook time.

description: TANAKA TOREPORT ON HIS FINANCES

title: New Jersey Sports
description: For the second consecutive week, The Rahway High football team averted defeat with seconds remaining. And, once again, the coach was a dramatic hero.

title: stalled City Subway Expension
description: Cost overruns  on everything from warplanes, tanks and ships to civilian airports and Albany Mallshave become a painful governmental commonplace in the last decade. Still, the city's residents were distressed to learn last week that the subwayexpansion program here had a price tag estimate of at least $4.7billion, well over four times the figure given the public when the program was put forward early in 1968.

title: 2 STUDIES REPORT FOSTERCARE BIAS
description: Two studies releaseti here yesterday show that private fostercare agencies handling black children receive and spend 42 per cent less public money than agencies handling Jewigh children and 19 per cent less than agencies handling. Boman Catholic children.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: YOUTHFUL BULLSEYE There can't be anything seriously wrong with show business, not with six young performers like Gail Johnston, Maureen Maloney, Nancy Reddon, Don Bradford, Torn Hastings and Michael David Laibson and a composerlyricistdirector like Joyce Stoner. This 28yearold blonde, abetted by William Boswell, has devised a stage struck revue titled I'll Die If I Can't Live Forever, whose tonic effect is marvelous. Fresh as a daisy, sharp as a tack and as funny as it is fast, this 90minute show is the best minimusical in town.

title: CHOICE OP GIBSON IS UNDER REVIEW
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11A White House spokesman said today that the controversial nomination of Andrew E. Gibson as Federal Energy Administrator was still under review.

title: Plans to Close 3 Branches Of Library Here Protested
description: In letters to Mayor Beame and the trustees of the New York Public Library, Greenwich Village civic and political leaders yesterday called upon the library to rescind its decision to close three branches later this week.

title: CPC Increases Price of Sugar; Poricze Addi Plans Revisio
description: CPC International, Inc., an nounced yesterday that its industrial division, effective today, would increase its sugar price by $11 per 100 pounds to $63.95 for bulk granulated sugar and industrial liquid sugar and $64.25 for extra fine granulatedsugar. The move follows an increase of $3.35 per 100 pounds on industrial sugars announced last week, by the Sucrest Corporation and the Amstar Corporation.

title: ISRAELI JETS ATTACK SOUTHERN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov, 11The Defense Ministry said today that 12 Israeli Phantom jets had attacked targets in southern Lebanon, killing two Lebanese farmers and two Palestinians.

description: The budget cuts planned by Mayor Beame for the next seven months portend drastic reduction in municipal services, resulting in certain hardship unless the city agencies, the unions and individuals cooperate in boost ing productivity.

title: COLA PACT DELAYTO EXTEND STRIKE  Walkout Begins officially as Duration of at Least3 Weeks Is itorecast
description: WASHINGTON,Tuesday, Nov 12A national coal miners strike began at one minute past midnight today, and Its likely duration was stretched from two weeks to at least three by the failure of industry and union negotiators to approach final settlement on a new contract.

title: Hunger Strike in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 11 (AP)Mrs. Yun Po Sun, wife of a former South Korean President who was convicted last summer of antiGovernment activities, began a hunger s'trike today to demand the release of political prisoners. Mrs. Yun and a group of about 60 relatives of political prisoners started a oneweek fast in downtown building owned by the Roman Catholic Church. They are seeking the release of 203 persons convicted this year under emergency laws.

description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov.11 (AP)  The Venezuelan Treasury and the Mines and Hydrocarbons Ministry are studying the possibility of lifting taxes paid by foreign oil companies operating in the country, the newspaper El Nacional reported today.

title: Ballet: Tubby the Tuba

Graduation Ball and Allegro Brillante complated a program that showed the company handling a wide range of styles impressively.

Production of Steel off 1.2% in Week; Third Drop in Row.
description: Steel production for the week ended Nov. 9 fell by 1.2 per cent to 2,780,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Instituted reported yesterday. This was the third consecutive weekly decline and compared with the 2,814,000 tons poured in the week ended Nov. 2.

title: U,N. GUARD TIGHT AS PALESTINIANS FLY IN FOR DEBATE
description: The United Nations headquarters was like a citadel awaiting a siege yesterday as the first contingent of the Palestine Liberation Organization arrived in the city for the General Assembly debate on Palestine, which begins tomorrow.

title: DR. FRANCIS L. WEILLE
description: Dr. Francis Lee Weille, a Boston otolaryngologist and former assistant professor at Harvard Medical School, died Sunday at his home in Needham, Mass. He was 75 years old and had practiced in Boston from 1929 until last, summer.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: The Supreme Court of the United States declined yesterday to step into a controversy over a proposed water treatment plant for eight New Jersey communities. The court let stand a decision by the Appellate Division Superior Courtupholding plans for a water treatment plant at Wanaque. The decision was appealed by the Passaic Valley Water Commission, which said it preferred to upgrade its own filtration plant rather than help pay for new plant at Wanaque. The commission represent Paterson, Passaic and. Clifton, three of the eight cities that obtain water from Wanaque Reservoir under a contract with the New Jersey. Dishict Water Supply Commission.

description: Britain's Joe Bugner the European heavyweight champion, needs an impressive victory over, Jinmy Ellis of Louisville tonight in their fight at Wembley Pool, London, to rate a shot at the world title held by Muhammad Ali. But Ellis has similar and Conflictingaims.Bugner thinks he needs me to get a world title chance, said the 34yearold Ellis yesterday. But I need him to become my windfall. I still have a chance at the big apple.
