title: Muskie Backs G.I Aid Rise
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 11 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, told a Veterans Day observance today that an increase in educational benefits was an important step toward repaying the nation's debt to Vietnam veterans. A cosponsor of legislation increasing G.I. Bill payments by more than 23 percent, Senator Muskie said that he disagreed with President Ford, who described the measure as inflationary and threatened to veto it.

description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 11In one of their most chaotic meetings on record, the foreign ministers of the nine European Common Market countries failed to make progress here today on any of the major points slated for discusslon at a summit meeting the countries heads of government in Paris next month.

description: The oil industry adopted a united front yesterday on major tax issues, including continued support for the controversial depletion allowance.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI)  Vietnamera veterans receiving education benefits to attend schools in the East or Midwest may be getting shortchanged under the G.I. Bill, according to a report prepared for the National Conference of Mayors.

title: If in Doubt Gamble
description: Thanks to a twentymile belt of ozone beginning about ten miles above the earth, this planet is shielded from the direct ultraviolet rays of the sun. Without that screen, all animals, including the human species, would be subject at the least to an increased incidence of cancer and at worst to disruption of the plantanimal food chain which could shatter the ecological structure that permits man to remain alive on this planet,

title: DEATH THREAT LAID TO DEBT COLLECTOR
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday handed up an indictment against a debt collector who had allegedly threatened the life of a man who was $5,060 in debt from a gambling junket.

title: Missing Hunter Found Dead
description: JEFFERSON, N. H., Nov. 11 (AP)Clayton Prenette Jr., 36 years add, of Southington, Conn., was found dead today on Mount Waumbec's Pond of Safety Trail where he had been missing since yesterday when he became separated from his son and seven other persons while hunting. His death was attributed to a heart attack.

title: Jane Ace Is Dead at 74; Noted for Malapropisms
description: Jane Ace, whose malapropisms in radio shows with her husband, Goodman Ace, delighted national audiences in the nineteenthirties and forties, died yesterday in poctors Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived at the Ritz Tower Hotel.

title: Bus Strike in Seattle Halts Service for 90,000 in Area
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 11 (AP)About 90,000 commuters formed car pools, hitchhiked and sought other ways to get to and from work here today as a bus strike entered its third day.

description: NIXON EXPECTED TO GO HOME SOON

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) The Commerce Department reported today that retail sales declined in October for the second straight month, giving further evidence to a weakening of the nation's economy.

description: Frank Yablans, the 39yearold motionpicture executive who was superseded seven weeks ago as the active head of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, has resigned as president and chief operating officer.

title: George Benedict, 73, Dies; Phillips Academy ExDean
description: George G. Benedict, dean of students at Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., from 1943 to 1967, died Sunday in Providence, R.I., where he lived. He was 73 years old.

title: Doctor Guilty in Tax Case
description: NEWARK, Nov. 11 (AP)  A Hackensack physician was sentenced to a week in jail and fined $4,000 today for not filing his income tax return in 1969. Dr. Charles P. Campbell, 62 years old, was sentenced by Judge H. Curtis Meanor in Federal District Court. According to a guilty plea, Dr. Campbell failed to file his tax return in 1969, when his income was $22,697. A similar charge for 1968 was dismissed.

title: MATHILDE P. SEWALL
description: Mathilde Parmelee Sewall, wife of Prof. Richard B. Sewall of Yale University and a founder of the Creative Arts Workshop in New Haven, died Saturday in YaleNew Haven Hospital. She was 65 years old.

title: Germans Join French Armistice Rites
description: PARIS, Nov. 11Today for the first time Germany participated in Armistice Day ceremonies at the tomb of France's Unknown Soldier, symbol of millions of victims of two World Wars with the old enemy.

title: REV. HUNTERGUTHRIE, LED GEORGETOWN V.
description: WERNERSVILLE, Pa., Nov. 11 (AP)The Rev. Hunter Guthrie, a member of the Jesuit order who was president of Georgetown University in Washington from 1949 to 1952, died today at the Novitiate of St. Isaac Jogues. He was 73 years old.

title: PAUL S. GESSWEIN
description: Paul Schofield Gesswein, a former insurance and pension counselor and boat designer here, died of cancer Sunday in Guadalajara, Mexico. He was 72 years old.

description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12If it was possible to construct plausible scripts for Monday night football, which is an aspect of the entertainment business, last night's game between the Vikings and Cardi nals would do as a model. The first required ingredient is obvious. Since the show endures for three liours, it Must have a worthy finale, a last hurrah. This game did.

title: Hazing Rite Burial Kills Jersey Student
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J. Nov. 12 William Flowers, a 19 year old Monmouth College Student, suffotated early today when a sandy grave he was forced to die in the rainswept beach, as part of a fraternity initiation collapsed as he was lying in it.

title: J.D.L Aide Held in Threat To Kill Palestinian Leader
description: Russet Kelner, who called himself chief of operations of the Jewish Defense League, was arrested yesterday after he had asserted that we plan to assaisinate Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

description: Steve Garvey of the Los Angeles Dodgers, whose boyhood dream was to become a major league star, was named the National League's most valuable player by the Baseball Writers Association of America yesterday.

title: G.O.P. Senate Leader Challenges Carey, Saying 1975 Tax Reduction Is Possible
description: Moving quickly to challenge the incoming Carey administrathe the, Republican Majority leader of the State Senate said yesterday that he foresaw an excellent chance of a tax cut in the legislative session that opens in January.

title: PENT AGON IS SEEKING 300,000 FOR RAISES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) The Pentagon is looking for 300,000 former servicemen because the military owes them money.

title: SCHOOL PAY UNIT ACCUSED OF GRAFT; DataProcessing Company Is Cited by State on Gifts to Employes of Board
description: A payrollprocessing company that has received more than $2million from the Board of Education over the last four years has been accused by the State Cominission, of Investigaltion of illegally, giving money, gifts and the services of call girls to employes of the board.

title: U.S.C. Establishes Chairs for Heifetz And Piatigorsky
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12The University of Southern California today announced it was establishing two $1million chairs in music in the names of Jascha Heifetz and Gregor Piatigorsky.

title: BUSING CURB VOID IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: BOSTON, Nov. 12 (AP) The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court ruled today that an antibusing provision of a state school desegregation law passed this year is unconstitutional because it prohibits the use of mandatory school assignments and busing to achieve racial balance.

title: Union to Study Position in Parcel Strike
description: Ronald Carey, president of Local 804 of the teamsters union, said yesterday that the union would reevaluate its position in the 78day strike against the United Parcel Service if it were established by a fair and honest accounting procedure that the company was losing $8million a year in its New York area operations.

title: Jersey P.U.C. President Faces U.S. Tax Inquiry
description: TRENTON, Nov. 12  The United States Attorney for New Jersey, has ordered a Federal income tax investigation of Anthony J. Grossi, the president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, who is already under investigation by the state in connection with its inquiry into alleged mob influence in New Jersey's garbage industry.

title: A CREDITOR PLAN SET ON HERSTATT
description: COLOGNE;, West Germany, Nov: 12.(AP)  The immediate threat of bankruptcy proceed ings in the Banithaus I. D.Her statt case was averted today by a neW proposal for compen sating creditors.

title: 2 Killed, 5 Hurt on Cyprus As U.N. Vehicle Hits Mine
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 12 (Reuters)An Australian policeman serving with the United Nations truce force in Cyprus and a Turkish Cypriote civilian were killed foday, when their Land Rover hit a mine on a main road in northwest Cyprus, a United Nations spokesman said.

title: Japan Exports Set Record
description: TOKYO, Nov 12 (Reuters)The value of Japan's exports reached a record level in October because of active sales of chemicals; cars, steel and ships, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: Britain's Market Talks Enter Key Phase
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 12Britain's effort to renegotiate her terms of entry into the European Common Market entered a crucial phase today as the group's nine Foreign Ministers, meeting in Brussels, examined a report about which countries gain and which lose financially from community membership.

description: SEOUL South Korea, Nov. 12  South Korea's largest national daily, DongA Ilbo, skip ped its regular edition today.

description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 12 (AP)The first issue of The Sun, an interim newspaper born of the Newspaper Guild strike against The Cleveland Plain Dealer and the subsequent shutdown of The Cleveland Press, was distributed this morning.

description: ROME, Nov. 12  Is Italy becoming a protectorate of America? Europeo, the popular weekly news magazine, asked recently.

description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 12 (Reuters)  The Government press agency reported today that Iraqi forces fired artillery and machine guns at three Iranian border posts in the last two days but caused no casualties or damage.

title: In This Marriage, the Open Years Have Been Best
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y.For a man who is trying to save money in the supermarket, Richard Bock had a curious strategy at the meat counter.

title: Let Them Eat Petroleum
description: PARIS The unprecedented crises now engulfing the world, including an energy shortage threatening to cripple advanced countries and a food shortage threatening to starve backward countries, are directly linked. The Second Report to the Club of Rome (an ecological group) says these and other threats exist simultaneously and with a strongly woven relationship between them.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Appellate Division, Second Department, censured a Long Island lawyer who had previously been cited for contemptuous behavior by the Federal judge who presided over the first Superfecta harnessracing drivers trial last summer in Brooklyn. The lawyer, Nicholas L. Castellano, who represented several drivers, all of whom were acquitted pleaded guilty to one count of contempt of court last Sept. 3 before District Judge Edward R. Neaher, who fined him $500.

title: New York Realities
description: As countless delegates to the United Nations have discovered, the right of free, peaceful expression is taken seriously in the United States and in its greatest city. No government or cause can usurp the right of free men to make their feelings known in orderly demonstrations such as occurred last week when many American Jews and thousands of sympathizers of all faiths massed in protest against the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Chile Shaken by Quake
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 12 (UPI) A strong earthquake shook a large part of Chile early today but no injuries or substantial damage was reported.

title: INDIAN TRIAL JURORS WANT CASE DROPPED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12Five of the twelve jurors who served in the trial of Dennis J. Banks and Russell C. Means, the American Indian leaders of the 1973 armed takeover Wounded Knee, ??? to the Justice Department today to drop Charges in the remaining Wounded Knee cases.

title: TERMS ARE SET ON A PHONE ISSUE
description: Underwriters set tentative terms late yesterday on a closely watched $600million financing for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that were in line with Wall Street expectations.

description: Although the vote will not be considered official for four more weeks, the makeup of the 1975 State Legislature now appears almost certain to be 88 Democrats and 62 Republicans in the Assembly, and 34 Republicans and 26 Democrats in the Senate.

title: Soviet Moves Ahead of U.S. in oil output.
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12The Soviet Union said today that it had surpassed the United States as the world's leading oil producer but that it still sought American technology to resolve continuing inefficiency in oil extraction.

title: Poll by Harris Finds 46% Doubt Kennedy's Integrity
description: Louis Harris, the pollster, says that 46 per cent of Amercans do not trust the integrity of Senator Edward M. Kennedy but 75 per cent think he is doing a good job as Senator.

title: Books of The Times
description: Repression as routine, duty as pain, anger muffled and converted to grief  civilized adult behavior. This was Miriam Scheinman's 13 years of marriage. Ms. Superego is my name, she wrote when it was over. Her husband, Stan, whom she had once seen as a Dostoyevskian wild man, had succumbed to career interest  creeping convenience. She had turned to divorce the way someone who has swallowed something indigestible thrusts her fingers down her throat. Now their enmity was spewed out in the open: he heading toward an evernarrower security and respectability, she toward that centrifugality whose ripples nag at mfinity.

title: The Best of Art Deco Architecture Displayed at Finch
description: It has become common to employ the term art deco loosely, but the exhibition that has opened at the Finch College Museum of Art, American Art Deco Architecture, sets such broad limits for at deco that definition becomes almost impossible. The exhibition include's, for example, such diverse examples of nineteenthirties design as the Hoover Dam and the Golden Gate Bridge works that are far more notable for their sense of structural strength than for their details. And it is in the details, reallythe splendid geometric ornaments and reliefs symbolizing the modern agethat the deco style makes its mark.

title: Deaths
description: AMBROSEEdna, on October 30, 1974, formerly of East Orange, N.J., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry T. Ambrose. Sister of Mrs. Alfred M. Tilden of Winter Haven, Fla. A memorial service will be held on Thursday morning, November 14th at 11 o'clork at Calvary United Methodist Church, Main & Walnut Streets, East Orange, N.J. Friends are invited to attend. AMOROSIAnlolnette G., on Nov, II, 1974, wife of the late Joseph A. Amorosi, mother of Leo J. Amorosi, sister of Mrs. Maria Campoli and Mrs. Philomena Casolaro, also surviving, five granddaughters and one greatgrandson. John and Paul Church, Larchmont, N.Y., Friday, 10 A.M.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his criticism of Attorney General Saxbe's statement that a rising crime rate is related to the failure of courts to jail all criminals, Mr. McCaffrey, in a recent letter, ascribes the cause of most criminality to the ills within our ghettos, the burdens of our socially and economically deprived and our system's inability to deal with the underlying problems.

title: HUNDREDS ATTEND STUDENT'S RITES
description: Three floors of an East Harlem funeral home were filled last night with hundreds of mourning friends and relatives of a neighborhood youth, a premedical student at Fordham who had been shot and killed in a grocery store on his block for warning the grocer about a possible holdup.

description: Cash Prices

title: A Look at the Palestine Liberation Organization
description: Background  The Palestine Liberation Organization was founded in East Jerusalem in 1964 to act as the political representative of Palestinian Arabs. The organization started with a fighting force of its own, and after the June war of 1967, it became the umbrella for the diverse guerrilla groups operating against Israel. Their strength estimated at 10,000.

title: Yonkers Council Puts Off Vote on Curfew for Minors
description: YONKERS, Nov. 12  The Yonkers City Council postponed action tonight on a controversial ordinance that would establish a midnightto6 A.M. curfew for minors under the age of 17.

title: AHARON MESKIN

title: Rockefeller Scrutiny
description: When the Senate Rules Committee reopens its hearings today on the nomination of Nelson A. Rockefeller for Vice President, it takes up again a grave constitutional responsibility imposed by the 25th Amendment. Under that amendment, the members of the House and Senate act as surrogates for the whole people in confirming a man who may become President of the United States. This surrogate responsibility weighs all the more heavily when, as in this instance, the nominee is of one political party and the Congress is controlled by the other party.

title: Something Gaining On Us?
description: When I was in kindergarten on the West Coast, I developed a fear of airplanes. Each time one flew over, I restrained myself from hiding under the nearest table only because I was afraid that grownups would laugh at me. I was convinced that all airplanes were potential bombers, having gotten stories of World War II (then still in the recent past) mixed, up with what I understood of the purpose of our air raid drills in school.

title: Colleges Seek Budget Rise
description: BROCKTON, Mass., Nov. 12 (AP)  The 10college Massachusetts State College system is requesting a more than 26 per cent increase in its budget for the next fiscal year. The acting provost, Donald E. Walters, said today that the request for $71.5millioir would allow the system to enroll 1,223 more students for a total of 31,045.

title: SCHOOL PAY UNIT ACCUSED OF GRAFT
description: A payrollprocessing company that has received more than $2 million from the Board of Education over the last four years has been accused by the State Commission of Investigation of illegally giving, money, gifts and the services of call girls to employes of the board.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12The Department of Justice conceded today that the President does not have the power to block spending of water pollution fluids authorized by Congress, but it insisted that the President can delay expenditures fin broad economic policy reasons.

description: CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP)Coach Ara Parseghian of Notre Dame said todaythat Art Best, a star running back, had been suspended for a week for violation of rules and would miss Saturday's game against Pitt.

title: Palestinian Realities
description: By its own illconsidered invitation, the United Nations General Assembly is about to welcome as national spokesmen the leaders of a semiclandestine revolutionary apparatus who offer nothing but terrorism and armed struggle. The stated purpose of this faction is contrary to the goals established in the United Nations for world peace in general and in the Middle East in particular; their extremist policies only guarantee lifetimes of fear and deprivation for the very peoplethe long suffering Palestinian Arabswhom they claim to represent.

title: Fire in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 (AP) A fire broke out in a Century City highrise office building today, but the building was rapidly evacuated and firemen quickly put the fire out. One injury was reported in the fire, on the eighth, floor of the City National Bank building in the heart of the business and financial district, and four persons were treated for burns.

description: Capital expenditures of the Monsanto Company in 1975 are expected to reach $600million and should be equally as high in 1976 based on current estimates, John W. Hanley, president, said at the meeting yesterday of the St. Louis Society of Financial Analysts.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12Following are highlights of the Project Independence report published today:CONSERVATION: A determined effort, including mandatory Federal standards for cars, appliances and buildings; industrial planning; more public transportation, and redesign of electricity rates could cut energy growth to 2 per cent a year by 1985, less than half the recent growth rate. Demandmanagement measures, such as prohibiting naturalgas and oilheating in new buildings, could shift demand to electricity and diminish oil imports and vulnerability to another embargo.

description: Has the sheen rubbed off the Islanders? Are the Rangers really on the road back? These and other questions may find answers tonight when New York's two National Hockey League teams take on the sort of teams that can provide responses. The Rangers, who came back from the West Coast happy with their record of one, loss, one victory and one tie in games with Vancouver, California and Los Angeles, respectively, may learn just how far happiness extends. Tonight's opponent, the Philadelphia Flyers, has won eight games in a row, including a 51 decision the last time it met the Rangers.

title: Notes on People Fords Toast Kreisky With a Michigan Vintage (71)
description: Chancellor Bruno kreisky of Austria was welcomed to the White House by President Ford and Mrs. Ford yesterday, and last night they entertained the visitor at a formal state dinner that was bigger than affairs of that sort usually are. Mr. Kreisky was to have flown from Williamsburg, Va., by helicopter, but rain forced him to use a small military plane, and he was 20 minutes late. He and Mr. Ford conferred for more than an hour in the Oval Office.

It's well worth a trip to churchto the annex of St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and 50th Street where the show is playing Wednesdays through Saturdays.

With productions such as My Sweet Charlie, That Certain Summer and The Execution of Private Slovik, the two have operated well above the runofthemill ordinary. Tonight at 8:30 on ABC, they are represented with The Gun. Typically, the project is ambitious. Unfortunately, it doesn't quite succeed.

description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 12 (AP)Travis Grant scored 30 points, 18 in the second half, to lead the San Diego Q's to a 113104 victory over the Memphis Sounds in an American Hasketball Association game tonight.

title: BRITAIN TRIPLES TAX ON GASOLINE TO SAVE ENERGY
description: LONDON, Nov. 12The British Government announced today that it was tripling the tax on gasoline in an effort to discourage the wasteful use of energy at a time of deepening disquiet over the state of the economy.

title: Movement of Dollar Irregular; Pound Falls to 10Month Low
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 12(UPI)The dollar moved irregularly on world money markets today, while gold was unchanged in London at $182 an ounce. In Zurich, gold increased 50 cents an ounce to $180.25.

description: TOKYO, Nov. 12 (UPI)Six thousand workers and students staged a demonstration today to oppose President Ford's visit to Japan next week and to demand Premier Kakuei Tanaka's resignation.

title: The Crisis of Authority
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12This town is alive these days with free advice. It is a time of economic and political instability, with a new President and a new Congress, and while everybody is vaguely confused, suddenly the air is full of demands about what somebody else should do to set things right.

title: New BedPushing Record
description: LATROBE, Pa., Nov. 12 (UPI) Twelve St. Vincent College students claimed a new world bedpushing record today after surpassing 138, miles during an eightday marathon. The group completed 1,638 laps of a halfmile campus course and planned to end the marathon at 1 P.M. tomorrow. According to the Guinness Book of Records, the previous world bedpushing record of 138.3 miles was set last Sept. 8 by a team in Royston, Hertfordshire, England.

title: PAPANDREOU SETS SOCIALIST GOALS
Norton Simon Dividend Rise
description: Norton Simon, Inc., announced yesterday that it was raising its quarterly dividend to 10 cents a common share from 7 cents, payable Feb. 28 to shareholders of record Feb. 7. The action places the dividend at an annual cash rate of 40 cents a share against 30 cents. Following the annual shareholder meeting here yesterday, David J. Mahoney, chairman and president, estimated that earnings for the second fiscal quartet ending Dec. 31 would exceed the 50 cents a share of the yearearlier period.

title: Concert
description: What a marvelous thing publicity is. Herbert von Karajan rides into town at the head of his Berlin Philharmonic preceded by a thunderous thumping of drums, and good sense flees before him. At Carnegie Hall on Monday night, the conductor began the third concert of his current stay with a thoroughly ordinary, sometimes quite insensitive performance of the Beethoven Symphony No. 4. He was rewarded with such applause that one would have thought he were the composer himself. What are we to make of all this?

description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Nov 12 The City Council of this hardpressed community tonight proposed eliminating 50 of its 460 municipal jobs effective Dec. 1 as a response to the $1.7million budget deficit that has brought this city to the edge of insolvency.

The others, whose political status was said to require clarifical tion, were given temporary shelter in refugee camps.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Its proponents, always have contended that Little League baseball is asAmerican as apple pie and hot dogs. But now there is evidence that it's really as American as sour grapes. On the theory that if you can't beat em, bar em, Little League Baseball, Inc., of Williamsport, Pa has decreed that foreign teams no longer will be permitted to compete in what it euphemistically will continue to call its world series. By coincidence, of course, teams from, Taiwan had won the world series the last four years and five of the last six years. The two previous years, Japanese teams had won. The success of the Taiwan teams provoked an investigation by Little League officials last year on the assumption that the Taiwanese must be cheating. The investigation uncovered the unforgiving fact that the 12yearold Taiwan players really were 12 years old. It also uncovered the rude embarrassment that the Taiwan organizers had obeyed all the Little League rules. More than anything else, it uncovered the uncomfortable truth that the Taiwan players, living in a climate that permits them to play baseball all year round, had displayed two ideals, ambition and dedication, that the Little League program is supposed to foster. For those indiscretions, the 14 adults on the Little League board of directors voted the only appropriate punishmentexpulsion from the world series.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Unnoticed by many foreign observeers is the fact that the West Bank Palestinians are divided, in the fashion typical of backward agrarian societies, by a big economic gap between the few wealthy families and the many poor peasants. The Palestine Liberation Organization's rhetoric is well suited for exploitation of this revolutionary potential. However, its ability to deal with, much less solve, the West Bank's real economic problems is far beyond both its capacity and its interest: The only goal of the P.L.O. is political power.

Water damage to the car was extensive. But he put out the fire.

title: GOING OUT Gulde

The display, drawn from collections of rare Asian material owned by the museum, centers around more then 200 twodimensional figures exemplifying the shadow theater heritage of India, China and other Asian cultures, in addition to masks, scenery, musical instruments and other theater paraphernalia.

title: TV's Public Role

Radio listeners to noncommercial WBAI and cityowned WNYC could also tune in on these significant events. This is what broadcasting can do best serve as a mirror reflecting the public's concerns, not simply as a box delivering soft soap in living color.

title: Tentative Agreernent Reached On Contract for Coal Miners
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13Negotiators for the coal industry and the United Mine Workers of America announced agreement tonight on a threeyear labormanagement contract that could end the nationwide coal strike by Nov. 25, after only a twoweek work stoppage and before the miners walkout inflicts serious damage on the national economy.

title: Penguins Led by MacDonald and Apps
description: PITTSBURGH, NOV. 13An angry Al Arbour refused to go into the New York Islanders dressing room tonight after they were routed, 82, by the Pittsburgh Penguins. They are old enough to know what they did wrong, the New York Is lander coach said They were just Waltzing out there. They weren't, knocking any One down.

title: New Army Command Head
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) Lieut. Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, now Army personnel chief, will become commanding general of the Army Forces Command, the Pentagon says. He replaces Gen. Walter T. Kerwin Jr., the new Army vice chief of staff.

title: Schools Contracts Under State Inquiry
description: The State Commission of Investigation is looking into possible corruption in the awarding by the Board of Education and local school districts of $25million In contracts for program evaluations and other services.

title: Representative Has Surgery
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 13 (AP)United States Representative Edwin D. Eshleman, Republican of Pennsylvania, underwent cancer sugery today at Lancaster General Hospital. Surgeons, said that two tumors in the colon had been removed. Dr. Peter Pranckun said that Mr. Eshleman, reelected to a fifth term Nov. 5, was in excellent Condition. Mr. Eshleman underwent surgery 10 years ago.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Consumere complaints about warranties are on the rise at the regional office of the Federal Trade Commission at 26 Federal Plazaan increase that is attributed to growing cost consciousness on The part of buyers.

title: Business Briefs
description: The 119 savings banks in New York State had a net deposit outflow of $203million last month  the lowest such outflow since last May. This October's drain was also less than the $237million in the similar month of last year as well as the $365million in September, 1974.

title: C.I.A. MEN EXPELLED, PERUVIAN CHIEF SAYS
description: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 13 (Reuters)President Juan. Velasco Alvarado said tonight that his Government had quietly expelled several agents of the Central Intelligence Agency from Peru, including a senior United States Embassy official.

title: E.E.C. Deficit With OPEC Expected to Rise Sharply
description: BRUSSELS, Nov, 13, (Reuters)The Common. Market is eipected to have a 1974 trade deficit with the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries of $25billion to $30billion, the European Economic Community Comission said today

title: Crisis Mars a joyous Indian Holiday
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 13Diwali, the most joyotis Hin du holiday of the year, was celebrated tonight on tomelancholy note, Sellers of sweets grumbled that sales had declined. Fewer firecrackers and Candles were sold. Sari purehases fell.

title: U.S AGENCY BACKS CHANGE SEX IN LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Nov 13 (AP) The Ford Administration will support Congressional efforts to amend the law Prohibiting Sex dscrimination In schools and colleges, the director of the United States Office for Civil Rights said today.

title: U.S., Soviet Embassies in Tokyo Firebombed by Leftist Youths
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 14 (UPI)Two groups of Japanese youths hurled Molotov cocktails at the United States and Soviet Embassies, compounds today and were arrested on the spot, the police said.

title: To Play's Star, Holmes Is the 'Superactor
description: When John Wood agreed to play the title role in Sherlock Holmes for the Royal Shakespeare Company (the London production opened Tuesday night at the Broadhurst Theater on Broadway), he began doing archeology on the character.

title: Recount of 60,000 Ballots in Alaska Ordered
description: ANCHORAGE, Nov.13Gov William A. Egan issued it directive to his Lieutenant. Gorernor today ordeting the state election office to hand count 60,000. computerized ballots cast in last Tuesday's state wide election.

title: U.S.Soviet. Study Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (Reuters)  United States and Soviet transport officials today agreed to cooperate in a study f transport systems of the future. A report is expected to be drawn up by November, 1975.

title: Jewish Museum Focuses On Freud as Art Collector
description: Sigmund Freud is known to have responded to the high places of art with an intensity that can rarely have been equaled. In September, 1904, for instance, he paid his first visit to Athens. After putting on his best shirt for the occasion, he climbed up to the Acropolis. Such was the depth of his feeling that he literally could not believe he was there. At the age of 48, with much of his most important work already behind him, he was faced with what he called the phenomenon of derealization: a defensive refusal to believe that he was enough of a success to be able to allow himself so stupendous an experience.

title: PRINCESS OBOLENSKY
description: Princess Vera Obolensky, widow of Prince Yuri Obolensky, a relative of Tolstoy, died Nov. 6. She was 79 years old. A son, Georges, and two grand children survive.

title: Six in Family Found Slain In Bedrooms in L.I. Home
description: AMITYVILLE, L.I. Nov. 13Six members of an Amityville family were found slain here tonight. The police said the only surviving member of the family, a 23yearold man, reported that he returned to the home and discovered the bodies of his parents, two brothers and two sisters.

title: WRVR DENIES TALKS ON A POSSIBLE SALE
description: The executive committee of radio station WRVRFM has issued a statement denying reports that it was engaged in negotiations with any prospective purchaser, including WNET. The Riverside Church owns. WRVR, whose programing is predominently jazz.

title: Uruguayan Peso Devalued
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 13 (UPI)The Uruguayan peso was devalued 7.95 per cent today, according to an official announcement. The commercial dollar, used for exports and imports, was quoted today at 1,488 and 1,503 pesos respectively. The devaluation was the 11th this year and the 31st since President Juan Maria Bordaberry began a series of mini devaluations March 1, 1972.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two former Columbia University students who charged that they were beaten on the campus by plainclothes policemen in 1968, and who sued the university and New York City for $6million, settled their suit yesterday for $11,000. James E. Weddell received $3,850 and Ronald Carver was awarded $7,150: The settlement came after four days of testimony before Civil Court Judge Seymour Schwartz and before the case went to the jury. New York City paid all the damages.

title: FiremanCoach Takes Tottenvile Team to Semifinals
description: Tottenville has reached the Public School Athletic League foothall semifinals as an unknown quantity from Staten Island With a skinny team and a fulltime fireman as coach. The Pirates beat Brooklyn Tech in a quarterfinal last Week and travel to Lineola Field in Brooklyn Saturday ing to try to uphold the island's reputation against a powerful Jeffirson team.

title: Paine Webber, Inc., Defil Narrowed in Last Quarter
description: Paine Webber, Inc., holding company for the brokerage firm of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, Inda reported, here yesterday that it lost $885,000 in the fiscal quarter, ended Sept. 27 even, after an extaordinary gain of $143,000. This compared with a loss a Year earler of $1.5million.

title: SEOUL NEWSPAPER BACK AFTER STRIKE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 13 The masscirculation DongA Ilbo resumed publication today with a frontpage statement by its publisher saying that his right to publish whatever he wants to is being challenged by a group of his paper's reporters. The daily skipped its regular, edition yesterday, when the reporters refused to go to work unless a more prominent space was given to a report of Monday's large antiGovernment Roman Catholic mass celebrated in Seoul and elsewhere.

title: Favorites sweep at Aqueduct
description: Favorites swept all nine races at Aqueduct yesterday, and even the oldest racetrackers on the premises could, not remember when that had ever happened here. With the last race of Tuesday's Card added to the list, the favorite string reached 10.

title: Dumping Permit Issued,
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 13 (Reuter's)E. I. du Pont de Nemoures & Co. says it has, been issued a oneyear permit to continue dumping liquid acid waste in the Atlantic Ocean off the Delaware coast. The company originally asked for a special permit that could have been granted for up to three years and would have been renewable, perhaps without further public hearings, its statement said.

title: Female Role in TV Spots Studied
description: Female Role in TV Spots Studied

title: BAD RECORDS LAID TO NURSING HOME
description: The State Welfare Inspector General's office said Yesterday that it had found irregularities in the financial records of the Towers Nursing Home and had then met a refusal by the home to supply further data.

title: Tides Around New York
description: Tides Around New York

title: DOW UNCHANGED AS VOLUME RISES
description: The stick market finished lower, yesterday although it managed to reduce some of its earlier losses On expectations that the nationwide coal strike could end shortly.

title: The Longest Campaign
description: MANCHESTER, N. H.Every man who intends to campaign for President in 1976 comes to New Hampshire, where the first Presidential primary is to be run, and takes a long look at this plaque in the Carpenter Hotel in the state's largest city:

title: Dangerous Debate
description: The words exchanged across the rostrum of the United Nations General Assembly yesterday stand as perfect example of the futility of trying to elucidate complex and profound problems in such a forum. With the stated positions of both the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Government of Israel hardened in intolerant selfrighteousness, only less public dialogue in the delegates lounges in the coming days stands any chance of defining a useful mediatory role for the General Assembly.

title: bance: Symphony in 3 Movements
description: The New York City Ballet returned to the State Theater Tuesday night for its fallwinter season with the invigorating freshness of a cold shower.

title: LaRue Links Mitchell to Payments to Seven Watergate Burglary Defendants
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 The jury at the Watergate coverup trial heard lengthy testimony today that linked former Attorney General John N. Mitchell with secret payments of thousands of dollars to the seven Watergate burglary defendants.

title: Nixon Scheduled to Leave Hospital After Doctor Report Improvements in His Condition
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 13  Former Pxesident Richard M. Nixon is scheduled to be discharged tomorrow from Memorial Medical Center offcials of the hospital said to night.

title: Trooper Hit in Shootout on Turnpike
description: MOUNT LAUREL, Nov. 13 (UPI)A state trooper and a suspect were wounded today in a shootout on the New Jersey Turnpike after the trooper stopped four men speeding north, the police said.

title: 10Day Sales of Cars Down by 38%
description: Continued From Page 69 compared with 27.6, Chrysler's was 12.8 per cent compared with 11.9 and A.M.C.'s was 2.9 per cent compared with 3.9.

title: Saxbe Orders Sorting Out Of Draft Evasion Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (Reuters)  Aattorney General William B. Saxbe ordered Federal prosecutors today to sort out the 6,200 draft evasion cases In their files and drop the ones not worth prosecuting.

title: Two Killed in Jet Trainer
description: KINGSVILLE, Tex., Nov. 13 (AP)A Marine flight instructor and his student were killed yesterday when their TA4 jet trainer crashed 10 miles north of Freer in South Texas, the Navy said. The authorities identified the instructor as Capt. Andrew K. Lone, 28 years old, of Kingsville, formerly of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the student as First Lieut. Clinton E. Plummer Jr. of Ketterington, Ohio.

title: izwe Banzi Is a Message From Africa
description: Theatrical power is a curlous thing. It can start small, like a murmur in a chimneyond then build up to a hurricane. It can slide into you as stealthily as a knife. It can make you wonder, make you think. The South African play Sizwe Banzi Dead starts almost slower than slow. A black South African photographer from Port Elizabeth wandered onto the stage at Edison Theater last night and started chatting to the audience, talking nonchalantly about Ford, Kissinger, Nixon and the like.

title: In a U.N. Corner. Lobby, Arafat Held Audiences
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberatien Organization, was accorded the protocol honors of a chief of state today by the General Assembly. He played the role to the full, although he as yet lacks a state.

title: Sabres Win First Time At Montreal
description: MONTREAL, Nov, 13 (UPI)Rene Robert achieved the second threegoal game of his career tonight and added an assist as the Buffalo Sabres downed the Montreal Canadiens, 86, to stretch their National Hockey League undefeated streak to nine.

title: ABC Cancels Three More PrimeTime Programs
description: ABCTV announced yesterday the cancellation of three more primetime programs, The Sonny Comedy Revue, Nakia and Paper Moon, in its second revision of the primetime schedule that will be effective after the first of the year.

title: Sets Response by 75 On Chicago Road Loan Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The Administration expects to give its response by the first of the year to a request of the Chi cago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad for a $100million Federally guaranteed, loan for rehabilitation of its 7;500mile roadway, Edward G. Jordan president of the United States Railway Association, said to day.

title: U.S. Transit Aid, Expected by Dec. Cited by City as Close to Saving Fare
description: A flat prediction that Congress would pass masstransit aid before Christmas and a hedged prediction that this would come close to saving New York City's 35cent transit fare emerged from a City Hall strategy session yesterday.

title: Policeman Is Burned By Acid Planted in Van
description: A police officer in Greenwich Village suffered thirddegree burns of the face yesterday morning when he slid behind the driver's wheel of a police van and dislodged a pint of sulphuric acid from atop the sun visor, causing the acid to spill across the upper part of hib body.

title: BRANCH LIBRARIES WILL BE KEPT OPEN
description: The board of trustees of the New York Public Library agreed last night to keep open the three branches that it had threatened to close next Monday because of budget cuts.

title: Bridge:
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 13Norway is favored to win an upset victory in the European championships here. The Scandinavian stars trail France, the defending champions, by one victory point going into the final two matches, but have an easier schedule. They meet sixthranked Portugal and 17thranked Finland, while their rivals meet thirdranked Italy and seventhranked Belgium.

title: Six in Family Found Slain In Bedrooms in L. I. Home
description: AMITYVILLE, L. I., Nov. 13 A Welltodo car dealer, his wife and four of his five children were found murdered in their beds tonight here on Long Island's South Shore.

title: Jersey Aide Says He Met Indicted Garbage Figure
description: NEWARK, Nov. 13Anthony J. Grossi, president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, admitted under questioning here today that he met with a man now under state indictment the night before that man allegedly perjured himself before a state grand jury investigating political corruption.

title: Hint From S.E.C.
description: A senior staff official of the Securities and Exchange Commission has hinted strongly that the S.E.C. would act next year to give added protection to shareholders of public companies acquired by stock tender offers whether by domestic or foreign interests. Details on Page 76.

title: LOANS DISCUSSED
description: Rockefeller Calls Book on Goldber a Mistake; Denies Any Dirty Tricks insulate Mr. Morhouse against temptation, adding, Our help evidently was not enough.

title: Jersey Aide Linked To Garbage Figure
description: Newark, Nov, 13Anthony J. Grossi, president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, admitted under questioning here today that he met with a man now under state indictment the night before that man allegedly perjured himself before a state grand jury investigating political corruption.

title: Veterans in Benefits Drive
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 13 (UPI)A group of veterans at the University of California has organized a Campaign to persuade President Ford not to veto a veterans benefit bill. The veterans said today they would have at least 50 supporters to donate blood to a local blood bank as a demonstration of their need for in creased educational benefits contained in the bill threatened by a Presidential veto.

title: France, With SmilingGiscard at Helm Showing the Symptomsof Mal de Mef
description: PARIS, Nov. 13The Mood of France, particularly Peris, could be compared these days to the mat liner named after this country, whose passengers ate, and drank her out of existence.

title: It's Christmastime in Palisades Park as Town Also Marks 75th Year
description: PALISADES PARK, Nov. 13 Christmas has come early to this Bergen County residential town of 13,000 residents.

title: Seientists Produce Sorghum Variety With High Protein
description: Scientists at Purdue University have produced a highprotein variety of sorghum, the world's fourth largest cereql grain crop, that they say has great promise of improving the diet in some poor countries.

title: Difficulty Is Seen For Private Banking Handling Oil Money
description: Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Said yesterday the private banking system may need assistance in trying to cope with the heavy flow of oil money.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An Elmwood Park man was held in Bergen County Jail pending a hearing on charges of murder after a 15yearold boy he is accused of having assaulted on Halloween night died in a hospital. The police said the suspect, Leo Smith, 44, was being held in connection with the death of Paul Litter, who died at Barnert Memorial Hospital in nearby Paterson, where he had been in coma following the assault on Oct. 31. An autopsy will be performed on the body of the boy to determine the exact cause of death, the police said.

title: HOUSE REFORMERS SEEK MORE POWER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13Reformminded Democratic Representatives are seeking to increase their power at the expense of their leaders in a bid to make the House more responsible to the will of newer and more liberal members.

title: BRITAIN'S DEFICIT ON TRADE WIDENS
description: LONDON, Nov. 13The British trade deficit Climbed above the $1billion mark again in October and approached a record level, the Government reported today, as the financial markets reacted nervously to the new economic measures announced in yesterday'S budget.

title: Morhouse, a Decade After Scandal, Is a Sick, Troubled Recluse
description: TICONDEROGA, N. Y.A man in Bob's T.V. Bar on Montcalm Street recalled seeing him at the barber shop. A neighbor said he showed up to congratulate the groomtobe at a stag party in July. Now and then he is seen on a short walk, his body shaking with illness. But mainly, said a neighbor, he's in that house all the time. He can't do anything else.

title: SUGAR FUTURES DECLINE BY LIMIT
description: After 11 sessions of rising prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, most sugar futures contracts dropped the daily 2centapourid limit yesterday. The March delivery closed at about 55 cents a pound. However, sugar prices rose in London and on the world spot market.

title: DRAMATIC SESSION
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 13  head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yesir Arafat, told the United Nationas General Assem bly today that his Organization's goal remained a Paleatinian state that would include Moslems, Christians and Jews.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: MASKS IN BLACK, the Al Tann Ensemble, Presented by the Black Theater Alliance, 137th Street and Seventh Avenue, 7:30.

title: RETAIL FOOD ITEMS FOR FAMILY AT $1,734
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) During the first nine months of this year the retail cost of an year's supply of farmproduced food went up $197 from its 1973 average, with higher middleman charges accounting for 84 per cent of the increase, new figures by the Agriculture Department showed today.

title: Dr. Thomas F. O'Dea, 58, Taught Religion, Sociology
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Nov. 13 (UPI)Dr. Thomas F. O'Dea, a former professor at Columbia and Fordham universities in New York, died last night at his home here of complications connected with Hopkins disease. He was 58 years old.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company has awarded a contract to the Exxon Nuclear Company, of Bellevue, Wash., for fabricated enriched uranium for the latter's Susquehanna Power plant beginning in 1981 and ending at the close of 1984. No estimate of the value of the contract was given.

title: LOANS DISOUSSEI
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 Vice presidentdesignate Nelsein A. Rockefeller gave a Senata committee today detafls of his involvement in 1970 With a critical biography of his political opponent, Arthur, J. Goldberg, which he said was the most embarrassing episode of his political career. But he angrily denied that it Was comparable; to the dirty tricks associated with the Watergate scandals.

title: Stocks on Amex and on Counter Show Another Decline in Prices
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market fell again yesterday as bullish news continued to be scarce.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Weather Reports and Forecast

title: Fraternity Suspends Chapter in Jersey Over Halzing Death Over Hazing Deat
description: LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 13 The Delta Rho Chaptet of the Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity at Monmouth College here was suspended today by the national fraternity in the wake of a hazing incident that resulted in the Heath of a fraternity pledge and the arrest of seven fraternity members on manslaughter changes.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: 36 Southern Student Visit Boston to Talk Integration.
description: BOSTON, Nov. 13 (A13)Thirtysix high school students from four Southern states arrived in Boston today to share their ideas about gration with students here.

title: Possible Cancer Causers In Water Found in Blood
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) Scientists In New Orleans who found substances suspected of causing cancer in the drinking water now say some of those same compounds are showing up in the blood of people who drink the water

title: South Africa, Out of This Assembly, Calls Aide Home
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13South Africa called her chief United Nations delegate home today in the wake of the General Assembly's vote to suspend her from participation in its current session.

title: Sam Goldaper
description: The boyish grin is still there, and some boy still to mains in Jim Chones, the man Missing are the pressures on a young man forced to grow up too swiftly because he had been sized up as a valuable commodity. The Chones who left Marquette in 1972 during his junior year to sign a fiveyear, $1.5million contract with the New York Nets of the American Basketball Association has disappeared. The new Chones is still 6 feet, 11 inches tall, but a rookie in the National Basketball Association and a personal whipping boy of Bill Fitch, coach of the Sporta Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: 3 DOCTORS NAMED TO EXAMINE NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13Judge John J. Sirica appointed day a panel of three doctors to go to California this month to determine whether former presideht Rithard M. Nixon is Phsically able to give testimony in the Watergate coverup trial.

title: News Summary and Index
description: News Summary and Index

title: New Jersey Sports
description: The inexorable demise of unbeaten football teams will continue at an accelerated pace this week, mainly because four of the remaining undefeated in New Jersey schoolboy competition will be meeting one another.

title: ACTION TO AVERT FAMINE IN DOUBT
description: ACTION TO AVERT FAMINE IN DOUBT

title: U.S. Aide in Jordan for Talks
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 13 (AP)The United States Under Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, Robert Ellsworth, arrived in Amman yesterday at the head of a military delegation for talks with Jordanian officials, a Government announcement said. The announcement said they would discuss military cooperation.

title: Tentative Agreement Reached On Contract for Coal Miners
description: WASHINGTON, Negotiators for the coal industry and the United Mine Workrs Of America announced agreement tonight on a threeyear labormanagement contract that could end the nationwide coal strike by Nov. 25, after only a twoweek work stoppage and before the miners walkout inflicts serious damage tirement and welfare fund over on the, national economy.

title: Landing Gear Fixed in Air
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 13 (UPI)The entertainer Wayne Newton was aboard a twinengine airplane that circled McCarran International Airport for some time yesterday while its landing gear was repaired. He and four other persons were on a flight from Lake Tahoe when it was discovered that the landing gear would not lock into place.

title: Nixon to Go Home
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon Is scheduled to be discharged from the hospital today, a hospital spokesman in Long Beach, Calif., said. Earlier, Judge John J. Sirica appointed a panel of three doctors to go to California this month to determine whether Mr. Nixon is physically able to give testimony in he Watergate coverup trial. Page 29.

title: L.T.T. INCOME FELL 12.9% IN 3D PERIOD
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, one of the world's largest conglomerates, reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter of 1974 declined 12.9 per cent to $111.6million from yearearlier levels.

title: Four in Fix Trial Win on 5 Counts
description: ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 13 (UPI) A United States district court jury today returned notguilty verdicts on five charges today and said it was unable to reach a decision on seven other charges facing four persons accused of racefixing at the Finger Lakes track.

title: State Checks City School Contracts in Graft Inquiry
description: The State Commission of Investigation is looking into possible corruption in the awarding by the Board of Education and local school districts, of $25  million in contracts for program evaluations and other services.

title: 2 Killed as Israel, in Reprisal, Shells Town in South Lebanon
description: SAID, Lebanon Thursday, No. 14 (Reuters)  At least two people were killed and five injured this morning when Israeli artillery shelled Nahadye, southeast of here in southern Lebanon.

title: Chess:
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 13Anatoly Karpov was granted a postponement today of the 22d game of his final Candidates match for the world championship with Viktor Korchnoi. The game, scheduled for 5 o'clock this afternoon in Tchaikowsky Hall, has been reset for the same time Friday.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Frace Retires a General Oritical of the Nation's Jets
description: PARIS, Nov. 13 (AP)Gen. Paul Stehlin, the former French Air Force chief of staff who raised a political storm with a report that United States warplanes were superior to French jets, was retired from active reserve today.

title: Knicks Happy to Leave Oregon
description: PORTLAND, Ore, Nov. 13  Having experienced at least three familiar and uncomfortable sensations, the New York Knicks finally took off for home today, where they will play their next three games and 10 of their next 15.

title: Tally by Clarke in Last Minute Is Decisive
description: Bobby Clarke, the superpesky captain of the Philadelphia Flyers, blocked a Ranger shot last night and turned it into a breakaway goal with 15 seconds left to beat New York, 32. The victory by the firstplace Flyers was only their second at Madison Square Garden in the last six years.

title: Vittorio De Sica, 7 3, Dies; Neorealist Movie Director
description: PARIS, Nov. 13Vittorio De Sica, the director of such film classics as Shoeshine and The Bicycle Thief, died here today at the age of 73.

title: News Strike in Italy
description: ROME, Nov. 13 (Reuters)A virtual news blackout descended on much of Italy today as news agencies, radio, television and newspapers were hit by a 24hour strike of journalists and technical workers.

title: COAST COUPLE PLEAD GUILTY IN BOND PLOT
description: PORTLAND, Ore. Nov. 13 (UPI)A truck driver admitted in court today that he was the J. Hawker, who tried to extort $1million from a government agency by threatening to black out the city of Portland.

title: Rousseau Is Out
description: Bobby Rousseau, the New York Rangers powerPlay specialist, will undeigo spinal fusion surgery within the next 10 days and will be out for the rest of the season, the club announced yesterday.

title: Excerpts From Rockefeller Statement and From Transcript of Senate Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13Following are excerpts from Nelson A. Rockefeller's statement today to a Senate committee and excerpts from a transcript of questions and answers at the committee hearing as recorded by The New York Times:

title: RITA D. HOWES
description: Rita D. Howes, a copy editor at Consumer Reports magazine since 1967, was found dead Tuesday at her apartment at Washington Square Village. She was 48 years old. The New York;, City medical examiner's office listed the cause of death an apparent overdose of parbiturates.

title: S.E.C. Aide Hints More Merger Protection is Due
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13A senior staff official of the Securities and Exchange Commission hinted strongly today that the agency would act next year to give added protection to shareholders of public companies acquired by stock tender offers whether by domestic or foreign interests. Alan B. Levenson, director of the agency's Division of Corporate Finance, said pronouncements by the commission to protect the interests of shareholders should not come as a surprise to those familiar with the agency's corporatedisclosure policy.

title: Yunich Says Con Ed Rise Could Doom the 35c Fare
description: The utility says the typical customer uses. 250 kilowatta Month, twethirds of customers using 250 kilowatts a month or less. Such a customer's present bill including the 12 per cent interim increase, is $21.20 a month. The latest increase will bring the bill to $22.72. This rate is based on customers who use electricity for lighting but not for heating.

title: Basic Issue Confronted
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13Nelson A. Rockefeller confronted directly today the undrlying issue that has stalled and perhaps imperiled his confirmation as the next Vice President of the United States. The central question, he told the Senate Rules Committee at the resumption of confirmation hearings, is whether it is dangerous, too dangerous, to have a person of great personal wealth potentially in the line of succession to the power of the Presidency.

title: Turkey Reported to Cut 5,000 From Cyprus Force of 40,000
description: ATHENS, Nov. 13 Turkey has withdrawn about 5,000 of her 40,000 troops on Cyprus, Western diplomats said today. The diplomats said they were uncertain whether the withdrawals were specifically designed to forestall the cutoff of American aid to Turkey. Congress has voted to terminate that aid on Dec. 10 unless there is progress toward a settlement on Cyprus, where Turkish troops control 40 per cent of the territory after their invasion last summer.

title: FORD MAKES PLEA FOR OFFSHORE OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13President Ford strongly urged the Governors of the nation's coastal states today to back offshore drilling as the solution to one of the most serious problems we facethe lack of domestic petroleum supplies.

title: Off Limits
description: President Ford acted with commendable promptness in administering a public rebuke to Gen. George S. Brown, chairman of the Joint, Chiefs of Staff, for his offensive and ignorant remarks about what he termed excessive Jewish influence on national policies. Underscoring his displeasure over misleading and inflammatory statements made by the country's highestranking military officer, Mr. Ford has assured the American people that these views in no way represent the opinions of any other senior military or civilian official in his Administration.

title: Bucks Lose 10thin Row, To Pistons
description: DETROIT, Nov. 13 (AP)With. Kareem AbdulJabbar sidelined, Bob Lanier was virtually unstoppable tonight as he scored 40 points, hauled down 24 rebounds and blocked six shots to pace the Detroit Pistons to a 9891 National Basketball Association, victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Fords Sign a Pledge To Aid Inflation Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)President and Mrs Ford jointly signed a consumer pledge today that the President said he hoped would be part of a concerted mass effort to stop inflation.

title: AMEX CITES SALE OF $60,000 SEAT
description: The American Stock Exchange which reported a Seat sale a Month ago is low as $38,500, said yesterday that it had sold a seat at $60,000only $35,000 less than the last seat sale on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: People in Sports Brock Bitter About Exclusion From Award

The St. Louis Swifty lost to G'arvey of the Los Angeles Dodgers in the voting for the award on Tuesday. Brock, who remained eventempered throughout his pressurepacked race to break Maury Wills's 12yearold record of 104 stolen bases, was bitter about his exclusion from the top award and acciised the baseball writers of bad judgment. Wills won the award in 1962. Red Schoehdienst, the Cardinal manager, said, It's really hard to underitand how they ??? Not that the other guy [Garvey] didn't have a good year, but I don't know what else anyone could ask Brock to do.

title: Screen: 'Trial of Billy Jack,' a Sequel:More or Less a Rerun of the 1971 Success
description: "The Trial of Billy Jack" is nearly three hours of naivet" merchandised and marketed with the not-so-innocent vengeance that I associate with religious movements that take leases on places like the Houston Astrodome.The film, which opened at theaters around town yesterday, is the sequel to the hugely successful "Billy Jack" and is more or less a rerun of the kind of things that happened in that 1971 film. It's part pageant, part kung fu action film, part Western, part earnest civics lesson, part Show Boat melodrama, part recollection of the various horrors of the late nineteen-sixties and early nineteen-seventies updated (sometimes desperately) to make contact with today.Like "The Little Prince," it places a heavy philosophical load on the old ticker. "That's the trouble," says a character at one point, "you always try to understand with your head. You don't listen to your heart." Brains are getting it in the neck in the new movies."The Trial of Billy Jack," like the original film, is about the good-doing Indian half-breed, Billy Jack (Tom Laughlin), who has a lot of Bruce Lee, Robin Hood, Cochise and Jesus in him. (It's no accident that the film contains a song that asks "Are You Dying Just for Me, Billy Jack?" and seems to expect an affirmative reply.)It's also about Jean Roberts (Delores Taylor), who is beloved (usually from afar) by Billy Jack and runs the Freedom School, somewhere near Arizona's Monument Valley, where flower children left over from the sixties edit "Nader-like periodicals and newspapers" that expose Big Government and Big Business.The narrative, which has a gargantuan clumsiness to it that some critics have professed to find endearing, though it strikes me as aggressively dumb, picks up the story of Billy Jack where the first film left off. Billy Jack gets out of prison and returns to the Freedom School, which has had such success with its exposs that not only the local bigots but also the rascals in Washington try to crush the school. In between rap sessions on child abuse and the rights of American Indians, the melodrama accumulates (it certainly doesn't mount), climaxing in a Kent State-like attack on the school by members of the National Guard.It would be easier to accept the film's good intentions if the movie weren't so schizoid that one can't be at all sure what its intentions really are.Though it means to preach nonviolence, the only scenes of any interest are the violent ones, and always violence shows up as the only meaningful way to deal with evil.We are told that the Freedom School kids have successfully exposed the oil industry's influence on Washington, yet the kids we see and hear would have difficulty exposing anything more complicated than a Baby Ruth bar. Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. and Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. didn't get to the bottom of Watergate by sitting around and listening to their hearts, for heaven's sake.The movie is very, very long. It lurches towards obligatory scenes that turn up in no special order, and it is spotted here and there with topical references that are so arbitrary they prompt laughter ("With Ford and Rockefeller, nothing will change much"). It's also shot through with Indian (American) mysticism and self-improvement suggestions that evoke shades of Moral Re-Armament, which was never a hotbed for radical political thinkers.Even the scenery becomes offensive after a while; it's such a waste of magnificent backgrounds we have long associated with the great John Ford films.In addition to Mr. Laughlin and Miss Taylor (Mrs. Laughlin in private life), the cast includes Teresa Laughlin, their 16-year-old daughter; in a prominent supporting role, while 19-year-old Frank Laughlin, their son, is given directorial credit. None of them is terrific. The screenplay was written by Frank and Teresa Christina, who, I understand, are actually Pa and Ma Laughlin. If this film has even half of the success of the first film, "Billy Jack" could well become Hollywood's first one-family, multimillion-dollar cottage industry.

And here's Bob Greene, a 27yearold columnist for The Chicago SunTimes, who's been given this chance to perform on a Christmas tour with the Alice Cooper troupe and indulge his fantasy of becoming a rock n roll star. title: Seminarian Is Hero of 'Let the Church Say Amen!':The Program
description: "I know I want to be a minister and I know I've got to be black": the discoveries and the dilemmas of a young seminarian are evoked in St. Clair Bourne's "Let the Church Say Amen!", a thoughtful and skillfully made documentary which opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art and will run through Tuesday.We first encounter the young man on the campus of the Interdenominational Theological Center in Atlanta, where it's stated that "religion has been one of the basic elements of black life. . .from the church, many progressive movements have sprung." One student remarks, "I don't think we deal with challenging the white man's conception of God." Before participating in a field interneship program, the future minister says that the choice of a denomination doesn't matter greatly to him, but that he's particularly interested in the ghetto church. However, an adviser suggests that he become acquainted with a rural church.The film follows him to a Baptist church in Mound Bayou, Miss., where he confers with an old country preacher about the intensity of religious feeling in that community. Next, he spends time at a Methodist church in Chicago, where the urban congregation airs some generational conflicts. He also visits a group of teen-agers whom a youth organizer encourages to talk about their attitudes toward death, suicide"Is is a cop-out?"and the assassinations of black leaders. A member of the church later objects that the organizer "teaches them too much black."Finally, the seminarian returns to Atlanta; the film then intercuts between a Christian minister's sermon and a discussion with some Black Muslims who are standing outside the chapel. The minister stresses the tangible realities of black lifeincluding the children who suffer from malnutrition "while the politicians thrive"and he warns against an overly mystical approach to religion. Especially because the camera never seems to be intrusive, the film yields a strong sense of the varieties of religious experience that one young man has been exposed to, and the breadth of choice that confronts him. Since the different roles of the contemporary church are so sensitively explored, the documentary should be equally enlightening for those who do or don't belong to the church itself.

title: GunControl Group Formed

The group opened an office in Washington to increase public awareness of the dangers of handguns; seek Federal laws to narrowly limit their use and ownership; press for more stringent enforcement of laws; and coordinate local, state and regional handgun control efforts.

This month, car sales are off 38 per cent, the worst decline since 1959, when there was a steel strike.

title: The Screen: 'Hindered'
description: Having chosen a decidedly unusual, if slightly improbable but altogether touching subject, Steve Dwoskin demonstrates delicate artistry in "Hindered," which had its American premiere last night at the Film Forum. The 35-year-old, New York-born moviemaker-artist, reportedly completed his feature in recent months for showing on German television. He has made a liaison between an Angst-ridden girl and her disabled, crutch and braces-encumbered young man into a microscopically fine and sensitive dissection of the tenderness and pain of an extraordinary involvement.Mr. Dwoskin, who was represented here last year by another absorbing feature, "Dyn Amo," exhibits an almost exhausting predilection for close-ups of eyes, noses, hands, feet and faces to dramatize, ever so slowly, the feeling of his star-crossed principals. But if a viewer is nagged by a need for explanations, the cumulative effect of their personal drama is both bittersweet and moving.The film, whose sparse German dialogue is translated by literal English subtitles, projects a special kind of poignancy since, as a program note mentions, it is basically autobiographical and Mr. Dwoskin, who also plays the young man, seems also to be handicapped. But to his credit, his color camera focuses mostly on the object of his affection, Carola Regnier, a newcomer to this observer, who uses her expressive, if not beautiful face and body to affect a powerful, controlled tour de force.Her detailed fascination with his disability, her precise, sensitive reactions to growing anxieties, her mounting indecision and her final wrenching decision to leave him are interlaced, glowing cameos of authentic emotion and meaning.Mr. Dwoskin's comparatively rare appearances are self-effacing but equally realistic. At one point, Mr. Dwoskin, a long-haired, laconic, seemingly unemotional type, comforts his perturbed girl. "Don't worry. You think too much about it." Mr. Dwoskin's forthright and unsentimental drama not only gives us something to think about but also stirs the heart.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.18billion, up 3 per cent from the yearearlier $1.15billion. Total retail store sales were about $10.30billion, up 5 per cent from last year's $9.85billion.

title: TV Review
description: The Nova series has returned to public televielon, on Sundays at 7:30 P.M., and is quite nicely living up to its own billing as science adventures for curio grownups. The 23 hourlong productions, made either by station WGBH/Boston or imported from the British Broadcasting Corporation, can be almost deceptively diverting or unashamedly demending. It's the kind of mix that salvages the reputation of educational television.

title: SelfDestruct at the U.N.
description: The suspension of South Africa from the current United Nations General, Assembly is illegal and dangerous. It is a disastrous precedent for an organization that cannot be effective unless its membership is universal. It is a grim irony that virtually the same Assembly majority that suspended a founding member of the U.N. one day could on the next enthusiastically welcome the leader of a terrorist organization whose goal is destruction of another member state.

title: Notes on People
description: The United Nations Educational, Ecientific and Cultural Organization will swear In Amadou Mahtar M'Bow as first black director general, today. Mr. M'Bow, a Senegalese, was elected to the post yesterday by the UNESCO general conference, by a vote of 123 to 1. He succeeds Ren Maheu, head of the organization for, the. last 12 years, who was not a Candidate for a third sixyear term. Mr. M'Bow, who was born 53 years ago in Dakar when Senegal was a French colony, was feared on the edge of the Sahara. Even though he is a member of his country's Frenchtrained. lite he was educated at the University of Parishe considers himself an African traditionalist and a man of the earth. He has taught on several levels in Senegal and is the author of studies on African geography. A former Senegalese Cabinet member, Mr. M'Bow has been associated with UNESCO since 1966, first as head of his country's delegation and later as a rnember of the executive board. In 1970 Mr. Maheu named him assistant director general for education.

description: Gold prices in London yesterday were fixed at a record high of $188.25, up $3 from the previous high set on Wednesday. Dealers said there was trading earlier, in the day at $189 to $191 an ounce.
