description: OLA A B, The Cornbread Players, at the Harlem Cultural Council, 137 Street and Seventh Avenue, 7:30.

title: Jobless Benefit Claimant's Grow to Over Two Million
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) Large surges in unemployment benefit claimants in five states swelled these benefit lists across the nation, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Unions Considering Loans To Builders to Spur Jobs
description: NEWARK, Nov. 14Leaders of New Jersey's construction trade unions, alarmed by what they have described as our highest unemployment rate since the Depression, said today that they were considering using their multimilliondollar pension funds for lowinterest loans to contractors to stimulate building in the state.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: S.E.C. Suspends Trading In Stocks of 4 Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it was suspending trading in the stocks of four companies as a result of the companies failure to file required reports with they commission.

title: Scientists Group Terms Boston Study of Children With Extra Sex Chromosome Unethical and Harmful
description: A Boston scientists group has charged that an ongoing study there of the fate of children born with extra sex chromosomes is unethical, unscientific and potentially harmful to the youngsters involved. The charges have spurred a review by a special Harvard cornmittee on ethics, which is expected to issue its findings next week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In all of the reporting, editorializing and jawboning about the inflation problem, both in and out of government, there seems to be a strange lack of recognition or a purposeful silence on the most insidious longterm byproduct of prolonged inflation: A drastic effective increase in individual income tax rates without change in the tax laws.

title: $100,000 Prize, Anyone?
description: A $100,000 winner in the Oct. 26 New Jersey Sweepstakes Lottery has yet to claim his prize. Lottery officials said the ticket had been bought at the International Tobacco Shop in Elizabeth. The winning number: 343937.

title: Abortion Order Upheld
description: BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP)A special threejudge Federal court refused today to dissolve a temporary restraining order banning enforcement of the state's new abortion law. One of the three, Federal District Court Judge Frank Freedman, issued the injunction two weeks ago. The new law, among other thing, requires parental consent for abortions performed on young women under 18.

title: JOHN F. WALTON JR., A GULF OIL OFFICIAL
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 John Fawcett Walton Jr., who retired in 1963 as a vice president and director of the Gulf Oil Corporation, diedtoday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: FordBrezhnev Talks Set for Resort Area
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 14 (UPI) "The Siberiaw meeting between President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev on Nov. 2324 will take place in the newly built guesthouse of a sanatorium north of Vladivostok.

title: Motorists Shop For Gasoline Now
description: A plentiful supply of gasoline in and around New York City at the higher prices of the energy crisis era has led to a return of pricecutting competition among many retellers and is encouraging bargainhunting among inflationconscious motorists.

title: Libya Fills Foreign Post And Resbuffles Her Cabinet
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Nov. 14 (Reuters)  Libya's ruling Revolutionary Command Council today announced a major Cabinet reshuffle designed to expand foreign contacts and develop domestic public services.

title: Arafat's Message
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14With Yasir Arafat gone, the excitement at United Nations headquarters has abated. In the lobbies here and in diplomatic offices on Manhattan's East Side, meanwhile, News the professionals Analysis are trying to penetrate behind the histrionics of the current General Assembly debate on Palestine and analyze the substance.

title: Library Budget Tactics Backfire
description: In the fiscal gloom that hangs over City Hall these days, the New York Public Library was the first institution to engage in the delicate business of budget brinkmanihip with the moneyminded Mayor Beame.

title: MRS. RICHARD ROGERS
description: Marilyn Vonderschmitt Rogers, wife of Richard C. Rogers, general services manager of The New York Times, died yesterday at United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y., after a brief illness. She was 51 years old and lived at 313 South Barry Avenue, Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Overweight Beauty Queen
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 14 (UPI)Twentytwoyearold Kathleen Beth Moore resigned her Miss Washington title in protest yesterday after pageant officials decided that she was overweight.

title: SAFETY BOARD ASKS MILITARY JET CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)  The National Transportation Safety Board recommended today that military jets he barred from practicing interception missions in air lanes used by civilian aircraft.

title: Concert: A Messiaen. Piano Debut
description: Has any artist since. John J Audubon been so obsessed with birds as Olivier Mes siaen? Mr. Messiaen, the French composer who has ben cataloguing bird calls for many years with a devotion that long ago edged into pure mysticism, continues to find both raw material and inspiraticin in his collections. He was present to take bows Wednesday night at Kaufmann Hall of the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., where his wife, Yvonne Loriod, gave the first New York performance of his La Fauvette des Jardins, a 1970 piano work of characteristically ambitious proportions and formidable technical challenges.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.3 billion tonmiles, 1.5 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 534,210 cars, 4.1 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 7.7 per cent below last year.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: ZAIRE STRUGGLES TO BUILD NATION
description: KISANGANI, Zaire, Nov. 7 Like many Africans here, Monya Tshuapa dates most happenings from the events, but she does not talk much about the events themselvds.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time
description: Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships

title: The Pop Life It's Not Only a Composer Who Gives a Song Life
description: Creators are more prized than recreators, and justly so. In pop music, at least since the days of Dylan, it has been the singersongwriter, instead of the mere singer, who has earned the greatest blend of adulation and critical respect.

title: 3 PHYSICIANS SEEK ADVICE ON NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14The panel of three physicians appointed by Judge John J. Sirica is waiting to hear. Ftoni the court whether former President Richard M. Nixon will agree to the examination the judge has ordered to determine if Mr. Nixon is physically able to give testimony in the Watergate coverup trial.

title: 500,00 More Voted for Riverdale Park
description: An additional $500,0.00 to cemplete Riverdale Park in the Bronx was approved yesterday by the City Connell despite a question about the propriety of the project.

title: Writers Honor Busby
description: KANSAS CITY, Nov. 14 (UPI)Steve Busby the only pitcher to throw nohitters. in his first two major league seasons, was picked unanimously today by local writers as the Kansas City Royals pitcher of the year.

title: A. S. PANYUSIIKIN, EXENVOY, IS DEAD
description: Aleksandr Semyonovich Panyushkin a former Soviet Ambassado to the United States and a Kremlin specialist in intelligence work, died yesterday In Moscow after a long illness, according to Pravda, the official newspaper of the Soviet Communist party. He was 69 yeara old.

title: Nixon Campaign Aides Describe Payoffs to Burglars
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14The jury at the Watergate coverup trial was told today that Nixon campaign officials gave hundreds of thousands of dollars to the Watergate burglars to meet eommitmente to the burglars without ever knowing who had made the com. mitments.

title: HARLEM SCHOOL UNIT OUSTS INTERIM HEAD
description: The Community School Board of District 5, which covers Central Harlem, jest unanimously passed a resolution dismissing Louis A. DeFreitas as interim district superintend ent.

title: Sport Today
description: Nets vs. Utah Stars, at Salt Lake City. (TelevisionChannel 9, 9:30 P.M.)

title: EQUITY FINANCING,
description: An underwriting group headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., offered yesterday 600,000 shares of Puget Sound Power and Light Company common stock at $21.50 per share. The utility plans to use net proceeds from the sale toward repayment of outstanding bank loans incurred for construction purposes.

title: Books of The Times
description: After reading William Manchester's The Glory and the Dream, I feel as if I am just coming out of a posthypnotic trance. It is a rather traumatic experience, the impact of this book, one that leaves you wrung by ambivalence, asking, alternately, were we really that bad? and could we have been that good? Because I had to read this book in four days, these 40 years of American history took on the concentrated, surreal quality of a dream or psychotic fantasy. The sensation is something like dying and viewing life from another plane.

title: State to Terminate Some Ph.D. Studies
description: The State Education Department is ordering the termination of some doctoral programs at four universities on the ground that the programs are of inadequate quality.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: CHARLESTOWN, N. H. When Vic came out of the swamp with his rifle in one hand and a cluster of red berries in the other, I was reminded of how much our approach to deer hunting has changed.

title: BAUXITE MEASURE OF MONEY ASKED
description: Guyana would like to see members of the International Bauxite Association develop a bauxite unit of currency in order to avoid the effects of possible devaluations and fluctuations of foreign currencies, Haslyn Parris, deputy chairman of the Guyana Bauxite Company, said in an interview here yesterday.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: LOTTERY NUMBERS Nov. 14, 1974.

title: Dubuffet Raises Eyebrows Here
description: To Arlene Fenwick of Long Island it looked like a giant astronaut, but to her young daughter, Anise, it looked like giant version of the Tin Man in The Wizard of Oz.

title: Macmillan General Editor Quits 4 Months After Joining Publisher
description: Aaron Asher, editor in chief of the general books division of the Macmillan Publishing Company, Inc., resigned yesterday, little more than four months after he had joined the company.

title: RESEARCHERS URGED TO NAME PRIORITIES
description: Representative. Daniel J. Flood, chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Haalth, Education and Welfare, told medical researchers yesterday to set their own priorities for Federal funding and explain their finding to the public.

title: Hayes Gains 3Shot Lead In S. Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov, 14 (AP)Dale Hayes of South Africa bettered the course record, today with a fiveunderpar 65 and took the secondrolind lead at 133 in the $50,000 South Africa Professidnal Golfers Association championship.

title: Alaska Ruled Disaster Area
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 14 (UPI)President Ford today declared a state of major disaster in Alaska and parts of the Virgin Islands as a result of storms and flooding, White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, announced. The declaration is a step toward application for Federal funds for reliew and recovery.

title: PRICES ARE DOWN ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell again yesterday In light trading while those in the overthecounter market finished mixed in desultory trading.

description: AMITYVILLE, L I., Nov. 14 They charged Butch.

title: OMAR SAQQAF DIES; SAUDI ARABIA AIDE
description: Omar Saqqaf, the Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia, died suddenly last night in his WaldorfAstoria Hotel room, according to an announcement by Jamil Baroody, Saudi Arabian Ambassador to the United Nations.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Janes inlet (Pt. Lookout), deduct 19 min, from Sandy Hook time. For high tide at Atlantic City (Steel Pier), deduct 26 min, from Sandy Hook time.

title: Archives and CBS To Supply Cassettes Of TV Newscasts
description: The National Archives and CBS Inc. have announced the establishment of an archive of television news broadcasts, in which CBS will give the National Archives videocassettes of news broadcasts.

title: Islanders Drop Back To Reality
description: The situation returned to normal Wednesday night as the New York Islanders were beaten by the Pittsburgh Penguins, 82. It was the Islanders fifth consecutive game without a victory and it brought giddy Islander fans back to earth after the aspiring team had dared fly too close to the sun atop the Lester Patrick Division.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In the days before the recent world heavyweight championship fight in Zaire, somebody jokingly suggested to Don King that, by all laws of geographical progression, Tibet was the logical site for boxing's next extravaganza. The promoter laughed. But after Muhammad Ali regained the title, King casually mentioned that some people are even talking about Tibet for the next fight. Which just goes to prove how easy it is in boxing to be a placedropper. Tibet won't materialize as the locale of Ali's title defense next year but Iran might. Another possible site is Cairo, but at the moment Iran, with a soccer stadium in Teheran that was the site of the recent Asian Games, is the leading contender. Governments want me now, not promoters, Ali keeps saying. Governments want me to put them on the map.

title: Congress, the Press and Federal Agencies Are Taking Sides for Battle Over Government's Right to Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14A battle is building over the cornplicated question of the Government's right to keep secret its secrets.

title: Philadelphia Aide Acquitted
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 (UFO)City Councilman Isadore H. Bellis was acquitted by a Federal court jury yesterday on all four counts of income tax evasion. He had been charged with evading $46.317 in taxes for 1968 and 1969.

title: Arthur Weiser, Urologist Who Led Wickersham Unit
description: Dr. Arthur Weiser, former chief of urology at Wickersham Hospital, died yesterday of cancer in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 115 East 89th Street.

title: SOITIET DISSIDENTS IN CRITICAL ESSAYS
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 14The exiled author Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn has joined a halfdozen dissident intellectuals within the Soviet Union in publishing a forthcoming anthology of critical essays on aspects of Soviet life, a dissident here disclosed today.

title: People in Sports
description: Ferguson Jenkins, who helped the Texas Rangers become a pennant contender last season by winning 25 games, was named yesterday major league baseball's comeback player of the year by United Press International.

title: Chinise Law Major Economic Ills to Political Drive
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 14 China's leadership acknowledged early last summer that the antiConfucian political campaign had created major weaknesses in the economy., according to excerpts from a secret document that were published heretoday.

title: KISSINGER URGES OIL USERS TO JOIN IN PRICE CUT BID
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 14Secretary of State Kissinger announced tonight that the United States was undertaking a vast new effort on an international scale to deal with the world energy crisis and the deteriorating financial situation in many countries.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Nov. 14The New Jersey Conference collige football title will be decided at Glassboro tomorrow night when Montclair State meets Glassboro State, but another important contest will be a nonconference game at Seton Hall on Saturday between Kean College and Seton hall.

title: DISPUTE PERSISTS OVER HIRING PLAN
description: After four years of fighting a federally approved plan for getting more a minority workers into the construction industry in New York City, lawyers, civil rights representatives and others, yesterday applauded the Department of Labor's decision to withdraw the plan.

title: FORD PLANS PLEAS FOR TRANSIT AID
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14President Ford will make personal telephone calls to Congressmen to help pass legislation for masstransit, his Secretary of Transportation today assured a delegation of 14 Mayors, including Mayor Beame of New York.

title: About New York
description: The woman had gone to the clinic because she was pregnant, and a nurse had discovered that she used coCaine. The nurse sent her to a social work in the hosPital, and although the woman did not like this, she went. Yes, she told the so so cial worker, she used cocaine, but in such small qutintities that it didn't matter. Besides, she said, she could stop taking cocaine anytime she wanted to, just as she had stopped taking heroin the month before.

title: Burning at Sea Opposed
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 14 (UPI)Pour Gulf Coast states jointly opposed the Shell Oil Company's request today for another permit to burn industrial wastes at sea despite an Environmental Protection Agency report that no harmful effects were found during a test in October. We find the data we have been called to consider to be completely inadequate, representatives of Texas, Louisiana, Alabama and Florida said in a statement.

title: Jane Alpert Gives Up After Four Years
description: Renouncing her days as a militant radical, Jane L. Alpert gave herself up to Federal authorities here yesterday, more t'an four year's after she jumped bail and disappeared following her conviction for conspiracy in a series of bombings here in 1969.

title: State Democrats Fight For Leadership Posts
description: Black Democrats and the newly powerful upstate Democratic bloc joined suburban Democrats this week in pressing for major roles for themselves in the Assembly Democractic leadership, until now the exclusive province of New York City.

title: Two Adversaries From Coal Mining Country
description: By extracting a contract from the coal industry that union officials are conservatively calling hefty, Arnold Ray Miller, the president of the United Mine Workers of America, has surprised his closest associates, who thought him weak, and stepped out of the shadow of Joseph A. Yablonski, the slain union insurgent whose standard he picked up.

title: Paultz Gets 29 as Nets Top Sounds
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 14  The Memphis Sounds proved to be the tonic that the New York Nets needed tonight.

title: Economists Outlook Glum On Basis of Auto Sales Dip
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14A worse than expected erosion of the antomobile industry in recent weeks is now leading the Ford Administration to take a gloomier view of the nation's economic prospects in the coming months.

title: TOKYO MOBILIZES TO PROTECT FORD
description: TOKYO, Nov. 14  The Japanese Government, increasingly nervous about President, Ford's scheduled visit here next week, announced today that 160,000 policemen would be mobilized to protect him.

title: Is Living Safer on East Side or West side? The Debate Goes On
description: the 17 private metha done ics between 59th and 96th Streets and the conversion of 86th Street form a ribbon of Old World Shops to what one policenian called the Times Square of the East.

title: Recently Published Books
description: Amo, by Alice Denham (Coward, McCann, & Geoghegan, $7.95). A fashion model's ideas of equality and liberty.

title: Daurylea Indicted in Milk Adulteration
description: An Albany County grand jury has voted to indict the Dairylea milk cooperative on charges of conspiracy and filing false and misleading reports with the Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.

title: Thomas P. Jerman Dies; Retired Bank Executive, 67
description: Thomas Palmer Jerman, who retired in 1959 as senior executive vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of NM York, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Pinehurst, N.C. He was 67 years old.

title: Writers Elect Pepe
description: The New York chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America elected Phil Pepe of The Daily News as chairman yesterday. He succeeds Joseph Durso of The New York Times, who had served two terms. Joe Gergen of Newsday was named vice chairman and Jack Lang of The Long Island Press was reelected secretarytreasurer. The writers also scheduled their annual awards dinner for Feb. 2 at the Americana.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Over protests by Israel, the General Assembly voted 75 to 23 to limit each nation to one major speech in the current debate on Palestine. The decision was, denounced by Yosef Tekoah, the Israeli delegate, who said it was clearly a move to muzzle Israel's freedom to speak. It was believed to be the first time that such a restriction had been approved in the history of the United Nations. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: China's Foreign Minister Replaced by ExU.N. Aide
description: PEKING, Friday, Nov. 15 (Reuters)China announced today that she had replaced her Foreign Minister, naming the former United Nations delegate Chiao Kuanhua to take over the post from Chi Pengfei.

title: Taiwan Explores Little League Series
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 14 (AP)  Taiwan sports officials and baseball authorities are studying the possibility of holding their own little league world series after the United States little league decided to bar foreign teams from competition at Williamsport, Pa. We have been discussing the possibility of organizing a similar little league world series. It is uncertain yet. Our main concern is money, F. L. Lin, the secretary general of the Baseball Association, said today.

title: Lebanese Report 6 Killed After Israelis Shell Towns
description: NABATIYE, Lebanon, Nov. 14Longrange Israeli artillery shelled this commercial center and other towns in southern Lebanon early today, reportedly killing six persons and wounding at least 20.

title: Soaring Sugar Cost Arouses Consumers And U.S. Inquiries
description: At the first of the year, sugar sold in grocery stores at 18 cents a pound. It is now averaging about 55 cents and is expected to, be above 65 cents a pound within a few days.

title: U.N. VOTES A CURB IN MIDEAST DEBATE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14Over protests by Israel, the General Assembly voted today to limit each nation to one major speech in the current debate on the issue of Palestine. The vote was 75 to 23 with 18 abstentions.

title: U.N. VOTES A CURB IN MIDEAST DEBATE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14Over protests by Israel, the General Assembly voted today to Iimit each nation to one major speech in the current debate on the issue of Palestine The vote was 75 to 23 with 18 abstentions.

title: Hoffa Agreeable to Nomination for a Union Post
description: DETROIT, Nov. 14The former teamsters union president, James R. Hoffa, said today that he would accept a nomination for the presidency of Detroit Local 299 if he was nominated at a meeting of the local.

title: BIG UTILITY TO CUT CONSTRUCTION IN 75
description: The Consumers Power Company, informed the Michigan Public Service Commission yesterday that it would be forced to cut back its 1975 construction program. The big utility said the latest move would cut about $147millionabout 36 per cent from the $413million construction budget. It would be achieved mainly by deferring for about a year the completion of two major projects two 650kilowatt units at Midland and the fourth unit660,000kilowatts at the Kern plant.

title: Jerome P. Webster Dead at 86; Plastic Surgeon and Professor
description: Dr. Jerome Pierce Webster, an internationally known plastic surgeon and professor emeritus of clinical surgery at the Columbia University. College of Physicians and Surgeons, died yesterday at Harkness Pavillion, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, after a brief illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Oslo Warns Food Parle on Affluent Societies' Diet
description: ROME, Nov.; 14The diet of the affluent countries should not be taken as a model for good nutrition, Norway told the World Food Conference today. The statement was made during a description of Norway's own pioneering efforts to change, the, foodconsumptitin patterns of her people to give them improved health and greater food selfsufficiency.

title: Jane Alpert Gives Up After Four Years
description: Renouncing her days as a militant radical, Jane L. Alpert gave herself up to Federal authorities here yesterday, more than four years after she jumped bail and disappeared following her conviction for conspiracy in a series of bombings here in 1969.

title: NonStop Inflation
description: Even before President Ford chose Las Vegas as the place to make his straightfaced forecast yesterday that inflation would turn down and the economy up, the country needed no confirmation that the Administration's economic analysis, has about the same scientific basis as a gambler's approach to the roulette wheel.

title: Stocks Off 3d Day in Row; Dow Slips 0.78 to 658.40
description: The stock market posted its third consecutive loss yesterday in lethargic trading as bearish economic news weakened prices slightly.

title: ABITIBI IN TENDER ON PRICE COMPANY
description: The Abitibi Paper Company announced yesterday in Toronto a tender offer for 49 per cent of the outstanding shares of the Price Company of Quebec City at a price of $18 a share. The deal is valued at $86.9million. In Quebec, C. R. Tittemore, president of Price, urged stockholders to refrain from taking any action on the offer. He said directors would meet Nov. 16 to consider the matter and, that an announcement of the board's recommendations would be made immediately after the meeting.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Treasurer of New Jersey, Richard C. Leone, yesterday warned that the state faced a fiscal crisis and that the gap between income and anticipated state expenditures could produce a budget deficit of as much as $638million next year. Earlier estimates of the deficit's magnitude, made following the defeat of Governor Byrne's taxreform program, ranged from $300million to $500million.

title: Inflation and Unemployment
description: The responsibility for current worldwide inflation, I am sorry to say, rests wholly and squarely with the economists, or at least with that great majority of my fellow economists who have embraced the teachings of Lord Keynes.

title: Four Children Perish In a OneAlarm Fire Brooklyn Home
description: Four children were killed yesterday morning in a onealarm fire, listed as suspicious by fire officials, in a twofamily house in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NEW DIMENSION Deaf persons are rarely afforded the chance to enjoy local theater in total communication, with an interpreter posted at the side of the stage throughout the performance, using sign language and lip movement. Two such performances will take place, tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. and again on Thursday at 7:30 P.M., during the revival of William Inge's Picnic by the Academy Arts Theater Company at the Elysian Playhouse (5326657), 138 Fifth Avenue, near 19th Street. With general admission priced at $2.50, and special group rates, all deaf persons are being welcomed to both performances. Sixty older students from Junior High School 47 are due to attend tomorrow's matinee. Bridget Cusack, the director of Picnic, and Greg Jones, who will serve as stage interpreter, are also instructors at the city's only public day school for thedeaf.

title: 3 Bomb Attacks Damage Cities in English Midlands
description: LONDON, Nov. 14One man was killed tonight in a series of terrorist bomb attacks in Northampton, Coventry and Birmingham, all in the Midlands.

title: Rope Factory Reflects Woes of Plants in City
description: The city is a place of nooks and cramies. Hidden in many of them are the small manufacturing plants that account for no small share of the manufacturing employment in town.

description: A group of Manhattan videotape enthusiasts, who gained entry into Cuba last spring, have sold to WNET/13 and the Public Broadcasting Service a cinma vrit documentary on the people of Cuba and their living standards that the three commercial television networks had rejected.

title: President Prodes Congeress For Action on Rockefeler
description: PHOENIX; Ariz., Nov. 14President Ford declared tonight that it was time for Congress to fish or cut bait in confriming his nearly threernenthold, nomination of Nelson A. Rockefeller to be Vice President.

title: GUNMEN KILL YOUTH IN BROOKLYN HOME
description: A 21yearold youth was shot and killed and his brother and two friends were wounded yesterday afternoon when two gunmen forced their way into an apartment in Gowanus Houses in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn.

title: Ford Personally Rebukes Chairman of Joint Chiefs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14President Ford personally rebuked Gen. George S. Brown today for his critical comments about American Jews but said tonight that he had no intention of replacing him as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: GREEN ACRES AID PLEDGED TO CITIES
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14The State Department of Environmntal Protection promised today that rejuvenation of older cities and programs to stimulate employment would be given priority in the expenditure of funds provided by the $200  million Green Acres bond issue approved by New Jersey's voters last week.

title: THIEU CENSORSHIP BACKED IN A TEST
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 14The lower house of the National Assembly thwarted an opposition drive for press freedom today by approving a slight relaxation of the press law that leaves President Nguyen Van Thieu with his most effective tool of censorship: the power to confiscate issues of newspapers.

title: Jersey Treasurer Warns of a Deficit Up to $638Million
description: TRENTON, Nov. 14State Treasurer Richard C. Leone warned today that New Jersey faced a fiscal crisis, with a gap between income and anticipated state expenditures that could produce a budget deficit of as much as $638milliok next year.

title: U. S. Lawmakers Meet With P.L.O. Group
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14A group of United States Senators and Representatives met here informally for about an hour today with members of the Palestine Liberation Organiiation.

title: Braves Win 6th Straight 112 100
description: PROVIDENCE, R.1., Nov. 14 (AP)Randy Smith scored 17 points in the fourth period tonight in leading the Buffalo Braves to their sixth consecutive victory, a 112100 triumph over the Boston Celtics.

title: Hayes Gains 3 Shot Lead In S. Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 14 (AP)Dale Hayes of South Africa bettered the course record today with a fiveunderpar 65 and took the secondround lead at 133 in the $50,000 South Africa Professional Golfers Association championship.

title: WIFE FREED IN DEATH OF CASTRO SOFA HEIR
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 14 (UPI)A grand jury decided today not to file charges against Julie Castro, the 24yearold wife of the recently slain heir to the Castro Convertible furniture fortune.

title: Kissinger's Travels
description: As spokesman for the world's most powerful nation and, a masterly diplomat, Secretary of State Kissinger once seemed able on his trips abroad to rival King Canute and command the tides of history. His present appearance, after a grueling seventeencountry, 27,000mile voyage, is more that of the desperate Dutch boy holding back the flood.

title: Tells Senate Unit He Would Give Nominal Presents, and Hardship Help
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14Nelson A. Rockefeller agreed today to pledge to make no gifts or loans to Federal employes if confirmed as Vice President except for nominal gifts for birthdays or weddings or in the event of, medical hardships of a compelling human character.

title: Film: Vietnam Lesson:'Introduction to Enemy' From Jane Fonda
description: Patience may never become one of our national characteristics. But we could take some lessons from the Vietnamese. Rebuilding and rebirth are the themes of "Introduction to the Enemy," which was made collectively by Jane Fonda, Tom Hayden, Haskell Wexler, and others; it depicts their travels through North and South Vietnam last spring. The documentary is playing today and tomorrow at the First Avenue Screening Room. Anyone who was or is concerned with the war should see italong with those who think that the war is over.Throughout this quiet, modest film, in which scrap metal from American airplanes is made into bicycles, and an old man explains that he rebuilt his house 12 times (on five occasions after the French bombings, and seven times after the American raids) and misty green crops rise from filled-in craters, it is stressed that the Vietnamese do not hate Americans, that they want to know more about us. Again and again, different Vietnamese citizens say that they distinguish between a population and its political leaders: they repeat that they do not blame Americans at large for the destruction of their country. Yet the wounds of their continuing experience are as tangible as the unexploded mine that goes off and kills a man during the filming.The film seethes with small children; it seems quite amazing that there are so many Vietnamese children left alive, or that smiles of all ages should be turned toward the camera. Miss Fonda and Mr. Hayden function as un-obtrusive guides. They journey from Hanoi to the South, crossing the demilitarized zone to the Quang Tri province. Miss Fonda interviews people about their work, asking why one chose to become an actress, or a translator, or a member of the resistance. The answers are thoughtful, decisive  as much personal as political.Another recurrent theme is that Vietnam is one countrythat the artificial division of the North and the South is not accepted by the Vietnamese. It's remarked that most families have relatives living in both areas; an editor adds, "The North and the South have always shared moments of joy as well as moments of sorrow and tragedy." Moreover, "American leaders are constantly reminding us that the bombing could be renewed." A very old man says he'd be happy to die if he could see one day of reunification.Though the Paris Peace Agreements have not been fulfilled, a restrained optimism surges through this documentary. The mood of the film is distilled when someone asserts that "the needs of peace are greater than the needs of war"meaning that rebuilding schools and hospitals and homes and entire cities demands resources and energies that simply aren't available in wartime. All in all, this pensive and moving film serves as a chapter of our own education about the Vietnamese past and the rhythm of life in that country now.

title: John S. Radosta
description: Sometime in the next few days the nation's No. 1 weekend hacker will be invited, in the fulfillment of a Walter Mitty dream, to contribute one of his clubs, and perhaps a scuffed ball with his name printed on it, to the Museum and Library of Golf House, the headquarters of the United States Golf Association. And so one of President Ford's souvenirs will join those putters of Arnold Palmer; the 6iron with which Alan Shepard hit that chip shot on the moon on Feb. 6, 1971; Joe Kirkwood's trick clubs, and Calamity Jane II, the hickoryshafted putter that Bobby Jones used in winning 10 of his 13 major championships. One of the functions of the U.S.G.A., the governing body of golf in this country, is to serve as custodian of the game's history in the United States. That explains, in part, why the U.S.G.A. left its midtown Manhattan base two years agothe museum and library needed more space. The answer was the new Golf House, a converted Georgian Colonial mansion set in 68 bucolic acres in the village of Far Hills, Somerset County, N. J.

title: Film: 'Savage Is Loose'
description: "The Savage Is Loose," produced, directed and distributed by George C. Scott, who also stars in it with his wife, Trish Van Devere, is one of those desert-island movies in which the members of the audience, more often than the characters within the film, keep searching the horizon in hopes that a ship will pass by.The film, which opened yesterday at the Rivoli and other theaters, is a three-character, four-actor melodrama about a scientist, his much younger wife and their son who are shipwrecked on a tropical isle early in this century. What begins as a kind of tab show version of "The Swiss Family Robinson" quickly disintegrates into a muddled meditation upon the survival of the human race, but under conditions so special that the film's primal concerns eventually become ludicrous.A heavily portentous line spoken early in the film by the son (played as an adolescent by Lee H. Montgomery) points the way: "Mother, when I grow up, can we get married?"Trouble erupts 10 years later when the son, now played by John David Carlson, has started to court his mother in earnest. He leaves orchids by her coconut-shell soup bowl and asks pointed questions on the order of: "Who was Cain's wife?" When Mom and Dad make love, he likes to peek.Says Mom to Dad in the semi-privacy of their bamboo-walled bedroom: "We've got a lusting male with no outlet." That is, no satisfactory outlet. Mom has found that the boy has constructed a curious substitute woman, apparently out of the all-purpose coconut shells, in a jungle hideaway.It isn't long before things come to a showdown, largely because Dad has allowed himself to get cranky and go to wrack and ruin (Mr. Scott at this point looks like a cross between the Biblical Abraham and Raymond Duncan) and seemingly because the life force is so strong that Mom's resistance to her son begins to run out.Someone might very well have made a plausible Oedipal metaphor out of this story, but not Max Ehrlich and Frank De Felitta Jr., who wrote the screenplay and stuffed it with unequal alternatives.A major point is made at the beginning of the film of the conflict between the parents. The mother wants to raise the boy as a civilized child who can read and write, while the father feels the boy must be taught to dominate his environment. This supposedly has the effect of turning him into the savage of the title, though why he couldn't also have learned to read and write is never properly explained.By reducing the Oedipal conflict to such a basic confrontation, the movie has the effect of making a common psychological conflict seem as remote to most of us as the emotional lives of Siamese twins."The Savage Is Loose" works neither as an adventure film, as a psychological exploration, nor, heaven help us, as a family melodrama. Although I think that Mr. Scott has been talking through his hat in recent public statements that the movie is not about incest, the subject is so genteelly handled that I can't imagine children seeing the film would be anything but confused and probably bored.The production, photographed entirely on location south of Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, looks pretty and has the studied blandness of a film directed according to a 50-year-old textbook on movie making. What force it has comes entirely from the performances of Mr. Scott and Miss Van Devere, though the banality of the script has a way of letting them seem overwrought when they mean to be believably passionate. The less said about the other performances, the better.

title: Hunt Bid Fought in Court By Great Western United
description: The Great Western United Corporation, the nation's largest producer of beet sugar, said yesterday it had started legal proceedings to restrain Nelson Bunker Hunt and W. Herbert Hunt and their agents from purchasing control of Great Western. In papers filed in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York, Great Western charged that the Hunt brothers, sons of W. L. Hunt, Texas oil billionaire had violated the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 connection with their tender offer of $27.50 a share for 910,000 common shares of Great Western. That number of shares, together with the amount already owned, would give them more than 68 per cent of the shares of Great Western.

title: and the Record

Neal outlined the prosecution's theory that the former President directed the obstruction of justice and that Messrs. Haldeman, Ehrlichman, et al acted as his agents in carrying it out. There's no other way you can show the agencyfrom the former President of the United States to Haldeman and Ehrlichman to Walters to Grayand that is the obstruction, Mr. Neal said. It's the act itself.

title: Education or Subversion?
description: Nobody could really quarrel with the notion, developed at the height of the Boston school controversy, that it might help if an integrated group of Boston students were given the chance to look at a school system in the South where integration works. So, a few weeks ago, some Boston youngsters did go South to see that, indeed, it could work. This week, a group of 34 private groups in Boston, seeking to further the program of understanding through exchange, invited groups of students from places such as Charlotte, N. C., and Greenville, Miss., where quaint old integration battles were fought in the past, to visit the latest civil rights hot spot.

title: Screen: 'Earthquake' Evokes Feelies:The Cast
description: Although no one has yet produced the feelies that Aldous Huxley evoked in "Brave New World"  in which a love scene on a bearskin rug transmitted every hair of the bear, and there were aromas of newmown hay and kidney pudding, while a kiss on the lips or a blow on the skull were felt by everyone in the audience  Mark Robson's "Earthquake" makes an awesome stab in that direction. The dam breaking, floods rising, bodies falling, towers crashing or burning, the earth heaving, pavements parting and the random explosions are all enhanced by Sensur-round: special vibrations on the soundtrack cause your spine and your throat to tingle. (You may also wonder if they curdle the brain cells.) It seems greedy to wish that "Earthquake" were in 3-D. At any rate, the whole experience opened yesterday at the Ziegfeld Theater.The deadpan delivery of key lines informs us when the worst is coming. Such as: "I know you'll laugh, butI think we're going to have a really big quake." Or (to a child on his way to the playground): "Just be careful crossing that bridge." And (to those fleeing from a cellar that's about to be flooded): "Relax! there's lots of time!" The impulse to shout advice to the screenget out! go away! don't enter that buildingis quite powerful, so this does rank as a participatory movie.While the exertions that the cast goes through can't really be called acting, Ava Gardner (looking magnificent), Charlton Heston (a bit less wooden than usual), Genevieve Bujold (brisk and beguiling), Marjoe Gortner (a righteous psychotic) and George Kennedy (a nimble cop) do convey an exhilarating amount of panic. There's also a pleasing glimpse of Walter Matthau as an imperturbable drunk; he's listed under his true name, Walter Matuschanskavasky. Although the special effects are staggeringly realistic, I'll go along with the psychologists who say that the disaster movies manage to assert that it couldn't happen to youbecause it's happening to movie stars."Earthquake" is far less sophisticated than "Jugger-naut," but much more so than "Airport 75"a really rotten movie that's entertaining just because it's so bad. (There, it would be nice to see the Charlton Heston and Karen Black roles reversed, so that an experienced woman pilot would guide a sobbing male steward at the controls: "Take a left turn, honey." "Oh God I can't." "Now, now.") "Earthquake" also includes a skyscraper bursting into flames  no doubt in order to steal a march on "The Towering Inferno," which won't open until next month. While the quake isn't gory, it's the most harrowing of these movies so far, hence it mightn't be appropriate for anyone under 10. But for those who have a soft spot for calamity pictures, there's a sense of ritual cleansing afterward. And for some reason, it also made me hungry.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov 15 (Reuter)The Ford Administration, under strong pressure to help cattlemen out of a costprice squeeze, has decided to put tight import controls on the volume of Canadian livestock and meat allowed into the United States, accordin gto informed sources here.

title: HEAD OF ASSEMBLY IRKS WEST AT U.N.
description: UNITED. NATIONS, N. Y. Nov. 15Recent rulings by the President of the current General Assembly, Foreign Minister Abdelaziz Bouteflika of Algeria, have caused uneasiness among Western nations at United Nations headquarters and disillusionment with the world organization at large.

title: The Russians Reportedly Reject Peking Nonaggression Proposal
description: MOSCOW; Nov. 15Official Soviet circles were reported by the Hungarian news agency M.T.I. here, to have rejected as entirely unacceptable a diplomatic bid by Peking earlier this month for a SovietChinese nonaggression pact.

title: Kissinger Plan on Energy Gets Favorable Response
description: Secretary of State Kissinger's fivepoint plan for dealing with the world energy crisis drew a generally favorable response yesterday from oil consuming countries.

title: Nets Sag In Losirig To Stars
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 15 Signs of wear and tearlike shots that wouldn't drop, a weakened defense and too many lost reboundswere visible in the New York Nets tonight as they lost a 109.98 decision to the Utah Stars before a crowd of 7,771.

title: Jane Alpert Says Surfacing Was the Right Thing to Do
description: Jane L. Alpert, declaring that she had returned from underground because it was the right thing to do, went to Federal Court yesterday to keep her first date with, probation officers after her surrender on Thursday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: News Summary and Index

title: industrial Output Declines, Adding to Recession Data
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 157The output of the nation's factories, utilities and mines all declined in October, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Television
description: 5:30 (4)Modern Farmer

title: AMEX ENDS MIXED BUT 0TC DECLINES
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday but those in the Overthecounter market dropped markedly.

title: East Connecticut In Soccer Final
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 15 (AP) Eastern Connecticut State College scored a 32 soccer victory over the University of Hartford double overtime today. The victory sent Eastern Connecticut to the finals against New England College tomorrow in New. England regional play of the Eastern College Athletic Conference.

title: MORTGAGE FUNDS FOR BUILDING LAG
description: WASHINGTON, Nov 15A Government program signed into law a month ago to pump $3billion into the mortgage pipeline to help the lagging building industry, has so far put only $671Million to work.

title: Antiques: Neither Boom Nor Gloom
description: The boom years in the antiques business may be over. But no bust is expected now or soon by any one of a score of antiques dealers and auctioneers interviewed this week.

title: City Urged to Forgo Control of Its 3 Zoos
description: A transfer of New York's municipal zoos to the quasipublic New York Zoological Society to improve the condition of the animals has been proposed to Mayor Beanie by Parks Commissioner Edwin L. Weisl Jr.

title: Violence Interrupts Saigon Assembly Debate Over Political Parties
description: give it, and negotiations between Opposition leaders and the Speaker of the House continued into the night.

title: MINERS' COUNCIL FAILS FOR 29 DAY TO APPROVE PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15A prolonged coal miners' strike became an increasing likelihood tonight after officers failed unexpectedly for the second day to obtain union approval of a tentative agreement and a union official was killed in a motel.

title: Hung Jury rids the Trial Of Doctor in Murder Plot
description: TRENTON, Nov. 15The trial of Dr. William R. King, a former state prison psychiatrist charged with planning a triple murder, ended today with a hung jury. It was deadlocked over the question of his sanity.

title: Stomach Pains Hit Braves McMillian
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 15 (AP)The Buffalo Braves forward, Jim McMillian, was reported in good condition today after hospitalization for what doctors said was a possible case of appendicities.

title: Television
description: 5:30 (4)Modern Farmer

title: Angola's Divided Blacks
description: It was inevitable that Angola's road to black majority government and independence would be more difficult than the passages to nation status of Portugal's other African territories, Mozambique and GuineaBissau. Angola is larger in area, richer by far in resourcesoil, diamonds, coffee, ironand includes among six million inhabitants some 500,000 whites, most of whom are settled in and determined to stay.

title: Frehch Protest Polices in Strike
description: PARIS, Nov. 15 Tens of thousands of workers marched in the from the Place de la Rpublique to the Place de la Bastille in Paris this afternoon in a demonstration called late last night by France's major unions.

title: Wall St. Is a Circus at Financial Follies
description: Wall Street is a circus, according to the New York Financial Writers Association, which last night told that story in song and dance at the annual Financial Follies.

title: KOREA TRUCE LINE SCENE OF BATTLE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Nov. 16 (UPI)North and South Korean troops fought a gun battle yesterday when South Korean troops discovered a tunnel dug by northern forces to a point about 1,000 yards south, of the military demarcation line, a United Nations command spokesman said.

title: World Football League
description: Central Division

title: People in Sports
description: Is Jim Plunkett the quar terback of the New England Patroits, worth $1millkon? Bob Woolf, the Bostonbased sports attorney, thinks he is There is no way you can evaluate the worth of a great quarterback, Woolf, said yesterday as he and his client sat down to distuss terms with Patroit officials. Every coach in the league will tell you Piunkett is the best. You could pay a great quarterback, a million dollars a year, and it would not be enough. No agreement was reached between the, parties, but reportedly both sides are not that far apart The contract under discussion is a fiveyear extension, of Plunkett's current pact, which has two seasons to plus the option year.

title: Good News For Jets: Hill to Play
description: Winston Hill, the New York Jets allstart offensive tackle visited a throat specialist yesterday, and the Jets got some good newsthe he would not miss tomorrow's game against the New England Patriots after all.

title: Chrysler May Shut Its Plants for Month
description: DETROIT, Nov. 15  The Chrysler Corporation is seriously considering closing most of its United States assembly plants during December because of a severe decline in car sales, automotive sources disclosed today.

title: AMTRAK FARE IS UP 10% ON MOST LINES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) Starting today, travel costs were up 10 per cent on most Amtrak trains. Family groups will pay an even bigger increase.

title: F.C.C. Eases Curbs on Cable, PayTV
description: After extensive hearings and deliberations on whether to lift restrictions on movies, sports and continuing series for pay television on cable systems, the Federal Communications Commission agreed yesterday to ease somewhat the present rules, which the cabletelevision industry had argued were inhibiting its growth.

title: Business Briefs
description: The nation's railroads, except for the Chessie System, parent of the Chesapeake & Ohio, the Baltimore & Ohio and the Western Maryland railways, yesterday filed a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission for a 7 per'cent freightrate increase. The higher rates, if approved by the regulatory agency, would yield the carriers an additional $1billion in revenues annually.

title: Kissinger Says He Is Sure Of No War in Mideast Now
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that President Ford and he were convinced that there was no immediate danger of fighting in the Middle East.

title: Kings Repel Celtic Rally, Win, 110109
description: BOSTON, Nov. 15 (AP)Nate Archibald and Jimmy Walker, combined for 52 points as the Kansas CityOmah Kings defeated the Boston Celtics tonight, 110109, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Belgrade Frees 2 Britons
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 15 (Reuters)Two young BritOS imprisoned for espionage last year were released today from prison here, where they were serving threeyear terms, a Briish Embassy spokesman said. Paul Mason, 24 years old and Robert Curtis, 25, later left for London.

title: Waldheim to Meet Israeils Victims of Guerrilla Attacks
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations will meet Monday with Israeli victims of Arab guerrilla attacks 6 heir their protests against the appearance of Palestine Liberation Organization representatives in the General Assembly this week.

title: Westchester Gets New Budget With No Increase in Tax Rate
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 15Westchester County Executive Alfred B. DelBello today filed his first budget requesting a record $307,406,000 in expenditures but calling for no increase in the average tax rate.

title: Nets Sag In Losing To Stars
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 15 Signs of wear and tearlike shots that wouldn't drop, a weakened defense, and too many lost reboundswere visible in the New York Nets tonight as they lost a 10998 decision to the Utah Stars before a crowd of 7,771.

title: Copyright and the Right to Copy
description: What lawyers are calling the most important copyright case in the last 30 or 40 years is making its way to the Supreme Court with a minimum of fanfare. The caseWilliams & Wilkins Co. v. the United Stateshas already opened a fissure between the publishing industry and the library and educational worldtwo groups that are traditionally on the same side of the fence of such issues as censorship or Federal aid to education. The plaintiff, a small but important Baltimore pub lisher of scientific booksand journals, is backed by amici curiae briefs from a stellar cast of authorpublisher associations, including the Authors League, Association of American Publishers, Advocates for the Arts (representing artists as well as writers) and the university presses. The Federal Government, representing the National Institutes of Health and the National Medical Library, has in its corner such heavyweight intellectual consumers as the American Library Association, the National Education Association and variassociations.

title: The Town Pound, a Yankee Acropolis
description: HERE and there in small New England townsclose by the village green, perhaps, or at the side of a winding country road leading out of townthe eagleeyed traveler will chance upon what looks like a small corral. Stone, most likely, although perhaps of weathered wood.

title: Mary E. Pollin Fiancee of Officer
description: Col. Jack Murph Pollin, head of the mathematics department at the United States Military Academy, and Mrs. Pollin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Pollin, to Second Lieut. Robert Wayne Richards, who was graduated from West Point this year. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Glenn Richards of Cornelia, Ga.

title: Crowd Jams W. 40th St. in Call For Price Rollback and New Jobs
description: Several hundred persons jammed 40th Street betWeen Avenue of the Americas and Fifth Avenue yesterday for a demonstration to demand that prices for basic necessities be rolled back to the 1970 levels and that publicservice jobs at union wages be provided the unemployed.

title: Capitol Hill Dropping In On Europe
description: LONDON, Nov., 16More. than 50 United States Senators and Representatives de. scended on Europe and points east this week, held news conferences, visited a synagogue in Moscow, drank with Queen Elizabeth II, attended meetings, went to parties, talked with foreign governments and insisted there was no playjust work,

title: Cricket's Choice; Edited by Clifton Fadinian and Marianne Carus. Illustrated. 291 pp.; La Salle, Ill.: Open Court. $5.95. (Ages 6 to 12)
description: This is a Collection of over 70 stories, poems and pictures chosen from the first year of Cricket, the new children's literary magazine. When it was launched Senior Editor Clifton Fadiman said he hoped Cricket would translate into terms of our own day the ideals of quality, in both text and illustration, that are traditionally associated with St. Nicholas.

title: Harsher Drug Statute Ur ed
description: TRENTONA special legislative study commission has recommended that the severity.of the present penalty provisions for nonaddict sellers of hard drugs be increased substantially. The recommendation is part of an overall program proposed by the commission to reduce the availability of drugs in the state and to detect, prosecute and punish highechelon drug traffickers.

title: INQUIRY ON IMPACT OF A POWER URGED;
Headliners
description: Like many other New York City School employes, Ralph Blintzer and.Stanley Blight received their paychecks from Computer Specifics Corporation, a company hired by the city's Board of Education'to handle its 35,000 member nonteaching payroll. But Mr. Bagle and Mr. Blintzer performed no noticeable tasks in any of the city's schools. In fact, Mr. Blintzer's checks were cashed by a secretary at Computer Specifics; a check issued to Mr. Bagle turned up in the hands of a Board of.Education employe. Why? Bagle and Blintzer were fictitious names, rested, says the New York State Commission of Investigation, to disguise payoffs of cash, gifts, and the services of call girls to Board of Education employes, in return for which Computer Specifics was awarded the payroll contract without submitting a competitive bid. The investigation has already resulted in the indictment of a board accountant, and is part of a broader inquiry into the general practice of awarding education contracts with no competitive bidding.

title: PepsiCola Strike Settled
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Nov. 16 A threemonth strike that had dried up supplies of PepsiCola in a fivecounty MidHudson Valley area was settled last night. A new threeyear agreement between a local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and PepsiCola Newburgh, Inc., calls for an immediate 14. per cent pay increase plus fringe benefits, with 10 per cent raises at the beginning of each of the next two years, a company official said.

title: MEMOIRS OPEN BRITISH DISPUTE
Queens Youth Slain And Grandmother Dies on Being Told
description: A 17yearold Queens youth was shot to death in a street argument with a friend on Friday night and his grandmother died of a heart attack a few hours later. when informed of the death, the police said yesterday.

title: Youth Sues to Get Into Army
description: MIAMI, Nov. 16 (UPI)An 18yearold who was rejected by the Army because of his juvenile delinquency record is suing the Secretary of the Army and Dade County's chief recruiter for violation of his constitutional rights. Timothy McGuire says any regulation preventing him from joining the Army because of his record is unconstitutional, deprives him of due process of law and is cruel and unusual punishment.

title: Nancy Gumley Sets Summer Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Gumley of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Gumley, to Benjamin R. Katz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques J. Katz, also of Scarsdale. A wedding next summer is planned.

title: New and Surprising Type Of Atomic Particle Found
Grambling Wins, 1610
description: GRAMBLING, La., Nov. 16 (AP)James Hunter's Zyard touchdown run in, the fourth quarter gave Grambling a 16.10 victory over Norfolk State today.

title: Heidi Grossman Plus Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Everett P. Grossman of. West Newton, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Heidi Pamela Grossman, to Joseph Meresman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham C. Meresman of Santa Clara, Calif.

title: U.S.C. Routs Washington, 4211
POLICE SLAY YOUTH IN SUBWAY HOLDUP
description: A 15yearold boy wearing ski mask was shot and killed by the police yesterday during an aborted attempt to rob tokenbooth clerk at the Winthrop Street station of the IRT Seventh Avenue line in Brooklyn.

title: The Spanish Opposition Is Growing Bolder
description: MADRIDThings have changed in Spain. Officials are resigning from government and others are protesting suddenly. In his 81st year, a year of dangerous illness and declining faculties, Generalissimo Francisco Franco is losing his grip. More than ever, his compatriots are thinking of a future without him.

title: Erskine Childers,68,Dies; Was President of Ireland
description: DUBLIN, Sunday, Nov. 17 (AP)  Erskine Childers, Ireland's second Protestant President, died early, today after suffering a heartlittack during a speech. He was 68 years old.

title: Helen R. Patch, Robert Schmid Are Wed Here
description: Helen Rentschler Patch of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., widow of Norman Parke Patch, was married here yes terday morning to Robert A. Schmid, also of New York. The Rev. Terence J. Finlay performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: President's Proclamation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI)Following is the te of President Ford's Thanksgiving bay proclamation, signed Monday, Nov. 11:

title: Recession Is Said to Spur Drive To Unionize College Faculties
description: The recession and increased competition for Government assistance to education will force more and more college and university faculties to join unions for their political power, speakers contended yesterday at a conference on higher education conducted by the American Federation of Teachers.

title: The Nation In Summary
description: Little of importance that is new has been divulged during the resumed hearings on the confirmation of Nei son, Rockefeller for the Vice Presidency, and Congress has now been challenged by President Ford to fish or cut bait on the matter. The Democrats in control of the hearings replied that they will not be stampeded.

title: Flanigan Is Dropped
description: President Ford withdrew the controversial nomination of Peter M. Flanigan to be Ambassador to Spain yesterday. Page 13.

title: Sanctuary Director To Speak on Owls
description: DENVILLERichard Kane, director of the New Jersey Audubon Society's Scherman Wildlife Sanctuary in Bernardsville, will speak on Owls of New Jersey at the monthly meeting of the Morris Highlands Audubon Society.

title: MISS CHUNG PLAYS WORKS BY KREISLER
description: The 100th anniversary of the birth of Fritz Kreisler on Feb. 2 is still some weeks away, but the violinist Kyung4ha Chung apparently thought it worth an early celebration, and at. the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night she devotedthe second half of her recital to works by the. Viennese violinistcomposer.

title: Another Abduction in Italy
description: MILAN, Italy, Nov. 16 (AP)The IIyearold daughter of a jewelry dealer was abducted as she walked to school here today. She was the fourth kidnapping victim in Italy in four days and the 36th so far this year.

title: Merri Markowitz Planning Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milton Markowitz of Yonkers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Merri Markowitz, to John Paul Scho sheim. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Schosheim of Great Neck, L. I., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: St. John's Victor, Gains Bid to Bowl
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16Charlie Vito scored three touchdowns in leading St. John's to a 296 victory over American University today. The victory put the Redmen in the Empire Bowl against Marist.

title: Ruth. Benedict
description: Ruth Benedict did not begin the study of anthropology until she was 34. Through her twenties, she tried, one after another, the roles traditionally open to womensocial work, teaching in a private girls school, marriagesearching, more despairingly as time went on, for a useful and creative life. So much of the trouble is because am a woman, she wrote in her journal. To me it seems a very terrible thing to be a woman.

title: ST. CLAIR ASSERTS CONGRESS GAINED
description: BOSTON, Nov. 16 (AP)James D. St. Clair says he does not think Watergate means that future Presidents will be forced out of office but it was a spark that allowed Congfess to regain some of its power.

title: Landmark Status Sought for Falls
description: PATERSONPart of New Jersey's, planned celebration of the United States Bicentennial involves some of the state's more impressive natAral resources, particularly the Great Falls on the Passaic River near the center of this industrial city.

title: Reagan Urged to Run.
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 16 (UPI)  Human Events, nationwide conservative weekly, urged Gov. Ronald Reagan yesterday to declare immediately his candidacy for President if he truly values the conservative ideas he espouses. Mr. Reagan was not available for comment.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Hans Helimut Kirst, whose The Night of the Generals attracted such attention some years back, is at work on a Munich trilogy. Damned to Success, the first volume, came out here last year. Now A TIME FOR TRUTH (Coward, McCann and Geoghegan, $7.95) has been published (again in a translation by J. Maxwell Brownjohn), and it is even better than its predecessor.

title: No Lift Lines, But: For Members Only
JUNKETS DRAWING SOME LAME DUCKS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16With the Congressional elections over, the lame duck Senators and Representatives who retired or lost are off and running again, not for reelection but on junkets around the world.

title: Ballet: Into the Breach
description: In recent years the New York City Ballet has built up something of a tradition of taking many of its principal male dancers from , Europe. Peter Martins came from Denmark, JeanPierre Bonnefous from France and Helgi Tomasson from Iceland. After a few years, indeed usually after a few months, these young men become acclimated to the City Ballet ambiance and completely assimilated into the company.

title: Fashion
description: The smartest womenand they are usually the most successful and the busiestare becoming increasingly aware of the importance of the shape they are in. They are also aware that staying in shape is a lifetime task. Those women who seem to have the least time are the ones who insist on making time to work out once, twice or five times a week at their favorite exercise spots. And stores are stocking up on exercise clothes to fit the women who work at keeping fit.

title: Flood Cleanup Is Pressed in Alaska
description: NOME; Alaska, Nov. 16 Mopup operations continued today in the worst northwestern Alaska flood in 20 years, estimated to have caused more than $15million in damages.

title: Dance Panel Appoints Nine
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has appointed nine new members to its dance panel, which reviews grant applications. This year the panel will make grants of approximately $5million. The new niembers are Robert Joffrey, Bella Lewitzky, Manuel Alum, Toby Armour, Jane Combs, Chuck Davis, Shelbe Freeman, Elvi Moore and Tom Leabhart, the panel's first mime expert.

title: Sydney Louise Dunn Is Bride Of Harry Reed in Short Hills
description: Sydney Louise Dunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart A. Dunn of Short Hills, N. J., and Harry Ferenbach Reed, son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard L Reed of Centerville, Del., were married. yesterday afternoon by the Rev. George MacCray in Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills.

title: Princeton Students Are Tutoring Inmates at Trenton Prison
Suffolk's Girl Scouts Becoming a Feminist Force;
Cylinda Shull Sets Wedding
description: Cylinda Raye Shull plans to be married in late December to Lairy Doran Hazen. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Shull of Staunton, Va., parents of the bridetobe.

title: Sarajevo to the Great Crash, the Bonus Army to Watergate
description: On page 371 of Great Times, Joseph Chamberlain Furnas quotes from an obscure work written in 1927 by Elmer Davis: A good deal of the solemnity of recent literature, like good deal of the embittered zealotry of recent political radicalism, is obvious the work of earnest young people who are unaware that they are not the first earnest young people in history. That the universe is unsatisfactory [is] not exactly a novel discovery, but it is news to most of the earnest young people. They feel that something ought to be done, or at least said, about it. Davis ascribed the solemnity with which the 1920's took Youthand vice versato a reading public which is 90 per cent illiterate, in the sense that it knows nothing of what has been thought, and said, in the past.

title: Wood, Field&Stream Hunters Aid U.S. Woodcock Study.
description: Woodcock hunters May assist, if they wish, in a continuing United States Fish and Wildlife study of what is one of this country's most delightful game birds.

title: No Clues Reported in Murder Of 69 GunRing Figure on L I.
description: Suffolk County detectives said yesterday that they were still without a, clue in the fatal shooting Friday of Arthur Needles outside his home in Southampton, L. L

title: SHOP TALK The Human Body As an M or a 4
description: Sometimes people buy Lucille SpirdSmith's lucky numbers and letters of the alphabet pendants: because theynike then; as sculpture. And indeed each oneis a sculpture, in miniature.

title: York College Raises Curtain on Future
What's Doing in the VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: SAFETYOn Sept. 6, 1972, eight persons were senselessly slaughtered at the Fountain Valley Golf Club on St. Croix by a band of black militants. The murdersand several others that followed . quickly caused St. Croix and to a lesser extent St. Thomas to be branded as racially troubled islands despite. years of harmony. As a result, tourism declined drastically. Today the islands seem to have emerged from their long nightmare. There has not been a serious incidentlet alone a murdepon either island in 1974, and 1 feel as safe walking the streets of St. Croix and St. Thomas at night as I do just about any. where.

title: Courttars 0.1. ,Behefits For Most Filipino. Soldiers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 (AP)  Most Filipino soldiers who served with the United States Army in World War II are not entitled to veterans benefits, a Federal District Court has ruled.

title: Music in Review
description: The Concert Artisti Guild's Madeleine Malraux Award winner this year was Gary Steigerwalt, an unusually gifted and unusual pianist. Last Tuesday night he made his deblit at Carnegie Recital Hall, playing a refreshing program that promised well for his career.

title: Westbury Pace Marred By Spills
description: WESTBURY, LI., Nov. 16 Two separate, threehorse accidents left only two finishes in the opening contest at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: The South Africans and Apartheid Today
It's Thanksgiving in Country Time
Editors Choice
description: Fiction

title: Auctioneers in State Seeking Licensed Status
description: RUMSONSptirred by the upswing in the popularity of public sales, a bill to license New Jersey's 350 fulltime and part time auctioneers may be enacted by the first of the year, according to B. G. Coats, head of B. G. Coats & Associates here.

title: Invisible Cities
description: Invisible Cities is a new book by Italy's most original storyteller, Italo Calvino. But this time not a book of stories. Something more.

title: I Fought the Good Fight, but the House Won
description: The house has won. Determining score or margin of victory is difficult, but the telling blow came with the call to the lawn service. Until that point, I had deluded myself into believing that I was in control. That I, after a lifetime of urban landlorddependency, could stage a successful occupation of a onefamily house, fight off attacks of weeds and beetles, clear away leaders and gutters and stand conqueringly tall on a green, plushcarpet lawn, proud that no carpenter, bricklayer or painter had lain a $15anhour hand on my property.

title: New Pact Ratified at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 16The members of Local 35 of the Federation of University Employes at Yale University last night ratified a new threeyear contract, with the school. The 1,100member union had been without a contract since April 30.

title: Tana V. Ulmer Will Be Bride
description: Tana Virginia Ulmer and James Teasdale Hitch 3d, who is in his final year at Harvard Law School, plan to be married May 31 at the Metropolitan Memorial Methodist Church in Washington.

title: Free Concert Slated for Fair Lawn Dec.1
description: FAIR LAWNMembers of the New York Philharmonic filrcheitra and Isadore Freeman, concert pianist, present a concert of chamber music at the Fair Lawn Publie Library on Dec. 1. The concert, which will begin at 730 P.M., is being sponsored by the borough. There is no admission charge.

title: Dubins Have Daughter
description: A daughter was born Oct. 10 to Dr. and Mrs. Michael R. Dubin of Mill Neck, LI., in the Community Hospital at Glen Cove, Li. Mrs. Dubin is the former Paulette Fritz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Fritz of Huntington, L.I. The child, the couple's second daughter; is named Nancy Ellen. Her father, chief, of respiratory therapy at the. Community Hospital,. is a fellow of the American College of Chest Physicians and of the American College of Physicians.

title: SEPARATIST GROUP TRIED IN ARMENIA
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 16The Soviet authorities have held a series of trials in Armenia to crush a separatist movement existing in the Caucasian republic, the physicist Andrei D. Sakharov has reported.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Collectors in the New York metropolitan area whose only interest is American coins might as well plan to relax at home during the first week of December. The entire period from Monday, Dec. 2, through Sunday, Dec. 8, will be filled with activities deVated to collectors of ancient and modem foreign coins.

title: ANTIOCH PUTS OFF DECISION ON CHIEF
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Nov. 16The continued tenure of Antioch College's president, James P. Dixon, after seeming to be in serious doubt over the last two weeks, Will apparently not be considered by the Board of Trustees at its semiannual meeting here next week.

title: RAYMOND E.RYAN,67, REAL ESTATE BROKER
description: Raymond E. Ryan, a real, estate broker here for almost, 50 years, died Friday at his home, 535 East 86th Street. He was 67 years old.

title: American Chippendale Chairs Bring Record $207,500
description: A set of five American Chippendale chairs, a focus at auction yesterday for major collectors and dealers from all parts of the country, proved that, even in a recession great things bring great prices. The chairs, which posted, a record for a native set, bringing $207,500, were purchaied for an unnamed client by Israel Sack, Inc., of New York.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The Bully Chop House, Route 303, Congers, N.Y. (914) CO 86555.

title: ART VIEW;
Thoughts on reading about a summercamp cabin covered with garbage
description: I can think of no more enlightening commentary on that perplexing topic, The American Moral Condition Today, than a long report which appeared The New York Times last Sept. 2. Under the heading, A Coed Camp That's Run Like a Mountain Resort, the reporter gives us a glowing account Camp Keowa, N.Y a camp for 200 teenage boys and girls ruh by the highschool division of the Boy Scouts of America. It is a quite radical departure from the Boy Scout camps of yesteryear. There are no uniforms, and no bugles are blown for reveillebecause, the reporter explains, teenagers are too sophisticated for that kind of stuff these days. The campers go to bed when they please, rise when they please and pass the day as they please. The only rules are no drugs, no liquor and no coed showers. According to the reporter, the kids absolutely loved this new kind of camp, and the final paragraph of the story consists of the following enthusiastic endorsement by one of the campers:

title: Ideas
description: The American adults who run the Little League haVe accomplished what American boys have not been able to do for the last four years: keep the Taiwan team from winning the Little League Wild Series. The league's board of directors has simply declared that foreign teams will no longer,be allowed to compete.

title: Orchestra That Teaches
description: Back In 1962, while Martin Dreiwitz of Sea Cliff, a trained musician and frustrated conductor, was giving a clarinet lesson, his pupil began to complain. I've gotten this far, said the student, and now I must wait years, until I get into a major orchestra; before I get some really good experience. Where do I go from here?

title: Reception to the Kissinger Plan Has Been Cool
description: LONDONThere can be few issues which have aroused so much passion so many words, as oil. Ever since the producers first broke up the traditional pricenegotiating mechanism a year ago,. the world has been filled with argument over whether oil prices would fall or continue to rise, over how the oil states would spend their revenues and how the financial institutions of the world should be adjusted to recycle their surplUs funds, over how the energy crisis was to be beaten.

title: Exemption on Bias Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) A key Government official predicted Wednesday that Congress would exempt college fraternities and Girl Scout groups from the law against sex discrimination. Peter E. Holmes, director of the Office for Civil Rights, said the Administration could be expected to support attempts to exempt service and social organizations.

title: Connors, Net Victor In London

title: Bittersweet
description: Along the winding country roads and up in the edge of the woods the bittersweet dangles its clustered berries, their pale husks now open and the bright orange berries revealed. They are like midNovember flowers in the leafcrisp evening of the year, brighter than the haws of the wild roses, far more generous than the lacquerred berries of their creeper neighbors, the partridge berries. Bittersweet berries and sumac heads are the bright bangles of the brushiand.
