title: The West as historical necessity
description: The New Country is the result of some 35 years of travel in and study of the American Westa serious, detailed and obviously affectionate attempt at an appreciation of the material reality of Western settlement. Bartlett summarizes the succession of frontiers that marched from Appalachia to California, then devotes a series of chapters to general treatment of aspects of Western life: demography, agronomy, the technology of wagon, plow, rifle and axe, transportation, ecology and family life. Although an effort is made to distinguish between the differing lifestyles, Bartlett's emphasis is, on what he sees as the unity or wholeness of the frontier experience of common folk in the

title: 2,000 Miles Long, It Has Both Economic and Military Significance

title: First an Undeclared War Nowan Unseen Film

It is the work of Peter Davis, who made controversial 1971 television documentary The Selling of the Pentagon, The new film, "Hearts and Minds, is a docurnentary dealing with this country's involvement in vietnam It is a montage of the foolishness; tragedy and sheer horror in Vietnam contrasted selfabsorbed complacency of many Americans at home; It leaves audiences hi a state of moral and emotional shock arid has become a cause: alebre among people of no mean celebrity theniselves and a minor scandal for Columbia Pictures.

title: Hackensack Is Regaining Old Vitality

Despite its importance as the Bergen County seat, Hackensack seemed to have lost its vitality in the last two decades, especially after major shopping centers opened on nearby highways and lured the crowds that once thronged Main Street.

title: As soon as they put the box over their heads, they become no one. Being no one means at the same time that one can be anyone  Kobo Ab, Japan's foremost fiction writer
description: All you need to become a Box Man is a large, empty carton. You remove its bottom, cut out peep hole, get yourself some toilet articles, and hang them all up inside. Get inside, and you are Box Man. The soft darkness of your new abode will immediately relax you. It will shelter you not only from the rain and cold hut from the piercing stares of the hostile world, while permitting you to stare back at people through the hole. Now stand up. and just walk away from it alffrom the worries and cares of your Compulsory Life.

title: Future Social Events
description: Let's Be Friends Nov. 18November may be drear, but City Center should be dear to every New Y6rker because it was founded by the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia and cultureconscious confreres to bring a high level of performingart forms to the people at prices they could afford. Prices have risen, and so has the cultural level. You can help perpetuate this leveland enjoy a sample by joining the Friends of City Center at their ninth annual matinee luncheon in the New York State Theater. You'll see on stage Edward Villella of the New York City Ballet and Judith Jamison of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater, and you'll listen to the New York City Opera Children's Chorus. Then, a sumptuous luncheon in the Promenade. If you crave the Gloria Vanderbilt napery, you can buy it. Tickets, $25, and you can snake last

Those bottles and bowls everyone is planting are summed up in Weibsterian terms, as a derivation from the Latin word, terra, for earth. Actually, this garden of small plants enclosed in a glass description originally applied to the Wardian Case, the forerunner of the contemporary bottle gardening boom.

title: Mayor Gets His Car. Back

Mr. Taylor left the car parked with the keys in the ignition. Somebody stole it It was found abandoned Wednesday on a city street.

title: Cowboys Play the Redskins And a 40YearOld Jorgensen
description: Almost all if not all pro football players are expected to practice each.week provided they are ambulatory. Rehearsal is the heart of this cerebral game. That is why today's. pivotal contest in the National Football League, the Red skins against the Cowboys in Washington, has a unique quality. The man likely to become the central figure, a redhaired 40yearold with yards of brown Ace bandage rolled around each pink freckled knee and thigh, ignored praptice this last week.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The Art Deco avalanche is on. The period and its products are being flirted with by the popular press, puffed by dealers in nostalgia and apotheosized in a series of forthcoming books. The subject is also being celebrated right now in an exhibition at Finch. College called American Art Deco Architecture. The timing is just right. The, show serves to put the movement into proper focus in the broad terms of American building of the 1920's and 30's, with emphasis on what is increasingly called the Skyscraper Style.

title: The charge was stealing nuclear secrets
description: The title, like much of this book, is misleading. It is about onethird prison memoir and twothirds polemic. In 1951, Morton Sobell was charged with conspiracy to steal nuclear secrets, found guilty, and sentenced to 30 years in a Federal prison; the other defendants were Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who were executed at Sing Sing in 1953, amid protest in almost every corner of the globe. Sobel! maintains the absolute innocence of all three. It is hard to see how he could be sure about the Rosenbergs, for although they had once been part of the same circle in New York, he had little to do with them during the war and postwar years. In maintaining his own innocence, he seems to have the better of the argument. He had fled to Mexico in 1951 because he and his wife had falsely signed nonCommunist affidavits in order to hold on to their jobs and feared their perjuries might be uncovered. Mexican police came knocking on their door one night. He was badly beaten,, and the whole familyhe, his wife and two childrenwere taken to the northern border and delivered to the Feds. He was wanted, he later learned, on the conspiracy charge. According to Sobell, it was a time when none of the regular defenders of Communists would

title: Pennsylvania Colonial
description: To most Americans, Colonial conjures up visions of saltboxes and white clapboarded New England houses, but the lesserknown fieldstone and stuccooverstone Colonials of the midAtlantic states are their equals in charm and design. A pocket of these handsome stone dwellings dating from 1725 to 1750 survives in Bucks and Chester Counties, two of the three counties originally founded by William Penn. (The third was Philadelphia,)

title: Leakey is a legend, even according to Leakey

This chronicle of Leakey's middle years has passed through too many filters to preserve the man as he must have been. Leakey wrote the memoirs near the end of his life, 20.40 years after the events he describes. The harshness of life turns sweet in distant memory; how else could we tolerate it so cheerfully? Leakey, who was never accused of modesty, makes it sweeter still. He com

title: A Tory on Values
description: BIRMINGHAM, EnglandThe aspect of the Tory approach that I wish to discuss here tonight relates. to the family. and to civilized values. They are the foundation on which the nation is built; they;are being undermined. If we cannot restore them to health, our nation can be utterly ruined, whatever economic policies we might try to. follow.

They are searching the junior colleges and openly inviting some of the disgruntled talent there to come home.

title: Food vs. Population
description: With the agreement to establish a World Food Council to deal with shortand longterm problems of shortages and hunger, the World, Food Conference has ended on a more positive note than seemed possible only a few days ago. The Rome gathering left many disappointments, however, notably the failure of the United States make a firm commitment for increased emergency food aid and, most ominous for the future, Pope Paul's retrogressive attempt to unlink the problems of food and population.

title: Slake's Limbo; By Felice Holman. 117 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $5.95. (Ages 10 to 14)
description: Most of us, I think, remember the hideaways of our youthan attic, backyard cubbyhole made from branches and cardboard, a secret tent of clothing in a littleused closetfriendly, secure places where we took ourselves and our troubles whenever we were feeling hurt, rejected or afraid. The urge is deep, the imagery intensely Freudian.

title: A Williams Tigress
description: Tennessee Williams's Battle of Angels has last been taken from the shelf where it has reposed since the Theater Guild opened it In Boston and left it there in 1940, giving us our longdelayed opportunity  at the Circle Repertory Company's new outlet on Sheridan Square  to see what Mr. Williams's very first fulllength work may have been like. Actually, its repose has not been entirely easy: Mr. Williams reworked it into the: much more mythically ambitious, symboldrenched Orpheus Descending midway in his career,. with not much greater popular success. All the same, it's an eyeopener.

title: STAMPS

description: Joseph S. Kutrzeba, the embattled producer and artistic director of thee Queens Playhouse, Inc., has resigned from. that borough's first, nonprofit professional theater to pursue a career as a Broadway producer.

title: Mao's Location In Provinces Poses Peking Puzzle
description: PEKING, Nov. 16  Nororally Mao Tsetung lives in a modest villa beside a willowfringed lake in the center of Peking. But since early September, visiting foreign leaders have been flown out of the capital in the utmost secrecy to meet the Communist party chairman somewhere in the province's.

title: 3 AIRMEN CONVICTED IN TORTURE MURDERS
description: FARMINGTON, Utah, Nov. 16 (UPI)  An allwhite jury convicted ,.three black airmen today in the robbery, torture and murder of a group of whites in.the basement of an Ogden stereo store.

title: Supership
description: When The New Yorker featured two long and frightening articles on supertankers by Noel Mostert last May, they had a stunning impact. But excellent as they were, Mostert's articles only hinted at the eloquence and power of his finished book, Supership. With their indictment of tanker safety standards and their warning of the ecological dangers the huge ships pose, the articles interweave the best traditions of Ralph Nader and Rachel Carson. But the book takes this basic expos and turns it into real literature, a story of ships, sailors and the sea narrated with an unselfconscious skill that Conrad or Melville might have envied.

title: Best Seller List
A Pair of Charlies Log 50,000 Miles for Honors
description: Many exhibitors in the dogshow world have had their start in obedience. To train a dog takes time, patience and a devotion to one's pet. At trials, week after week, obedience devotes and their dogs, regardless of weather, are working for degrees. Whereas in the breed ring, if there a downpour, the judge will look over the dogs under tent, the hardy obedience performers go through their long sits and downs, leap fences and run through the various other exercises in the open.

title: BRIDGE
Whitman Is Among 3 Victors Crowned
The fashion Industry Gets Dose of Hard Truth
description: The fashion industry was tossed a few hard truths about consumer opinion on Friday, but whether it will field the ball or fumble it, remains to be seen.

title: Noted Science Writer Finds the Perfect Place to Think
description: EAST HANPTON  For most of his 60 years, Dr. Lewis Thomas, the widely known science writer and head of the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer center in New York, has been smiling stone.

title: The Dollar Man; By Harry Mazer. 204 pp. New York Delacorte Press. $5.95. (Ages 12 to 15)
description: Marcus Rosenbloom is fat and he daydreams. He has a large fantasy life and a large rubber tire of fat around his gut. Both seem to be the result of an understandable, greedy emotional hungerthe acute longing of adolescence  for love, identity, communication, roots. Fourteenyearold Marcus's search for selfidentity takes the form of a search for his father, whom he has never known. His mother, Sally, is unmarried, charmingly forthright in personal style, and stubbornly selfsufficient, but she gives Marcus nothing of his fathernot a picture, not a name.

title: DANCE VIEW CLIVE BARNES
description: Agnes de Mille is a natural force in the dance world. She is both feisty and patrician, argumentative and sentimental, loyal and cantankerous. She has one of the very best minds in ballet. Few people write so gracefully or so interestingly about dance. Her prose is lean and sinewy, full of opinions but always laced with a sometimes deadly, always engaging wit. As a member of many dance committees, she is as effective as a tank against cavalry. Combative and superbly armed with a bulidoggedness that would have done Churchill credit, de Mille is a brilliant fighter for dance causes. Her years on the Committee for the National Endowment for the Arts, for example, were notable for the advance of dance funding. She is also dazzling as a lecturer. She talks from the hip, is terribly funny and beautifully articulate, yet still has.a common touch that audiences identify with.

title: The Glory and The Dream
description: This fluent, likeable, can'tputitdown narrative history of America from the Bonus Army to Watergate is popular history in our special tradition of literary merchandising. It is all about the audience that will read it. Mr. Manchester is a steadier and more reliable source on American vicissitudes than photograph books, Theodore H. White, Time and Life, Frederick Lewis Allen, The New York Times OpEd page, Norman Mailer, Betty Friedan, Peanuts et al. But his real virtue is not just that he is a dependable fact man with an eye for the unexpected fact and that he tells his story with all the ease of a practiced rewrite man who has been inspired by Dos Passos. He is really obsessed by the American audience, the great American consensus, the mass, the popular mind itself. He is confident that there is an allpresent character called the American people and that he can describe 40 years of simultaneous experience. He identifies with this character and makes you believe that your whole life has been lived inside it. Reading Manchester, you run with the Bonus Army, lift up your chin like Roosevelt, put up the flag at Two Jima, and nervously dismiss MacArthur. You are against Communism and the Cold War. You participate!

title: A Place to Plant, Yearround
Clements Tallies On Keeper for Victory

title: STAGE VIEW WALTER KERR
description: I am afraid the most devastating thing I can say about Congreve's Love for Love is that the Phoenix production is a good one. Certainly. Harold Prince's staging of the late 17thcentury manners comedy now in revival at the Helen Hayes is thoughtful when it should be (there's a nice candlelit delicacy about the heroine's rueful conclusion, The pleasure of a masquerade is done when we come to show our faces) and bumptious most of the rest of the time (seafaring Ben, tight red curls topping his peajacket, backslapping old friends till one expects to see them collapse like jackknives). Certainly the performers blow Congreve's cool prose through what seem silver straws, making balanced sentences liquid and wrapping their lips about syllables as though to savor the last naughtily insinuating drop. And certainly the visual side of things, with a wench's goldandumber bonnet looking as though. a tropical hilt bad alighted upon it while she was passing through a rainforest and Douglas Higgins's necessarily crowded living quarters adroop with lowering antlers and polished huntinghorns, reflects and reinforces the bedtime busyness of the play. But, with virtues showing; Love for Love much fun.

title: Travel Is Destroying a Major Reason for Travelling
description: HEN you're taught European history in school, your attention is so focused on the upheavals of migrations, Crusades, explorers and wars that you're made to forget how rare a thing travel used to be there. Indeed, until our present age, only soldiers, sailors, wandering merchants and craftsmen traveled joined, from the 18th century on, by a tiny coterie of rich Englishmen and other eccentrics. The myriad customs and even languages of the Continent show how immobile the human race by nature and necessity was or had become since prehistoric nomadic days. The smallest barriera river, heath, swamp or hillside, even, a juridical borderlinewas enough to create separate environments, each with its own unique characteristics. If one of the essences of civilization is diversity, human immobility has been a necessary condition

title: Possibly the greatest
description: There is an idea, to which I think Jean Renoir would subscribe, that it is natural for the major talents of a time and place to express themselves in the major art forms of that time and place: to paint frescoes in Renaissance Italy, to compose symphonies in 18th century Austria, to write Victorian novels, or to direct movies. This isn't to suggest that there is much value in such pious concepts as The Art Form of Our Times"; but it is to deflate, at least slightly, the aura of sanctity that in some circles still hangs over the idea of the artist's vocation. The greatest artists never finish with their forms because they never run out of things to discover in them: indeed, that is one definition of their greatness. But such artists could well have gone into something else and, often enough, before their lives they do.

title: Preferences
description: Among the countless anthologies of poetry are ones in which the poet chooses a favorite from his own poems, or in which the author and his fellow poets provide commentary on a poem; or in which photographs of the poets appear prominently. Now Richard Howard has taken upon himself the original, ambitious and demanding task of inviting 51 contemporary American poets to select a single preference from their own work and put it together with poetry from the pastEccleslastes, Dante, Campion, Emerson. Mr. Howard then undertakes, in a few hundred words for each pair of poems, to elucidate the fit, the interesting relation thus made. Thomas Victor's accomplished photographs are there, in Howard's prefatory words, as a model of interpretation, of illumination in that the poet is led to disclose himself without the interposition of Mr. Victor's Prefernces."

title: A Dance to Still Music; By Barbara Corcoran. Illustrated by Charles Robinson. 180 pp. New York Atheneum. $6.95. (Ages 10 to 14)
description: Not all desperate teenage runaways have the good fortune to run straight into the arms of exactly the right person to help them.., Barbara Corcoran's heroines generally do. With a lesser author, this could be simply slick plotting, but with Barbara Corcoran the very fortuitousness is, I think, part of the message at the core of her writing. Trust life, she says. Go into the world. There'll be good people out there as well as bad. There'll be help. She handles her theme like a prism, holding it up to catch the light at different angles, turning it this way and that so that each book is a fresh experience and a variation of the pattern.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE
description: HOW do you take the cyclical swings out of the apparel business? By, running it as though it were less susceptible to swings, says Robert W. Roth, president of Jantzen, Inc.

description: If you chance upon some prosperous gentleman weeping softly into his cognac glass at the Plaza, it may be that he is mourning the passing of those glittering high yields in Treasury bills.

title: Traditional; (with a foreign accent)
description: If there is one menu that most Americans tendand with reasonto be sentimental about, it that for Thanksgiving. We know of homes where that particular holiday's menu has remained more or less stable for the past quarter century. On these pages we offer a Thanksgiving menu based partly on a longremembered Southern reciperoast turkey filled with corn bread stuffingplus a few trimmings of European inspiration. These include Brussels sprouts in cream, braised red cabbage with chestnuts and gratined potatoes. A slight departure from tradition, this menu may he yet another reason for giving thanks.

description: A chain of 320 vocational schools has agreed to refund up to $1.25million to students who completed training but were unable to get jobs.

The project will mark a departure for the partners, most of whose seven earlier films concentrated on Indian subjects such as the The Householder and Shakespeare Wallah.

title: Manson meets The Bug
description: This inmate will no doubt be in serious difficulty soon, wrote the orientation officer at Terminal Island Prison in California, when, in 1956, 22yearold Charles Manson entered the facility to begin a threeyear sentence. He is young, small, babyfaced, and unable to control himself... the officer observed. Manson had expressed one preference with regard to his work assignment: ...a small detail where he is not with too many men. He states that he has a tendency to cut up and misbehave if he is around a gang.... Manson, a decade later, found his ultimate ganga pack of mindblown runaways, very young and mostly female, detritus of the psychedelic midsixtiesand, with their unquestioning obedience, Manson managed his ultimate cutups: a spate of savage, mindless murderssome, almost certainly, as yet unsolvedthat culminated in 1969, one hot August weekend in Los Angeles.

title: Sell! Sell!  Builders Try Discounts and Gimmicks
Book Ends
description: December. Although the stores are currently bursting with sumptuous picture books for the Christmas trade and December is the most important sales month of the entire year, as far as new titles go the month is barren one. The main reason for this is that the bookstores have already stocked up heavily on gift books and current best sellers and about now are reluctant to order more, nervously wondering if their eyes were not bigger than their customers pocketbooks. Consequently, the publishers trot out what they consider to be their most salable wares by November and the rest of the year is silence. A few books trickle out but we shall omit their titles here rather than invidiously scar those authors sentenced to the December dungeon.

title: Bobby Allison Has Another Try To Post a Big. Victory, in 1974
description: Bobby Allison has won million dollars racing automobiles and he'd be the last person to tell you he's been successful. Which is to say, heaven knows Mr. Allison has won a lot of races (at last count almost 400) but it's been a long time between victories on the Grand National trail. The 36yearold Southern gentleman has one last try this season in the Los. Angeles Times 500 next Sunday at Ontario, Calif. Allison's only Grand National victory this year was on the halfmile Richmond oval, but things are due to improve. The 1972 driver of the year has found it difficult reaching the winner's circle since leaving Junior Johnson's team and heading out on his own. Now he's back working for someone elseRoger Penske and the American Motors Matadorand with the problems of running the team on someone else's shoulders Allison can concentrate again on driving.

title: Where to Wallow in Whisky and Stay Sober
Sunday Observer
description: Recently I discovered that was going sane. It was surprisingly pleasant. There were weeks unbroken by fits of melancholia, rage, anxiety, despair, hypochondria or terror. Life, inexplicably, seemed worth living again, and I went through my daily rounds whistling Redwing instead of bristling with hostility and perspiring with fear that my deodorant might not keep me safe alt day long.

title: Time to End Sports, Opiate of the Masses
description: Karl Marx once described religion as the opiate of the masses. Well, Marx went away too soon or he might have revised his dictum to make organized sports the villain of the piece. There is nothing that comes close to sports in the seizure of men's souls, in the fanning of fanaticism, in the proliferation of tedium. Bring back religion. Bring back drink. Bring back sex. But it is time to bench sports.

title: It's possible to be as happy in old age as at 40
description: The young man was good, but as sometimes happens with reporters, he told me more than he needed to about why he was doing the story. While he didn't say it in so many words, I gathered that his editor's assignment went something like this: I want you to do a piece on an old party. He retired in 1969, at the age of 62, and has taken up a new career as a writer. He collects things. He's surprisingly active for someone almost 68 years old. (The editor, learned later, is 44.)

Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The loves in her life
description: At a time when feminism is flourishing and Freud is enjoying a new respectability in its ranks, this novel about a 34year old intellectual whose justdiscovered sexuality turns her life around might seem to offer intriguing possibilities. Instead, reading it made me feel as though I'd walked up to a handsomelydecorated building and, a couple of hours later, found myself dumped smartly into the back alley, glaring hack in wonder that the facade had turned out to he hollow and most of the inhabitants glib hired hands. Let us at once avoid confusion: female sexuality is hardly the private property of female writers (both the author and the publishers hint modestly that his subject matter here makes him heir to Hardy), but Alan Lelchuk's exploitation of its concept in this novel leaves readers holding a bag of demonstration sex scenes and pretentious modern moralizing while the author has slipped out to the latest Sam Peckinpah/Clint

description: A worker who is receiving partial permanent disability compensation for the statutory period and who becomes totally disabled will be entitled to full disability payments, according to.a New Jersey Supreme Court ruling. Before 1967, an injured worker usually did not press for permanent disability because there was only $5aweek difference between it and partial disability. But beginning in 1975 permanent totaldisability payments will be $119 a week, while partial payments remain at $40.

Darryl Bal. doni, 16 years old, and Bruce Bertrand, 18, were dead on arrival at St. Raphael's Hospital, in New Haven. Gordon Shandiler, 14, was in serious condition at the hospital. description: PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 17 (AP)A Japanese filching vessel detained two months in Portland Harbor on charges of violating American coastal fishing limits has sailed for home. The Taiyo Maru departed early yesterday after a $425,000 general bond was posted.

title: Saxbe Says F. B.I. failed to Disclose Antiradical Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) Attorney General William B. Sexbe said today that the Federal BUreau of Investigation apparently failed to report regularly to the Attorney. General on its counterintelligence program aimed at radical and extremist groups.

title: Watergate Jury Seeks Truth, But Gets Only Approximation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17The jury at the Watergate coverup trial has now heard 24 witnesses and 11 tape recordings in five weeks of testimony. It has heard squabbles among the attorneys. And it has heard Judge John J. Sirica say that the point of the trial is to get the truth and the complete picture.

title: Issue and Debate

Garrett Jr. chairman of the S.E.C., and kick off one of the most important battles in the history of Wall Street.

title: MONITOR ON MOON ENDING 5TH YEAR
description: An automated observatory on the surface of the moon, which had been expected to go off the air three or four years ago, is this week completing five years of transmitting back to scientists on earth Information about meteorite impacts, moon quakes, and other lunar phenomena.

title: Coal Strike Nearly Week Old; No Talks Held During Recess
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The sixth day of the nationwide coal strike passed today with no action by the United Mine Workers of America, the industry or the Government.

title: MINERS IN BRITAIN REJECT PAY PLAN
description: LONDON, Nov. 17Britain's miners demonstrated new militancy today by turning down Government proposals that would have paid nem more money for producing more coal.

title: States Get Right to Force Welfare Mothers to Work
description: A virtually unnoticed new Federal action has opened the way for states to compel wetfare mothers to take unpaid public service jobs to work off their relief checks, a staff counsel for the Center on Social Welfare Policy land Law said here yesterday.

title: An AntiInflation Proposal

description: To the Editor: The news media have just reported that King Faisal pledged again tonight that Saudi Arabia would try to keep oil prices at the current level and if possible reduce them, at least symbolically. Our Secretary of State, Henry Kissinger, has stated with regard to this pledge, I would like to express our gratification.

title: SPANISH RIGHTIST RALLIES VETERANS
description: MADRID, Nov. 17One of Spain's most prominent rightists is leading a powerful new group of Civil War veterans In opposition to efforts to liberalize the authoritarian regime.

title: Storm King Termed Dangerous to Bass By Massachusetts
Five Men, Two Voters
19 States Now Agree to Audits Of Funds for Revenue Sharing
Dave Anderson
description: As just about everyone expected, the $3.3million thrust upon Larry Csonka, Paul Warfield and Jim Kiick by the World Football League obViously has spoiled them forever. Anybody promised that kind of money doesn't want to play football: His wallet might suffer torn ligaments. Csonka, surely faking an ankle, injury after;, scoring only two touchdowns, just loafed on the sideline in the final quarter of, the easy 3528 victory over the Buffalo Bills that dropped the Dolphing into first place in the American Con ference East yesterday. Warfield, who hadn't bothered to appear for several games because of a pulled hamstring muscle that didn't even require amputation, caught only one touchdown pass from Bob Gniese for only 49 yards; caught a pass for a mere 54 yards that positioned one of Csonka's reluctant touchdowns and waited until the final minute to catch another pass for a 31yard gain on the Dolphins winning drive. Kiick, who enjoys his weekly naps on the Dolphins bench and who annually has nominated Don Shula as the National Football League's humanitarian of the year, woke up time to maintain the winning desire by agreeing to catch a 12yard pass and deigning to run 11 yards on the next play. Typical of their unfeeling attitude, none of the three did anything beyond jumping out of his skin when Csonka's standin, Don Nottingham, scored the decisive touchdown with seconds of time.

description: Experts said here yesterday that Americans would buy gold bullion strongly next year, but their enthusiasm would begin to wane before the year was over. It will become legal for Americans to own gold bullion after Dec. 31.

Nov. 18 (UPI)More than 758,000 peopie toured the. first lVfonnon Temple built on the East Coast before the building was closed to the public, a church spokes. man said today. The $14mil lion structure will be used exclusively. for Mormon sacred ceremonies starting tomorrow.

title: 2 Realty Groups Agree To End Dictating of Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The Justice Department announced today that it had settled its pricefixing case against the Real Estate Board of New, York and an apartmentowner association, with the two groups agreeing to refrain from dictating what commissions could be charged in realty transactions.

title: Women Fashion Designers Emerging as Leaders Again
description: Making clothes is as traditional an occupation for women as preparing food. Still, women acquire the mantle of influential designer about as rarely as they, don the toque blanche of master chef.

title: Inflation Fighter Perturbed as. Ford Rejects a $25 Gift
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Nov. 18BorisFeinman, a local businessman and city booster, decided one day last month to fight inflation his own way. He sat down and wrote $25 checks to the city, county,.state and Federal governments. All but the Federal Government accepte d the money.

title: Chiefs Defeat Broncos
Policeman Asserts Criticism of Force Led to His Transfer
description: A 15yearveteran of the Po lice Department was transferred from an elite investiga tive unit to routine patrol duty because, he said yesterday, he had sharply criticized the de partment's policies on race am firearms after, the slaying of 14yearold black by a whit policeman.

title: Vouchers Now Help The Dance
description: The Theater Development. Fund which has in the past extended a helping hand to Broadway, has expanded its off OffBroadway voucher program to include dance. The results have been encouraging, both to the fundWhich. has budgeted its 197475 program at $75,000and to the 98 dance companies, which redeemed vouchers for hearly $24,000 in the first six months of 1974,

title: SIDNEY GINSBERG
description: Sidney Ginsberg, a supervising lawyer for the Legal Aid Society's Bronx Supreme Court branch, died Friday of a heart attack at his home, 59 Glen Gray Road, Oakland, N.J. He was 52 yearsold.

title: REPUBLICAN NAMED WINNER IN ALASKA
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Nov. 18 (UPI)Final unofficial totals in the Alaska Governor's race show the Republican challenger, Jay Hammond, defeated Democratic Gov, William A. Egan by 487 votes in the Nov, 5 general election.

title: Setamboat Launching Set
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 18 (AP)The first new steaboat to be built in the United States in half a century will be launched at Jefferson, Ind, on Nov. 30 The owners, the Delta Queen Steamboat Company of Cincin nati, said today the new 400passengers sternwhwwler would not be in service for at least another 10 months.

title: New Books
description: Animals in Pottery and Porcelain by John P. Cushion (Crown Publishers, $12.50). A survey.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A State Supreme Court justice sentenced an 18yearold addict to life in prison for the slaying of a retired police officer in a Times Square subway station on Jan. 14, 1973. In imposing the life sentence, Justice Peter McQuillan Made 15 years mandatory before the defendant would become eligible for parole.

title: FOOD TALK Learning to Cook on Vacation
description: Cooking, schools and wine symposiums have been held in diverse settings in department stores, for instance, and in cellars, vineyards and on ocean liners. Now it's possible to work in some vacation time in Bermuda along with picking up some helpful hints: in the food and drink areas.

title: Hirohito and TAnakA Greet Ford in Tokyo
A Dividend of $1.50 Declared by du Pont
description: E. I. duPont de Nemours & Co., Inc., the world's largest themical producer, declared yesterday a yearend dividend of $1.50 a share payable Dec. 14 to holders of record Nov. 20. This reptesents a drop from the $2 yearend dividend distributed to shareholders a year earlier.

title: Kaiser Steel Dividend Up
description: The Kaiger Steel Corporation announced yesterday in Oakland, Calif that it would pay a quarterly dividend of 37  cents a common share up from 20 cents a share The dividend is payable Dec. 31 to shaerholders of record Dec. 13.

title: Picket Line Honored
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss., Nov. 18 (UPI)Production workers refused today to cross picket lines set up by striking machinists shutting down the Ingalls Shipyard and halting work on dozens of navy, vessels.

title: Pauline McHarg Dies at 51; Fought in. Dutch Resistance
description: Pauline Crena de Iongh McHarg, wife of Ian L. McHarg, chairman of the department of landscape architecture and regional planning at the University Of Pennsylyania, died yesterday of leukemia in Presbyterian Hospital, Philadelphia. She was 51 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: CHANADA WILL CUT PERSONAL TAXES
Ronan Says Rockefeller Made Loans as a Friend
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Dr. William J. Ronan denied today any sinister purpose in the $625,000 in loans and gifts made to him by Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller, which he said were motivated solely by friendship and a lifelong practice of sharing."

title: ITALY GETS TIME  TO REPAY A LOAN
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 18 (UPI)The European Common Market gave Italy today another three years to repay a loan she should have paid next month.

title: PRICING OF STEEL STUDIED BY F.T.C.
$86,000 Stolen in Bomb Threat at Bank
description: A young holdup man who told the manager of a Fifth Avenue bank that he represented a Puerto Rican nationalist organization escaped with $86,000 yesterday after threatening to blow up the bank if the manager did not follow his precise instructions.

title: ARABS PRESS U.N. ON PALESTINIANS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18Arab delegates are seeking support for a proposed resolution by the General Assembly affirming the right of the Palestinians to return to their homes and property.

title: U.S. Baseball Team Shares Lead
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. (AP)The United States, the defender, banged out 10 extfabase hits and coasted to an 111 triumph over. South. Africa today to gain a share first place in the worldamateur baseball tournament. Italy bunched six runs in the seventh inning to, beat Taiwan, 64.

title: New State Drug Law Is Upheld by Court
description: A state appellate court unanimously upheld yesterday the constitutionality of the 1973 state narcotics law, which provides for mandatory life sentences for the sale or possession of a variety of drugs.

title: EUROPEANS CONFIRM NEW ATOM PARTICLE
description: Experiments at Italian and German laboratories have con firmed the existence of a new and mysterious atomic particle whose discovery was reported last week by physicists in California and on the East Coast.

title: Hearing for Activist Priest Put Off in Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 18 (UPI) A hearing for an activist Roman Catholic priest who was charged with disorderly conduct while distributing handbills to support a grape and lettuce boycott at a shopping center here was postponed today when attorneys and the police failed to show up.

title: Coed Status Pleases Vassar Despite Problems
SMUGGLERS  RIGHTS REVOKED IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 18 An unusual Government order that bar imprisoned smugglers from appealing to the courts and revokes their civil liberties for six months was fiercely denounced today in Parliament and the press and among opposition politicians.

title: Music For Ives,Deft 114Song Salute
description: Charles Ives was a many splendored song composer, a point that was made at least 114 times Sunday afternoon at an extraordinary Marathan Salon Concert, Start ing at 2 and extending (with tour short intermissions) to 8:15, soloists from the Gregg Smith Singers held forth in one of the upstairs galleries at the New York Cultural Center, performing the complete set of 114 songs that lves had published privately in 1922, along with, for good measure, other more recent discoveries.

title: OPENING OF CANAL TO ALTER BALANCE
description: The passage of four Egyptian ships halfway dOwn the Suez Canalthis weekend has focused attention on the possible strategic significance for the Middle East, as well as for the United States and the Soviet Union, of the expected reopening of the canal early next year.

title: Despite Alert, Tourists Flock to Golan Heights
description: ON ISRAELISYRIAN DE MARCATION LINE, Nov. 18 Busloads of tourists, mainly American, provide the only visible signs of excitethent at this principal focus of current Middle Eastern tension.

title: Theater: Fame, aComedy Misnamed
Nationwide Delivery Service Grew From Six Messengers 07
description: In a 6 by 17foot basement in Seattl James E. Casey started a messenger service on Aug. 28 1907, with $100, six messengers, two bicycles and a telephone.

title: Price Co. Advises Acceptance of Best  Stock Offer
description: The board of the Price Cornpany announced yesterday in Montreal that it was advising shaieholders who Wish to sell their shares to tender through their brokers with instructions to accept the best offer available. Merger The board was reNews ferring to the offer made last week by Abitioi Paper Company one of the largest producers of pulp and paper in Canada to pay $18 a share for 4.83 million shares of Price Company. The offer which had been due to expire this morning has been extended to 9:45 A.M. tomorrow.

title: A Summary of Various Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
U.S.PLANE MAKER TALKING IN EUROPE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) The General Dynamics Corporation is negotiating with a Belgian company half owned by Matcel Dassault, the French plane maker for the possible production in Europe of its YF16 fighter a company official said today.

title: Death of Plutonium Worker Questioned by Union Official
description: WASHINGTON, NOV. 18A highranking union official said today that the death last week of a woman who had raised crisafety questions about one of the two commercial pinto Biro factories in the United States might not have been an accident.

title: ExRep. Gallagher Due For Parole on Saturday
description: NEWARK, Nov. 18 (AP)Former Representative. Cornelius E. Gallagher will be paroled from prison on Saturday after serving 17 months of a twoyear sentence for tax evasion.

title: Jenkins in a Rut
description: Fergy Jenkins, now with the Texas Rangers, has won 20 decisions during seven of his 10 major league seasons.

title: The winning New Jersey dally lottery number yesterday was:
description: Tickets matching the number win $10,000. Tickets with the five numbers in reverse win $1,000. Tickets with the first Or last four numbers jn order win $225, Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in regimes win $25 Losing tickets are eligible for a special prize drawn on Thursday.

title: $100,000 HUDDLE ELUDES WILSON
description: Governor Wilson Said Yesterday through a spokesman that he had no recollection of a 1959 meeting at which high state Repliblican officials Were allegedly informed by the party chairman, L. Judson Morhouse, of a $100,000 cash contribution in a site box.

title: Arafat Hails Protests By Arabs of West Bank
description: ALGIERS, Nov. 18Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, upon Palestinians on the occupied West Bank of Jordan today to. continue and escalate your resistance and sacrifices in their campaign for independence.

title: Hirohito and Tanaka Greet Ford in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Tuesday; Nov. 19President Ford was formally greeted by EmPeror Hirohito and Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan this morning to begin a state visit to America's major ally in East Asia.

title: Food Parley: Plans Laid for Future Action
description: ROME, Nov. 18Delegates to the World FOod Conference convened here Nov. 5 to try to shape a broad international plan for eradicating hunger By adjournment early yesterday, they had produced a number of reso lutions containing the outline of sys tems that might eventually achieve that vial if developed and fully put into operation.

title: Ford Is Staying in a Remodeled Palace
description: TOKYO, Nov. 18The elegantly remodeled state guest house known as the Geihinkan where President Ford is staying during his three day in Tokyo is an 18thcentury neobaroque striictuce styled after the Versailles Palace.

title: Dow Index Plunges by 22.69; Bond Market Shows Weakness
Dr. Erich Lindemann Dies at 74; Psychiatrist and Social Scientist
description: Dr. Erich Lindemann, an experimental psychiatrist and psychologist who pioneered in applying socialscience approaches to psychiatric problems; died Saturday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: STRIKE IN JERSEY HITS 8 COLLEGES
description: MONTCLAIR, Nov. 18Teachers at New Jersey's eight public fouryear colleges went on strike today in an effort to force the state to renegotiate salaries and increase fringe benefits for 2,800 faculty members on the eight campuses.

title: BUSINESS MAGAZINE SHUT DOWN BY PERU
description: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 18The Peruvian military Government has closed an influential business magazine and arrested leading members of the Lima Bar Association for criticizing a Government contract with Japanese oil companies helping to finance a $500milllon oil pipeline here.

title: DOCTOR FINED $30,000 IN MEDICARE FRAUD
description: A 34yearold physician, who pleaded guilty to submitting false Medicare bills for $1,771, was sentenced yesterday to pay a $30,000 fine, spend one month in jail and offer some free medical aid during his probation for 4 years and 11 months.

title: Mendenhall Case Puzzling
Metamorphosis of Robert Byrd Continues
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18Senator Robert C. Byrd did, not pause to think twice when President Ford telephoned him last August to solicit advice on a nominee for Vice President.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KOKURA, Japan Nov. 18 (AP)A fiverun ninthinning rally, highlighted by home runs by Felix Milian and Teddy Martinez, gave the New York Mets a 9.5 victory over Tokyo's Yomiuri Giants today. It was only the Mets third victory, in 10 exhibition baseball games against the Giants. The two teams also have tied twice, Against all teams including allstar clubs, the Mets have eight victories six losses and two ties with two games remaining in Japanone more against the Giants. Playing before a crowd of 12,000 at Kokura Stadium, Japan's home run King, Sadaharu Oh, hit a homer in the fifth inning, his second of the game, and gave the Giants a 52 lead. The Mets closed the gap to 5.4 with one run in the sixth inning and another in the seventh. Then Millan started the lastinning rally with a gametying home run into the left field stands. Ed Kranepool drove in the tiebreaking run with a sacrifice fly and Martinez followed with a tworun homer.

title: HENRIETTE LIBERMAN
description: Henriette Pascar Liberman, who formerly directed the State Theater for Children in Moscow, died yesterday in Paris, where she had lived since 1924 except during World War II, when she lived in New York.

title: Ronan Prospered As Civil Servant
description: More than 25 years ago, WilHam J.,Ronan, then a fastrising professor at New York University, published, a scholarly report deploring the generally low salaries paid to government executives. Poor wages, he said, had lost the government many able career people.

title: Clive Brook, 87, Suave Briton Of Stage and Screen, Is Dead
description: Clive Brook, the durable actor who epitomized British suavity and elegance in scores of portrayals on the stage and in silent and talking films on both sides of the Atlantic, died Sunday night at his home in London. He was 87 years old.

title: Chess: In His Last Shot as White, Korchnoi Only Draws Again
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 18Viktor Korchnoi spent his last chance with the white pieces tonight in the 23d game of his final candidates Match for the world championship, but he could not budge Anatoly Karpov's defense and had to agree to a draw after 29 moves in Tchaikowsky Ball here.

title: JOSEPH P. RIPLEY, FINANCIER, DEAD
description: Joseph Pierce Ripley, a retired investment banker considered by many to be the dean of Wall Street, died on Sunday. He was 85 years old and lived at 570 Park Avenue here.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: A Deer Rain
description: WENTWORTH LOCATION; N. H.Moaning off Black Mountain across the valley of the Dead Diamond River, and over the high ridge on which I stood watching for deer, the westerly wind was laced with a fine rain.

title: BARAKA ASSAILS NEWARK COUNCIL
description: NEWARK, Nov. 18Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black nationalist whose political influence here has waned since he broke last year with Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, said today that the Newark City Council was attempting to thwart his efforts to build new lowincome housing in the city by denying it a tax abatement.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 45

title: 75 SUGAR QUOTA SET BY PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPOThe White House announced today a sugar import quota for 1975 and urged Americans to reduce their use of sugar in cooking and to cut in half the amount used with coffee and tea.

title: KROL SAYS CHURCH IS STILL VIGOROUS
Briefs on the Arts
description: Mayor Beame visited a motion picture set in Manhattan Yesterday but, to the clamorous disappointment of a waiting crew of news and television photographers, plans to have him pose with the star, Robert Redford, failed to come off.

title: DOLLAR REGISTERS DECLINE EUROPE
NIXON WENT HOME TO SMALLER STAFF
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18Former President Richard M. Nixon went home last week to a somewhat smaller staff than he had when he entered the hospital three weeks earlier.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: OASIS The Tin Palace (6740566), with its friendly bar, fine food, efficient table serv ice and luscious jazz sounds, is a relaxing place to !.be any night. A clean and cbmfortably Bohemian restaurant, with none of the cobweb scruffiness associat ed with East Village hangouts, it's also easy to find, at the corner of the Bowery and Second. Street. Use some brightly lighted beacons: the Amato Opera House next door, the Bowery Lane Thea ter across the street or the WPA Theater a few steps north.

title: PIONEER 11 Is TAKING PICTURES OF JUPITER
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Nov. 18 (AP)Pioneer. 11 began taking pictures of Jupiter and sending them back to earth today as the spacecraft hurtled toward the largest planet in the solar sygtem at 22,000 miles an hour.

title: Miss Hearst Still a Fugitive 6 Months After Reaffirming Allegiance to Kidnappers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18Spring and summer are long gone and, with Thanksgiving near, there is still no trace of Patricia Campbell Hearst after six months.

title: Mayor Prunes a Tree and Suggests It's Easier ThAn Pruning the Budget
description: A fivepiece band struck up The Man On the Flying Trapeze and with that Mayor Beame climbed into the bucket of a cherry picker in Central Park yesterday and officially opened a program to help preserve the city's 2.3 million trees.

title: Stage: Two by O'Neill Center Writers
SituationCrampea In Steelers Camp
description: With playoff pressures mounting and upsets lighting stadium scoreboards every Sunday, it is no wonder that players and coaches let their feelings go. Take Terry Bradshaw, the No. 1 quarterback of the. Pittsburgh Steelefs who suddenly found himself No. 3 last Sunday. Chuck Noll, the coach of a firstplace team living by, its defense, pulled a surprise by starting Terry Hanratty at quarterback About Pro Football

title: CITY BALLET GIVES A TENACIOUS TRIFLE
description: Variations Pour une Porte et Un soupir is a tenacious trifle that has somehow remained in the New York City Ballet's repertory for a second season. Perhaps no one noticed how tedious it was the first time around.

title: TO SOLZHENITSYN, REDS DEBASE ART
description: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, in an assessment of Soviet intellectual life, charges that the Communist system has so debased writers and artists that they will ridicule party dogma among themselves but repeat it in public when asked to do so.

title: SYRIANS AWAITING SOVIET NAVAL UNIT
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 18A Soviet naval flotilla made up of a missile cruiser, a destroyer and a submarine from the Black Sea Fleet is due to arrive Wednesday for a fiveday visit to Latakia, the port where, Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel said Friday, 20 Soviet cargo ships were unloading arms.

title: PAUL S. FARLEY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18 (AP)Paul S. Farley, a former president of the Atlantic County Bar Association, died yesterday in the Atlantic City Medical Center. He was 78 years old.

title: Bridge: A Diagram From the Days When Red Cards Reigned
NEW TOCKS STUDY IS CALLED SHAM
description: TRENTON, Nov. 18Critics of the proposed, Tocks Island edam today assailed a planned $1.5million reevaluation of the $360million project as a waste of taxpayers money.

title: $76.7Million Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) The White House asked Congress today to appropriate 876.7million in additional funds for the Federal Energy Administration, the Agriculture Department, the Interior De partment and the General Services Administration.

title: G.I. Benefits Bill Sent to President In Face of a Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP)  weeks after it gave final approval, Congress sent to the White House legislation to in crease G.I. education benefits by 22.7 per cent for 10 million Vietnamera and. postKorea veterans.

title: A FORD MESSAGE URGES CONGRESS TO ACT SPEEDILY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The White House greeted the reconVening 93d Congress today with a Presidential message asking for prompt consideration of a streamlined action program for the nation.

title: Colbert Traded In 3Team Deal
description: SAN. DIEGO, Nov. 18 (UPI) Nate Colbert, once regarded as one of the premier homerun hitters in the National League, was traded by the San Diego padres to the Detroit Tigers tonight in a complicated threeteam, eightplayer transaction.

title: Phone Company Will Seek $350Million Rise in State
description: The New York Telephone Company, citing inflation, announced plans yesterday to seek an annual rate increase of $350million to $400million so it could get 15 per cent to 20 per cent more revenue next year.

title: House Panel Pushes Bill to Phase Out Oil Depletion Tax Allowance by 1979
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The conservatives who control the House Ways and Means Committee, attempting to head off possibly harsher action by the Congress that takes office in January, moved swiftly today to push legislation through the present Congress that would increase taxes paid by the oil industry.

title: City Planners Alter Zoning to Preserve Wild Tracts on S.1
description: A new zoning concept to preserve natural features in parts of the city that are still reli tively countrified was adopten6 unanimously yesterday by. tb; City Planning Commission.

title: 22 Are Arrested As Racial Clashes Contnue in Beacon
description: BEACON, N.Y., Nov. 18 (AP) The police arrested at least 22 youths in an attempt to prevent confrontations between groups of whites and blacks armed with knives and clubs in a third day Of racial tensions here today.

title: Saxbe Says Top Officials Had Some Knowledge of F.B.I.'s Drive to Disrupt Various Political Group
A Select Audience Hails Yevtushenko
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 18Yevgeny Yevtushenko Who raised eyebrows recently by twitting the children of the Soviet elite for their hedonistic bourgeois tastes and life style, warmed the hearts of the Establishment yesterday with an evening of lyrical love songs, patriotic, war poems and hymns to the Motherland.

title: Housing Starts off a Bit; Leveling Might Not Last
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Housing starts declined slightly in October, marking the second consecutive month of virtually no change, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Steuben Glass: The Look Is Different
description: When Thomas S Buechner quietly took command of Steuben Glass two years ago, he announced no changes and outlined no new design direction. But Steuben's wares have changedand dramatically. Not the lead crystal itself, mind you, That sophisticated material, developed decades ago by technicians at Corning Glass Works, the parent company, is still possibly the purest ever produced. And it's not the craftsmanship either. The skills of Steuben's artisans remain the envy of artisans everywhere.

title: State Drafts a Rule to speed Payments
description: The State Insurance Department yesterday proposed regulations to speed and in some cases, increase payments for auto collisiondamage claims, long a source of complaints by consumers.

title: High Costs End CanAm Auto Racing
description: The CanAm Monsters have been slain by inflation, it was announced yesterday in Denver.

title: JOHN J. BURKE
description: John J. Burke, who retired in 1969 as principal of the evening division of Charles Evans Hughes High School, died Sunday at the Todd Nursing Home in Southampton, L. I. He was 68 years old and lived in Hampton Bays, L. I

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A Nov. 4 Times editorial quotes E.P.A. Deptity Director Quarles's statement that cars are the."core of the energy problem. The editorial suggests the core of the solution is commitment and tough talk from President Ford. I agree On both counts. But automobiles do more than merely guzzle precious petroleum.

title: Why Rush To Change The 25th?
description: President Ford is off to the Orient. in: a Russian fur hat that brought to mind nothing so much as Cal Coolidge, another Republican political accident who had a penchant for funny headgear in the White House. Since Congress has not yet confirmed Nelson Rockefeller as Vice President, Mr. Ford is taking some criticism for leaving the country, legislators are being accused of dangerous dawdling, and the 25th Amendment itself is certainly under fire.

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Auction
Honeywell Raises Keyboard Prices In 2 Major Lines
description: Honeywell Raises Keyboard Prices In 2 Major Lines Price increases for its two major lines of solid state keyboards were announced yesterday by the microswitch division of Honeywell, Inc. The 1975 delivery prices of its original SW line will be at current prices or about $70, rather than at the 10 per cent reduction announced a year ago. The lowprofile SD line scheduled for volume prodtiction on July 1, 1975, will sell for about 10 per cent below 1974 prices or about $62, rather than the predicted 20 per cent reduction.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan yesterday repudiated his support of a plan to move the condemned Towers Nursing Home to East Harlem and to double its revenue from Medicaid.

title: Japanese Ship Released
description: PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 18 (AP)A fishing vessel is steming toward its home port in Japan after two months of detention in Portland Harbor on charges of violating United States coastal fishing limits. The Taiyo Maru departed Saturday after posting a $425,000 general bond. The ship's captain, who pleaded not guilty to the charges last month, was released Friday on a $25,000 bond.

title: Development of Aluminum Industry Foreseen by New foundland Premier
description: Premier Frank D. Moores of Newfoundland predicted in an Interview here yesterday that his province would have a going aluminum industry just after the end of this danacte.

title: Excerpts From Three White House Tapes Played. at Watergate CoverUp Trial
Afrikaners Run Things Their Way, but Don't Always Agree on What It Is
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 18  Cracks are beginning to appear in the flinty surface of Afrikanerdom as a struggle over ideology and power develops among the Afrikaners, who dominate South African life and politics.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE FABULOUS EGO; Absolute Power in History. By Milton Klonsky. 436 pages. Illustrated. Quadrangle. $15.

title: Charles Rose Is Dead at 88; Ring's Broadway Charley
description: Charles Rose, known In boxing circles as Broadway Charley for almost 70 years, died Saturday night as the result of smoke inhalation from a fire earlier at his room in the President hotel. The former boxer, trainer, manager and promoter was 88 years old.

title: Pressmen Accept L. I. Pact
description: A twoyear contract to expire next March 30 was ratified Sinday by the printing pressmen employed at the Long Lsland plant in Jamaica, Queens. The aPproval by an 81to19 vote, was announced yesterday by William J. Kennedy, president of Printing Pressmen's Local 2. The settlement provides tivo retroactive annual wage increases of $13.85 each in weekly pay.

title: Boston Historical Sites Held Needing $27Million Repair
description: BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP)The National Park Service says that many of Boston's most famous historical sites are in such bad shape that it will take at least $27million to put them in shape for the nation's bicentennial celebration in 1976.

title: People and Business Merrill Chief. Recession Grows
Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street; 7:35 (TelevisionChannel (H), cable, 7:30 P.M.)

title: JerusalemProtest by the Arbabs Meets Israeli Crackdown
description: JERUALEM, Nov. 18Israeli riot policemen and Soldiers battled stone throwing crowds in the former Arabsector of Jerusalem today as demonstrations in favor of Palestinian independence continued on the occupled West Bank for the sixth consecutive day.

title: 8 Jersey State College Hit by faculty Walkout
description: MONTCLAIR, Nov. 18 Teachers at New Jersey's eight public fouryear colleges went on strike today in an effort to force the state to renegotiate salaries and increase fringe benefits for 2,800 faculty members on the eight campuses.

title: U.S. Proposes Fund in Payments Crises
description: PARIS, Nov 18 Following up a new push by the United States for closer cooperation by major oil consumer states this time with financial incentivesWashington opened a diplomatic offensive here today to try to sell the idea of a $25billion fund for mutual support in balanceofpayments crises.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The San Diego Gas and Electric Company, announced yesterday it had reached agreement with underwriters for the sale of 2 million shares of common stock but had postponed the sale of $50million in firstmortgage bonds because of bondmarket conditions and high interest rates. The stock goes on sale today at 11.625 a share and will be issued Nov. 26.

title: Notes on People
description: The arrival in Moscow yesterday of the Shah of Iran brought back onto the political scene Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader. Mr. Brezhnev was out of sight most of last week, suffering from, what diplomatic sources believe was influenza. He was forced to cancel scheduled meetings with Prime Ministet Sirimavo Bandaranalke of Sri Lanka and Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota. The shah is in the Soviet Union for a threeday working visit, in keeping with an understanding between Iran and the Soviet Union that the two nations try to exchange annual visits.

title: Stocks Drop Sharply
description: Concern over the widening recession gave the stock market its sharpest loss yesterday in more than 11 months. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 22.69 points to 624.92. Page 61.

title: PRINCIPALS URGE INQUIRY ON FUNDS
description: The head of the organization that represents most of the city's principals and other school supervisors called yesterday for the State Legislature to investigate the alleged misuse of funds and mismanagement in some of, the city's decentralized community school districts.

title: CANADA WILL CUT PERSONA TAXES
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 18The Canadian Government introduced a $30billion budget tonight calling substantial reductions in personal income taxes but an increase in the taxes of big corporations.

title: Monarchy: Stability Amid Flux
description: Following are excerpts from an address on the occasion of the 150th anniversary of the founding of the parliament in the Australian state of New South Wales.

title: Thousands Line Dublin Streets As Childers Is Borne to Castle
description: DUBLIN, Nov, 18 (UPI)Thousands of Irish people lined the streets of Dublin today to witness the flagdraped coffin of President Erskine Childers, being borne by, It was carried on a gun carriage to Dublin Castle for a ceremonial lying in state.

title: Butz Defends U.S. Policy On Food Aid to Poor Lands
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) Secretary. of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today the United States was quietly going about its business of providing food to hungry countries. Charges that the Ford Administration is dragging its feet on aid are unfounded, he declared.

title: Phone Company Will Seek $350Million Rise in State
description: The New York Telephone Company citing inflation, announced plans yesterday to seek an annual rate inerease of $350million to $400million so it could get 15 per cent to 20 per cent more revenue next year.

title: Codd Dismisses 19 Former Plainclothes Police Officers in a Bribery Scandal

description: The war of nerves joined during the last few days between Israel and. Syria threatens to become a way of life for weeks to come, Indeed, it would be a relatively optimiitic assessment to conclude that the pentup tensions can be confined in a war of nerves.

title: Saudi Extends Egypt Loan
description: CAIRO, Nov: 18 (Reuters)Saudi Arabia will extend a $161million loan to Egypt to be used in part for developing the Suez Canal. A joint communique, issued today in Riyadh and Cairo after talks between Egyptian Prime Minister Abdel Aziz Hegazi and Saudi officials, said the loan would be offered by the Saudi development fund.

The film is being shown at the Columbia 1 and 2 Theaters, Second Avenue and 64th Street. Running time: 155 minutes. This film has not been classified.

title: A Phone Executive Assails Bell System, In His Suicide Note
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 18, (AP)  The chief executive in Texas for the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company left a suicide note that said,"Watergate is a gnat compared to the. Bell System, a lawyer and a. colleague said today.

title: Democratic Governors Uphold Compromise on the MakeUp of Conventions
description: HILTON HEAD, S.C., Nov. 18 More than 30 Democratic Governors and Governorstobe declared unanimously today that their, party should stick with its yearold compromise on the makeup of national conventions and should focus on breadandTbutter issues at the party conference in Kansas City next month.

title: State Property Tax Proposed in Jersey
description: TRENTON; Nov. 18,  The Education Finance Forum, a special bipartisan legislative committee autorized to develop a new Plan for financing the state's public schools, today proposed a statewide property tax that would yield nearly $300million for New Jersey's public Schools.

title: RapistSlayer Sentenced
description: MAYS LANDING, Nov. 18 (AP)James P. Hyson was sentenced today to a 25to27 year term in prison for raping and murdering Mrs. Lillian Wood, 79 years old, during a breakin at her house in Dorothy last April 4. Judge James A. O'Neill passed sentence on Mr. Hyson, 22, who had pleaded no contest to the charges, Judge O'Neill also sentenced Mr. Hyson's brother Amply, 28, to five to seven years for robbery.

title: SUTTON RESCINDS BACKING OF MOVE

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18Richard M. Nixon agreed to a plan for clemency for E. Howard Hunt Jr., one ofthe Seven original Watergate defendants, on Jan. 8, 1973, the day they went on trial, according to, a tape recording played today in the Watergate coverup case.

title: Safer Water

title: Trevino Is Fined By Aussie PG.A.

title: U.S. Oil Plan Unfolds
description: The United States response to the threat to the world economy posed by the international oil cartel, is starting to take form and gather. force, by was the American strategy to blunt the oil threat so slow to emerge? One rea son was the fren zied and divided response of this country's principal allies in Western Europe and Japan. Another was the plain intellectual difficulty in coming to a firmer economic and strategic understanding of the threatand how to counter it. Finally, the agony of Watergate, and, the lack of Presidential leadership during the final year of the Nixon Administration delayed and crippled United States countermeasures.

title: ... and Two Vetoes

One is a set of amendments to the Freedom Information Act of 1966 and the other is.a vocational rehibilitation bill which provided a number of important benefits for the nation's handicapped. We think both vetoes should be overriden.

description: Dr. Ralph E. Goodall, a surgeon, died Monday at Whitestone (Queens) General Hospital. He was 72 years old, and lived at 3325 162d Street, Flushing, Queens.

Mayor Alois Lugger of Innsbruck said that, the games would get away from the gigantic affairs of earlier years. Besides action on snow and ice, the games will feature performances by the Vienna Philharmonic, the Vienna State Opera and an international art exhibition with a sports theme.

description: PARIS, Nov. 19  Former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany suggested today that the march toward united Europe could be much accelerated if those who dragged their feet were left behind.

Mr. Ponzio turned himself in at the United States Marshal's office Newark. He was one of seven former city officials convicted in March, 1973, of shaking down $15,000 from firms doing business with the resort city from 1968 to 1972. Two weeks ago, the United States Supreme Court let his appeal stand.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Nearly two years ago, when Don Coryell was hired by the St. Louis Cardinals, the new coach knew his first task. We're going to have one quarterback, Coryell said. I'm not going to decide on the quarterback from week week. Not long after that Coryell named. Jim Hart as his quarterback: Hart had been With the Cardinals Since 1966, but in 4972 he had been One of three quarterbacks: Gary Cuozzo and Tim an Gelder were the others.Bob Hollway, the ,ardinal coach that season, usually didn't announce his starting, quarterback until the Friday before Sports the, game. But in the team meetings during the week, the quarterbacks usually knew a which one would be knighted, You had The Times feeling, Hart says now When the coaches talked about Plays, they Woult look at the quarterback that, they were thinking about starting; It got to be,. a private joke among the quarterbacks.

On its face, his candidacy seemed almost bizarre: born in London, educated in England, possessed of a Cambridge accent but possessing only a smidgin of Gaelic, a naturalized Irish citizen.
