B. R. Ryder Marries Donna McDonough
description: Donna Marie McDonough of Short Hills and Monmouth Beach, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Barry Richand Ryder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ryder of Dayton, Ohio. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. James S. McDonoUgh of Short Hills and the late Mr. McDonough.

title: PhotoJournalism Gets Trip Exposure at New City Museum
description: Whatever else New York may be missing in the way of cultural attractions these days, it certainly cannot be said to be lacking in museums that Upheld a serious Commitment to The achievements of photography. The Museum of Modern Art, in addition to its regulir program of new acquisitions and temporary exhibitions, maintains a permanent gallery devoted, to masterworks of the medium. In recent years, both the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the New York Historical Society have organized major exhibitions in the field, and even the Whitney Museum of American Art, which has steadfastly resisted any involvement in photography in the past, has just opened its first major showa survey called Photography in America. Photography has clearly established itself as a museum art.

title: Schmidt Gets U.S. Briefing On Plan to Pool Oil Costs
description: BONN, Nov. 22  Two high Washington officials briefed Chancellor Helmut Schmidt today on Secretary of State Kissinger's proposal to establish a 25billion loan guarantee facility to help industrial nations pay their oil bills. The West German response has been noncommittal so far, according to informed Western officials.

title: Undermining O.N.G.
description: The future of the Office of Neighborhood Government, a Lindsay administration innovation that has sought with some notable success to improve the delivery of municipal services through the creation of district offices and service councils, is threatened by a struggle among the Beame administration, the borough presidents and members of the City Council. Until their differences are resolved and unless the politicians agree on a formula that will preserve O.N.G.'s essential features, some $10 million in funds already appropriated for local personnel and programs will remain blocked.

title: 45 Plants to Be Shut
description: DALLAS, Nov. 22 (UPI)Texas Instruments, Inc., announced today that many of its worldwide operationsincluding 24 in the United States and 23 abroadwould be partly or completely closed from next Friday to Jan. 5, 1975.

title: Civilian Defense Jobs Cut To Aid Combat Strength
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22The Defense Department announced today a consolidation of military bases and headquarters around the country that it said would lead to increased combat strength but not to a reduction in the defense budget.

title: SENATE PANEL,90, BACKS ROCKEFELLER FORCONFIRMATION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22The Senate Rules Committee voted unanimously today to recommend to the full Senate the confirmation of Nelson A. Rockefeller as Vice President. The vote was taken as Mr. hockefeller began to undergo a second day of questioning before the House Judiciary Cornmittie.

title: Dance: Sleeping Beauty
description: The Royal Swedish Ballet presented a thirdand new program Thursday night as part of its current week at the City Center.

title: invitation to Disaster...
description: Twentyseven years ago this month, after exhaustively examining all possible remedies for resolving an increasingly bloody conflict between Arabs and Jews in Palestine, a special committee of the United Nations recommended that the disputed territory be partitioned into separate independent Arab and Jewish states as the only practical solution. The General Assembly adopted that recommendation by a vote of 33 to 13, with both the United States and the Soviet Union voting in the affirmative. The founders of Israel promptly accepted this pragmatte compromise. The Arabs did not.

title: Canadian Geese Increasing
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. (UPI) The number of nesting female Canadian geese in 1974 was up. 14 per cent from 1973 and should offset lower average broods, according to the Missouri Conservation Commission.

title: BEAME CUTS 1,510 WORKERS AND IMPOSES A JOB FREEZE TO SAVE CITY $100MILLION
U.S. Steel Lays Off 4,300
description: The steel industry, hardest hit by the coal strike, continued to cut back production and lay off workers yesterday.

title: Panovs Hail Press As Instrumental In Their Freedom
description: Valery Panov, the Soviet ballet star who was denied permission to immigrate to Israel with his ballerinawife, Galina Ragozina, for two years until last June, has credited the couple's release to the public campaign waged on their behalf.

title: Accepting Women in the Pulpit
description: WOMEN PRIESTSthe phrase gives some people the shivers. Women priests! Strange combination words, conflict of images.

title: CANADA REDUCING OIL GOING TO U.S
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 22Canada, the largest single supplier of foreign oil to the United States, announced today that exports of crude oil to the United States market would be reduced by 100,000 barrels a day, effective Jan. I.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:In a recent letter, N. D. Roodkowsky, relying on the fuzzy and authoritarian social philosophy of Messrs. Hegel and Dostoevsky, admits, As far as I know, statistical evidence does not support the view that the incidence of crime is negatively correlated with improvement in socioi economic conditions.

title: Bishops Ask That Congressmen Question Rockefeller on Abortion
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22Eight Roman Catholic bishops asked the chairmen of the House Judiciary Committee and the Senate Rules Committee today to make sure that Nelson A. Rockefeller will not use the office of Vice President to promote a personal viewpoint on permissive abortion.

title: Excerpts From FordPark Communique
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 22 (AP)Following are excerpts from the text of the joint communiqu issued to, day by President Ford and President Park Chung Hee:

title: Henry Ford Urges A 10Cent Increase In Tax on Gasoline
People and Business
description: As part of the cost cutting at Bache & Co. the big brokerage house, John E. Leslie, chairman, took a pay cut this year, as did a number of the firm's other officers, company records indicate.

title: U.S. JUDGE UPHOLDS LIMITS ON IMMUNITY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 22A United States District judge ruled yesterday at a Govern1 ment lawyer named by the Gainesville Eight in a perjury suit cannot use prosecutorial immunity to have the case dismissed.

title: Hester Leaving N.Y.U. to Head New U.N. University in Japan
description: James M. Hester will leave the presidency of New York University next summer to become the first head of the newly formed United Nations University, an international research and training institution that will have its headquarters in Tokyo, it was announced yesterday.

title: Art: Zorach's Carved Sculpture
description: The work of the American sculptor William Zorach, who died in 1966 at the age of 77, once occupied what seemed to be a secure place in the pantheon of modern American masters. Museums accorded his sculpture a place of honor in their exhibitions and collections, and his name loomed largeas a writer and authority, on sculpture no less than as a distinguished practitioner of the artin the higher councils of the art world.

title: LOCKHEED'SSTEP ISCOSTLIEST EVER
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's decision to write off $800million of Tristar aircraft development costs ranks as the largest such reduction in assets in American corporate history.

title: State Plan Seeks Industry TO Establish 55,000 Jobs
description: EDISON, N. JNov. 22In an effort to stem the state's worsening economic situation, Joseph A. Hoffman, the Labor and Industry Commissioner, announced a plan today to attract new industry to the state which could create 55,000 jobs within the next 18 months.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS 1 Magical incantation 12 Amassment 13 Nonrolling stone's activity, presumably 14 Famous fuguist 15... as a bug in 16 Darrow's field 17 Son of Adam 18 Reputations 20 Twelve, in Spain 21 Brewed tea 23 Boring tool 24 Unhappy endings 26 Quarries 27 D.C. man 29 Saw 32 Lowcalorie desserts 37 Blood vessel 38 Kind of city election 39 Weaver's reed 40 Hollywood trophy 43 Viscous  breve Volcano Scooped Firstaid kits of a sort Certain Apocalypse believers 45 46 47 51 52

title: Bridge: New Goren Book Explores Some Unfamiliar Subjects
description: In the last three decades, the bridge books of Charles Goren have outsold those of rival authors by substantial margins.

title: Art: Guston's Last Tape Mislaid
description: To an exceptional degree, Philip Guston has lived the gamut of the American painting of the last 40 years. He was into mural painting, Mexican style, as early as 1934, when he was just 21 He was into the Federal Art Project as soon as he moved to New York from the West, in 1936. Along with many others, though with distinctly more success, he wanted to paint complicated figure subjects that would combine an awareness of what was going wrong with the world with an awareness of what had lately right in art.

description: To an exceptional degree, Philip Guston has lived the gamut of the American painting of the last 40 years. He was into mural painting, Mexican style, as early as 1934, when he was just 21 He was into the Federal Art Project as soon as he moved to New York from the West, in 1936. Along with many others, though with distinctly more success, he wanted to paint complicated figure subjects that would combine an awareness of what was going wrong with the world with an awareness of what had lately right in art.

title: ASSEMBLY ADOPTS 2 U.N. RESOLUTION AIDING P.L.O. AIMS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22The General Assembly approved two resolutions tonight declaring that the Palestinian people have the right to independence and sovereignty and giving the Palestine Liberation Organization observer status in United Nations affairs.

title: Griffith Loses On Decision
description: Youth was served in Madison Square Garden's boxing ring last night when 22yearold Vito Antuofermo of Brooklyn took a major step up the ladder of the middleweight division.

title: The Meaning of U.S. Transit Aid
description: The final passage Thursday of a sixyear, $11.8billion Federal masstransit bill was at once a triumph and a day of reckoning for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and New York City. The action by. the House of Representatives following Senate approval marked a historic higtat through for American Cities by establishing the prinoiple that Washington will help subsidies the daytoday costs of running Subways, buses and commuter trains across the country. This has not been done before except in isolated exper imental projects.

title: Service for Childers
description: A memorial service for Erskine Childers, the President of Ireland who died of a heart attack Sunday, will be held Tuesday at noon at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at 53d Street, by the Permanent Representative of Ireland to the United Nations and the Minister and Consul General of Ireland.

title: MET TURANDOT SUNG WITH 2 NEW TO CAST
description: Puccini's Turandot is so much a pastiche that it needs a strong hand to hold it together, and in its current performances at the Metropolitan Opera it is not getting that hand from the conductor, Alberto Erede Still, Thursday evening's performance had a couple of casting novelties to keep it interesting.

title: News Summary and Index
Albert Predicts House Passage Of Health Insurance Bill by June
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22Carl Albert, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, has predicted that a ntional health insurance program will be passed by the House next year after being stalemated since 970.

description: MOSCOW, Nov. 22President Ford's meeting with Leonid I, Brezhnev this weekend is a hasty effort by both sides to reaffirm policies of accommodation at a time when there are strains on the underpinnings of d tente.

title: Rate of U.S. Business Failures Rose 19% in September to 839
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22The rate of business failures climbed 19 per cent in September to 839, the highest failure rate for a month since May and the most for any September since 1970, according to Dun & Bradstreet, Inc.

title: Barnes's Lawyer Backs Spirits'
description: The perplexedand angry lawyer for Marvin Barnes, Bob Woolf of, Boston,;said last night. that Barnes had valid contract to play basketball and that Barnes was legally bound to honor it.

title: DOW CLIMBS 6.73; TURNOVER DROPS
3 Escape With $75,000 In S.I. Jewelry Robbery
description: Three men in their thirties held up a Staten Island jewelry shop yesterday evening and escaped with jewelry estimated at more than $75,000, along with the owner's pistol, the police at the Richmond Terrace station house reported.

title: ...P.L.O. vs. UNESCO
description: In the name of culture, the Arab bloc and its obedient Communist and African allies have succeeded in politicizing the heretofore nonpolitical United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization by banning Israeli participation and cutting off the modest aid received for its museums, libraries and restorationsa sum, incidentally, that amounts to about oneeighth of Israel's own contribution to UNESCO. This shameful act, condemned by the United States, Canada and most the Western European and LatinAmerican nations, effect makes the Palestine Liberation Organization the censor of UNESCO's activities.

title: Channel 13 to Aid Group Trying To Expand Videotape Programs
description: WNET/13 and its experimental unit, the Television! Laboratory, has agreed, to lend financial support to a Californiabased independent video group, TVTV (Top Value Television), to examine ways to use the new, lowcost videotape technology for programing.

description: MOSCOW, Nov. 22President Ford's meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev this weekend is a hasty effort by both'sides to reaffirm policies of accommodation at a time when there are strains on the underpinnings of detente.

title: Grocer in Bronx Foils A Holdup by Two Men
description: A 37yearold grocer shot twice last night when he foiled a holdup of his store at 732 Courtlandt Ave; nue in the Melrose section of the Bronx, causing his two assailants to flee emptyhanded, the police reptored.

title: Ford, Hints Seoul Repression Perils Aid
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Nov. 23President Ford completed a brief visit to South Korea this morning after indicating to President Park Chung Hee that political repression here jeopardized American military aid.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State housing officials predicted that new housing construction in the city this year would be at least 50 per cent less than last year's totalwhich was sharply less than the year before.

title: Albert Predicts House Passage Of Health Insurance Bill by June
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22Carl Albert, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, has predicted that a ntional health insurance program will be passed by the House next year after being stalemated since 970.

title: Snowball Toss Brings Fine
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 22 (AP)"It was the most expensive snowball I've ever thrown, said Kate Seanell, a senior at Michigan State University, after paying a $10 fine. Miss Seanell's fine stemmed from.enforcement by police,. of a section of this city's: did orderly conduct ordinance ,Oat makes it a misdemeanor to wrongfully throw or propel any snowball from a car or toss one at a car or person.

title: MRS. C. R. HENSCHEL
description: Ruth Kerr Henschel, the widow of Charles R. Henschel, who was for many years president of M. Knoedler, Inc., the art gallery, died in Roosevelt Hospital yesterday. She lived at 1 East 66th Street.

title: WHEAT PRICE SLIDE BLAMED ON SYSTEM
description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex., Nov. 22 (UPI)  A Department of Agriculture official contending that the Government wanted no export controls, said today a new reporting system has caused, wheat prices to drop $1.20 a bushel in 20 days.

title: Bliss Returns, Gingerly, to the Met Opera
description: Anthony Addison Bliss, newIy appointed executive in charge of pulling in the Metropolitan Opera's horns, is settling rather gingerly into his new chair.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW ADA LOUISE HUXTABLE
N.Y. Yacht Club Toasts Past Glories New Tests
description: Amid the ringing enthusiasm of an impressive annual dinner in the famous clubhouse on West 44th Street, the officers of the New York Yacht Club last Wednesday evening anstrered the large question that has lingered over the sport of yacht racing for the last two months. Will there be another America's Cup competition?

title: THE PENNSYLVANIA DUTCH COUNTRY
Old Homes Revived on L.I. Estate
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.A modest attempt to rescue from the bulldozer a crumbling 1747 building in Amagansett has become a multimilliondollar restoration project here.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
Deptford Fears It Will. Become the Dumping Capital of South Jersey
description: DEPTFORD TOWNSHIPTo the owners, they are soIidwaste disposal facilities. To the local citizenry, they are dumps. And residents of this rural Gloucester County township believe they have some good reasons for fearing that their community is becoming the dumping capital of South Jersey.

title: Schoolboy Runner Finishes Unbeaten
Betty J. Harris Plans Nuptials
description: The engagement of Betty Jane Harris to Louis Douglas Barba, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis R. Barba of Short Hills, N. J,, and Stowe, Vt., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Harris Jr. of White Plains.

title: Canada's New Playwrights Have Found a Home at Home
description: TORONTO; The Tarragon Theater isn't simply on the wrong side of the railway tracks: it's virtually on those tracks. Regular theatergoers at the Tarragon accept the roar of passing trains as part of the sound effects of whatever play they're seeing. Nevertheless, in the three years of its existence, this small theater has become probably the most important center of new playwriting in Canada. Successful plays discovered at the Tarragon move out east and west across the country, virtually as if they traveled on the tracks just outside the front door.

title: TerArutunian Sculpts Space
description: Space in which movement takes place is the raw material of the stage designer who works in the realm of dance. Within this magic circumference he must create illusions that will heighten our perception of what a choreographer wishes to say. It is a subtle and highly complex artand a dangerous one, for dance decor can suffocate movement and undermine choreographic intent.

title: For Equal, Dual Sovereignty in Jerusalem
description: LONDON When we unanimously passed Security Council Resolution 242 in November, 1967, we made no direct reference to Jerusalem. Better, we United Nations delegates thought, to state the overriding purposes first. But increasingly it has become clear that without a settlement in Jerusalem there will never be peace.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Agreement Reported At Suffolk Symphony
description: The Suffolk Symphony, which suffered through some stormy months of labor strife earlier this year, is apparently closer to being able to concentrate primarily on the more tranquil task of bringing music to appreciative Long Islanders.

title: Tocks Study To Explore Salmonella Dangers
description: TRENTON  Study after study of the merits and demerits of a plan to build dam across the Delaware River at Tocks Island have followed Congressional authorization of the project in 1962.

title: The Telephone Suit
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company controls 82 per cent of the telecommunication networks in the United States, which makes it a near monopoly. A.T.&T. also makes most of the equipment it uses, which one could argue makes it two monopolies in one

title: 17 indicates in Bronx as Members of a Cocaine Ring
description: Seventeen persons including a physician, allegedly involved in a $25millionayear cocainesmuggling ring that operated between Bolivia and New York were indicted yesterday in the Bronx.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
Tape Casettes of Bible Going to the President
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP)A threevolume set of 64 tape cassettes containing the entire King James Version of the Bible has been presented to a presidential assistant L. William Seidman for President Ford as a prelude to National Bible Week, which begins tomorrow.

title: When Autos Are Hurt
description: The corporate and umion headquarters of the big car manufacturers may be the center of an economic disaster area, but they are only the center. When car sales drop as sharply as they have and auto workers are furloughed, the Big Three do not suffer alone.

title: Ford and Brezhnev: Jests Amid the Snow
description: VLADIVOSTOK, U. S. S. R., Nov. 23General Secretary, said Henry A. Kissinger to Leonid I. Brezhnev, I think we can definitely say this is a firstan American President and the General Secretary riding on a train through the snow in Far Eastern Russia..

title: Multinationals as High Fiction
description: PARISThe multinational corporation has made it for the first time as the subject of, serious literary fiction, a Kafkaesque new French novel with a message that narrowly missed winning France's top literary prize, the Goncourt, last week,

title: Was That Dr. Caligari On Last Night's Newscast?
description: I want to switch channels and get a different news. It is not, of course, television's fault that the news recently seems to have been written by Dr. Caligari. But surely it is Dr. Caligari's cabinet we have been looking into at 11 o'clock in the evening these past several weeks. As if in a delirium, whole orders of reality are declared inoperative. Cesare, the somnambulist, lives; he is an electronic journalist. One night he tells us that the Little League will no longer allow foreign teams to compete in its World Series, the Taiwanese and Japanese having won seven of the last eight championships. On another night he tells us that another Little League, the U.N. General Assembly, has legitimized Palestinian terrorism, permitting Yassir Arafat to impersonate a statesman. On a third night it is reported, with a straight face, that Lieut. William Calley is a free man. In a moment, the weather prediction... but first a word about the rape of Connie Francis in her motel room. (Was there a TV station, a magazine or a newspaper anywhere in the country with the decency to ignore that last item?)

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A photograph that appeared on Page 2 in the New Jersey section of Oct. 27 was of New Brunswick Junior High School and not of New Brunswick High School, as the caption said.

title: How. Anglers Rite of Winter Preserves Gear
description: Now is the time when anglers in the northeastern states shoule Work on their fishing.gear before putting it away for the winter. If one simply does not have the heart to wade into the entire project now, one, particularly the saltwaterangler, should spray reel seats, reel handles and, other exposed working parts with any.of the several good penetrants and corrosion removers currently available. If this is done, one will at least avoid, the problem of freeing frozen parts in spring.

title: A New Polaroid
description: The lowest priced Polaroid camera ever produced has been put out by, the Polaroid Corporation in a concerted effort to put one, of these cameras in the hands of thousands of teenagers. Called Zip, and bearing a list price of only $13.95, this camera uses a new type of Polaroid film (Type 87) which comes in blackandwhite only and which does not require any coating or other treatment after the picture is madeprints can be handled and passed around as soon as they have been pulled out of the camera and allowed to develop for the recommended 30 seconds.

title: Literary Dublin
description: There is paradox in Ireland which deceives the superficial observer, Herbert Kenny rightly remarks; and there's paradox in himself, IrishAmerican aficionado of Ireland that he is, in titling his book Literary Dublin. Indeed he observes, To write the history of Dublin will, at times, seem tantamount to writing the literary history of Ireland. a modest understatement for a work that scans Irish history, politics, religion and literature. From the great preChristian saga cycles and poems of Ossian, to the founding of the Irish Republic and the latest literary voices, Mr. Kenny zealously makes his way through the thickets of Ireland's peculiarly tortuous history.

title: Design
description: The floor plan shows the division of the loft into living and servicesleeping areas. The vast, lightfilled living room (1) shown in the photograph below occupies the giant's share of the space. Behind it, architect Hanford Yang, who is shown at right one of his Aalto lounge chairs, built what is almost a housewithinahouse to contain service and sleeping areas. The stairs behind him at the upper left of the photograph lead up to the kitchendining level (2). The dining area, shown at far right, overlooks the living room. From the dining table, one can glimpse the Morris Louis painting below. The bedroom, which also overlooks the living room, and bath (3) are one level higher. The dead space below the levels is used for storage.

title: Odetie Veysey Will Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Veysey of Old Greenwich, Conn., Nantucket, Mass., and Stratton, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Odette Veysey, to Spencer B. ,Hays, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Lansing Hays, of Riverside, Conn., and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, L.I.

title: Hollander Recital Postponed
description: The recital Lorin Hollander was scheduled to give this afternoon at the Hunter College Assembly Hall has been postponed because the pianist is ill. Mr. Hollander will appear Sunday, Jan. 5, at 2:15 P.M., when tickets for today's event will be honored.

title: James Taylor Weds Susan Hynes
description: Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit, N. J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Susan Eileen Hynes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. Hynes, to James T. Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Taylor Jr. Both families live in Summit.

title: Elizabeth Salutes Boudinot
description: ELIZABETH  This city, which played a prominent role in the American Revolution, will hold a ceremony today honoring Elias Boudinot, President of the Continental Congress, and his part in making Thanksgiving a national holiday.

title: Brace Yourself, Here Splat  Movies;FILM VIEW
description: In this year of the Big Splat, otherwise known as the disaster movie, it may be difficult to find one as wishfulfilling; as technicallY ingenious and as classically nutty as Earthquake, written by George Fox and Mario Puzo, and directed by Mark Robson. It's thu biggest, corniest; most spectacular calamity movie since Merian C. Cooper's The Last Days of Pompeii, whiCh goes all the way back to 1935, but, then The Last Days of Pompeii (Cooper's not BulwerLytton's) didn't have the brainbending accompaniment of Sensurround (patent pending):

title: Mayan Art Show in Newark
description: NEWARK  A small but significant exhibition of Mayan art at the Newark Museum is once again a reminder that Western civilization took too much time to recognize the splendor of that ancient culture.

title: The Hunts, Sugar and Great Western United
AROUND THE Garden
description: Although it has been reviewed a few times, just a reminder on tree pruning. Fall and late winter months are excellent times to tackle the job. The trees are dormant, their outline and shape is clear. And there is no worry about stimulating any additional growth. Pruning is essentially training and shaping, so keep it to a minimum.

title: A Rare Sinai Leopard Is Photographed for First Time
description: A species of Sinai leopard thought until recently to have become extinct, has been located and photographed in Israeli hills about 20 miles from where the Dead Sea Scrolls were found in 1947.

title: Music in Review
description: There are women who play the classical guitar professionally, but not as many as might. be expected. One of them, a young American named Alice Artzt, who has already toured extensively all over the world, made her New York debut on Friday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Presented under the auspices of Concert Socials, she drew a packed house.

title: Burned Volkswagen Owner Wins a Suit Over Gas Tank
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Nov. 23 (UPI)A Superior Court jury has awarded $1.9million to a teacher, severely burned in an automobile accident, on the ground that the design of her Volkswagen's gasoline tank was a safety hazard.

title: Rahel Varnhagen; The Life of a Jewish Woman. By Hannah Arendt.; Revised Edition. Translated by Richard and Clara Winston.; 236 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Cloth, $7.95. Paper. $3.95.; Cursed with living in interesting times
World of Blacks In Museum Show
description: NEWARKWhen a museum in a city with a sizeable black population seeks to present exhibitions with special, appeal to that community, the results may sometimes be ambivalent. Nevertheless, the attempt deserves to be made.

title: INDIA OVERHAULS BIRTHCURB PLANS
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 23India, a nation growing by 13 million people each year, is overhauling her shaky birthcontrol program.

title: Penn Defeats Dartmouth, 2720, As Vaughn Sparks Late Rally
Inquiry on General Asked
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Nov. 23 (UPI)The national executive committee of the Jewish War Veterans called on Congress today to investigate remarks by Gen. George S. Brown, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, that Jews control the nation's banks and newspapers.

title: BRIDGE
description: The simple things in life, especially bridge life, are rarely as simple as they appear. The basic tactical rules that a beginner absorbs turn out to be less clearcut on a higher level, when the handling of a single suit has to be considered in the strategic light of the whole hand.

title: Oklahoma Tops Nebraska, 2814; Stays Unbeaten, Wins Big 8 Title
The Women Belong to a Club That Doesn't SwingIt Glides
description: Ellen McCluskey Long almost never attends what she describes as girls lunches. Nor do Meriam Knott or Joan Scribner or Nancy Streeter or Linda Hacker or scores of likeminded women.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Nov. 26Tacontc Mtge Sports Club monthly meeting at Nino's Restaurant, Jefferson. Valley, N.Y., 8:30 P.M. Interested persons welcome.

title: Don't Invite Burglars to Your Home
description: There may be still a few communities where local residents can safely leave doors unlocked when no one is at home, and where robberies are almost unheard ofbut if any such Utopias still exist in this country they are undoubtedly few and far between. Crime statistics indicate that burglaries now take place at the rate of more than two per minute for every day of the year, and this rate is still climbing.

title: Maurice Andre
description: Want to be a trumpet player? Try a little coal mining first. It worked by force of circumstance for Maurice Andre, although he would not recommend the process to everyone. He attributes his powerful lungs and chest to the experience of digging in coal mines between the ages of 14 and 18, and the development of those mighty bellows has served him well in his enormously successful career as a solo trumpeter.

title: The Theater: Arthur
Adenoids, academics and angst; A Billion For Boris By Mary Rodgers. 211 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $4.95. (Ages 10 and Up)
description: Take notice! Rejoice! Mary Rodgers, daughter of Dorothy and Richard and an author in her own right, his now given us her second young people's book, A Billion for Boris. (Although I haven't read her first one, Freaky Friday, I certainly intend to track it down.)

title: Land Girl, $65.20, Triumphs in Demoiselle
description: The Tartan Stable's ,Land Girl contributed a surprise performance in the $59,900 Demoiselle at Aqueduct yesterday by winning the onemile test for 2yearold fillies. And Paul Cresci's Aunt lint turned in a more surprising effort by finishing off the board as the oddson favorite in the field of 14.

title: Girls Join Crewing Competition
description: BAYVILLEThe name of the sport is crew. The action is called sculling.When a person rows with only one oar, it is called sweeping, Terms like these are just part of the continuing education of what its members say is the only allgirl crew on Long Island.

title: All Buckeye Points Made On Field Goals by Klaban

description: Mr. and Mrs. William P. Kennard of Montclair, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Kennard, to Russell H. Hislip Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hislip of East Hampton, L. I. Miss Kennard is studying to be a Montessori teacher; her fianc is an electronics technician who served with the Navy in Vietnam. The couple plan to be married in June.

title: Moro Forms 2Party Cabinet in Italy
description: ROME, Nov. 23  Premier Aldo Moro today presented President Giovanni Leone with a list of ministers in his new Cabinet.

title: 63Yard Kick Sets An N.C.A.A. Mark
description: JONESBORO, Ark., Nov. 23 (AP)Joe Duren kicked a record 63yard field goal and added a 56yarder as time ran out today to eve Arkansas State a 2220 victory over McNeese.

title: Illegal Aliens Living in Queens sailed at Hearing
description: The hundreds of illegal aliens who have settled in the Corona and Elmhurst sections of Queens were the subject of an emotional and sometimes bitter public hearing last Wednesday night.

title: Silence in Peru
description: For the second time in four months, Peru's military rulers have resorted to drastic action to silence criticism of their policies. They have closed three magazines, exiled ten journalists and arrested five leading members of the Lima Bar AssoLation, including its president. For good measure, they have ousted 137 American Peace Corps volunteers, who had been working mostly in forestry, agriculture and education.

title: McGovern Foes Say They Prevail On Democratic Charter Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23The Coalition for a Democratic Majority, formed two years ago by opponents of the McGovern movement in their party, said today that our view has prevailed on most of the charter that the the Democrats will adopt in Kansas City next month.

title: Snick  Stands Out In Rout of Cornell
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 23 The crowd. of 12,500 was yelling Snick, Snick! but wasn't directed. at the hapless Cornell team, which was defeated, 4120, by Princeton today in Palmer Stadium.

title: WALLACE AIDES SEE A TOTAL CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI), Gov. George C. Wallace 0f Alabama is planning to eliter almost every major Democratic Presidential primary in 1976 according to his senior staff aides.

title: Great Neck South Gains in Soccer
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 23 Jon Raab's goal with 2 minutes 58 seconds left to play gave Great Neck South a 10 victory over Calhoun for the Nassau County scholastic soccer championship at Hofstra University Stadium today.

title: Students Repairing Historic Plume Home
description: NEWARK  Young men learning carpentry skills in a publicfinanced construction training program are helping to repair storm damage to the historic Plume House, the city's oldest building.

description: George Brockett, an actor, director and theater consultant, has been named overall artistic director of the Performing Arts Foundation in Huntington, L.I.

title: Georg Brunis, Jazz Trombonist, Dixieland Pioneer, is Dead at 74
description: Georg Brunis, the New Orleans jazz trombonist who was a pioneer in Dixieland, died Tuesday of a heart ailment in Edgewater Hospital, Chicago. He was 74 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Municipal Suit Settled
description: ROCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 23 (AP) Rochester Mayor John Shaw has announced the outofcourt settlement of a. $2.4million suit against the city. Two companies, Mat Harrison Associates of Florida and the F.E. Dadderio Corporation of Braintree, Mass., sued to recover losses from work stoppages while working on a city sewer system.

description: TRENTONThe state's Division of Criminal Justice has refused to move into a new headquarters leased to it by a builder who lent money to his cousin, a reputed Mafia figure.

Weicker Jr., Connecticut Republican, to require highranking Federal officials to file annual net worth statements.

description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Nov. 23 (AP)Dr, William E. Lavery, 44 years old, executive vice president of Virginia Tech, was named president of the university today, succeeding Dr. T. Marshall Hahn Jr. Dr. Hahn has resigned to become executive vice president of the GeorgiaPacific Corporation in Portland, Ore.

description: The story of Aimee Semple McPherson, the evangelist who was one of America's more flamboyant personalities in the period after World War I, will be brought to the musical stage next year by Frederick Brisson.

description: DALLAS, Nov. 23 (AP) yen recovering from heart attacks need not adopt a less active role in sexual intercourse because of their cardiac con dition, according to a study by a specialist.

title: Pamela Romei Engaged

title: AR SEEN ERODING GERMANU.S. TIES
description: BONN, Nov. 23  At the eighth AmericanGerman conference here this week, some who value friendship between the two countries expressed concern that that friendship was in danger of becoming the preserve of an old and conservative generation.

description: Susan Groisi, a lawyer with Cahill Gordon & Reindel, and Allan Forsyth, an editor with Worth Publisher will be married Jan. 18.

title: The Tragic Deterioration of Fellini's Genius
description: THOSE whom the Catholic Church did prevent from seeing Rossellini's The Miracle ((the ban on it was reversed by the Supreme Court, but the film has been shown very little, all the same) will remember the mute figure of the Stranger, a handsome, delicate faced, sensitivelooking man whom the heroine; a simple peasant joman guarding the villagers sheep, could understan4ably mistake for St. Joseph. His visage had rare dignity and subtlety, and the mysteriously ironic expression with which he responded to the idoration,of, the shepherdess was worthy of the Mona Lisa's countenance. That tall, slender man; who was none other than the notyetdirector Federico Fellini, was in (wry way the antithesis of the gross sensualistdoublechinned and bulgingbellied, though still in his early fifties Fellini of today, the hasbeen director. It is not so much that he was younger and had dyed his hair blond for the film; it is rather that there was no vulgarity in his

Merlino, the Democratic Majority Whip in the upper house, indicated last week that a number of Democratic legislators were regarding Governor Byrne with deepening dissatisfaction. They are critital of his apparent lack of interest in the legislative process and in particular the schoolfinancing battle.

title: OpenMeetings Acquittal
description: LANGHORNE, Pa., Nov. 23 (AP) The five members of the Middletown Township Board of Supervisors have been acquitted of charges that they violated Pennsylvania's new openmeetings law. District Justice Samuel Hughes said in announcing the verdict on Tuesday that there was no proof that business was transacted during part of a recent meeting that was closed to the public.

title: City Opens SixLiner Terminal
description: After 20 years of planning, New York opened a gleaming new passenger gateway to the high seas yesterday, in the Ilene that it is not too late to reverse a relentless loss of travelers to the jet airliner and to ports in warmer climates.

description: Nathan Graf, coordinator of the graduate taxation program at Pace University and a professor at the New York Law School, died Friday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park. He was 62 years old and lived at 48 Kalda Avenue, New Hyde Park.

John L. Schmidtke, manager of StarKist Samoa, Inc., and James Baumgarten, a plant superintendent, were sentenced yesterday by District Court Judge Robert Firth.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23A leading constitutional authority believes it is impossible for states to draft capital punishment laws without permitting so ninth arbitrary discretion in the final lifeordeath decision as to make enforcement of the laws totally unfair and unjust.

title: A WeightLosing Record
description: GREENVILLE, Ohio, Nov.23 (UPI) Dan Younce, 24 years old, says that in three years he has slimmed down from 350 pounds to 165 pounds to hold the local weight watchers club's record for losing weight. Mr. Younce, who used to eat from 8 A.M. to 10 P.M., said this week that his newest hobby was getting into the bathtub.

description: SAIGON, Nov. 23The Vietcong today denounced a prominent Roman Catholic opponent of President Nguyen Van Thieu as a stooge of the United States.

description: NEWARKAn attempt to block the appointment of Penelope L. Kuykendall, named by Governor Byrne to head the recently upgraded Division on Women, appears to have rallied women activists about the state to her defense. Groups ranging from the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs to the feministoriented Women's Political Caucus are calling for Mrs. Kuykendall's speedy confirmation.

title: HIJACKERS OF JET KILL A PASSENGER AT TUNIS AIRPORT
description: TUNIS, Sunday, Nov. 24Palestinian hijackers killed a German banker yesterday and later released 13 hostages kit threatened the liyes of their 27 remaining captives aboard a British airliner unless terrorists held in Cairo were released.

title: Stan Smith Weds Miss Gengler
description: Marjory Logan Gengler, who was ranked No. women's tennis player in the East last year, and Stanley (Stan) Roger Smith, former United States Open singles champion and 1972 Wimbledon champion, were married yesterday afternoon.

title: FollowUp on The New
description: One day last summer the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced that it was training attack dogs to help patrol its subway yards and chase the vandals who paint graffiti on trains. Reporters were invited to a demonstration, and the M.T.A. got a lot of publicity.

title: BEETHOVEN PLAYED BY BEAUX ARTS TRIO
description: The Beaux Arts Trio is one of the most elegant ensembles playing today, and its program of three works for piano, violin and cello by Beethoven Friday night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium was a marvelous example of chamber music at its very best.

title: Clout
description: Most reporters have a favor ite assignment, a Story That Made Me See the Light: for many women the place that mattered this decade was Miami Beach, 1972 site of the Democratic National Convention. The largest female press corps in modern times covered the largest female delegate group in modern times. There and then we lost our innocence and began to understandand sometimes gain clout. I remember the steamy, noisy atmosphere: elation over women operating film cameras; women's stories getting frontpage play; confusion among members of the male press corps, who had to ask their female colleagues to explain certain events (highlighted by Walter Cronkite's misinterpreting one key credentials vote and wondering aloud why the ladies were angry). And, after the abortion plank lost and George McGovern was nominated anyway, when a lot of women felt doublecrossed, I remember a Massachusetts delegate telling me she was voting for Sissy Farenthold for Vice President that this kind of garbage is never going to happen again.

title: Security Guard Slays Two Men Seeking to Rob Massage Parlor.
description: Two men who had invaded a dingy midtown massage parlor in an alleged robbery attempt last night were shot to death by a retired city police officer who was working there as a security guard.

title: CUTEST VIEW
description: LOS ANGELES.; What are two fullfledged film stars like Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau doing in a stage production of Sean O'Casey's Juno and the Paycock"? That question is inescapable appraising the revival here at the Mark Taper Forum of O'Casey's 1924 drama about the Irish civil war: The new production, which also stars Maureen Stapleton, was directed for the stage by veteran Hollywood filmmaker George Seaton (Miracle on 34th Street, Airport) and is part of the tenth anniversary celebration of the Los Angeles Music Center, a threetheater complex roughly comparable to New York's Lincoln Center or the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C.

title: Headliners
description: Twice in the last two months, Italian politicians have tried and failed to form coalition governments to deal with that country's runaway economic problems. Now Christian Democrat Aldo Moro, three times a Premier in the past, has finally formed a new Cabinet. Rut there is some doubt as to whether his Government can survive the current crisis. Mr. Moro is not in the best of health; his coalition partner, Ugo La Malfa of the Republican party, is in his seventies. His party has also suffered losses to the left in recent local elections. He faces an inflation rate of more than 24 per cent and a balance of payments deficit that is barely being kept in hand with loans from West Germany and the Common Market.

title: Man Wins Apple Cookoff
description: BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP)  A factory worker from Beverly, Mass., competing against almost 2,000 women, has emerged as the winner of the New England Apple Cookoff. Paul St. Linger won top prize in the contest Wednesday in a television cookoff with five women from the other New England states. His recipe: pork chops in applesauce.

title: The magical and the mundane
description: Conceived in poetic license and dedicated to the proposition that all characters are created equal, Touch the Water Touch the Wind lightly touches everything under the sun as flows and turns from Poland to Israel, from Heidegger to Stalin, from mathematics to gossip, from espionage to metaphysics, from infernal Nazism to international Communism to eternal love. This is the third novel by the lavishly gifted Israeli writer Amos.0z, and it offers a profusion of delightful passages couched in unfailingly lovely language. Inadvertently, it also offers an elegant proof for the theorem that a novel as a whole can be less than the sum of its parts.

title: Tourists Still Avoiding U.S. Virgin Islands
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, Nov. 23Although racial tensions in the United States Virgin Islands seem to have eased, tourists are still avoiding this resort area.

description: They are as persistent as potholes, but much bigger. The Highways Department says that on a given day there are 20,000 to 30,000 of them throughout the city.

title: Two Sentenced to Death In Utah Torture Murders
description: FARMINGTON, Utah, Nov. 21 (UPI)Two young airmen convicted of the torturemurder three persons during a record store holdup in April were sentenced to death yesterday. Under Utah law, they have the choice of shotby a firing squad.

description: Unemployment in the auto Industry this winter is almost certainly to reach the 20 per cent mark, more than three times the national rate. And it's not hard to find the reason.

title: Churchill at 100
description: The posthumous life of Winston Churchill is one of the most remarkable pbenomena of the postChurchillian age and might serve as the subject for a book in itself. How illuminating it would be to follow the pattern and progression by which a great historical figure, as Churchill undoubtedly was, moves, transmigrates, from history into legend, as Churchill also undoubtedly has done. Which is not to say that he has lost his historical existence.

Costanza of Moore College of Art in Philadelphia and Mrs. Costanza of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Hill of Decatur, Ga., an accountant with the Family and Children's Services, and the late Mr. Hill, who was a lawyer. The wedding is planned for Feb. 1.

title: 2 Men Are Found Slain In Queens Rooming House
description: Two men who had come to New York recently from El Salvador were found murdered yesterday afternoon in Queens rooming house after the ppolice received an anonymous call telling them of the deaths.

description: Dr. Robert L. Levy, a noted cardiologist, died here yesterday at the age of 86.

description: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 23Greenwich annexed its first Fairfield County conference football championship by defeating stubborn Staples of Westport, 2314, before 4,235 fans today in Boyle Stadium.

description: TRENTONThe organization that has been lobbying for improved tenants rights for the last five years is about to decide if it will begin a major new campaign for a statewide rentcontrol law.

description: ATHENS, Nov. 23 (AP)The Government gazette published legislation today officially setting Dec. 8 as the date of the plebiscite on the fate of Greece's 142 year old mon arehy.

title: California Cities and States on 2 Coasts Ask Delay on Offshore Oil Hearings
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23Concerted opposition to the Federal Government's program of offshore oil leasing to ease the energy crisis has erupted among both Atlantic and Pacific coastal states, with California in the lead.

title: Between Me And Life
description: In this biography of a highly gifted but little known woman artist, Meryle Secrest combines lucid psychological insight with empathy in a deep exploration of character and relationships. She brings into vivid life a lost segment of art history. She has the skill and power to recreate history in shimmering colors. It is unusual when a study of character probes so deeply within a human being and still paints the atmosphere around it, the life style of the times.

title: J.C.'s Shadow Scores
description: BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP)J. C.'s Shadow took the $8,000 mile and 70yard feature today at Suffolk Downs. J. C.'s Shadow finished in 1:44.3 and paid $8.40. First Dawn ran second and Tudor's Plume was third.

title: GOVERNMENT ACTS IN COAL DEADLOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 The Government took its first formal step tonight to intervene in the deadlocked national coal miners strike by ordering both sides to renew intensive bargaining with the help of Federal mediators.

title: Loss and Change
description: As I write this, my city, with an almost sacred tradition of liberalism, is undergoing an agony of racial conflict. There is a furious denial of the reality of an implacable change, a retreat to tribalism, an angry yearning for an idealized but irrevocably lost past, a sense of hopelessness, helplessness and futilityit is as it the endless waves of ambivalence will never relent. One searches for a paradigm, a model to explain and objectify these events and give them some large meaning. It emerges from Peter Marris's book, Loss and Change, which tries to correlate the sense of anguish that accompanies change. Profound social change must be the ultimate result of Boston's current history because it summons up in each involved soul the quality of grief.

title: Inflation Pinch Strands Yarborough and Ross
description: To those who.don't think auto racing, is In serious trouble, realize this: Cale Yarborough, who probably will be voted American driver of the year by the Martini & Rossi panel this week, has lost his major spellsor for 1975. The Carling Brewing Company of Canada, citing simpie economic reasons, withdrew. from its National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing program, although Yarborough, in Junior Johnson's Chevrolet, has. had his best season and Earl Ross, in the other Carling et 7, could clinch rookie of the year honors in the NASCAR finale at Ontario, Calif.,

title: Joseph Bartley to Wed Concepcion M. Luayon

The wedding is planned for Dec 7. in St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church here.

title: Accused Mobsters Still Silent
description: TRENTONFour reputed leaders of organized crime are confined to a New Jersey penal institution because they refuse to talk to state investigators about their business. title: 3 Tons of Cheese Sold In Protest by Farmers
description: NASHVILLE, Nov. 23 (UPI) Farmers, bypassing the middle man, quickly sold 3 tons of aged cheddar cheese today to costconscious shoppers at 95 cents a poundabout half of what the price is at the supermarket.

title: The Dance: Rudy Perez
description: The cunning childlike sensibility that fashions all of Rudy Perez's work enables him to make artful dances while appearing to play. His approach to space is like that of a child's to a game: His concentration is total, and he will use the stock tools of running, jumping and standing still at the appropriate moments to gain his goal. Glamour, as such;, plays no part in his work, and he is currently presenting a series of programs at the Brooklyn Academy, of Music displaying his concerns throughout the last decade. The final program will be given this after noon.

title: Inescapable Issue
description: The recent election has proved once again that those candidates who refuse to take the public's environmental concern seriously are likely to find themselves out of office. Earlier this year, Environmental Action, one of the; environmentaloriented citizens organizations that has sprung up in recent years, again made public its dirty dozen, a list of twelve members of the House of Representatives whose voting records had proved them to be hostile to doing what needs to be done to protect the nation's natural resources and clean up its land, water and air. Of the twelve, two were defeated in the primaries and six in the general election,

title: State Tax Unit, Plagued by Bad Checks, to Step Up Collection
description: TRENTON  New Jersey tax officials, expressing deep concern over a rising number of business failures and growing lists of uncollected state levies, are preparing to step up collection efforts.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market suffered another sharp loss last week as the attention of traders was focosed on layoffs In the automobile industry, the antitrust action against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and tie continuing coal strike.

title: Deer Season Ends Saturday
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 23 (AP) The deer season will close as scheduled next Saturday, State Fish and Game Commissioner Maynard F. Marsh said today. He said that he did not foresee any early closure of the season. Officials said last week that the deer kill stood at more than 14;200 as of Nov. 16.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles

description: PARIS, Nov. 23The Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization urged its 135 member states today to resolve their disputes through dialogue and tolerance rather than confrontation.

description: KHARG ISLAND, Iran.n a sense, this small hot hump of coral in the Persian Gulf is the other end of the oilOice crisis.

title: Opera: The Turn of the Screw at Pace
description: One of Benjamin Britten's many claims to tame is that he has been able to make fascinating operas out of two of modern literature's most famous short novels. His His version of Thomas Mann's Death in Venice is being performed by the Metropolitan Opera this fall, and this weekend (Friday night and this afternoon) the Eastern Opera Theater is presenting Mr. Britten's treatment Henry James's The Turn the Screw at Pace Universitys's Schimel Center for the Arts.

title: Sheryl Lynn Chapman, an Artist, Is Betrothed to A. F. Kammer 3d

title: Mary Jo Reilly, Lawyer, Bride of Timothy Essaye

The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Igmatius Loyola by the Rev. Hugh Reilly, a cousin of the bride.

title: JAZZ AT FIVE SPOT
description: The Five Spot at 2 St. Mark's Place is a legendary jazz row in the East Village that the rise of rock and the parallel diminution of jazz in the late nineteensixties forced to close. Now it is back in business as a jazz cabaret and offering, as entertainment, An Enter tainment.

title: Queens Reading Program Aids Young Offenders
description: Youthful offenders between the ages of 7 and 16 are learning not only to read but also to turn on to themselves in a newly revamped program conducted by York College and the Department of Probation in Queens.

title: SAMUEL C. OTTO
description: Samuel C. Otto, a partner in the law firm of Otto & Easterday and vice president of Otto & Co., Inc., insurance, died Wednesday in his office at 150 Broadway. He was 71 years old and lived at 11020 73d Road, Forest Hills, Queens, and Allenhurst, N. J.

title: Cape Cod Panel Urges the Banning Of Nude Bathing
description: SOUTH WELLFLEET, Mass., Nov. 23Truro's celebrated nude beach will be closed to unclad bathers next summer if a recommendation by the Advisory Commission to the Cape Cod National Seashore is aps proved by the National Park Service. The measure would also ban nude bathing at all other beaches within the Seashore.

title: F.B.I. SEIZES SUSPECT IN 1MILLION HOLDUP
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had captured a 35yearold man in California charged with one of the largest bank robberies in the history of the United States.

title: Brown 2819 Victor As Beatrice Stars
What They Are Saying
description: Larry Banks, a Michigan defensive end, made a prediction about yesterday's Big Ten showdown game with Ohio State: The only way Archie Griffin will get 100 yards is if I die. Banks is still alive, even though Griffin gained 111 yards.

title: A family pursues economics, health and compassion by joining the new vegetarians
If You Don't Dance They Beat You
description: Situation normal: When Jos Quintero and a few friends were interviewing actors for what became Circle in the Square they had no theater, no scripts and no money. Since they were working for nothing it never occurred to them that the first question a hungry actor might ask is: What is the salary? All Mr. Quintero and his friends had was a sweet thought that after the company was chosen the seed was beginning to sprout and the future looked bright to them. Money was unreal as well as irrelevant.

title: GUEST VIEW

description: Two major law firms have expanded end moved to new quarters downtown.

title: Army Tells Recruiters To Ease Off Next Month
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI)  The allvolunteer Army has too many volunteers and is telling recruiters to take it easy next month.

title: Letter
description: To the Editor:Although I am the director of the Great Neck Library, am writing in the capacities of both a taxpayer and a professional librarian.

title: Behind the Trail Of Broken Treaties An Indian Declaration of Independence. By Vine Deloria Jr. 263 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $8.95.
description: Among his people Vine Delcria Jr. has achieved a status somewhat similar to that of Sitting Bull's leadership of the Sioux tribes a century ago. Deloria is not a warrior (The time for playing cowboys and Indians is over, he said recently) but is more the strategistthe thinker and the planner. Let us alone, Sitting Bull said repeatedly. We want only to be left alone. We can live well if you will only let us alone. What Deloria wants is affirmative action by the U.S. Congress to define Indian tribes as smaller nations to be left alone to run their own affairs.

title: Helene Cohen Fiancee Of Donald Schoenholt
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harold Cohen of Lindenwood, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helene May Cohen, to Donald N. Schoenholt, son of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Schoenholt of Averill Park, N. Y., Forest Hills, Queens, and Miami Beach. Dr. Cohen is a podiatrist.

Marshall Hahn Jr. Dr. Hahn has resigned to become executive vice president of the GeorgiaPacific Corporation in Portland, Ore.

title: Copyright and the Right to CopyPart II
description: For all the Court of Claims majority's talk of judicial parsimony and the limited scope of its ruling in the Williams & Wilkins case involving the right to make Xerox copies, the decision, if upheld by the Supreme Court, could affect much more than a few arcane technical journals. As Judge Nichols observed in his dissent, However hedged, the decision will be read, that a copy.right holder has no rights a library is bound to respect. We are making the Dred Scott decision of copyright law.

description: Ralph Capone, who had national notoriety when he was a member of the crime syndicate run by his brother Al Capone during the Prohibition era of the nineteentwenties and early thirties, died Friday at a nursing home in Hurley, Wis. He was 81 years old.

title: N. Carolina Edges Duke, 1413

description: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 23 (AP)The judge who placed former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew on probation says it was more important to get him out of office than into jail. He said that officials involved in the case had feared that a trial might end in hung jury and divide the nation.

title: Boardwalk Kennel Club Fixture Draws Entry of 3 ,813 Dogs for Shciow Next Sunday
description: Boardwalk and Park Place are familiar to every Monopoly player in America. So are they to thousands of dog fanciers. The. Boardwalk Kennel Club show, to be held next Sunday, in Atlantic City's Convention Hall, is only five blocks from Park Place. The canine variety. Boardwalk has drawn 3,813 dogs, an increase of 94 over last. year. It's a far cry from the 1,521 at Atlantic City's first show in 1967. Indeed, it is the fourth largest of the 628 allbreed fixtures held thus far in the United States this year.

title: Hijack Attempt Failsin Japan
description: TOKYO, Nov. 23 (AP)  A 16yearold youth brandishing sticks resembling dynamite attempted to hijack a domestic Japanese airliner today, but was subdued by the flight engineer, John F. Vivian, 32 of Philadelphia the police reported. They said that Mr. Vivian had been slightly injured in a scuffle with the youth, whose name was withheld because he is a minor.

title: GUEST VIEW
description: LONDON; To say that Hans Werner Henze's huge oniact opera The Bassarids was less than warmly.received when it had its premiere ethe Salzburg Festival of 1966 would be an understatement. To those who had not done their homework, the libretto by W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman seemed quirkish and obscure; the firstnight audience clearly did not relish a twoandahalfhour opera without an interval; and the composer himself, feeling that the production had betrayed his intentions, has related how he spent the night wandering in misery through the narrow streets of the old city. As the curtain fell, the chairman of Covent Garden leapt from his seat like a scalded cat. I was seated directly behind him, and I knew then that any chance that the Loyal Opera House would mount what seemed to me then and still seems one of the finest new operas to arrive since the war was nil.

title: Racial Violence Spreads in Upstate Towns
description: Racial violenCe among teenagers and even, younger children has broken out in a second small city in the Hudson Valley, and no on seems to be sure why. FolloWing a number of injuries and largescale vandalism, Beacon closed its schools for two days last week and imposed a stringent curfew for youths under the age of 18. Its sister city across the Hudson, Newburgh, had done the same thing earlier this month.

title: Highway Outlook Is Gloomy

title: Not Enough Is Coming In, Too Much Is Going Out
Liszt
description: This book traces the career and accomplishments of that great chameleon of music, Liszt the Magnanimous: 25 years of apprenticeship, during which the young prodigy seems no more than a juggler before the great cathedral (Beethoven, etc.); 10 years of unparallelled glory; 12 years of misguided creative labors; and 25 years of duskthough the author drops him before this last segment, being concerned chiefly with the Figure rather than the Maker.

title: Letters
description: Robert Sherrill missed the point in his article on Jerry Ford's home town (What Grand Rapids did for Jerry Ford and vice versa, Oct. 20). There is nothing inconsistent about Ford's voting record in Congress and the willingness of Grand Rapids residents to tax themselves for everything that's been put on the ballot. The explanation for this seeming contradiction is very simple: Ford and his constituents believe firmly in home rule, in effective decentralized government. Over the years, Jerry Ford has done his part to keep things in Grand Rapids independent of Washington by voting against programs which would expand the role of the Federal Government in local affairs, while his constituents have done their part by voting for local levies which would make improvements in the communityin their community (don't forget that 75 per cent of the county's residents are home owners)without the Federal Government dictating how

title: Imagination Is the Thing In Classified
description: Most people read the apartment classifieds when they are looking for a new place. Some people pride themselves on never reading apartment ads. And there is a small, if not select, group of New Yorkers Who always read the apartment ads, preferably aloud and over Sunday brunch. Because they enjoy them.

title: DEMOCRATIC BOSS CITED IN VOTE CASE

Barbieri, the powerful Democratic Boss here, Is among the targets of a yearllong grand jury investigation into the city's votefraud scandal, which.includes a conspiracy to forge at least 170 absentee ballots cast in last year's municipal elections. Major new developments in the investigation are expected soon.

title: Israel Is Weighing Role on West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 23  Israel is willing to consider granting local autonomy in gradual stages to the 700,000 PaleStinians living in the occupied West Bank but still refuses to deal with the Ralestine Liberation Organization, Israel's Information Minister, Aharon Yariv, said today.

title: Ella Still Sings Just This Side Of the Angels
description: In the darkened amphitheater of the Nanuet TheaterGo Round in suburban Spring Valley, N.Y., late one recent afternoon, Ella Fitzgerald sat brooding in a front row seat. Squatting silently on the circular stage before her, bathed in the orange glow from a pair of muted spotlights, were a piano and a set of drums with transparent skins. Ella was waiting to begin rehearsal for her appearance at the club that night. I was there to watch her and talk with her about her forthcoming Great Performers Series concert at Avery Fisher hall. That event, this Friday night, will mark the return of the First Lady of Song to the New York concert stage after an absence of than

It said also that the scope of the quasiembassies set up by the two countries in each other's capitals would continue to be expanded.

description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 23 (UPI) The United States has agreed to give Pakistan an $18million loan for the purchase of 100,0000 tons of wheat, a government spokesman said today.

title: Fulbright's last frustration The great dissenter finally found himself a compatible Secretary of State
description: For more than 30 years, he managed his trick, to be two things to two sets of people. To the people of the world, he was the urbane peace prophet J. William Fulbright, of the furrowed brow, the threepiece suit, the dignified mien, and, for almost all that time, of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. To the folks down home in Arkansas, he was plain old Bill Fulbright, shirt sleeves rolled up, baggy pants held up by suspenders and collar open at the neck, talking to them about the price of cotton and chickens, doing their business in Washington, D.C., and mostly keeping a discreet silence on the burning matter of race. At last, however, as he approached his 70th year, the trick failed him. Voters in the Democratic primary decided that Fulbright had neglected them and that they preferred instead an immensely popular young Governor named Dale Bumpers, young enough to be Fulbrighfs son, new enough to have almost no history and no enemies. Bumpers had declared throughout his campaign that there was a mess in Washington, and that Fulbright had been there all those years. So, curiously, this man, never touched himself by a hint of scandal, became the first major casualty of Watergate and the Incumbents Syndrome of 1974.

title: Women also have dark hearts
description: My mother used to have a little china cream and sugar set that was given to her by a woman who later killed her children with an axe. It sat cheerfully in the china cabinet, as inadequate symbol as I have ever seen of the dark mysteries within us. Yet at least it was there to remind us that no matter how much Jesus wanted us for a sunbeam, we would still have some day to cope with a deeper reality than common sense could explain. It stood for strange cars not to get into, running shoes to wear when you were out alone at night and the backs of Chinese restaurants you were not supposed to go into.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Derek Marlowe achieved some recognition as a literary man with A Dandy in Aspic. After several novels since then, he has now turned to mystery fiction. with SOMEBODY'S SISTER (Viking, $6.95), and has come up with a peculiar book. He seems a bit uncomfortable in the genre, and some of the writing, especially at the beginning, has its pretentious moments. He also has not added much to the privateeye conventions, and his hero is the typical middleaged, tired and selfpitying failure represented in so many books of this kind. Yet Marlowe is nevertheless a real writer, and there are sections of Somebody's Sister that are as much above hack writing as the Himalayas are above Island.

description: MISHKA barks at the break of dawn and I awaken. Oh hush up, girl, there's nobody there, I hear my landlady say in her foggy London voice.

description: While all the attention is focused on what to eat for Thanksgiving dinner, the question of what to drink also deserves serious consideration. If turkey and pumpkin pie faithfully commemorate the Colonial celebration, then so. do glasses of cider.

description: TOKYO, Nov. 23Leaders of Japan's governing LiberalDemocratic party held intensive meetings today to find a way to select a successor to Preshier Kakuei Tanaka, should he an nounce his intention to resign next week as has been widely rumored.

description: Alexandra Dianne Redding, daughter of Mrs. Marie R. Redding of Murphysboro, and Warren E. Redding of Kansas City, Kan., was married yesterday afternoon to Douglas Bertrand Marshall Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall of Houston and grandson of the late Hugh Roy Cullen, Texas oil operator, philanthropist and founder of the University of Houston.

description: CHICAGO, Nov. 23  Five Chicago Democrats are running for their party's nomination for Mayor in the February primary, and they have one hope in common  that Mayor Richard J. Daley will not seek a sixth four year term.

title: Sports News Briefs

title: Benign Occupation Has Never Fully Converted the Refugees
New Help for Young Patients
description: MORRISTOWN  Sixteenyearold Diane T. is a diabetic. She needs insulin shots daily and must follow a special diet, but, like all teenagers, she yearns to be part of the group.

title: Aldous Huxley
description: I never pretended to be a congenital novelist, says Aldous Huxley through his fictional creation, Philip Quarles; the lamed, overintellectualized author and deficient husband and father who is his dim standin in Point Counter Point. The chief defect of the novel of ideas is that you must write about people who have ideas to express which excludes all but about.01 per cent of the human race. Hence,the real, the congenital novelists don't write such books.

title: U.S. Names Navy Officer Killed in Korea DMZ Blast
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 23 (Reuters)  A United States Navy officer, Comdr. Robert M. Ballinger, 41 years old, died in na explosion in a tunnel in the demilitarized zone dividing the two Koreas on Wednesday, the United Nations Command announced today.

title: Dance; Despite all probabilities, the Pennsylvania Ballet is absolutely of the best troupes in the country. (Clive. Barnes); DANCE VIEW.; Philadelphia Is No JokeAt Least in Dance
description: After a while a New Yorker gets so used to Philadelphia jokes that he begins to believe them, just as he believes in cream cheese, the Liberty Bell and motherhood. For myself, I would dearly love to know whether W. C. Fields, who happens to be my favorite founding father, actually had on his gravestone the words: On the whole I would have preferred Philadelphia! Everyone has heard that joke, but is it true? Personally, I believe that Fields went up in a flash of brimstonehaving spent too long at the ball. Yet, whichever way you look at it, there have been Philadelphia jokes. As Mr. Fields might have said: It is nice place to grave, but I wouldn't want to groove there.

title: Sunday Observer
description: How to carve a turkey:

title: A friend at Quakertown National
description: Dr. Calvin Moyer used to set out regularly in the afternoons some years ago to make barn calls. Dr. Moyer was a veterinarian who also served parttime in the forties and fifties as the president of the local bank in Quakertown, a bucolic community nestled among the lush rolling hills of eastern Pennsylvania, and after banking hours he would visit his bovine patients. While he treated a sick cow in a farmer's barn, the good doctor would also try gently to drum up some loan business for the bank. He'd tell the farmer that if he'd buy a barn cleaner (a thennewfangled machine that scoops up manure), he could handle another five or six milch cows. The profits from the additional milk, Dr. Moyer explained, would more than pay the 5 per cent interest on a loan to buy the machine. Quakertown's Pennsylvania Dutch farmers were cautious folk, not eager to be in debt, and they thought about it for awhile. But a good many, eventually followed their friend's advice, and that was how the Quakertown National Bank made of its loans.

title: Nancy Livia Newman Is Engaged
description: Edwin Newman, a commentator and correspondent for NBC News, and Mrs. Newman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Livia Newman, to Henry Drucker, son of Mr. and Mrs, Arthur Drucker of Rutherford. N. J.

title: Kings Skate to 00 Tie, Stay Unbeaten on Road
Miss Dwyer, David Stewart Have Nuptials

title: ART VIEW HILTON KRAMER Unspecified Disasters
description: W hen Yves Tanguy died in 1955, he bad long been established as a figure of some importance in the history of Surrealist, painting. His death was immediately followed by a major retrospective exhibition of his work at the Museum of Modern Art, and his oeuvre seemed assured of a permanent place among the classics of modern painting. In recent years, however, his work has excited very. little interest. Although dntiftilly reproduced and discussed in studies of the Surrealist movement and occasionally exhibited in surveys of the Surrealist period Tanguy's paintings had effectively passed into a kind of limbo where the old claims were neither affirmed nor denied and no new claims made on their behalf.

title: STAMPS
description: This month marks the 100th anniversary of the birth of Sir Winston Churchill, the great British leader during the, war against Hitler, who refused to bow to tyranny, who demanded of his nation blood, sweat and tears to preserve freedom, and whose eloquence and resoluteness inspired the world.

title: Barbara Stoll Plans Bridal
description: Mrs. Bernard Stoll of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Barbara Joan Stoll, to Dr. Roger I. M. Glass, son of Dr. and Mrs. George A. Glass of Somerville, N. J. The prospective bride is also a daughter of the late Dr. Stoll, who served as chief of the department of physical medicine and rehabilitation at the Manhattan Veterans Hospital and as associate clinical professor of medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine here.

title: News Summary and Index
New State Lottery
description: A new 50cent New York State lottery that will give participants a chance to win $285,000 or more will go on sale Wednesday, replacing the present 50cent weekly lottery that has a top prize of $50,000. Page 25.

title: Ford Monitors U.S. Coverage of Trip;
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 Although he is pit the other side of the world, President Ford is receiving detailed reports each day on what the newspapers and television networks at home are saying about his Overseas journey and other events.

title: Meri Polstein Is Bride
description: In Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst, L. I., last night Meri Polstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, Joseph N. Polstein of East Rockaway, L. I., was married to John Richard Grumbacher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Grumbacher of Hagerstown. Md. Rabbi Edward T. Sandrow performed the ceremony.

title: New Yorker Is Veterinarian For Olympic Games in 1976
description: Dr. Joseph O'Dea of Geneseo, N. Y., longtime veterinarian of the United States Equestrian Team, has been named official veterinarian for he 1976 Olympic Games in Montreal. The Federation Equestre Internationale, the world governing body of equestrian sports, made the appointment. Dr. O'Dea is the first from the United States to be named to the post. The F.E.I., through Dr. O'Dea, plans to conduct an extensive drug testing program at the games, along the lines of the stringent measures instituted four years ago by the AmeriShows Association.

title: Yale Fans All Aboard For a LocomotiveCheer
description: BOSTON, Nov. 23As long as you're going to The Game, said a Yale sophomore, Blake Hannaford, in a blue and white Y sweater, you might as well go in style.

title: Batsto Is Restoring Houses
description: BATSTO  Seventeen workers houses in this onceprosperous bogiron and glass manufacturing center are being restored for the nation's Bicentennial observance in 1976. The cottages will be filled with craftsmen working and living as they did while casting cannons and cannonballs for the Revolutionary Army.

description: TRENTON  Although its sponsors are expected to push for a postponement the Democratic majority in the State Senate is scheduled to vote informally tomorrow on a proposed statewide property tax that apparently faces overwhelming opposition.

description: Dr. and Mrs. Roy R. Fells of Clifton, Bristol, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Jean Fells, to Henry Heath Learnard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Learnard of Newton and Chatham, Mass.

description: PORT JEFFERSON The, first oceangoing passenger liner to leave from a: Long, Island port is scheduled to depart from an oil tanker dock here April 46 for a sevenday cruise to Bermuda.
