description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23President Ford and his top advisers, while publicly insisting that they will adhere to the economic program he announced last month, are under mounting pressure to change their conservative, restrictive antiinflation. policies in the face of deepening recession. And there are indication& that the President's holdfast policies are beginning to soften.

title: Boxing Has Returned to New Brunswick
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The long, narrow redbrick building is dirty and sits next to a vacant lot. But the inside of the Franklin Boxing Club and Gym is a bright red and white, thus tending to minimize the otherwise drab surroundings.

title: DEMOCRATS REJECT HOUSE RECESS PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23(AP)The Democrats have turned down a plan to put the House on a one week a month off schedule, schedule, but its main sponsor) says he will try again when newly elected members have a chance to vote.

title: Escaped Tiger is Slain Alter Mauling Pursuer
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 23 (UPI) The police used more than 40 bullets to shoot to death a 300pound pregnant Bengal tiger today when the animal escaped from its cage at the Knoxville Zoo and mauled a veterinarian who was trying to subdue it with a tranquilizer gun.

title: NUMISMATICS HERBERTC BARDES
description: The coin counterfeiting problem is bad and getting worse  one reason being that the counterfeiters techniques are good and getting better. An equally important reason is that the number of sitting ducks"unsophisticated buyershas grown tremendously and continues to increase because coins are receiving a tremendous amount of national publicity as a hedge against inflation that is supposedly safer and surer than the stock market. Based on recent letters and phone calls that have come in to this department from people who have decided to put some money into coins, most if not all of these investors know little or nothing about them. This is a madetoorder situation for counterfeiters.

title: The Absent Conspirator
description: As the prosecution in the Watergate coverup trial winds down, it is evident that the disembodied voice and brooding absence of Richard M. Nixon have been at the center of the courtroom drama. All week long the tapes have been played, casting out the auditory replicas of the former President and his men, thrashing about, attempting to find some way to contain an uncontrollable problem. While the present defendants have only their freedom and their property at stake, their absent coconspirator's words are inexorably shaping for him that verdict for which he used to care most deeplythe judgment of history.

title: Parochial Text Aid Cost $ 3.6Million
description: TRENTON  William T. Searle, coordinator of the parochialaid program for the state's Department of Education, reports that New Jersey has distributed $3.6million to public schools for the purchase of textbooks for 243670 students in 682 private and parochial schools.

title: Neither Garbage Nor Salad Baskets
description: PARISWhenever things go really wrong in France there is a stink of garbage in the streets of Paris because, as usual, the unfortunates who earn ,Their keep by its removal are understandably among the first to join a strike wave. There has been a strike wave, but it is ending. The garbage has been cleared away by the army also as usualand the Giscard d'Estaing Government has survived its first crucial test without the President himself being forced to take exceptional measures.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (Reuters)Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today he would like to see the United States resume trading with Cuba because imports of Cuban sugar could help reduce soaring prices.

title: We Will Be Back for $600Million Says A.T.&T. Chief
description: We will be back for the $600million, said John D. De Butts, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, on CBS television yesterday. He was referring to the giant company's cancellation of a large public offering on Friday, two days after the Government's surprise announcement of an antitrust suit against A.T.&T. to force divestiture of its manufacturing right arm, the Western Electric Company.

title: Red Smith
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 24The most theatrical team in professional football brought its act east today to the town where Broadway's biggest hits have been trying out since the days of Edwin Booth. They may not be a very good football team, a man said before the show opened, but they're entertainers, and that's what this business is all about. The man was half right. On this afternoon the St. Louis Cardinals were not a good football team and also not entertaining. Neither were the New York New Haven New Jersey Giants, which explains why St. Louis still leads the Eastern Division of the National Conference. As the poorest of poor relations in the Eastern Division, the Giants have exhibited one special talent this seasonthe ability to lose games at the very last moment even if they have to go into overtime. They lost this one, 2321, with three seconds left on the clock. A week ago they lost to Detroit with exactly the same time left, and a week earlier they dropped one to the New York Jets in the fifth period.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Joan Fontaine will join faculty members of Brooklyn College next month in teaching a course, From Fiction to Film: The Films of Joan Fontaine. The films with Miss Fontaine, which will be shown Dec. 2, 3, 4 and 5, include Rebecca, Jane Eyre and Suspicion. Miss Fontaine will lecture on the Brooklyn College campus Dec. 4 and 18. The screenings and lectures will be open to the public. Miss Fontaine's sister, Olivia de Havilland, participated in a similar course on her films at Brooklyn College last spring.

title: ACCUSED ORGANIST FACES NEW CHARGE
DR. MARY R. ELESTON
description: Dr. Mary R. Eleston, a Manhattan psychoanalyst, died Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital. Dr. Eleston graduated from Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1925. She was a preceptor at the Mount Sinai Hospital Psychiatric Service and a lecturer in psychiatry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

title: Joyce Garrick Is Bride Of Alan R. Manheimer

title: News Summary and Index

Secretary of State Kissinger said it was a breakthrough in the efforts to halt the arms race, and that the final agreement could be signed next summer, when Mr. Brezhnev visits the United States, [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: A.E.C. Rebuts Scientist Critics Of a Report on Reactor Safety

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Not long ago the Ford Administration appeared to be casting the middleman in the role of bad guy responsible for soaring food prices. But in recent days, Administration spokesmen have been backing precipitately away from their accusations.

description: LEXINGTON, Mass., Nov. 24 (AP)The house where Paul Revere awakened John Hancock and Samuel Adams on the night of his famous ride almost 200 years ago has been moved across the street to its original foundation.

description: The Ampex Corporation, a leading maker of magnetic recording tape and data information systems, yesterday reported a sharp recovery in net earnings, to $14.7million, or $1.35 a share, in the first six months of its current fiscal year ended Oct. 26.

In publishing, this seems to be Hitler's year, and after reading The Hitler File, I find myself trying to understand the fascination he still holds for so many people.

title: WEISSENBERG PLAYS BACH'S VARIATIONS
description: They say that Bach wrote the Goldberg Variations to help cure a nobleman's insomnia with music of gentle and soothing character, and some players today approach the music accordingly. Not so Alexis Weissenberg. Saturday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., the pianist gave a performance of the Variations that was taut, highpower and anything but soothing and gentle.

title: CASHMAN AND WEST AT THE BOTTOM LINE
description: Terry Cashman and Tommy West are best known as record producers, but they are also a pop duo reminiscent of Simon and Garfunkel in their glory years, and last weekend they were opening for Al Kooper at the Bottom Line.

title: Allison Victor In Auto Race
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Nov. 24 (AP)Bobby Allison cruised to only his second Grand Natinal stock car triumph of the year today, winning the Los Angeles Times 500mile race When a fiveway battle for the lead dwindled to a rout in the last 10 miles.

title: Greyhound Accord Ends Week's Strike
description: PHOENIX, Ariz. Nov. 24Greyhound Bus Lines and the Amalgamated Transit Union reached an agreement today, ending a weeklong strike by bus drivers and other workers. Buses began rolling again shortly after the accord was announced. The agreement is subject to ratification by union members.

title: Maine Recount Set Today
Ohio State Rose Bowl Selection
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 24Ohio State was voted into the Rose Bowl today about 24 hours after the Buckeyes felt they had earned that bowl spot by beating Michigan, 1210, at Columbus, Ohio.

title: Deborah Cavalier a Bride
description: The marriage of Deborah Ann Cavalier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Cavalier of Ridgewood, N.J., to Roy Alan Lapidus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Lapidus of Fair Lawn, N.J., took place yesterday morning in Mahwah, N.J. Judge Paul Huot of the Bergen County District Court performed the ceremony at the Apple Ridge Country Club.

title: Experts Fear Growth  In Costly City Debts
description: In recent months, as New York City has plunged deeper into debt, the financial community has begun to put pressure on the city to reduce its mammoth appetite for borrowed money.

title: Flames Top Flyers, 43; Narrow Gap
Small Concerns Can't Compete for Workers.
Congress Moves to Modify Law Restricting Sex Bias by Schools
description: A HouseSenate conference committee has voted to qualify a 1972 antisex discrimination law to exclude fraternities and sororities from coverage and to allow schools to continue to operate separate gym classes for boys and girls.

title: Prestigious Victory for Far Rockaway
description: Far Rockaway High School became yesterday the first Public Schools Athletic League team in 15 years to defeat St. Francis Prep. The Sea Homes' defense kept the Catholic Schools Football League power throttled in its own territory through the second half of a 127 victory at St. John's University. Far Rockaway has won seven and lost one, with a Thanksgiving Day game with Brooklyn Tech to play. St. Francis is 53.

title: 2 U. S. MEN FACE SPY TRIAL IN INDIA
description: CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 24The Indian Government has decided to prosecute two young Americans on espionage charges. Lawyers for the two insist that the defendants were involved in attempted narcotics smuggling, and were not engaged in spying.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Joseph G. Barkan, Queens member of the Board of Education, said that the board could save $5million to $15million in budget cuts that Mayor Beame had sought by not filling vacant jobs and by a drive against teachers absenteeism.

title: L.I. Man Describes Ordeal as a Hostage
description: A young Long Island man and his girl friend, who were among the hostages released yesterday after four days aboard a hijacked British jetliner, called home from Tunis to calm their parents and say they were all right.

title: MEDIATOR SOUGHT IN TEACHER STRIKE
description: TRENTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) The union representing striking teachers at eight state colleges called today for the appointment of a mediator to help settle the weekold walkout, which has affected 60,000 students.

title: The A.T. & T. Case
description: The suit of the Justice Department to break up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is of enormous importance in its own right. A.T. & T. is the largest privately owned corporation in the world and communications is probably the most crucial sector of what has been called the postindustrial society. But the significance of the case goes even further, since its outcome will help determine the roles of competition, monopoly and government regulation in the emerging economic system.

title: R. P. ALEXANDER, 76, PHILADELPHIA JUDGE
description: Judge Raymond Pace Alexander, the first black to serve on Philadelphia's Court of Commin Pleas, of which he remained a senior judge, died apparently of a heart attack in his chambers there yesterday. He was 76 years old.

title: Only Connect

title: Busoni's Doctor Faust Staged Brilliantly at Indiana

title: New Jersey Sports
description: HAZLET, Nov. 24The nonathletes, boys and girls who have been left out of sports since the beginning of organized youth leagues, are getting a chance to play again in Hazlet. The Hazlet Youth Athletic League, an organization operated by about 200 men and women who want their children to grow up playing, provides approximately 2,500 youngsters with equipment, a place to play and a nopressure guarantee.

title: Hustler Takes On All Comers at TrashCan Chess Parlor on 8th Ave.
description: Eighth Avenue between 42d and 43d Streets, already a boulevard of offbeat diversions, has added a different kind of hustle to its scene: chess al fresco.

title: TUNISIA TO GRANT ASYLUM TO ARABS WHO SEIZED PLANE
Jersey Consumer Notes
description: If rising expectations, evidenced by a sharply rising case load, are any criteria, the State Division of Consumer Affairs has made a strong impression on consumers.

title: NIXON'S CHECKUP EXPECTED TODAY
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24The courtordered medical examination of former President Richard M. Nixon is likely to take place tomorrow at Mr. Nixon's San Clemente estate, the chairman of the threephysician examining panel said today.

description: VLADIVOSTOK, U. S. S. R., Nov. 24 (AP)Following is the text of a communiqu signed by President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev, General Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, and made public here today by the White House staff:and fully the mutual obligations undertaken by the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. in accordance with the treaties and agreements concluded between them.

title: Advertising
description: Continuing and increasing Government regulation of advertising has created a new function for agency research people, in the opinion of william T. Moran, a former agency man who is now marketing research director of Lever Brothers.

title: ARABS OPTIMISTIC ON GENEVA TALKS
description: CAIRO, Nov. 24The call by President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader for a resumption soon of the Geneva conference on the Middle East was taken in a spirit of optimism here today by moderate Arab diplomats.

title: Cause of Terror
description: Conning a majority of the United Nations into a grant of national respectability was relatively easyand relatively meaningless. The real challenge for Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and his myopic sponsors among the Arab leaders has now been thrust tragically before them: to assert their authority and discipline, so easily endorsed by governments far away in geography and understanding, upon fanatic murderers who consider themselves far more worthy fighters for the Palestinian cause.

title: Edward McMillan, 71, Dies; Princeton Center and Coach
description: PAOLI, Pa., Nov. 24 (AP)Edward McMillan, a Princeton University center whom Grantland Rice selected for his first allAmerica football team nearly 50 years ago, died yesterday. He was 71 years old.

title: JOHN CLARK, EXHEAD OF HIALEAH RACING
description: John C. Clark, president of Hialeah Park Race Course from 1940 to 1955, who directed the building of its $2.5million clubhouse, died Saturday in Miami Beach, where he lived. He was 83 years old and formerly lived here and in Binghamton, N. Y.

title: Cards Win, 2321, on Field Goal
Jets Upset Dolphins
description: The Jets upset the Miami Dolphins, 1714, at Shea Stadium yesterday as Joe Namath threw a 45yard touchdown pass to Rich Caster with 5 minutes left. The Giants lost to the Cardinals, 2321, at New Haven when Jim Bakken kicked a St. Louis field goal with three seconds left. Details on Page 41.

title: City to Salute 45 Today for Bicentennial Effort
description: The city will honor 45 institutions, community groups and individuals today for their exhibition projects and programs depicting aspects of New York City in the nearly 200 years since American independence.

title: Text of the Nuclear Arms Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI)Following is the text a joint United StatesSoviet agreement to limit strategic nuclear arms from 1975 to 1985, signed in Vladivostok and made public in Washington and Moscow;

title: Essex Woman Is Named NOW's State Coordinator
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 24 (UPI)Judy Knee, former vice president of the Essex County chapter of the National Organization of Women, was elected this weekend as state coordinator of the 3,000member group. She succeeds Rosemary Dempsey Belont, who has been named, codirector of the NOW eastern region.

title: Marina Princess Poutiatine Is Bride of Peter Afanasenko
description: Marina Princess Poutiatine and Peter Afanasenko, RussianEnglish interpreters for the United States astronauts in the joint ApolloSoyuz program with the Soviet Union, were married here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. John Meyendorff performed the ceremony in the Russian Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Virgin Protection.

title: 2 Leaders Simpatico, Says Ford Spokesman
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (Reuters)Aboard the Presidential plane returning from the Soviet Union today, Ron Nessen, the White House spokesman, told reporters the summit had produced one of the most significant agreements since World War II.

title: 12 Persons Drown, Another Is Missing In Texas Flooding

description: Three members of the city Board of Education said yesterday that they would be willing to have requirements for financial disclosures by board members and staff aides.

title: WALDHEIM LEAVES ON MIDEAST TRIP
SCHOOL AIDE TELLS HOW TO ECNONMIZE
description: Joseph G. Barkan, Queens member of the Board of Education, said yesterday that the board could save $5million to $15million in budget cuts that Mayor Beame had sought by not filling vacant jobs and by a drive against teacher absenteeism.

title: CAMBODIA AWAITS CRUCIAL U.N. VOTE
CALENDAR IS LIGHT IN BOND MARKET
The Nixon Conspiracy
description: Even at this late date, the testimony provided to the Watergate trial last week by the Presidential tapes would simply not be believed had it been brought into court in any format other than Mr. Nixon's own words. It would be all but impossible to persuade A jury that those characters huddling over plans of how best to erase the traces of their crimes were actually the President of the United States and his closest advisers.

title: Nursing Home Syndicator Subpoenaed By Lefkowitz in Inquiry on Towers
description: Bernard Bergman has been subpoenaed by the office of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to explain dealings in his syndicate of nursing homes, according to Government investigators.

title: Allison Victor In Auto Race
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Nov. 24 (AP)Bobby Allison cruised to only his second Grand Natinal stock car triumph of the year today, winning the Los Angeles Times 500mile race when a fiveway battle for they lead dwindled to a rout in the last 10 miles.

title: A Racial Trend in Immigration Is Troubling Canadians
description: TORONTOAnn MacDonald, widow who lives in a little old house in a part of Toronto that is shabby but still proud, has grown worried and afraid. Her fear tells the story of what is emerging in Canada as an agonizing national debate.

title: Sports Today
Major Bills in Congress
description: Fuel  Gives the President broad powers to curtail energy consumption and manage fuel supplies. Veto sustained by Senate.

title: New Coal Pact Is Reached Under Pressure by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24Negotiators for the coal industry and the United Mine Workers union agreed in principle tonight on a second version of a proposed contract that could end the national coal miners strike in about 10 days, if it wins acceptance by the union membership.

title: Mrs. Rockefeller Will Undergo Surgery on Right Breast Today
description: Margaretta Rockefeller will undergo surgery this morning for removal of her right breast, five weeks after her left breast was found to contain cancerous tissue and was removed in the same type of operation.

title: Scandals for Schools
description: James F. Regan, the president of the Board of Education, remarked recently that he had grown so concerned over the almost daily disclosures of fiscal irregularities in the school system that he was getting up earlier than usual these days just to see if there were fresh bombshells exploding in the morning newspapers.

title: Braves Lose, Streak Ends At 11 Games

description: CARACAS, Venezuela Government monetary authorities here are racing to contain the flood of petroleum earnings that threatens to undermine Venezuela's traditional stability in a matter of months.

MENINGITIS SCARE EASES AT COLLEGE
description: An analysis of 1,150 throat cultures taken among the 13,000 students, faculty memberg and employes of Trenton. State College last Friday found no new cases of meningitis a disease that kiled a 19yearold undergraduate earlier this month.

title: TEXTBOOK CRITICS SUED FOR SLANDER
description: FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov 23A $30million libel, slander and conspiracy suit has beer brought against three women who successfully opposed state approval of textbooks for use in Texas public schools.

description: Eugene F. Hillery, a lawyer and former county district judge in Morristown, N. J., died yesterday in a nursing home.

title: Letters to the Editor
Abitibi's Battle Highlights TorontoMontreal Split
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 24The Abitibi Paper Company's victory last week in a highstakes auction for control of one of its main competitors climaxed a week of colorful corporate drama that had kept the Canadian business community fascinated.

title: The Stage: Joseph Conrad's Victory
New Coal Pact Is Reached Under Pressure by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24Negotiators for:the coal industry and the United Mine Workers union agreed in principle tonight on a second version of a proposed contract that could end the national coal Miners' strike in about 10 days, if it wins acceptance by the union membership.

description: There are wide differences in the reported incidences of cancer in a remaining breast after a woman has had one cancerous breast removed.

title: SOL WILSON DEAD; EXPRESSIONIST, 81

description: A Nassau County police helicopter that had just rescued two stranded fishermen became disabled and crashed last evening into a tidal inlet at the southern tip of Freeport, L.I., killing one of the rescued persons.

title: Duke, Wire Fox Terrier, judged Best 35th Time
Notes on Mongolia at 50
Dismissed Executive Seeking Order on Southwestern Bell Files
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 24  An ousted executive of the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company is scheduled to appear in court tomorrow to ask that the company be ordered not to destroy records that he says will disclose rate rigging and a secret political fund.

title: A Gain Toward Detente
New Turkish Leader Asks Arms Industry Be Set Up
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 24 (AP)Preinier. Sadi Irmak of Turkey presented to Parliament today a program for his new government calling for Carly elections and the establishment of an armaments industry.

title: SCHOOL AIDES BACK FISCAL DISCLOSURE
description: Three members of the city Board of Education said yesterday that they would be willing to have requirements for financial disclosures by board members and staff aides.

title: Work Begins on 2 Skywalks at Hunter
description: Construction has begun on the city's first project to span a midtown avenue. Hunter College is building 17story towers on each side of Lexington Avenue between 67th and 68th Streets that will be connected by skywalks at the third and seventh floors.

title: Industry Aim to Raise SmallCar Margins Backfires
Concert: Messenger
description: Laren Rush, whose The Cloud Messenger was given its first New York performance Saturday night by the Boston Symphony at Carneegie Hall, is a composer from the San Francisco area who has won a good deal of recognition there but who is just beginning to become known around the rest of the country.

title: British Police Charge Six Men in Bombing of Pubs
description: LONDON, Nov. 24Six men from Northern Ireland, all living in Birmingham, were charged tonight with the explosions in two Birmingham pubs on Thursday that killed 19 persons and injured 184. The men will appear in court tomorrow.

title: MORTON GOULD LEADS AMERICAN SYMPHONY
description: Morton Gould led the American Symphony Orchestra in a refreshingly unusual program yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall that included two first New York performances and one certified rarity.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: WOMEN'S APPAREL IS UP 4% IN SALES
description: Factory sales of women's and children's clothing rose 4 per cent in dollar volume during the first eight months of 1974. But in terms of units, industry shipments were down 2 per cent from a year earlier, according to Lazare Teper, research director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

title: Vladivostok, Long Closed to Americans, Shows Off Its Bays and Snowy Hills
description: VLADIVOSTOK, U.S.S.R., Nov. 24Take all the pictures you want, said Valentin P. Byankin, president of the Soviet Far Eastern Shipping Company, as American journalists clicked their cameras at warships anchored in Vladivostok Harbor.used to take Soviet tourists to Japan and Hong Kong, was turned over to the American reporters by the Far Eastern Shipping Company, and the company president had a large contingent of officers and attendants aboard to entertain the visitors.

title: BEAN, PIANIST, PUTS FOCUS ON UNUSUAL
description: David Bean is not only a pianist with a big technique but also one whose personality and musical tastes lead Whim into repertory areas and program combinations not common to most performers.

title: A Gain Toward Detente
Massachusetts Port Head Dismissed
description: BOSTON Nov. 24One of the most powerful figures in Massachusetts, likened by many to a slightly smallerscale version of New York's Robert Moses, has been toppled.

title: Israel Plans West Bank Factory Center
Rangers Conquer Penguins
Suzen Beth Stampler Is Married
description: Suzen Beth Stampler, daughter of Mrs. Tess Lloyd of New York and Daniel Stampler of New York and Miami, was married here yesterday afternoon to Gerald Kenneth Drogin, vice president of Pearce, Mayer & Greer, Inc. He is the son of Mrs. Jacob Drogin of Bayonne, N.J., and the late Mr. Drogin. Rabbi Gunther Hirschberg performed the ceremony at the Hampshire House.

title: GOING OUT Guide
Judge Takes Case Of Suit on Northrop Under Advisement
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23Federal District Judge Warren J. Ferguson today took under advisement a precedentsetting tentative settlement of a class action suit shareholders filed here last May against the Northrop Corporation concerning illegal campaign contributions.

title: 525 Show Up for a Health Fair
description: LAURANCE HARBOR, Nov. 24An Adult Health Fair sponsored by Madison Township and the South Amboy Memorial Hospital to bring health and social services closer to the people and to encourage them to protect their health drew more than 525 people here today.

title: HIJACKERS FREE ALL BUT 3 IN CREW AT TUNIS AIRPORT
description: TUNIS, Monday, Nov. 25Four Palestinian guerrillas who hijacked a British airliner freed their remaining hostages yesterday, except for three crew members. The hijackers threatened to blow up the plane after Arab nations apparently refused them sanctuary.

title: City Offers a List Of Nutritious Meals That Need No Heat
description: Many elderly people do not have cooking facilities. Here are suggestions from the New York City Department of Health for nutritious meals that require no cooking:

description: Democratic legislative leaders in New Jersey indicated yesterday that they were prepared to recommend a 1cent increase in the state's 5cent sales tax and increases of 2 or 3 cents in the state excise tax, on gasoline and cigarettes to bridge the largest budget gap in the state's history.

title: 1C SALES TAX RISE STUDIED IN JERSEY
description: Democratic legislative leaders in New Jersey indicated yesterday that they were prepared to recommend a 1cent increase in the state's 5cent sales tax and increases of 2 or 3 cents in the state excise tax on gasoline and cigarettes to bridge the largest budget gap in the state's history.

title: Third World's War
Lunch Programs Feed Mind and Body of Elderly
Moses Has West Side Highway Plan
Cornelius Ryan Dies
description: Cornelius Ryan, Whose popular histories of World War II drew millions of readers, died at the age of 54. He was the author of The Longest Day. Page 34.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Bearne and his wife flew to Florida yesterday to spend the week with friends in Palm Beach. He is scheduled to return to New York next weekend. The Mayor's press office said that Mr. Beame would interrupt his vacation briefly to be at the White House tomorrow for the signing of the urban mass transit bill, which Congress passed last week.

title: Joblessness Rate Reported
description: BOSTON, Nov. 24 (AP)Massachusetts had the third highest unemployment rate in the nation during October with 7.4 per cent of its potential work force of 2.6 million persons out of work, The Boston Globe reported today. Federal statistics showed only Hawaii and Alaska had higher unemployment rates, the paper said.

title: Namath Passes to Caster for Two Scores
BYRNE ASKS STUDY OF TOCKS I. STUDY
description: Governor Byrne plans to name a 10member Citizens Advisory Board on the Tocks Island Study this week to monitor the progress of the Congressionally mandated analysis of the project.

description: CAIRO, Nov. 24The call by President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, for a resumption soon of the Geneva conference on the Middle East was taken in a spirit of optimism here today by moderate Arab diplomats.

title: The Major Events of the Day
description: President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, reached tentative agreement at their meeting in Vladivostok to limit the numbers of all offensive strategic nuclear weapons and delivery vehicles through 1985. Secretary of State Kissinger said it was a breakthrough in the efforts to halt the arms race, and that the final agreement could be signed next summer, when Mr. Brezhnev visits Ole United States. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Beth Simon Is Wed To Andrew Swartz
William Cahan, Surgeon, Weds Grace Mirabella
description: Grace Mirabella, editor in chief of Vogue magazine, and Dr. William G. Cahan, a surgeon, were married here yesterday afternoon.

title: Unemployment Claims Up
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 24 (UPI)Unemployment insurance claims in Connecticut have risen to 57,562, compared with 36,142 a year ago, the State Labor Department reported today. The unemployment rate, which covers insured workers, was 3.7 per cent for the twoweek period ended Nov. 16, compared with 2.6 per cent a year ago. The claims included 8,628 new and 48,934 continued claims.

title: KAREN SHAW EXCELS IN A PIANO RECIT AL
description: Karen Shaw, who made her debut here at Town Hall in 1967 and has been on the piano faculty of Indiana University since that year, gave a recital of Russian music yesterday at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. In certain hands, the program might have become cloying, containing as it did the 24 Preludes (Op. 11) and Sonata No. 4 in F sharp (Op. 30) of Scriabin; four Rachmaninoff Preludes, and  moving only partly out of the neoChopin, neoTchaikovsky idiom Prokofiev's Sonata No. 2 in D minor (Op. 14).

title: Alouettes Win Grey Cup, 20 to 7
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 24 (UPI)  Don Sweet booted four field goals today to lead the Montreal Alouettes to a 207 victory over the Edmonton Eskimos in the Grey Cup, the Canadian Football League's super bowl.

title: Federal Panel in Chicago Ends Hearings on Job Discrimination
Stockton, Drysdale, Roche Gain in japqn
description: TOKYO, Nov. 24 (AP)Dick Stockton, Cliff Drysdale and Tony Roche gained the men's singles semifinals today of a $100,000 tennis tournament here.

title: Expeits Pear Grpwth In Costly City Debts
description: In recent months, as New York City has plunged deeper into debt, the financial community has begun to put pressure on the city to reduce its mammoth appetite for borrowed money.

title: Wanted, History: $1,000 Reward
Nonsmokers Fight to Clear Public Air
description: No Smoking signs are going up in elevators, supermarkets and on the Puget Sound ferries. The right of America's nonsmoking majority to some smokefree air is increasingly being protected by law.

title: Teachers Meet to Fight Sexism in the Schools
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 24They have so few resources. And once they're saddled with a child, it's all over. Their lives are ended, said Isabel Byron, who teaches English and woman's studies at a minority high school in Manhattan.

title: Rams Beat Vikings, 2017; Harris Leads Late Surge
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24Succeeding where the mythical Sisyphus failed, the Los Angeles Rams kept pushing their burden uphill all afternoon and finally got it to the top in a 2017 victory over the Minnesota Vikings that brought them to the brink of the National Football League playoffs.

title: The Party Was a Success and Broke Up at Nap Time
Ballet: Swedes End a Visit Plagued by gad Luck
description: It was a somewhat brief encounter for New York to have with a national ballet. We are accustomed to our visitors staying longer. However, last night the Royal Swedish Ballet completed its week's season at the City Center 55th Street Theater. It was the first time the Swedes have payed in New York, and although the repertory was not especially wellplanned, it was wide in scope and gave opportunities to many of the company's dancers.

title: Greyhound Accord Ends Week's Strike
Motorists in Connecticut To Have Use of Call Boxes
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 24 (AP)Emergency gall boxes for disabled motorists will go into operation along two stretches of Connecticut's interstate highway network tomorrow, according to the State Transportation Department.

title: St. Louis, Textile Win  N.C.A.A. Soccer Games
description: St. Louis University and Philadelphia Textile posted 10 victories yesterday over Cleveland State and Bucknell, respectively. Howard, Southern Illinois and San Francisco also triumphed in the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournaments.

title: STUDY CITES NEEDS OF RURAL TRANSPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) The nation must end separate and unequal treatment of the transportation needs of the cities and the countryside, a House subcommittee has concluded after a sixmonth study.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The embattled directordesignate of the state Division of Women won support from a group of black officials and from state Senator Anthony Imperiale, Independent of Essex County. Mr. Imperiale and the Association of Black Elected Officials, in separate statements, announced their support for Penelope L. Kuykendall of East Brunswick to be head of the division.

title: Television
description: Afternoon

title: Seattle Federal Office Building Has Safety and Energy Theme
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24The General Services Administration is attempting to take the lead in designing and constructing office buildings that it hopes will be safer for occupants, consume considerably less energy and reduce the unfavorable impact of large people centers on the environment.

title: Torture in Spain
description: Spain is in a chaotic state of political decomposition. The Franco family has been discreetly removing furniture and other valuables from the Pardo Palace to family property in Torrelodones. The Franco estate in Mstoles has also been quietly sold. Clearly, the family is preparing for mobility.

title: ORDERS SHOW DIP IN MACHINE TOOLS
description: Machinetool orders fell below the yearago leyel in October but for the first 10 months of this year remained ahead of the 1973 level, according to figures released over the weekend by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
FASHION TALK
description: Not every woman wants clothes that will stop traffic, startle her friends and make a room full of people starecertainly not all of the time. So even the most avantgarde designers do not eschew a ruffle here, a flounce there in the interest of making a woman look pretty, not eccentric.

title: Stage: The Island, a Powerful Tale of Prison Life
With Crangle Gone, State Democrats Speculate Esposito Will Be Next to Be Ousted by Carey
description: With the Democratic state chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, ousted because he was a latecomer to Governorelect Hugh L. Carey's bandwagon, Carey aides and other Deniocratic politicians are predicting that Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, will be the next top Democrat to resign by invitation of the new Governor.

title: Mrs. Rockefeller Will Undergo Surgery on Right Breast Today
description: Margaretta Rockefeller will undergo surgery this morning for removal of her right breast, five weeks after her left breast was found to contain cancerous tissue and was removed in the same type of operation.

title: Winter Wheat Prospects Called Favorable
description: ABBYVILLE, Kan., Nov. 22A late autumn sun was warming the tiny office of the Abbyville Cooperative Elevator this week and from the back windows one could see the flat fields of winter wheat sweeping away to the distant skyline.

title: Personal Finance
description: Let's put it in escrow. If you have never used or heard that expression in a business dealing, the word escrow may be somewhat puzzling to you. But with more and more transactions either requiring or benefiting from the use of escrow, more and more individuals are coming up against it in one way or another.

title: Owl Nights
description: Chilly November nights are owl nights. Not even the earlynesting great horned owl will be courting till January, so he and the barred owl and the little screech owl are merely announcing their presence. This is their time to hoot, or screech, or yammer.

title: British Satellite in Orbit
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 24 (UPI)The Skynet II military communications satellite was anchored 22,300 miles above the Indian Ocean tonight, providing England a satellite system. The satellite, designed to handle secret communications for about five years was launched Friday night by a delta rocket. British officials, wary as a result of two recent failures, regarded Skynet II as the last chance for the United Kingdom to hav its own satellite system for the armed forces.

title: KISSINGER IN TOKYO ON WAY TO PEKING
description: TOKYO, Nov. 24 (Reuters)Secretary of State Kissinger returned to Tokyo tonight after accompanying President Ford to Vladivostok for summit talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader.

title: Carolyn Fulbright Is Wed to L. S. Fried
description: Carolyn Frances Fulbright, a sales assistant with T.V.A.R., a televisionrepresentative firm, and Lawrence Stephen Fried, a network television supervisor in the TV programing department of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osbern, were married here yesterday afternoon.

title: SECURITIES BILL GOING TO A VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25The House Rules Committee will decide tomorrow whether securities industry reform legislation will be passed during the current, Iame duck, session of Congress, as the most intensive lobbying efforts by that industry in recent years comes to a close.

title: BRITAIN WILL BAN I.R.A. AND IMPOSE CURBS ON TRAVEL
Copper Prices Cut By Three Makers; CPC Sugar Raised
description: Continuing the trend that started about a month ago, three copper producers announced price cuts yesterday, while manufacturers of other products were reporting increases in prices Those announcing a threecent cut a pound in copper were the Phelps Dodge Corporation; the Magna Copper Company, a Newmont Mining Corporation unit, and the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: EAST SIDE, WEST SIDE The Lower East Side is now on show on the fancy midtown West Side and no one who calls himself a New York fancier should miss it. The exhibition, Hands and Heart: Traditional Skills of the Lower East Side, will be at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts, 29 West 53d Street (9778989), through Jan. 1. It's a lively, living show in which the arts of a cosmopolitan community have been explored and attractively put on view.

title: CRASH OF COPTER LINKED TO GULLS
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov 25Nassau County detectives said today that a flock of gulls might have caused the fatal crash of a police rescue helicopter into a canal in Freeport. One man was killed and three others injured.

title: Pornography Fight Lags Across Nation
description: DENVER Nov. 25Pornography is flourishing nationwide 17 months after the United States Supreme Court, unable to define nationally what is obscene, told local communities to decide obscenity questions for themselves.

title: STATE UNIT IS TOLD OF LOW BY UNION
description: Howard N. Garfinkle, a Miami realestate operator who has served two jail sentences for fraud and who is alleged to have close ties with organized crime, was described yesterday as the recipient of more than $2million in loans from Amalgamated Union Local 355.

title: Court Orders Suffolk to Equalize Facilities in Jail
description: RIVERHEAD, L. L, Nov. 25 A Federal Judge ordered Suffolk County officials to provide inmates in isolated wards of jails with the same education, exercise and recreation facilities as prisoners in other cell blocks.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: Sears, Hit by Rise in Inventories, Bids Suppliers Divert Orders to Others
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co., concerned by inventories substantially higher than they were last year, has asked a number of its prime suppliers to try to self to other retailers large quantities of goods ordered by Sears.

title: Schweiker Bids Ford Oust Most Former Nixon Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) Senator Richard S. Schweiker, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today that President Ford would have continued trouble with Congress until he rids his staff and Cabinet of most Nixon holdovers.

title: SemiIndependence
description: One year after hearing President Nixon's brave talk of Project Independence, the Federal Government has managed to assemble the data needed to start formulating a national energy policy. It has gone little farther.

title: U.S. Carrier in Persian Gulf for First Time in 26 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) An American aircraft carrier has entered the Persian Gulf for the first time in 26 years, the Pentagon announced today.

title: MGM TO PURCHASE ITS COMMON STOCK
description: MetroGoldwnMayer, Inc., announced yesterday in Culver City, Calif., that it intended to buy 2 million shares of its own common stock but would not convert to a private company. The purchases will be made under the terms of an offer announced Sept. 30 that calls for the exchange of each share of MGM common stock for one share of a new issue of Class B stock.

title: Leaders in Cyprus Discuss Steps to Reopening Airport
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 25 (Reuters) President Glafkos Clerides and Rauf Denktash, leader of the Turkish Cypriote community, discussed the reactivation of Nicosia airport's flight information center today as a first step toward reopening the airport, it was officially announced here.

title: Population 212,38,000
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) The United States grew by an estimated 166,000 persons in September, bringing the nation's population to about 212,382,000 on Oct. 1, 1974, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: FitzGerald Is Named New Chief of N.Y.R.A.
description: Thomas J. FitzGerald was named yesterday president of the New York Racing Association, ending months of speculation over who would succeed John H. Krumpe. FitzGerald has been serving as interim president since Krumpe resigned April 26.

title: MRS. GORDON BARCLAY
description: Katherine Campbell Barclay, wife of Dr. Gordon L. Barclay, managing director of the Research Foundation for Mental Hygiene in Albany, died of cancer yesterday at their home, in Loudonville, N.Y. She was 57 years old.

title: The Prpoceedings In the U.N. Today
Cunningham To Remain With 76ers
Members of Big Board Show Loss in Quarter
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that its members lost a total of $34.1million during the third quarter of 1974, in contrast to an aggregate profit of $19.9million a year earlier.

title: U.S.Chinese Trade for 1974 to Be Below Forecast
description: TOKYO, Nov. 22  The value of trade between China and the United States is going to be at least $300 million less this year than expected as a result of cancellations and postponements by the Chinese of a series of grain and soybean purchases.

title: Erie Teachers Stay Out
description: ERIE, Pa., Nov. 25 (UPI)More than 900 city school teachers defied an antistrike injunction today and walked out of classrooms for the sixth time this year in a continuing protest over a contract. About 18,000 students were affected by the strike.

title: HigherEducation Board Votes Budget Increase
State Is Held Liable In a Case of Assault By a Mental Patient
Phone Strike in 4th Day With Impasse at Rochester
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 25 (UPI) A strike by 1,500 workers against the Rochester Telephone Company entered its fourth day today, with no new talks in sight to end the walkout.

title: Rosa Knocked Out By Gregory in 8th
description: Eddie Gregory of Brooklyn survived a knockdown in the sixth and in the seventh rounds and scored a knockout. over Mario Rosa of Paterson, N.J., in the eighth round of their middleweight fight last night at the Felt Forum. Gregory weighed 161 pounds and Rosa 159.

title: Singapore Practice of Flogging As Crime Deterrent Is Debated
description: SINGAPOREA lively crimeandpunishment debate is going on here over the controversial and widespread practice of flogging prisoners in addition to their sentences.

title: Senate Votes to Replace Health Plan Nixon Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) The Senate by a vote of 65 to 18 approved to day healthplanning legislation to replace hospital and medical programs that were long opposed by President Nixon. Similar legislation pending in the House.

title: PROSECUTION ENDS CASE IN COVERUP; DEFENSE STARTS
SHOOTING OF BOY, 14, IS STUDIED IN BRONX
description: The Police Department and the Bronx District Attorney's office yesterday were investigating the shafting of a 14yearold boy by a policeman who had taken the boy into custody after responding to a report of a burglary in a school.

title: NudeBathing Plea Weighed
description: TRURO, Mass., Nov. 25 (UPI)Lawrence Hadley, Cape Cod seashore superintendent, said yesterday that he would consider very carefully 41 recommendation that nude bathing be banned on the beach here. The advisory commission to the Cape Cod National Seashore has asked that Mr. Hadley prohibit nude bathing on the isloated threemile stretch where it has been a tradition for nearly 60 years.

title: NEWARK'S PUPILS SHOW TEST GAINS
description: NEWARK, Nov. 25The Superintendent of Schools, Stanley Taylor, said today that the city's public school students demonstrated slight improvement in reading and mathematic skills according to a citywide test administered last spring.

title: 7 Dissidents Doomed by Seoul Are Said to Be Spies for North
Deaths
Dr. Theodore Leventhal, 49, Child Psychiatric Expert
description: Dr. Theodore Leventhal, who retired recently as executive director of the Children's Psychiatric Center of Monmouth County in Eatontown, N. J., died Thursday at his home in Atlantic Highlands, N. J. He was 49 years old and had suffered from multiple sclerosis.

title: Suit Against Southwestern Bell Delayed For a Ruling
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 25 A judge today postponed a preliminary hearing on a $29million libel and slander suit against the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company.

title: Football Ratings WRITERS POLL
description: By The Associated Press

title: Stage: An Engaging Prodigal Sister.
City's Layoff Casualties Are Stunned and Bitter
SCHOOLS WARNED ON FISCAL POLICY
description: Arthur M. Gordon, director of the state Controller's metropolitan office, told a City Council hearing yesterday that the central Board of Education must take more aggressive action to improve fiscal procedures.

title: MOSCOW AND OSLO OPEN ARCTIC TALKS
SPYING ON CITIZENS SCORED BY LAWYERS
Scotch Symphony Danced Delicately By Violette Verdy
description: Violette Verdy's musical phrasing is a distillation of exceptional delicacy and intelligence, and it has been missed during the long months of her absence from the New York City Ballet. She returned to dance a romantically misty Scotch Symphony for the first time on Sunday evening at the State Theater.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Nov. 21 (UPI)The Libyan Arab Republic and the British Petroleum Exploration Company (Libya), have signed an agreement lot a full and final settlement of all of the issues outstanding between the Government and the company, including the issues arising out of the Government's takeover in December, 1971, of the company's interests, British Petroleum reported today.

title: lnquiry Hears of Windfall In Sugar Industry Profits
Court Upholds Bias Charge
description: TRENTON, Nov. 25 (UPI)The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled today that a Margate couple had violated the civil rights law by refusing to sell a seashore home to a black doctor. The court upheld the finding of the State Civil Rights Division aganist Leonard and Betty Paccione, Dr. Robert F. Goldsboro of Stirling charged that the Pacciones refused to sell their home to him solely because of his race.

title: Toward Normal U.S. China Ties
News Summary and Index
description: The British Government asked Parliament to approve emergency legislation outlawing the Irish Republican Army, giving the police sweeping powers of arrest and detention and imposing new controls on travel between England and Ireland. The measures were outlined in the House of Commons by Roy Jenkins, the Home Secretary, who described them as unprecedented in peacetime. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Rockefeller Surgery
description: Margaretta Rockefeller underwent surgery for removal of her right breast. Surgeons said the prognosis for the Vice President  designate's wife was excellent. Page 26.

title: HOUSE UNIT HEARS & ROCKEFELLER FOES
Rep. Brown's Home Hit
description: URBANA, Ohio, Nov. 25 (AP) United States Representative Clarence J. Brown Jr.'s 19th century home was damaged by an apparent gas explosion yesterday, the authorities said. No one was home at the time.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Detroit Pistons, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. (Television  Channel H (cable), 7:30 P.M.) (RadioWNBC, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Short Interest Figures Adjusted by Big Board
description: The Short interest figures reported last Thursday by the New York Stock Exchange and carried here Friday were overstated in aggregate and for four individual securities, the exchange announced yesterday.

title: Enough Is as Good as a Feast Books of The Times
description: MYRON. By Gore Vidal. 244 pages, Random House. $6.95. Predictably, Myron is to its predecessor, Myra Breckinridge, what your usual movie sequel is to its precursor. A movie called The Fly comes to mind, for some reasonan understated yet powerful scifi thriller about a who through a mixup with it transformation machine exchanges not his gender but his head with a common housefly, the film's only flaw being Vincent Price as a secondary character. But in The Return of the Fly, Mr. Price took over everything (I still carry around with me a troubling if somewhat vague memory of Mr. Price's staring in horror at a friend who has just been turned into a giant bunny  rabbit)and the result was dreadful, or, as Myra Breckinridge might put it, de trop. And so it goes with Gore Vidal's two novels. The first seemed original, surprising, a classic of its kind (since it was the only one of its kind, it could hardly avoid being such), and its only flaw was its somewhat too clever ending, in which Myra is hit by a car and transformed back to masculine Myron by the resulting surgery. But in Myron, Mr. Vidal's cleverness takes over everything, and if the result is not so bad as to be dreadful, it is certainly a shade too much.

title: North Korean, in U.N., Calls Ford's Trip Aggression
Prices of Corporate Bonds Fall Amid Buyer Hesitation
description: Corporate and taxexempt bond prices turned downward yesterday amid hesitation over the course of shortterm rates. This lack of immediate market conviction, which followed two months of steadily declining rates across the shortterm sector, was symbolized by the decision of the First National Bank or Chicago to hold its prime rate unchanged at 10 per cent.

title: Cher to Star in TV Series
description: A new Sunday television series starring Cher Bono, of the Sonny and Cher perform. ing team that dissolved in divorce last summer, has been scheduled by CBSTV to begin on Feb. 9. The 7:30 P.M. variety series, entitled Cher, will replace Apple's Way, which has been canceled.

title: Jersey Senate Deadlocked on School Aid
description: TRENTON, Nov. 25  The Democratic majority in the State Senate failed once again to come anywhere near agreement on a revenue plan to finance publicschool education in New Jersey.

title: Inquiry Asked on Transfer Of an Officer Who Fell Ill
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 25A politically active Hudson County park policeman, who suffered an apparent heart attack late Friday after being reassigned to foot patrol duty, remained in critical condition today, while the attorney for the Policemen's Benevolent Association called for an investigation into the motives behind the transfer.

title: Mr. Ford's Triumph
description: After achieving an agreement with the Soiviets on nuclear arms limitation, President Ford will return home in triumph, his press spokesman said. Mr. Ford and Secretary Kissinger are certainly to be congratulated on what Mr. Kissinger said was a 'breakthrough, and it does break Mr. Ford's recent string of setbacks and disasters. Whether it will constitute a domestic political triumph is another question.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: Bringing Together the Troubled Children of a Troubled Land
description: Two very upperclass British women  one Roman Catholic, the other Protestantsettled down on a sofa in a midtown skyscraper yesterday and told of their efforts to help the children of strifetorn Northern Ireland, where Catholics and Protestants hate one another.

title: State Panel Condemns Justice System In City as Uncoordinated and Inefficient
description: The State Commission of Investigation charged yesterday that the city's criminaljustice system had become a jumble of illcoordinated and inefficient agencies, each pushing its own budget and interests with no regard for any overall plan to cope with increasing crime.

title: Tanaka Quits in Japan
description: Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan, facing charges of financial scandal and record lows in popularity polls, announced his resignation. Page 3.

title: Texas Instruments Plans Holiday Period Closings
description: DALLAS, Nov. 22 (UPI)Texas Instruments, Inc., has announced that many of its worldwide operations will be partly or completely closed on the Friday following Thanksgiving Day and from Dec. 22 through Jan. 5. Shipments to customers will continue during the shutdowns. The maker of electronics materials estimated that about 50 per cent of its work force would be on the job Friday and about 20 per cent during the ChristmasNew Year's period.

title: 200 Whites Leave Classes In Boston Antibusing Drive
description: BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP)Opponents of busing for school desegregation began a new tactic ni South Boston today as 200 white students walked out of classes at south Boston High.

title: Postal Service Lifts Ban on ExAddicts
description: The United, States Postal Service yesterday reversed its current policy and said it would hire former drug addicts, including people participating in methadone Maintenance treatment programs.

title: Theater: Green Fields
10 Dead in 3 Days As Tension Mounts In Northern Ireland
description: BELFAST, Northen Ireland, Nov. 25A 55yearold Protestant was shot dead today and another seriously injured when they were ambushed on their way to work in north Belfast.

title: DR. ALVIN LEBENDIGER
Man Gets a Second Heart To Ease Load on the First
State Inquiry Panel Finds Incept City Justice System
description: The State Commission of Investigation charged yesterday that the city's criminaljustice system had become a jumble of illcoordinated and inefficient agencies, each pushing its own budget and interests with no regard for any overall plan to cope with increasing crime.

title: I.R.A  Living on History
description: The Irish Republican Army, born of the Struggle to free Ireland from British rule, has been nurtured since the independence of the Irish Republic by its refusal to accept continuing British rule in six of the island's northern countiesUlster.

title: 3 COURT DOCTORS VISIT NIXON HOME
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 25 (AP)Three physicians, appointed by a court to determine if former President Richard M. Nixon is physically fit to testify at the Watergate coverup trial, spent two hours today inside Mr. Nixon's walled, seaside estate in San Clemente.

title: MRS. ROCKEFELLER LOSES 2D BREAST
ROBERT GOELLER, 84, OF ELECTRICAL FIRM
description: Robert A. Goeller, president of Hatzel & Buehler, electrical contractors, 420 Lexington Avenue, died Friday in Mamaroneck, N.Y., where he lived. He was 84 years old and also had a home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: People and Business
description: The possibility of a shipping rate war in the Pacific has been sighted by the Federal Maritime Commission chairman, Helen Delich Bentley, who favors Congressional action to prevent it.

title: Ford Selects a Manager To Head Energy Agency
Ford's ExTeammates Joining Him Thursday
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP)President and Mrs. Ford will celebrate Thanksgiving Thursday with a family dinner and a brunch with members of Mr. Ford's Grand Rapids, Mich., high school football team of the nineteenthirties.

title: Chang Yunyi, Party Aide In China, Is Reported Dead
description: TOKYO, Nov. 26 (AP)Chang Yunyi, a member of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party, has died of illness in Peking, the official Hsinhua, news agency reported today. He was 82 years old.

title: The Stock Exchange Bill
description: Landmark, legislation to reform the nation's stock exchanges is facing its penultimate hurdle in the House Rules Committee, with the New York Stock Exchange and the brokers professional association fighting down to the line to prevent it from being brought to the floor of the House in this session.

title: PORTUGUESE REACH PACT WITH ISLANDS
description: ALGIERS, Nov. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)Portugal and a delegation from the Islands of So Tom and Principe, off West Africa, have reached agreement on the end of colonial rule there, an official source said tonight.

title: STATE UNIT IS TOLD OF LOANS BY UNION
Metropolitan Briefs
description: Peter Williams of the Bronx, believed to be the first person convicted under the state's new rape law, which abolished the requirements of corroboration of the victim's testimony, received the maximum penalty yesterday at his sentencing in State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The British Government asked Parliament to approve emergency legislation outlawing the Irish Republican Army, giving the police sweeping powers of arrest and detention and imposing new controls on travel between England and Ireland. The measures were outlined in the House of Commons by Roy Jenkins, the Home Secretary, who described them as unprecedented in peacetime. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Contract Awards
description: A $180million contract to fabricate pipeline shoes for the TransAlaska Pipeline has been received by the American Bridge division of the United States Steel Corporation from the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company. The shoes are part of the fabricated steel system that holds the pipeline.

title: For Children, a Book on Crafts for All Seasons
description: The problem with most crafts books for children is that either the child has already done most of the things in kindergarten, or the directions are so complicated it would take a Ph.D. to unravel them, or the products are so dreadful there seems little point in bothering in the first place.

title: ROSCOE P. KANDLE, HEALTH OFFICIAL
description: Dr. Roscoe P. Kandle, who as New Jersey Commissioner of Health from 1959 to 1970 was active in combating air and water pollution, died yesterday in the SloanKettering Institute for Cancer Research. He was 65 years old and lived in Trenton.

title: Hitchhiker Killed By Jersey Trooper In Turnpike Clash

description: A former commodities salesman for Loeb, Rhoades & Co., the brokerage firm, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges that he defrauded his employer in the sale of more than 25,000 tons of sugar futures contracts.

title: Chicago Papers Raise Prices
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP)Price increases for the weekend editions of The Chicago SunTimes and Chicago Daily News were announced today by Field Enterprises, Inc. The SunTimes will go from 40 cents to 50 cents for Sunday editions beginning Dec. 1 and The Daily News will increase the price of its weekend edition from 25 cents to 30 cents, effective Dec. 7.

title: Bolivians Are Drafted Into Civil Service in Move to Control Dissent

description: A man who refused to participate in his own trial was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to a term of 21 years to life in prison following his conviction on a charge of attempted murder of a policeman.

title: St. Vincent's Hospital 125 Years Old
description: St. Vincent's Hospital, which has been providing medical care for residents of Greenwich Village and Chelsea since its beginnings in 1849 as a 30bed charity ward, marked its 125th anniversary yesterday with a gala dinner and the start of a $30million fund drive.

title: SYRIANS YIELDING ON U.N. GOLAN UNIT
BLOODFAT ROLE IS STUDIED BY U.S.
Nicholas Johnson Gets Post
description: Nicholas Johnson, in advocate of broadcast reforms during his seven years on the Federal Communications Commission, will become publisher of a new biweekly magazine, access, devoted to the citizens' movement for reform in broadcasting, cable TV and journalism. The magazine will be published by the National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting, the Washingtonbased consumerist organization of which Mr. Johnson is chairman and chief executive officer. It will early' no advertising and will be sold by subscription at $20 a year.

title: RECALL IS SOUGHT ON CANS OF BEANS
description: The Federal Food and Drug Administration last disclosed the recall el underprocessed beans canned upstate and shipped to supermarkets. They included three Shipments sold at regional Pathmark stores under the Pathmark label.

Blues Gain A 22 Tie With Leafs
Historical Projects Aided
description: BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP)The Massachusetts Historical Commission said today that it had received a grant of $800,000 from the National Park Service For historical preservation projects around the state.

title: Nominee as Federal Energy Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25Frank can get a job done. He is an organizer. He's a manager. There is nothing complicated about it, he just does the job, said an associate, echoing the words of others who have worked for and with Frank G. Zarb. Today, President Ford turned to Mr. Zarb to get a job done in one of the country's major struggles the energy crisisnaming him to succeed John C. Sawhill as administrator of the Federal Energy Administration.

title: Panel Votes Fishing Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) The Senate Armed Services Committee today approved a bill that would extend United States fishing rights from 12 nautical miles to 200.

description: TOMS RIVER, Nov. 25 (UPI) The State Public Advocate launched a legal attack today on seashore areas that are closed to the public, by filing suit against private beaches in Bay Head.

title: Supreme Court Actions
description: Reversed a decision denying seasonal farm workers who live in Mexico and Canada the same free passage into the United States enjoyed by daily alien commuters (No. 73300, Saxbe v. Bustos). Dissenting: White, Brennan, Marshall and Blackmun.

title: MIDEAST GESTURE PROPOSED AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25An Arab Offlcial said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization, the umbrella grouping of guerrilla movements, would participate in a proposed new round of the Geneva conference on the Middle Wast if properly invited.

title: James A. Tumulty Jr. Is Dead; Jersey Lawyer and Politician, 74
description: James A. Tumulty Jr., a for mer City Clerk of Jersey City and Hudson County prosecutor from 1963 to 1970, died Sunday at his home 69 Condict Street, Jersey City. He was 74 years old.

title: Baer Migrant Bill Delayed As Farmers Push Own Plan
description: TRENTON, Nov. 25Assemblyman Byron M. Baer, Bergen County Democrat, decided tonight not to push for a vote on his bill that would hold farmers ultimately responsible for the actions of mgrant crew leaders. He did so after some supporters of the measure had agreed to wait a week to permit an alternative measure preferred by farmers to come up for debate simultaneously.

title: ACCOUNTANTS AID INQUIRY ON SCHOOLS
description: Aided by two accountants lent by the Board of Education, Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola will look into a number of allegations of financial irregularities in Bronx school districts.

title: A New Appeals Court
description: With only a week of arguments left in the current term of the Court of Appeals, lawyers are already preparing for they new courtand they are not certain what to expect. The changeover in the state's highest court occasioned by the November elections will not formally take place until New Year's Day, and it will take several more months for the court to develop an identifiable personality. But lawyers are compulsive about predicting voting patterns even though such predictions could be as hazardous as forecasting what the price of sugar will be six weeks or six months from now.

title: Breast Cancer Experts Predict Trend Toward, Less Surgery
Football Coach Quits
description: MANHATTAN, Kan., Nov. 25 (AP)Vince Gibson, Kan sas State football coach, announced his resignation today. The Wildcats had a 16 wonlost record in the Big Eight Conference and 47 over all.

description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov 25 (AP) The Greyhound Bus Lines, back in service after a weeklong strike, promised today that it would be able to accommodate Thanksgiving holiday passengers at the 40,000 cities and towns it serves in the United States.

title: OilPrice Guarantee System Is Urged
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 25Thomas O. Enders, the official who negotiated United States participation in the oilSharing International Energy Agency, called on consumer nations today to guarantee that the output of oil exploration within their borders can be sold at the equivalent of the current price of oil, protected for infla tion.

description: ROME, Nov. 25The Vatican reaffirmed its strong opposition to abortion in a document made public today.

title: $30,000 in Receipts Stolen From Lundy's Restaurant
description: Armed robbers wearing ski masks last night invaded the Lundy Brothers seafood restaurant, a landmark emporium Brooklyn Sheepshead. Bay in Brooklyn, and escaped with $30,000, the reeeipts of the weekend.

title: Volunteer Lawyers Argue for the Arts
description: Early this year the group of oldmusic experts known as the New York Pro Musica went out of existence after 22 years, pleading financial distress. The news left many admirere bereft, and it upset some Pro Musica members who felt the group should be allowed to survive. These musicians decided to regroup, but they faced a mound of legal problems, such as whether they might be able to use the Pro Musica name and have access to the disbanded troupe's music and its authentic instruments.

title: SIMON TESTIMONY DEFENDS OIL FUND
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon told Congress today that paying for the United State share of the proposed new $25billion oil financing facility for industrial countries would not result in creating money and credit at home or an increase in Treasury borrowing from American citizens or banks.

title: Four Hijackers Surrender; Tunisian Aide Denies Deal
Economy and Polities: Bipartisan Pledges Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25Judging by the pledges of cooperation that flowed back and forth between the White House and Capitol Hill last week, the economy is likely to get a lot worse before it gets better. The pledges may have been the first manifestation of the dominant issue in the 1976 national election campaign: who's to blame?

title: MULLIGAN, BAKER IN A JAZZ REUNION
description: The wave of jazz nostalgia is coming closer and closer to the present. For many years it focused primarily on the swing era. More recently, it began to feed on bebop. And on Sunday evening, the cool jazz of the nineteenfifties joined the nostalgia parade when the baritone saxophonist Gerry Mulligan and the trumpet player Chet Baker, half of the Gerty Mulligan Quartet that established the West Coast cool sound 20 years ago, held a reunion at Carnegie Hall.

title: 21 Publishers Sued To End British Pact
description: Twentyone major American publishing houses were accused yesterday of conspiring with British publishers to suppress competition by dividing a major part of the world book market into exclusive territories.

title: Testimony Is Heard On G. W. U. Case In Court in Dallas
description: DALLAS, Nov. 25A Federal court suit to stop Nelson Bunker Hunt and W. Herbert Hunt from gaining control of the Great Western United Corporation was labeled today as an effort by company officials to stay in office.

title: Senate Panel Declines to Query General Who Criticized Jews
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25The Senate Armed Services Committee decided today not to summon Gen. George S. Brown, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, for an explanation of his critical comments about Jews in the United States.

title: NEW JERSEY BRIEFS
description: A major northern New Jersey realtor agreed in Federal court in Newark yesterday to submit to supervision of its rental practices to insure fairness to black applicants. Paul Schmidt, owner of the Henpal and Mipal realty companies, which control seven apartment houses in predominantly white Bergen County, agreed to explain the specific reasons that black applicants for apartments, in the next three years are rejected.

title: Court, 54, Uphods Aliens Commuting for U.S. Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25The Supreme Court ruled today that Mexicans and Canadians can commute freely into the United States to work, either daily or for a season, regardless of the unemployment situation here or their intention to keep their foreign residences.

title: Two Chargers Suspended
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 25 (UPI) Cid Edwards, a running back, and Coy Bacon, defensive end, were suspended today by San Diego Charger Coach Tommy Prothro. Prothro refused to comment on the suspensions except to say Bacon's was effective pending further information.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
21 Publishers Sued To End British Pact
description: Twentyone major American publishing houses were accused yesterday of conspiring With British publishers to suppres competition by dividing a major part of the world book market into exclusive territories.

title: Hayes for Big 10 Rule Shift
description: Even Coach Woody Hayes of Ohio State, whose team has been sent to the Rose Bowl for three straight years by a vote of the Big Ten athletic directors, joined others yesterday in urging the conCollege ference to change Sports the procedure for Notes selecting its entry in the Rose Bowl game.

title: Ethiopian Forces Ordered on Alert; 150 Facing Trials
Mrs. Paish Net Victor
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Nov. 25Mrs. Wendy Paish won her second singles final of the Festival of Tournaments tonight by beating Mimi Kanarek, 62, 61, at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Dean Witter Vote On Union Ordered
description: Clerical workers at Dean Witter & Co., Inc., the brokerage house, won the right yesterday to decide whether they want to join a labor union.

title: Short Payments Charged To Great Western Unit
description: A class action suit filed in Denver Federal court has charged that the Great Western United Corporation's sugar subsidiary shortchanged sugar beet growers by $246.3million.

title: Edison Policeman Is Shot By Fleeing Bank Robbers
description: EDISON, Nov. 25A policeman was critically wounded today when he attempted to question two men who allegedly were seen fleeing from a holdup of the Howe Lane branch of the Middlesex County Bank in nearby North Brunswick.

title: Soviet Lab 5 Months Aloft
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 25 (Reuters) The Soviet orbital laboratory Salyut 3 is continuing to make television. surveys of the earth after five months in space, and 2,462 revolutions of the earthtwo months longer than plannedthe official Tass press agency reported today.

title: LEAD BY NORTHROP IN NATO DEAL SEEN
description: A British authorfty on warplanes said today that he thought four members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would probably buy the Northrop YF17 Cobra as their basic fighter aircraft for the nineteen eighties.

title: BONNPARIS LINKS BEING QUESTIONED
description: BONN, Nov. 25Official sources here say that Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has reluctantly concluded that President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France does not have sufficient domestic political support to join West Germany in bold moves to strengthen European unity and the Atlantic alliance.

title: Quake in Baja California
description: PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 25 (AP)  A moderately strong earthquake occurred today at 8:26 A.M. Eastern standard time and was centered about 30 miles southwest of San Felipe in Baja, California, the California Institute of Technology reported.

title: Letters to the Editor
Thomas to Start for Redskins
description: Duane Thomas will be given a starting role for the Washington Redskins on Thanksgiving Day when the team plays the Cowboys in Dallas. The Redskins, who can hardly afford a stumble as they strive to make the league playoffs, are somewhat desperate and Thomas has earned respect. After weak earlier performances and little playing time he gained 65 yards against Philadelphia on Sunday and ran and blocked with power and authority.

title: The Jersey Senate Remains Snagged On SchoolAid Plan
description: TRENTON, Nov. 25  The Democratic majority in the State Senate failed once again today to come anywhere near reaching agreement on a revenue plan to finance publicschool education in New Jersey.

title: DR. ALVIN LEBENDIGER
description: Dr. Alvin Lebendiger, a professor of surgety at the University of Louisville Medical School, died of a head injury yesterday in Louisville, where he lived. He was 46 years old and formerly lived here.

title: Amex Fee Rise of 8% Voted
description: Members of the American Stock Exchange voted yesterday by 390 to 40 to raise commission fees by 8 per cent, effective today, on transactions of $5,000 to $300,000.

Breitel, and the state Controller, Arthur Levitt, in the preparation of his judicial reform and budget programs, and announced the formation of a 16member panel of advisers on transportation problems.

description: A number of companies announced yesterday extra or increased quarterly dividends.

description: Midway through And Who Shall Feed This World? a White Paper presented by NBC News Sunday evening at 10, John Chancellor made a curiously defensive observation:

description: NEWARK, Nov. 25 (UPI)A former military policeman and a teenaged girl were sentenced in Federal Court today on separate charges stemming from the kidnapping last March of John Calzadilla, 8 years, old, and the disappearance of a $50,000 ransom raised by the boy's father.

description: W.H.A. LEADERS

title: Amex and OTC Prices Drop in Sluggish Trading
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market declined yesterday in continued sluggish trading.

title: Justice and the People
description: Faith in the judicial system depends on the people's belief that the law provides redress for deliberate violations of their rights. Three recent judicial rulings raise serious questions because they apparently conflict with the public's sense of fairness.

title: Bridge:
New England Seeks Visitors
description: BOSTON, Novv. 25 (AP) The New England Regional Commission has embarked on $100,000 campaign to spur tourism in the sixstate area. The campaign begins next Monday with newspaper and radio advertisements in New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington, Atlanta, Toronto, Montreal and other Eastern cities.

title: SALES OF NEW CARS CONTINUE TO DROP
description: DETROIT, Nov. 25Sales, of new cars continued to remain in a severe slump in the last 10day selling period, Industry figures showed yesterday. Commenting on the results, Henry Ford 2d, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, predicted that the sales decline can gete worse.

title: People in Sports
description: For the fourth time in two weeks the Rangers have lost the services of an important player. Walt Tkacznk, who centers a line with Bill Fairbairn and Steve Vickers, suffered a fractured fibula in his right leg Sunday in the victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins. He will be sidelined four to five weeks.

title: DEMOCRATIC PLAN ASSAILED BY G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 25House Republican leaders made public today what they said was a secret plan by the Democrats to pack committees with their members in the next and succeeding Congresses.

title: Steelers Wallop  Saints
