description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 (AP)Terry Bradshaw threw for two touchdowns and ran for one and Lynn Swann returned a punt 64 yards for a score as the Pittsburgh Steelers routed the New Orleans Saints, 287, in a nationally televised National Football League game tonight.

title: Dow Average Falls 3.36; Trading Pace Is Lethargic
The Price Of Union Democracy
description: A new wave of worker discontent is knocking some of the barnacles off a labor movement sunk in bureaucratic smugness. Resolute insurgents, using the uniondemocracy guarantees of the LandrumGriffin Labor Reform Act of 1959, have begun to demolish citadels of trade union autocracyfirst in coal and now in steel, where a 36yearold rebel has just shattered machine control over the union's biggest district.

title: Doctors Doubt New Transplant Will Curb Rejection Phenomenon
Tanaka a Resigns, Citing Political Chaos in Japan
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 26Premier Kakuei Tanaka, facing alleged financial scandals and record lows in popularity polls, announced his resignation today.

title: Smoot New Yale Captain
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 25 John Smoot was elected tonight the captain of Yale's 1975 football team. The 6foot1inch, 200pound linebacker, a graduate of Boston College High School led the team in tackles this year with 145. He is a history major.

title: Connally Will Get A Separate Trial On Bribe Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) A Federal district judge today ordered that bribery charges against John B. Connaly be tried separately from other Federal charges against the former Texas Governor.

title: Ashe Bows & To Connors In S. Africa
Fordham Harriers, Kept at Home, Protest; Oregon and Rose Capture N.C.A.A. Titles
Miners Council to Be Exhorted to Accept Offer
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25Labor, management and Government officials worked today toward a second attempt by the leadership of the United Mine Workers of America to persuade the union's 38member bargaining council to accept a coal industry contract offer. Acceptance could end the nation's miners strike in about two weeks.

title: Rising Costs Force U.D.C. to Reconsider Project in Brooklyn
description: Plans for a housing project considered by the city to be the keystone of plans to revitalize downtown Brooklyn are being revised because of soaring construction costs, a state official said yesterday.

title: F.D.A. DELAYS RULES for FOOD LABELING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) Fearful of fueling inflation, the Food and Drug Administration announced today a sixmonth delay in implementing its sweeping new food labeling regulations.

title: Sterling Drug Offers $36Million in Stock for BioDynamics
description: Sterling Drug, Inc., a company whose proprietary products include Bayer Aspirin and Phillips' Milk Of Magnesia, announced yesterday that it was entering a competing bid for BioDynamics Inc A letter of intent for the merger of BioDynamics into Sterling provides that Shareholders of the medical diagnostic and equipment company would receive 0.69 share of Sterling for each share of BioDynamics. There are 1,727,503 common shares of BioDynamics outstanding.

title: U Thant Is Dead of Cancer at 65
description: U Thant, the quiet Burmese schoolteacher who became the third Secretary General of the United Nations and held that post longer than any other person, died yesterday at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 65 years old.

title: INTEGRATION CASE OF '54 IS MARKED
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 25Plans by proponents of school integration for a joyful commemoration of the 20th anniversary of the Brown V. Topeka Board of Education case have gone awry.

title: Love and Potatoes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  Good times have been hard on love, marriage and family in the United States, which may help account for the soured spirit with which we meet the return of hard times. Instead of love, marriage and family, we now have sex, cohabitation and nursing homes, which may be dandy when the money is sufficient for footloose and fancyfree living, but don't help much when you're broke.

title: U.S. Apologizes to Lebanese Over Search
description: WASHINGTON, Nov.25An official apology has been sent to President Suleiman Franjieh of Lebanon over an incident on Nov. 10 when United States Customs Service dogs were used to sniff for drugs in the luggage of his party at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Two, Well, Short Fictions
description: THE ABBESS OF CREWE. By Muriel Spark, 116 pages. The Viking Press. $6.95.

title: New Books
description: J'Aime Paris: Photographs Since the Twenties by Andr Kertsz, edited by Nicolas Ducrot (Grossman Publishers, $22.50). Letters of James Stephens, edited by Richard J. Finneran (Macmillan, $20). The Irish writer's thoughts and commentaries.

title: Inquiry Hears of Windfall In Sugar Industry Profits
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25A Government staff study made public today concluded that all sectors of the U.S. sugar industry have realized very large windfall gains from the recent big increases in sugar prices.

title: Stage: Behnnan's End of Summer
description: In his 1936 Broadway comedy, End of Summer, S. N. Behrman was painting a light romanticized picture of the idle, oilrich oblivious, to breadlines and unemployment. The delightful Leonie Frothingham sits in her summer house happily squandering her life away on an assortment of unworthy parasites, who include her headstrong daughter and an adventurer of a psychoanalyst.

title: Questions and Answers on Projected Deficit City Budget
description: The dismissals, retrenchments and spending cuts Mayor Beame ordered last Friday in a move he called the tightest austerity program undertaken by the city since the Depression are designed to reduce a projected deficit of $430million in New York's 197475 expease budget.

title: SYRIANS YIELDING ON U.N. GOLAN UNIT
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 25 Secretary General Waldhelm of the United Nations, after a two and onehalf hour meeting with President Hafez alAssad, said today that he expected a sixmonth extension of the life of the peacekeeping force separating the Syrian and Israeli armies in the Golan area.

title: 2 AGNEW ASSOCIATES SENTENCED TO JAIL
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 25Two participants in the kickback scheme involving former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew were sentence today to jail terms by a threejudge Federal court panel.

title: Hunt Goes On at College for Source of Meningitis
New Jersey Sports
description: New Jersey schoolbpy football winds up its regular season with the traditional holiday flourish Thursdayexcept this time there will be a postscript. Along with the conference titles, unbeaten records and oldtime rivalries motivating the hostilities, which more than 500,000 spectators will enjoy, there will be the queston of who gets to play in the first sectional title playoffs sanctioned by the NewJersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association.

title: Health Plan for Indians
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) The Senate passed a bill today to provide an expanded health care program for American Indians at an authorized, fiveyear cost of $1.6billion. The measure, approved without debate, now goes to the House.

title: Tanaka Quits in Japan
description: Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan, facing charges of financial scandal and record lows in popularity polls, announced his resignation. Page 3.

title: MORGAN K. M'GUIRE
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 25Morgan K. McGuire, a former State Senator, died today after collapsing in downtown New London. He was 58 years old.

title: Are Humans Eating Canned Pet Food? The Growth of a Rumor
Dave Anderson
Survey of Students In City High Schools Finds 26% Drinking
Chess:The NimzoIndian Requires ?? ?? subtle Touch; Deft Touch Needed
Dispute Over Battery Park City Project Pits Architects vs. Planners vs. Developers.
Syntex Earnings Rise
Market Place
description: Many investors believe that this is a time to lie low and hope not to be hit by falling stocks  unless one can find some group of issues resistant to recession or worse.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Kissinger Begins Visit in Peking With Call on Chou
description: PEKING, Nov. 25Secretary of State Kissinger started his seventh visit to China this evening with a brief social call on Chou Enlai in the hospital where the 76yearold Premier has been convalescing for the last five months.

title: Family Sues Airline In Death of Woman Stricken on Flight
description: NEWARK, Nov. 25 (UPI)A $5million negligence suit was filed today against a pilot and Eastern Airlines by the family of a New Jersey woman who was stricken with a fatal heart attack last September aboard a Newark  to  Fort Lauderdale, Fla., flight.

title: Students Urged to Forgo Tuition at Struck Colleges
description: TRENTON, Nov. 25 (UPI)The head of the Montclair State College Student Government Association called on students at his school not to pay tuition until teachers and the state resumed talks in their strike, which moved into its second week today.

title: State's G.O.P. Chairman Endorses Buckley in 1976
description: ALBANY, Nov. 25The Republican state chairman, Richard M. Rosenbaum, today endorsed the renomination of Senator James L. Buckley even though Mr. Buckley did not support the state's senior Republican Senator, Jacob K. Javits, in last month's election.

title: City Studies Parking Fines for Fast Cash
description: A limited amnesty to lure thousands of people who hold unpaid New York City parking tickets into speeding payment of their fings is under study by the Beame administration as a further step in bridging the current budget gap.

title: Recital
description: Ray De Voll's recital at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night showed, how successful a program can be put together by a singer who knows his weaknesses and strengths and gees to the strengths. The tenor, a familiar figure for many years with the New York Pro Musics, does not have a voice of much size, and it is severely limited at the top. But he has impeccable taste, a dulcet tone and a rare feeling for subtleties of style, particularly in older music.

title: Joe Wins Japan Fight
description: TOKYO, Nov. 25 (AP)Masao (Gold) Joe, Japan's secondranked junior lightweight, knocked out Kim YungBok of South Korea at 2 minutes 19 seconds of the first round in a scheduled 10round fight tonight.

title: A.E.C. REJECTS PLAN ON BREEDER REACTOR
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commission has rejected portions of the application to build the nation's first breeder power reactor, telling its developers they have not supplied enough information.

title: Briefs On The Arts
Jerry and the Wolf
description: Photographs of the meeting between President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev at Vladivostok depict the Soviet leader wearing a wolfskin parka and hood that the President had obtained in Alaska. I'm a sheep in wolf's clothing, the President fatuously said, adding: I told the First Secretary I'm going to get him one.

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities. The average rate for the threemonth bill was 7.328 per cent, down from 7.528 per cent for the preceding week. The average rate for the sixmonth bill was 7.369 per cent, down from 7.427 per cent for the previous. week.

title: College, School Results
description: Colleges

title: Other U.S. Stock Exchanges
description: Monday, Nov. 25, 1974

title: Morton Delays Hearings On Offshore Oil Leases
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton told California's two Senators today that he had decided to postpone until February the hearings on the Administration's accelerated leasing of offshore oil lands.

title: Buyers Replace Orders for Canadian Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (Reuters  Hopes that the United States can donate more wheat to needy countries over the next seven months may have been dashed by the poor quality of the Canadian crop harvesterd this year, United, States officials said today.

title: Fight on Pornography, Mired in Confusion, Lags Across Nation
New Bond Issues
description: UTILITY BONDS

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation and Merrill Lynch yestered offered 1.1 million common shares of the Toledo Edison Company at $16.50 a share. The utility plans to use the proceeds to repay shortterm borrowings incurred in connection with its construction program.

title: Insurance Rate Rise Asked
description: HARRISBURG, Nov. 25 (AP) Six automobile insurance companies have requested rate increases that would affect two million Pennsylvanians and cost $30million a year, the Insurance Department said today.

title: UNESC0 Vote on Israel Scored
description: Francoise Giroud, France's Secretary of State for the Condition of Women, yesterday tourned down an invitation to address a meeting of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in view of the decisions taken by UNESCO, shocking in my eyes, with regard to Israel. UNESCO recently excluded Israel from its regional groups and barred her from receiving UNESCO aid.

title: Sears and Other Big Retailers Show Declines in Earnings in Third Quarter
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co., the nation's largest retailer, reported yesterday a 28.5 per cent decline in earnings for the third quarter ended Oct. 31 and a 10.6 per cent drop for the nine months, despite record sales.

title: Hitchhiker Killed By Jersey Trooper In Turnpike Clash
description: One of three barefoot hitchhikers was shot and killed yesterday afternoon on the New Jersey Turnpike during a fist fight with two state troopers trying to remove them from the superhighway, New Jersey state police reported.

title: 4 Post Offices Open for Christmas Rash
Nibbling the Bullet
description: In a letter to The Times recently published on this page, Mayor Beam promised to take tough decisions in order to preserve and strengthen the city's fiscal integrity in the face of a deepening budgetary crisis. The austerity program proclaimed by the Mayor last week to meet an anticipated $320million deficit in the current expense budget falls startlingly short of fulfilling that pledge.

title: Police Seeking Witnesses In Financial Area Murder
description: Detectives searching for the slayer of a 32yearold financial consultant stabbed to death outside 51 Beaver Street last Friday evening have distributed leaflets and made bullhorn appeals in the Wall Street IRT Seventh Avenue Subway station in an attempt to find witnesses.

title: MONOXIDE FUMES KILL 4 IN FAMILY
Vladivostok Accord?
description: There are two contradictory interpretations of the FordBrezhnev tents tive agreement on the control of offensive nuclear weapons. The first, defined by the White House Press Secretary, Ron Nessen, was that it was a triumph for arms control, and the second, that it was a delayed Soviet trap to assure Moscow of United States trade and modern technology.

title: City Is Told Budget Must Be Cut To Justify More Aid From Shate
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman said yesterday that Mayor Beame had to dismiss enough city workers and cut enough city services to save the $330million in his projected budget gap before the State Legislature would act to help the city.

title: Slaughter in Ethiopia
description: After carrying out a gradual and bloodless revolution over the past nine months, Ethiopia's young military rulers have shocked the world by abruptly killing sixty former Government officials and aristocrats close to the deposed Emperor Haile Selassie. Among the victims were Gen. Aman Michael Andom, who headed the provisional Government until last week, and former Premier Endalkachew Makonnen, a serious candidate for Secretary General of the United Nations only three years ago.

title: Doubled Rhone Rate Asked
description: BOSTON, Nov. 26 (AP)The New England Telephone Company asked today for permission to double the charge for pay phone calls in Massachusetts to 20 cents as part of a $210million rate increase package. The increase, filed with the state Department of Public Utilitiest, would raise the cost of for most residential customers from $1 to $2.40 a month, the company said.

title: Dress: Designers' Christmas Trees Are Elegant, Homey or Stark
description: Pauline Trigre understandably wanted to decorate her tree with turtleslast week she added Number 592 to her private collection. But her own crystal turtle was too heavy and she couldn't find enough others that were shiny enough and light enough to use as Christmas tree ornaments. So she settled for symbols of her other special interest, cooking.

title: SnowTire Sales Expected to Hit Low
PRESIDENT SIGNS MASSTRANSIT ACT
News Summary and Index
On Holiday, Full Dinner At No Cost
description: According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, it will cost you $6.30 this year to prepare a Thanksgiving dinner at home for a family of four. But if you happen to be in Valatie, N.Y., today, you can feed them all for nothing.

title: Dollar Shows Sharp Drop
description: LONDON, Nov. 26The dollar fell sharply on foreigneixchange markets throughout Europe today in an apparent reaction to declining American interest rates and fears that the United States would announce a big trade deficit for October. However, Washington later announced the first trade surplus in six months.

title: On Holiday, Full Dinner At No Cost
description: According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, it will cost you $6.30 this year to prepare a Thanksgiving dinner at home for a family of four. But if you happen to be in Valatie, N. Y., today, you can feed them all for nothing.

title: Suspended Officer Again Found Guilty Of Perjury Charge
description: A suspended plainclothes officer, who had won reversal of his 1970 conviction for lying about systematic payoffs by gamblers to Bonk police officers was again convicted of perjury yesterday, at a retrial in State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

title: Giscard Reassures French on Economy; Says Growth Will Resume Next Year
description: PARIS, Nov. 26President Valery Giscard d'Estaing went on television tonight to reassure a nation frightened of unamployment and to defend himself against growing personal criticism.

title: Rep. Jarman Son Sentenced
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Nov. 26 (AP)Stephan Jarman, the son of Representative John Jarman, Democrat of Oklahoma, was sentenced to oneyear deferred prosecution today on a charge of possession of marijuana.

title: The 2earOld Weighed 16 Pounds at Death
description: A genuine sense of concern for the helpless poor and distressed is in danger. We have been hearing now for many months that millions are hungry and starving in Afrita and Asia, and we are acting as if we have not heard.

title: Governments Are Allowed InterestEarning Savings
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 The Government's bank regulatory agencies Issued regulations today that will permit governments at all levels to place their money in savings accounts and earn interest.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Virginia Squires, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L. I., 8:05 P.M. (RadioWMCA, 8:05 P.M.)

title: Brezhnev in the Catbird Seat
description: PARISThere has been much public talk about a pentagonal world founded upon relationships between the United States, Russia, China, Japan and Western Europe and there has also been talk (now less often heard) about a triangular world based on a balance between the first three. But the quintessential policy devised by President Nixon with Henry Kissinger's aid and now, it, would seem, embraced by President Ford, still rests on the balance between the U.S.A. and U.S.S.R.

title: U.N. Begins Debate on Cambodia's Representation
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26Debate opened in the United Nations General Assembly today on whether to take away Cambodia's seat from the Lon Nol government and recognize instead the exile government in Peking headed by Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

title: Supermarkets Get Plea for a Holiday Freeze
description: Consumers Against Price Increases, a coalition of local civic and community groups, announced yesterday it had sent letters and telegrams to supermarkets urging them to impose a moratorium on food price increases during the Thanksgiving  to  Christmas holiday season.

title: Miss Beals Dances Desperate Heart With a Sure Grace
Gold Sales Seen Topping 10 Million Ounces in U S.
For Frankfurt Students, Struggle Is for Grades
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany The tall concrete chimney of Johann Wolfgang Goethe Univerity here bears the message Chile Socialists painted in red letters by a daredevil protester.

title: Events Today
Dollar Off
description: The dollar plunged in trading abroad yesterday in an apparent reaction to lower American interest rates. Gold prices increased. Details on Page 49.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: 6 Work Their Way Through College Behind a Horse
W. T. GRANT SETS AUSTERITY PLANS
Goal Judge Defends Move on Blind Sports
ARTIFICIAL BONE FIGHTS A CANCER
Cyril Connolly, Literary Critic, Is Dead
description: LONDON, Nov. 26  Cyril Connolly, the literary critic and author, died in a hospital here today. He was 71 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
FOEKO VAN DER LAAN
description: Foeko H. W. yan der Laan, who established the Netherlands National Tourist Office here in 1946, died Monday at Lennox Hill Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 10 East 81st Street.

title: KISSINGER BRIEFS CHINESE ON PACT
description: PEKING, Nov. 26Secretary of State Kissinger began formal talks today with Chinese officials and interpreted fot them the understanding on limiting strategic arms reached by the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: OUTPUT CURBLAID TO OIL COMPANIES
description: WASHINGTON, NOV. 26Senator Ernest F . Holtipga, suggested today, that the major United Staes oil companies were engaged in speculative withholding of oil and gas production from effshorer producible zones under leases purchased from the Federal Government.

title: 13 NATIONS TO GIVE AID TO LATIN BANK
Allon and Kissinger to Confer on Mideast Outlook
SENATE UNIT VOTES A FOREIGN AID BILL.
JAE GREENBERG, PUBLISHER, DEAD
description: NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 26Jae W. Greenberg, a pioneer publisher of popular books on mental hygiene, psychology and psychoanalysis, died today at a nursing home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 80 years old.

title: State Inquiry Trims Questions To Union Agent Held for Trial
description: The State Commission of Investigation yesterday abruptly limited its plans to question Bernard Tolkow, business agent of Amalgamated Union Local 355, after the union official's lawyer contended that the questioning and news reports about it would prevent Mr. Tolkow from getting a fair trial in a pending Federal court case.

title: ABRAHAM J. KRAKOW
description: Abraham J. Krakow, a retired shirt manufacturer, died Monday at Long Island Hospital Hillside Medical Center in New Hyde Park. He was 82 years old and lived at 7714 113th Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: City Rent Confusion
description: Procedures that authorized rent increases of up to 12 per cent in rentstabilized apartments in New York City were declared invalid in court, but the immediate impact was not known. Page 29.

title: Mayor Gibson and Council Give Up Contested Raises
State Jobless Rate May Be 9% Now, Labor Aides Say
description: TRENTON, Nov. 26 (AP)The State Labor Department reported today that unemployment had edged up to 8.5 per cent in October and might now be nearly 9 per cent.

title: Notes on People
description: Rumania's President, Nicolae Ceausescu, appeared to have been taken by surprise yesterday when it was proposed at the 11th Congress of the Rumanian Communist party that he be made leader of the party for life. He took the floor to say that although he was grateful for the proposal, he asked that it be withdrawn, for he felt willing to serve as long as he was capable of doing so.

title: Eddy Arnold Puts Polish in Palace Songs
Canadian Bill WouId End Jail Terms for Marijuana
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 26 (Reuters) A bill to abolish jail sentences for simple possession marijuana and hashish was introduced in the Canadian Senate tonight.

title: ETHIOPIA SAYS AMAN DIED IN GUN BATTLE
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 26 (Reuters)  Ethiopia's military rulers said today that Lieut. Gen. Aman Michael Andom, chairman of the military Government, was shot and killed in his house during a gun battle on Saturday night.

title: Britain Drops Plan To Build Rail Link To Channel Tunnel
description: LONDON, Nov. 26  The Government has abandoned its projected highspeed rail link between London and the entrance to the planned tunnel under the English Channel.

title: Miss Melville Takes Final In S. Africa
Scouts Win, 43, On 60Foot Shot
MINE UNION PANEL BACKS COAL PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 The United Mine Workers bargaining council rejected today and then approved tonight the union officers proposed agreement with the coal industry, opening the way for a final settlement of the national miners' strike by the middle of next week.

title: 2 Held in Attempted Rape After East Side Abduction
description: A young secretary on her way home from work Monday was dragged into a truck that minutes later was forced to stop by two police officers who rescued her from her two abductors.

title: Agnew Aftermath
description: The prison sentences imposed on two Baltimore businessmen who participated in the illegal kickback schemes that led to the resignation of Spiro Agnew from the VicePresidency inevitably raise questions about the equality of American justice. Like Mr. Agnew, the two defendants  I. H. Hammerman 2d and Alan I. Green took advantage of plea bargaining that permitted them to answer only for tax violations. But unlike Mr. Agnew, who got off with a light fine and three years of unsupervised probation, these accomplices in the former Vice President's crimes now must go to jail unless they can successfully appeal their sentences.

title: RedskinCowboy Game a Holiday Grudge
description: The National Football League has had a proprietary interest in Thanksgiving Day for over 40 years, utilizing the holiday as an occasion to put its wares on display. There will be two games tomorrow, Denver at Detroit and Washington at Dallas, and both will be seen here on television. Channel 4 will telecast the first one starting at 12:45 P.M. and Channel 2 the second at 3:45. Three of the teams are still in contention for postseason playoffs, the Broncos being the exception, although chances for Dallas and Detroit are slim. Dallas and Detroit have 65 wonlost records, while Washington is 8.3 and Den

title: PRESIDENT ASKS $46 BILLION CUT IN SPENDING NOW
Chicken (Not Turkey) On the Bowery Menu
description: The 2,000 homeless men who are expected to show up tomorrow for the Salvation Army's traditional Thanksgiving turkey dinner here will be served fried chicken instead.

title: Sweetness in Song by Beatrice Rippy
description: Beatrice Rippy is one of that special breed of artists whose work is technically flawed yet who manage to be rewarding in spite of it. On Monday night the soprano gave her latest recital here in Alice Tully Hall before a large and admiring crowd, winning it with the sweetness of her voice and the many felicities of her phrasing.

title: U Thant and the U.N.
description: U Thant was not the most imaginative Secretary General of the United Nations but he seemed an indispensable one for most of his unprecedented tenure. When Dag Hammarskjold died in an African plane crash in 1961, the mild and gentle Buddhist from Burma was the only figure on the U.N. scene on whom all blocs and factionsincluding the two competing superpowerscould unite. This was no less true when he was unanimously chosen for the full term in 1962 and again when he was drafted for reelection in 1966.

title: Leete Gets Football Job At Hofstra
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 26 (AP)Bill Leete was named head football coach today at Hofstra University, replacing Howdy Myers, who had served in that capacity for 25 years. Myers will reach the mandatory retirement age of 65 this year.

title: Racers Shut Out By Jets, 4 to 0
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 26 (UPI)Bobby Hull and Ulf Nillson got firstperiod goals tonight to lead the Winnipeg Jets to a 40 rout of the Indianapolis Racers in a World Hockey Association game. The Jets' gooalie, Curt Larsson, turned back 39 shots to claim his first shutout in the W.H.A.

title: Federal Law on Open SchoolRecords: Accountability and Privacy in Conflict
description: Watergate and the social movements of the decade that preceded it produced substantial publie support for measures that would assure openness and accountability on the part of institations and guarantee the right of privacy for individuals. The new Federal law that went into effect last week giving parents and adult students the right to inspect student's school records is a product of this type of concern. The reaction that the law has evoked among college administrators though, is a sign that in some instances the two principles accountability and privacy may come into conflict.

title: Modern Jazz Quartet Plays Farewell
HOUSE PANEL VOTES CONTROL OF TAPES
House Panel Blocks a Bill To End Fixed Stock Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26The House Rules Committee today blocked, for the rest of the Congressional session, floor consideration of omnibus legislation intended to restructure the securities market, to end fixed broker age commission rates and to strengthen the authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Comission designated the Steinway section of Astoria, Queens, noted for its 19century row houses, and Hamilton Heights, an upper Manhattan area laden with elegant brownstones and Queen Annestyle town houses, as historic districts.

title: Tight Money, Bobby Riggs Loom at W.T.T. Draft
description: The lights went out before the World Team Tennis player draft yesterday at the Americana Hotel, which might have been an omen for the league's second season.

title: STOOKS ON AMEX SHOW A DECLINE
CITY BOND ISSUE
Clinton Gilbert Jr. Weds Jane T. Paton
Robert Doty, Newsman, Is Dead; Led Times Paris, Rome Bureaus
description: ROME, Nov. 26Robert C. Doty, foreign correspondent and bureau chief for The New York Times for almost two decades before his retirement, in 1970, died here, today of leukemia.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
TV: Holiday Specials, From Splendid to Poor
Theft Gang in Bronx Is Accused of Using RadioAlarm Setup
description: Two alleged members of burglary gang in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx were in custody yesterday, accused by the police of using a radio beep communication system to warn against detection while they robbed about 30 dwellings and businesses.

title: PRESIDENT ASKS $4.6BILLION CUT IN SPENDING NOW
Bank Missing Certificates
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company reported yesterday that it is missing two $1million certificates of deposit issued by the Wells Fargo Bank. It reported that they were issued to the bearer.

title: DR. WILLIAM GLASS
description: Dr. William H. Glass, a surgeon, died Monday at the Hospital Center at Orange, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived in South Orange.

title: A Day Proposed in U.S. On World Food Crisis
Buckley, Back From Soviet, Says He Saw Intensified Repression
description: ALBANY, Nov. 26Senator James L. Buckley said yesterday after a sixday visit to the Soviet Union that the Kremlin had intensified repression within its borders.

title: Government Accused of Laxity In Enforcing Sex Bias Statutes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) Five national feminist and education organizations filed today a classaction lawsuit accusing the Government of failing to enforce antisexdiscrimination laws.

title: Constantine Urges Greek Voters to Back His Return
description: ATHENS Nov. 26King Constantine promised in a recorded statement broadcast tonight that if he returned to Greece he would be a figurehead monarch, devoted to democratic principles and subject in every case to the will of the sovereign people.

title: Business Records
A Listing of Recently Published Books
La Scala to Visit Capital During 1976
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26he John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and the Italian Government announced today that La Scala Opera Company of Milan would make its first appearance in the United States in 1976 as part of Italy's tribute to the America bicentennial.

title: City Gets Permission to Transfer Some From Its WorkRelief Plan
description: The United States Labor Department disclosed yesterday that it had granted permission to the city to transfer some participants from the Work Relief Employment Program here to federally financed public service jobs in city agencies.

title: Getty Oil Company Increases Prices Of Various Fuels
description: The Getty Oil Company's eastern operations division announced yesterday that effective today it was raising prices of various fuels because of higher crude oil costs. The rises include 1 cent a gallon for No. 2 home heating oil, Diesel fuel and propane and a 2 centsagallon increase for jet fuel JP4.

title: EDUCATION BOARD TO CHECK INCOMES
Trade Surplus Announcement Sends Commodity Prices Up
Panel Proposes a Stronger City Council
description: A radical change in the municipal government structure that would strengthen the City Council by watering down or transferring the powers of the Mayor, the Board of Estimate and the State Legislature was proposed yesterday in a draft report of the Council's charter and Governmental Operations Committee.

title: HARRISON HARPER
description: Harrison Harper, who retired in 1971 as senior vice president of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., creditreporting agency, died yesterday at his home, 43 Allen Place, Wayne, N.J. He was 65 years old.

title: 1Million in Cocaine Seized After Chase; Colombian Arrested
description: The seizure of a $1million shipment of cocaine after it was allegedly brought ashore from a Colombianregistry freighter docked in Brooklyn was announced yesterday by District Attorney Eugene Gold. A 33yearold Colombian alien living in Brooklyn was arrested.

title: Ford Vetoes 22.7% Veterans Aid Rise
TaxAnticipation Bills Sold by the Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26The Treasury auctioned today $1.25billion of taxanticipation bills maturing next June 17 at an average rate of 7.521 per cent. This finishes up the Treasury's program to raise $4.5billion in new cash in order to meet seasonal needs.

title: McAdoo's 46 Ties  Mark, Braves Win
PRESIDENT SIGNS MASSTRANSIT ACT
WESTVACO PROFIT INCREASES BY 77%
Saudi Buying OneThird Of San Jose, Calif., Bank
description: SAN JOSE, Calif. The First National Bank of San Jose announced today that Odnan M. Khashoggi, a private Saudi Arabian businessman, had bought a onethird interest in the bank for $14million. Mr. Khashoggie, who has acontrolling interest in two other California banks will receive 650,000 new shares, at a private placement price of $21.83 a share.

title: Bacon of Chargers Off Suspension List
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 26 (UPI) Coy Bacon, a San Diego Chargers defensive end, was reinstated today, but Cid Edwards, a fullback, remained on the suspended list.

title: Bridge: Sensitive Side  Suit Cards May Be Handy in End Game
Bill Slocum, Hearst Columnist And Radio Reporter, Dies at 62
description: Bill Slocum, the columnist, died yesterday at his home in Somerville, Mass. He was 62 years old.

title: Wilson Aides Shred His Sensitive Papers
description: ALBANY, Nov. 26 (AP)Thousands of documents are being fed into paper shredders during the last days of the administration of Governor Wilson.

title: Chicken (Not Turkey) On the Bowery Menu
description: The 2,000 homeless men who are expected to show up tomorrow for the Salvation Army's traditional Thanksgiving turkey dinner here will be served fried chicken instead.

title: Simon Foresees Long Recession
description: In one of the bleakest assessments so far from a senior Administration official, Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said yesterday the United States may be facing the longest recession since World War II. In an interview with the Associated Press in Washington, Mr. Simon declared: It might be longer than any of the recessions we've experienced since World War II, but it's way too early to tell whether it will be more severe.

title: California's Blacks Able To Capture White Votes
ALBERT M. SWIFT
description: Albert M. Swift, supervisor of day editorial operations for Newsday, was found dead Sunday at his home, 10 Yon Road, Huntington, L.I. He was 41 years old. The Suffolk County police are investigating.

title: 3 DOCTORS REACH OPINION ON NIXON
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26Courtappointed physicians announced today that they had formulated a unanimous opinion on former President Richard M. Nixon's ability to testify at the Watergate coverup trial but would not disclose it untill they deliver their evaluation to Federal District Judge John J. Sirica this week.

title: DR. ARTHUR GLOGAU
description: Dr. Arthur Glogau, a professor of psychology at the Oregon State College of Education, died Saturday at Salem, Ore. He was 52 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Nov. 26 (UPI)  West Germany's auto makers, among the hardest hit by the economic slowdown, said today that they saw no prospects for a pickup in foreign and domestic sales within the next few months.

title: Goal in Overtime Helps UConn Gain in Soccer
description: A goal by Don, Fehlinger after 128 minutes of play provided the University of Connecticut with a 43 victory over Brown in the New England final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament yesterday.

title: I.R.A and Its Impact on London
description: LONDON, Nov. 26The newspapers this morning carried pictures of the shattered bits of three of the pillarshaped red mailboxes that are one of London visual symbols. The Royal Mail Service is a national institution. Like the rest of Britain it is slower than it used to be, loses money and is vulnerable to Irish Republican Army bombs.

title: MINE UNION PANEL BACKS COAL PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26The United Mine Workers bargaining council rejected today and then approved tonight the union officers' proposed agreement with the coal industry, opening the way for a final settlement of the national miners' strike by the middle of next week.

title: Sears Sees Growth In Sales as Less Than Was Expected
description: Arthur M. Wood, chairman of Sears, Roebuck & Co., the country's largest retailer, yesterday told a a meeting of security analysts in Chicago that next year will be a year of continuing difficulty for retailers and a year of subpar growth.

title: JOHN A. GARTMAN
description: John A. Gartman, an interior designer who specialized in lamps, died at his home Monday of a heart attack. He was 67 years old and lived at 299 West 12th Street.

title: PORTUGAL IN PACT ON FREEING ISLES
Detroit Paper Staff in Turmoil Over Disputed Article
Dividend Actions Are Taken By a Number of Companies
description: A number of companies announced yesterday increased or extra dividends for the third quarter, while still others reported cuts in their quarterly dividend or omitted them entirely.

title: MONOXIDE KILLS 4 IN JERSEY FAMILY
description: WHARTON, Nov. 26  A couple and two of their sons were asphyxiated here early today when carbon monoxide from the family car, which had been left with the motor running in a basement garage, seeped through their fiveroom house at 113 Fern Avenue. A third son, who is married, does not live at home.

title: 8.5% Jobless in Jersey
description: The New Jersey Labor Department said that, with 286,800 persons unemployed, the jobless rate in the state reached 8.5 per cent in October and might be near 9 per cent now. Page 41.

title: Fire Hits Los Angeles Pier
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 (AP) A welding operation was blamed for a spectacular fire that resulted in extensive damage to Berth 212 at Los Angeles Harbor but caused no injuries, fire officials said after putting out the flames early today.

title: Proxmire Scores ExPentagon. Aide
Carey Asks Wilson to Freeze Hiring in Fiscal Austerity Plan
description: Warning that a "substantial" budget deficit threatened the state next year, Governorelect Hugh L. Carey asked Governor Wilson yesterday to enact an immediate hiring freeze to help begin an austerity process that would continue indefinitely.

title: A Freelance Repairman Is King in East Europe
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 24  In the Communist world, where everything seems to be breaking down most of the time, the freelance repairmen has become king.

title: MARGARET BONI, 82, A WRITER ON SONGS
description: Margaret Bradford Boni, a music teacher and writer of popular books on songs, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived at 2 Washington Square Village.

title: TURNPIKE DEATH TRACED TO PACT
description: TRENTON, Nov. 28The state police reported today that a 30yearold barefoot hitchhiker shot to death by a state trooper yesterday on the New Jersey Turnpike had entered into a pact with his two companions to give up all their belongings.

title: Con Edison Seeking Permission To Burn HighSulphur Fuel Oil
description: The Consolidated Edison Company asked yesterday for permission to burn highersul phur oil here for a potential saving of $85million a year to customers. It also requested a Federal oil priceequalization policy that might save $135million more a year.

title: N.J. Turf Aid Bill Gains
description: TRENTON, Nov. 26 (UPI)A bill designed to increase purses at New Jersey race tracks and provide more money for horse breeders in the state was passed last night by the New Jersey Assembly. The measure, already passed by the Senate, was returned to the upper house for concurrence in amendments. A spokesman for the state racing commission said the legislation would make New Jersey race tracks more competitive with tracks in Pennsylvania and New York. He said that better purses would attract better horses and the attendance at tracks would increase. With increased attendance, the betting also would increase, meaning more money for the state. Under the bill, the take would be increased on wagers other than straight winplaceshow bets. The take on exotic betting, such as the trifecta, would be increased from 17 per cent. to 25 per cent. The spokesman estimated that the state profit from the tracks would be increased by $1.3million a year. Horse owners would get about $1million more, breeders about $150,000 more.

title: Rosemary Lane of Singing Lanes Dies
description: HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 26 (UPI) Rosemary Lane, one of the four singing Lane sisters who broke into show business with Fred Waring's Pennsylvanians in the nineteenthirties, died yesterday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital. She was 61 years old. Death was attributed to complications caused by pulmonary obstruction and diabetes.

title: Arms Limit Said to Include 1,200 Vehicle for MIRVs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26President Ford has told Congressional leaders that the tentative armscontrol agreement that he completed with the Soviet Union Sunday would

title: Supermarkets Get Plea for Holiday Price Freeze
description: Consumers Against Price Increases; a coalition of local civic and community groups, announced yesterday it had sent letters and telegrams to supermarkets urging them to impose a moratorium on food price increases during the Thanksgiving  to  Christmas holiday season.

title: MEXICANS SEVER TIES WITH CHILE
City Plans a Tunnel for West Side Road South of 42d Street
Lyle Latest to Bid for Bout With Ali
description: No. 1, I wouldn't try to kill him, said Ron Lyle, the third ranking heavyweight contender, who yesterday challenged Muhammad Ali for the world title. That's what everyone else has tried to do, I don't have to worry about going the distance with the top  ranked fighters. That's the most important thingto be able to do that long route.

title: MAX B. PRYOR
description: Max B. Pryor, vice president and Eastern sales manager of Parade magazine, died Monday at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. He was 52 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: Southwestern Bell Accused of Aiding In Illegal Wiretap
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 26 (AP)A lawyer said today that Federal, state and city police agencies used an illegal wiretap placed with the help of Southwestern Bell Telephone Company personnel to gather information for about 70 narcotics cases.

title: Market Place
Students Ask Writ to End Strike at 8 State Colleges
EQUITY FINANCING
description: Underwriters headed by Kidder, Peabody Cook Inc. yesterday offered 1.2 million commnon shares of the Montana Power Company at 22 a share.

title: Iran Weighs Major Investment In Shell's East Coast Stations
description: The Shell Oil Company is negotiating a broad agreement with Iran that could result in a major Iranian investment in Shell's gasoline stations on the Eastern seaboard.

title: U.S. Oil Plan: High Price Is Key
For Fowles, Novel Mostly Means New
LONG BEACH DROPS 40 IN BUDGET CUTS
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Nov. 25 The City Council of this financially pressed city voted tonight to cut 40 of the 60 jobs it had originally proposed to cut, as it adopted an austerity budget. However, employes are still considering a strike.

title: House Panel Blocks a Bill To End Fixed Stock Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26The House Rules Committee today blocked, for the rest of the Congressional session, floor consideration of omnibus legislation intended to

title: Byrne Designates 3 Historic Sites for the Bicentennial
Turner Display in London Makes for Unusual Gala
description: LONDON, Nov. 26In this very wet and gloomy autumn pet about the only sunshine Londoners can seea great burst of itis crammed into the highroofed galleries of the Royal Academy.

title: 40 Hurt on Airliner in Rome
description: ROME, Nov. 26 (AP)About 40 persons guttered slight injuries today at Rome's Fiumicino airport while evacuating a New Yorkbound Trans World Airlines jumbo jet because of a short circuit in its electrical system. Most of the injuries were cuts and bruises as 142 persons on board scrambled out of the plane.

title: Radio
Impending Staff Cuts Cast a Pall Over Addict Agency
Court Rules City Acted Illgally in Setting 700,000 Rent Rises
Rockefeller Opposed by Witnesses of House Panel
U.S. Shows Trade Surplus As October Exports Gain
C .I .A. Intervention in Portugal Is Denied at a Senate Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26Frank C. Carlucci, who has been nominated to be Ambassador to Portugal, said at a Senate hearlng today that I know there is no intervention by the United States Central Intelligente Agency in Portuguese affairs.

title: State Inquiry Trims Questions To Union Agent Held for Trial
Still Hope
description: Hope for a resumption of ArabIsraeli negotiations is hanging on the slimmest of threads, but two developments of recent days flash the signal that the door remains at least ajar for the kind of diplomatic footwork that can forestall the outbreak of war.

title: Thanksgiving Day,
description: Macy's 48th annual Thanksgiving Day parade, tomorrow, with its traditional bal loons, floats, bands and celebrities, will began at 9:30 A.M. at Central Park West and 77th Street and will proceed down Central Pork West, through Columbus Circle and down Broad way, to finish at noon at 35th Street.

title: About New York
Brezhnev, in Ulan Bator, Rejects peking Pact Offer
Letters to the Editor
Delayed Disclosure
description: After three years of obstruction and procrastination, the City Council's Standards and Ethics Committee last month endorsed a financial disclosure law for city officials that was described by one committee member as a landmark for the entire country.

title: Deaths
Simmons's Maxi Commercial
description: Perhaps the only bright side of the national malady of the aching back is that it has brought Sid Caesar and Carl Reiner back together.

title: Dow Average Rises 5.32 As Volume Shows Gain
R.H. Macy Net Income Increases by 10 Per Cent
Forcing Congress's Hand on Micronesia
Abortion in the Soviet Union: Legal, Common, but Frowned Upon
Thant First Secretary General To Lie in State at United Nations
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26U Thant will be the first Secretary General of the United Nations to lie in state at the world organization's headquarters. The body of Mr. Thant, Who died yesterday, will lie in state from noon tomorrow to noon Thursday.

title: MRS. ROCKEFELLER HAD MORE LESIONS
LONG BEACH DROPS 40 IN BUDGET CUTS
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Nov. 25 The City Council of this financially pressed city voted tonight to cut 40 of the 60 jobs it had originally proposed to cut, as it adopted an austerity budget. However, employes are still considering a strike.

title: JUDGE IS ACCUSED ON CAMPAIGN GIFT
description: NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 26 (AP)A Massachusetts judge who allegedly tried to make a $1,000 political campaign contribution in violation of the state's judicial code of ethics stepped down from the bench today pending an investigation of the case.

title: Iran Weighs Major Investment In Shell's East Coast Stations
description: The Shell Oil Company is negotiating a broad agreement with Iran that could result in a major Iranian investment in Shell's gasoline stations on the Eastern seaboard.

title: 2D CHAIN OF STORES WITHDRAWING BEANS
description: A second supermarket chain in the Northeast, First National Stores, said yesterday it was removing a shipment of Frenchstyle green beans from its shelVes. The Federal Food and Drug Administration had ordered their recall because it found them undercooked and thus a potential health hazard.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A hushed, standingroomonly crowd at Sotheby Parke Bernet yesterday watched while bidding for a Tiffany lamp soared to $42,000, eclipsing the record of $33,000 that was set here in April. The blue and green leaded glass wisteria design, made by Tiffany Studios some time after 1904 and bearing the number 10116, went to an unnamed European buyer. The lamp had been purchased in 1941 by the late Gaetano Lancellotti, a baker, for $175 his son, Dr. Harry Lancellotti, a Providence, R. I., podiatrist, recalled yesterday.

title: California's Blacks Able To Carry White Areas
DEPOSITS AT S.&L.S TOP WITHDRAWALS
description: For the first time in four months savings and loan associations deposits exceeded withdrawals, Thomas R. Bomar, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, announced yesterday.

title: Sports News Briefs
EXCONVICTS WIN BRUTALITY SUIT
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 26A Federal court jury returned a verdict last night in favor of 11 former inmates of the Indiana State Reformatory who alleged in a civil suit that nine guards and two prison officials used undue force in quelling a disturbance there on Sept. 26, 1969.

title: MITCHELL DENIES ROLE IN DECISION TO PAY BURGLARS
Santiago the Money in Seven Big A Races
$33Billion Fund Bill Approved; President Is Expected to Sign It
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 The Senate and House gave final approval today to a $33billion appropriation bill for the department of Labor, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and other agencies.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on Cambodia's seat in the United Nations.

title: Girl, 10, Is Blamed for Haunting House
Douglas Rejects U.S. Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI)Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas has refused a Federal Government request that a Los Angeles broadcaster, Will Lewis, be returned to jail because he has refused to turn over evidence in the bombings at the Sheraton Airport Hotel. He said yesterday that he would keep his Nov. 2 order releasing Mr. Lewis until the entire Court disposes of a petition asking for review of Mr. Lewis's contempt conviction.

title: A PROTEST MARCH BARRED BY SAIGON
Held on BogusBill Charge
description: BOSTON, Nov. 26 (AP)Ralph P. Russo, 35 years old, of Somerville has been charged with possession of $4.4million worth of counterfeit $100,000 Treasury bills, the Justice Department said today. Mr. Russo was arrested yesterday at Logan International Airport.

title: News Summary and Index
The Wide World of Education
description: For almost 30 years now, the 10 culture foundries that make up the Western Conference have been sending a party of scholars to California each winter to help a peer group from one of the Pacific Coast universities promote tourism and sell real estate in Pasadena. Since the Big Ten and Pacific8 give shelter to some of the most eminent educators and enlightened administrators in all of academe, it must be true that participation in the Tournament of Roses or the Sugar or Orange or Cotton or Liberty or Bluebonnet Bowl advances the cause of formal education. However, due to a deficient intellect and a variety of character flaws, this bystander has never fully appreciated the importance of these carnivals in the educa tional system. It would be difficult to measure the indifference aroused here by arguments about which team should go to the Rose Bowl.

title: Chairman of Federal Council Criticizes Sugar Industry and Consumer Groups
GOING OUT Guide
description: RETRO Anthology Film Archives is now settled into its new SoHo home at 80 Wooster Street, near Spring Street (2260010), where it moved recently from its former digs in the New York Shakespeare Festival HQ across town. The house can hold up to 72 fans of the venerable great at the experimental new in the world of film.

title: Army Coach Awed Over Navy Game
South African Suffered Minor Stroke During Transplant for Second Heart
Rivals Begin Drive to Suceed Tanaka
description: TOKYO, Nov. 26With the resignation of Premier Kakuei Tanaka, the struggle for succession that has been rumbling just beneath the surface in the governing Liberal  Democratic party broke into the open today.

title: SYLVIA KERSENBAUM MAKES PIANO DEBUT
KISSINGER BRIEFS CHINESE ON PACT
description: PEKING, Nov. 26Secretary of State Kissinger began formal talks today with Chinese officials and interpreted for them the understanding on limiting strategic arms reached by the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: CAREY ASKS HALT ON STATE HIRING
description: Warning that a substantial budget deficit threatened the state next year, Governorelect Hugh L. Carey asked Governor Wilson yesterday to enact an immediate hiring freeze to help begin an austerity process that would continue indefinitely.

title: Panel to Discuss News
description: What's News and What Isn't? will be the subject for a panel discussion to be held at the New York Cultural Center in Columbus Circle at 8 P.M. next Tuesday. Participants in the discussion, which will be conducted by Lester Markel, retired Sunday editor of The New York Times and now a visiting professor at Fairleigh Dickinson University, will be Marya Mantles, the author and commentator; Edwin Newman of NBC News; Michael O'Neill, executive editor of The Daily News, and Tom Wicker, columnist for The New York Times.

title: Gravy for Thanksgiving Dinner: Turkey Costs Less
City Gets Permission to Transfer Some From Its WorkRlief Plan
description: The United States Labor DePartment disclosed yesterday that it had granted permission to the city to transfer some participants from the Work Relief Employment Program here to federally financed public service jobs in city agencies.

title: Tuss Mc Laughry,Football Coach, Dies
description: Tuss McLaugary, who coached foatball at two Ivy League colleges during a 40year career, died yesterday at his home in Norwich, Vt. He was 81 years old.

title: Varying Ways to Achieve School Integration Debated at Parley
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 26A civil rights lawyer, a school desegregation consultant and a former official of the Nixion Administration offered today varying and sometimes conflicting views on how to achieve full school integration.

title: Ford Refurnishes Office To Reflect Informality
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP)President Ford is having the Oval Office refurnished to refIect his taste and provide a warmer feeling than the Nixon decoratons provided, a White House spokesman said today.

title: CAREY WILL STAY WITH CUNNINGHAM
description: Leaders of the New Democratic Coalition failed in their effort yesterday to dissuade Governorelect Hugh L. Carey from supporting Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx party leader, for the Democratic state chairmanship, Following the meeting at Mr. Carey's temporary offiCe at 270 Broadway, Arnold Weiss, chairman of the coalition, released a memorandum critical of Mr. Cunningham that he said would be sent to all members of the Democratic State Committee.

title: 2Month Holdout Ended by Love
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP)The Chicago Bulls' forward, Bob Love, ended a twomonth holdout today and agreed to report to the National Basketball Association team in time to play against the Milwaukee Bucks in Milwaukee Saturday.

title: Impending Staff Cuts Cast a Pall Over Addict Agency
description: The lobby of the fivefloor building housing the Addiction Services Agency at Worth and Church Streets was repainted a bright yellow recently, in time for a visit by Mayor Beame. But that is the only bright touch in an otherwise gloomy atmosphere.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and index, Page 39

title: Ruby Keeler Has Surgery; Listed in Critical Condition
description: GREAT FALLS, Mont., Nov. 26 (UPI)Ruby Keeler, tap dancing star of the Broadway stage in the nineteentwenties and Hollywood musicals of the nineteenthirties, was in critical condition today following brain surgery.

title: Thanksgiving Day
description: Macy's 48th annual Thanksgiving Day parade, tomorrow, with its traditional balloons, floats, bands and celebrities, will began at 9:30 A.M, at Central Park West and 77th Street and will proceed down Central park West, through Columbus Circle and down Broadway, to finish at noon at 35th Street.

title: FED BACKS CHASE BID IN IRAN AND EGYPT
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that it had received Federal Reserve Board approval to establish joint banking ventures in Iran and Egypt. Local authorities have already approyed the ventures.

title: EVICTION BARRED DESPITE MUGGING
West German Police Conduct Sweep for Radicals
description: BONN, Nov. 26West German policemen swept through scores of apartments and homes today to search for members and supporters of leftist terrorist organizations, one of which is suspected in the assassination of a West Berlin judge on Nov. 10.

title: W. R. GRACE & CO. MODIFIES MERGER
2 City Areas Made Landmarks
description: The Steinway section of Astoria, Queens, noted for its 19thcentury row houses, and Hamilton Heights, an upper Manhattan area with elegant brownstones and Queen Annestyle town houses, were designated yesterday as historic districts by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Big Board Seat Price Down
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that a seat on the exchange had been sold at $72,000down $18,000 from the last sale on Nov. 15 A day earlier the exchange reported that members lost $34million in the third quarter.

title: Pro Transactions BASEBALL
Police Say Hitchhiker Trooper Killed Had Joined 2 Others in Mystical Pact
Cornell in Garden Hockey
description: Cornell, a threetime champion will meet Boston College in the opening game of the 13th Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Hockey Festival in Madison Square Garden on Friday, Jan. 3. The second game of the opening night doubleheader pairs Brown against St. Lawrence.

title: Westchester Planning to Stop Extension Service and Its 4H
description: PEEKSKILL, Nov. 26Residents of villages and towns in northern Westchester packed the City Hall here tonight, seeking reversal of a proposal to eliminate the County Cooperative Extension Service.

title: Time Sees Profit Rise
description: Earnings of Time Inc. this year are expected to be about $50million, or $5 a share, up from $47.5million, or $4.58 a share, in 1973, Richard B. McKeough, vice presidentfinance told a meeting here yesterday of the Printing and Publishing Industry Analysts Association. Combined revenues for 1974 are expected to increase by about $100million to $825million, the officer said. Revenues last year were $728.3million.

title: Karen Brown Is Wed To Kenneth R. Gnirke
description: Karen L. Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Brown of West Nyack, N. Y., was married yesterday evening to Kenneth R. Gnirke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl F. Gnirke of Carle Place, L. I. The ceremony was performed at Singer's Hotel in Spring Valley, N. Y., by Rabbi Abraham Krantz.

title: U.S. Agents Seize 10 Suspects In GunMaking and Sales Ring
description: Federal authorities announced yesterday that they had broken up a major gundistributing ring with the arrest of 10 suspects accused of stealing gun parts from legitimate manufacturers, assembling the parts at home and then selling the completed guns to criminals.

title: Rangers Turn Back Leafs, 41, Scoring All Goals in 2d Period
Hussein Says P.L.O. Reneges On Secret Vow Not to Fight Him
Royal Manhattan Hotel to Close In 10 Days Because of Big Losses
description: The 27story Royal Manhattan Hotel on Eighth Avenue between 44th and 45th Streets will close in 10 days, the victim of operating losses of about $1million a year.

title: SNOOPY ET AL SET for PRADE TODAY
Times Declares Dividend
description: Directors of The New York Times Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share on Class A and Class B common stock, of record Dec. 9. This brings dividend distributions this year to 60 cents, or the same as shareholders received in 1973. The board also voted the regular quarterly dividend of $1.375 on the 5 per cent cumulative prior preference stock. It is payable Jan. 2, 1975, to stockholders of record Dec. 9.

title: Notess on People
description: In Domestic Relations Court yesterday, Judge Nanette Dembitz ruled in favor of Representative Mario Biaggi, the Bronx Democrat, in a paternity suit brought by Bunnye Hearne, a volunteer worker in his mayoral campaign last year. The ruling was oral, and Judge Dembitz's written opnion is not expected to appear in The Law Journal for about a week.

title: Australia Moves Toward New Law Easing Divorces
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 27 (AP) One of the world's most liberal divorce laws, a nofault arrangement that requires only a year's separation, was passed by the Australian Senate tonight and was considered certain to go into effect throughout the country.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Nov. 28, 1974 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special political committee 10:30 A.M.

title: Music:Parker and Chadwick Pieces
description: They were called the Boston Classicists, although they all were postromantics, and last night at the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center, an audience had a chance to sample specimens of two of those classicists. Jens Nygaard, who played the piano accompaniments, put together a program that presented an excerpt from Mona by Horatio Parker and several excerpts from Judith by George W. Chadwick.

title: Democrats Oppose Ford Plea To Push Inflation Drive on TV
description: WASHINGTON Nov. 27 (Reuters)  Thirty Democratic members of Congress demanded today that the Advertising Council and the major radio and television network drop plans for a free advertising campaign backing President Ford's WIN antiinflation program.

title: $8.3Million Savings Due
Radio
EARL ALBION HUGHES
description: Earl Albion Hughes, retired turfracing columnist for Cue and Sports Illustrated magazines, died Monday at his home in Washington, at the age of 82.

title: BONN FOR CHANGE IN TERROR CASES
description: BONN, Nov. 27  The West German Government today proposed new laws to supervise lawyerclient relationships in radical terrorist cases. The action came a day after a nationwide police sweep that led to 24 arrests, including that of at least one lawyer defending alleged anarchists. Four other persons were picked up and held for investigation.

title: Tverdokhlebov, a Dissident, Seized on Moscow Street
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 27 (AP)Andrei N. Tverdokhlebov, a Soviet dissident, was taken into custody today and his apartment was searched, sources reported.

title: Barnard Is Eager to Try 2dHeart Surgery Again
U.N. ASKS ETHIOPIA TO SPARE PRISONERS
Car Makers Told to Show Need to Delay Fume Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27Russel E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that automobile manufacturers must make a convincing case for their request for a fiveyear freeze on present, interim automobile emission standards before he would ask congress to extend the date for meeting the final standards.

title: Events Today
description: THE ALIENIST, a Brazilian film in Portuguese with English subtitles, by Nelson Perelra Dos Santos, at the First Avenue Screening Room.

title: Paralyzed Agent Given a Horne
description: MONTCLAIR, Nov. 27  A Federal drug  enforcement agent who was paralyzed from the armpits down in a shootout during an abortive drug purchase in New York City two years ago received title to a custombuilt home near here today.

title: AMERICAN CYANAMID PLANS A WRITEOFF
description: The American Cyanamid Company, a leading chemical, medical and consumer products maker, is getting out of the realestate business. The company announced yesterday it has decided to write off about $25million, its equity and debt investments in Ervin Industries, Inc., and to limit further funding of its operations.

title: Screen: French Murder
Soviet Is About to Deploy New Missiles, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UPI) The Soviet Union is preparing to deploy its first multiplewarhead nuclear missiles in remodeled underground firing sites within a few months, the Pentagon said today.

title: Deaths
Health Department Lists 9 Food Places With a 2d Violation
description: The city's Health Department has listed nine more food establishments as having Health Code violations on two inspections. A food establishment that has not passed a third, or final inspection is subject to closing.

title: Antinudity Law Pressed
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27 (UPI)  Two naked sunbathers were arrested yesterday on Venice Beach by policemen who announced a gettough policy to enforce the city's new antinudity ordinance. Thirtyeight other naked bathers got warnings to put their clothes on, as the police have been doing since the law was passed three months ago to cope with increasing nudity on city beaches. But the police said those would be the last warnings, and that henceforth nudists would be arrested on sight.

title: Charles W. Pettengill Dies at 73; Lawyer Led Rotary International
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 27  Charles W. Pettengill Sr., a senior partner in the law firm here of Hirschberg, Pettengill, Strong & Nagle, died last night at Greenwich Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 156 Overlook Drive here.

title: Space at New High On the Curb Exchange
description: A $2.50 gold piece about the size of a dime but valued at $75 to $85 has been found by a city employe in a Manhattan parking meter.

title: Byrd Quartet Joins With Carroll Trio In Provocative Jazz
description: The Rainbow Grill, which is not usually counted among the city's jazz rooms, has become one of the more interesting such rooms for the next two and a half weeks while it is presenting the provocative combination of the Charlie Byrd Quartet and the Barbara Carroll Trio. Between them, these seven musicians cover a broad range that includes sophisticated blues, bossa nova and a loose, swinging jam session that goes beyond jazz to a performance of Villa Lobos's 11th Etude by Mr. Byrd, a guitarist who is as much at home in the classical repertory as he is in jazz.

title: Seniors Begin Ritual Hunt for College of Their Choice
Ford at Low Point in Poll; Economic Concerns Cited
Four Children Die in Fire
description: FORISTELL, Mo., Nov. 27 (UPI)Four children died today in a fire at their grandparents' home. The children's mother, Mary Ann Stovell, was at work and had left her children with her parents. The four were identified as Laron, 4 years old: Denice, 3; Larry, 2, and Randy, 1. The grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Willie Lee Culpepper, and their second daughter escaped uninjured from the house, which burned to the ground.

title: Wounded Daughter, 9, Tells Of Slayings by Her Mother
description: GREENFIELD, Wis., Nov. 27 (AP)Mary Jansen, 9 years old, lay alongside the bodies of her slain family for nearly two day's. She believed she would also die of the bullet wounds inflicted by her mother.

title: ESCAPED PRISONERS TRACE 14DAY BREAK
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 27 (UPI)for 11 days Paul Chamberlain and 23 other prisoners in a Mexican jail chipped at the concrete floor of their cell with a smuggled hammer muffled with rubber and cloth padding.

title: Music: Trumpet Glitter
description: The Wurttemberg Chamber Orchestra in its first performance here on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall was somewhat thrown into the shadow by the trumpet pyrotechnics of the guest soloist, Maurice Andre, an astounding virtuoso with few peers in his craft. Nevertheless, the German ensemble under the leadership of Jorg Faerber managed to demonstrate that it is an excellent, if somewhat unassertive, group with a personality of its own.

title: Diplomats and Staff File Past Thant's Coffin at United Nations
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27Diplomats, United Nations staff members and many outside of the world organization who admired U Thant, filed past his flagdraped coffin here today.

title: Gerling Continuing Talks With Zurich Insurance Unit
description: DUSSELDORF, Nov. 27 (Reuters)Negotiations between the West German banking consortium Hans Gerling and the Zurich Insurance Group in an attempt to avoid the Bankhaus I. D. Herstatt settlement proceedings turning into a bankruptcy case are continuing.

title: Wilson Rebuffs Carey on Plea for Job Freeze
description: Governor Wilson yesterday rejected Governorelect Hugh L. Carey's iequested job freeze as unnecessary and defended his own budget record as sound enough to make a small state surplus likely next year.

title: Tanksgiving, 1974
description: Americans are deeply troubled on this Thanksgiving Day. For a minority of peoplebut a rapidly growing minoritythese are times of economic hardship. Those out of work worry how they will make do when unemployment compensation payments end. Many of those still employed find that wages no longer cover all necessary expenses, much less any small gestures of selfindulgence. The elderly month by month watch their pensions diminish in buying power and their savings disappear. For all of these Americans, the novel phenomenon of inflation in the midst of recession has, become like a physical plague in ages past; no one knows how it began, where it will, end, or how to protect oneself against it.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday ended their sevensession losing streak and finished with sharp gains in slower trading.

title: DR. CLAIR E. TURNER, HEALTH EDUCATOR
description: Dr. Clair E. Turner, a pioneer in public health, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Arlington, Mass. He was 84 years old.

title: Kings Rally for Tie With Islanders, 33
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 27  Starting a threegame West Coast trip that will pit them against two of the National Hockey League's most successful teams, the New York Islanders took on the Los Angeles Kings at the Forum tonight.

title: Dow Will Pay Stock To Strike Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27, (Reuters)The Dow Chemical Company said today it was awarding five shares of its common stock to each of its approximately 4,000 employes who worked during a sixmonth strike by the Dow's factory in Midland, Mich.

title: AIRLINES AGAIN FAIL TO AGREE ON FARES
description: GENEVA, Nov. 27Airlines operating routes across the North Atlantic today recessed their talks on a new fares package for a second time when they were unable to agree on how best to meet the competition of cutrate charter flights.

title: OIL PRODUCERS EYE PRICE RISE
description: VIENNA, Nov. 27 (Reuters)The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' economic commission meeting here is almost certain to recommend an increase in oil prices to compensate for inflation, sources close to the meeting said.

title: Obfuscation Foes Anoint Ziegler and an Air Attache
Van Dillen to Marry
description: APTOS SEASCAPE, Calif., Nov. 27 (UPI)Erik van Dillen, the 23yearold tennis star, will be married on Saturday to Lailee McNair in her home town of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Business Briefs
Pro Transactions
description: CHICAGO (NL)Named Iry Noren as thirdbase coach.

title: Obfuscation Foes Anoint Ziegler and an Air Attache
description: The Committee on Public Doublespeak will present its first annual Doublespeak Awards in New Orleans today.

title: Stocks Advance Slightly In a PreHoliday Session
First Women Are Named To Greek Orthodox Council
Four Charged as Burglars
description: TULSA, Okla., Nov. 27 (UPI)  The police arrested and charged four teenage girls with burglary early today, in a series of cases in which the authorities said a 4yearold boy may have been used to open doors of the homes that were broken into. Ruth A. Norris and Connie J. McGarrah. both 19 years old, were charged with seconddegree burglary. The other two girls, ages 15 and 17, were turned over to the juvenile authorities. The boy, the son of Ruth Norris, was released to his grandparents.

title: BIGGER SALES FORCE IS SOUGHT BY BACHE
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Nov. 27Bache & Co., Inc., the brokerage house, said today that its first priority in the new year would be to strengthen its 2,000person sales force  if possible through the acquisition of other brokerage firms.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Controversy over the city's Third Water Tunnel, beset by heavy cost overruns, was discussed publicly for the first time, and it became evident the city would have to pay $340million to $499million to complete work originally bid at $223million.

title: MONSERRAT TIED TO SCHOOL PACT
Dublin Sentences Heiress In Ulster Bombing Case
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 27 (Reuters) Bridget Rose Dugdale, an heiress, was sentenced to nine years in jail here today for hijacking a helicopter in an abortive attempt to bomb a police station in Northern Ireland.

title: Waldheim Says Buffer Force Is Vital
Turkey Men Give Few Thanks
description: Turkey growers are finding less to be thankful for at this season than consumers, who are relishing their traditional holiday fare at prices well below a year ago.

title: MONSERRAT TIED TO SCHOOLS PACT
description: Joseph Monserrat, a member of the Board of Education, attended meetings here and in Puerto Rico involving a $211,660 board contract with a manpower training company while the company was paying him as a public relations consultant, according to an account yesterday by a board administrator.

title: SCHOOL HEARING DRAWS HUNDREDS
description: Hundreds of witnesses showed up at a hearing yesterday and last night to oppose the projected redistricting of five Manhattan school board districts and one in Brooklynshifts that are required by current state law on pupil attendance.

title: Ballet Theater to Abide by State Audit
description: The Ballet Theater Foundation, parent unit of the American Ballet Theater, has assured the New York State Council on the Arts that it will follow the recommendations of a recent audit by State Controller Arthur Levitt that questioned various aspects of the organization's fiscal management.

title: U.S. Will. Provide Jordan With 20,000 Tons of Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) Jordan will get 20,000 tons of Wheat worth $3.6million under a new Food for Peace loan agreement, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Woman Married to ExLawyer Who Hired Thugs to Blind Her
POLICE CAUTIONED ON HOLIDAY GRAFT
description: Warning against the temptations of graft during the holiday season, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday that corruption in the Police Department was at its lowest level ever but that he was still not satisfied.

title: ANKER SET TO RUN DISTRICT IN BRONX
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker said yesterday that he had received a report documenting a swollen payroll, fiscal mismanagement and a possible $1million deficit in Community School District 9 in the Bronx and that he probably would take over management of the district.

title: A native American Reftects On Thanksgiving
5 Rewarding Documentary Portraits at Film Forum
Spain Detains 14 Politicians, Frees Them After Hearings
description: MADRID, Nov. 27 (Reuters)  Fourteen prominent Spanish politicians detained yesterday in a apparent police crackdown on centerleft efforts to set up a united front were released today, the polite said.

title: Watergate Jurors Are to Get Holiday Reunion With Families
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) for the jurors who have been squestered for 42 days in the Watergate coverup trial, Thanksgiving is to be a daylong reunion with their families under the close watch of deputy United States marshals.

title: Utility Acts to Reduce Calls for Information
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 27 (UPI)In an effort to reduce the number of calls for information, the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company has decided not to answer calls to the number 411, until there are seven or eight rings.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: Egypt's Premier Hails U.S. But Terms It Unrealistic
description: CAIRO, Nov. 2Premier Abdel Aziz Hegazi praised the United States today for its active and positive role in seeking a resolution of the Middle East crisis but added that it was still in the stage of wishful thinking.

title: P.L.O. Reports Detaining 26 for a Trial in Hijacking
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 27 The Palestine Liberation Organization announced today that it had taken 26 persons into custody here and in other Arab countries on suspicion of involvement in the hijacking of a British airliner from Dubai to Tunis last week.

title: Cosmos No. 696 Launched
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 27 (AP) The Soviet Union launched today No. 696 in its secret Cosmos satellite series, Tess reported. The onboard equipment is functioning normally, the press agency reported. The computer center is processing the incoming information.

title: Be Thankful for the Good Guys
Israelis Appear to Be Accepting Austerity Measures
McGovern Asks Sacrifices
